headline: The Mullah and Democracy
abstract: To counter the threats made by Shiite leader Sistani, the Americans, at a loss, are now turning to the United Nations again. They want the UN to help bring peace to Iraq.

headline: MediaTalk; 2 Donalds and a World of Self-Confidence
abstract: Deutsch advertising agency head Donny Deutsch competes for screen time with Donald J Trump in upcoming episode of reality television program The Apprentice; both have reputations for being supremely assertive and self-confident; they comment; photo (M)

headline: PRIVATE EQUITY FIRM TAKES OVER MAIDENFORM
abstract: Ares Management acquires women's lingerie maker Maidenform (S)

headline: Aristide Says He Was Duped By U.S. Into Leaving Haiti
abstract: Exiled Haitian Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide, in Central African Republic en route to Jamaica, renews charge that US tricked him into fleeing country; United States denies accusation and says Aristide left willingly; Aristide's own lawyer suggests matter is misunderstanding; Aristide's letter of resignation notes his desire to avoid bloodshed in Haiti (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Under Investor Pressure, Disney Picks New Chairman  In a remarkable vote of no confidence against a once unassailable executive, shareholders owning an estimated 43 percent of the Walt Disney Company withheld their support to re-elect Michael D. Eisner, the chairman and chief executive, to the board.    The mounting shareholder dissent prodded the board to strip Mr. Eisner of the chairman's title and give it to George J. Mitchell, Disney's presiding director and a former United States senator. [Page A1.]

headline: Arab Summit Meeting Collapses Over Reforms
abstract: Host nation Tunisia insists on postponing Arab League summit meeting, saying that Arab states are not sufficiently committed to reforms for their 22 foreign ministers to reach any agreement on common goals; some ministers object to words like 'democracy', 'parliament' and 'civil society', others feel it is wrong to emphasize reform when peace process is in disarray, and many are upset that American proposal of blueprint for reforms was leaked before any Arab leader was aware of contents (M)

headline: Before Business School
abstract: Whitney Ransome and Meg Milne Moulton letter on encouraging girls to seek business degrees

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Monetary Tightening
abstract: Bank of Mexico tightens monetary policy for first time in nearly year, citing concerns over rising inflation expectations and wage increases; its inflation target this year is 3 percent (S)

headline: Revlon Announces Deal to Cut Its Debt Load
abstract: Ronald O. Perelman, the majority owner of Revlon, has struck a refinancing deal to help cut the cosmetic giants $1.9 billion debt load almost in half.

headline: New Conductor Guides Data Along the Fiber Optic Route
abstract: Anne Eisenberg What's Next column discusses optical nanowire developed by Harvard University research team; nanowire allows light to flow on the outside of a glass fiber; nanowire could be used for higher speed connections in mulitplexers and sensors; photo (M)

headline: European Union Agrees on Plan To Coordinate Antiterror Effort
abstract: Leaders of European Union's 25 present and future member countries agree to antiterrorism measures ranging from more secure passports to appointment of Gijs de Vries, former Dutch Deputy Interior Minister, as antiterrorism coordinator; moves come two weeks after train bombings in Madrid; many governments have yet to pass antiterrorism laws they agreed to after 9/11; deadline of June 2004 is set for countries to pass new laws (M)

headline: American and British Weapons Experts Return to Libya
abstract: Senior Bush administration official says British and American weapons experts have returned to Libya and within weeks could begin dismantling, destroying and removing technology and materials related to Libya's once secret programs to develop nuclear and other illicit weaopns; says plans are also being laid by Libyan chemical weapons scientists to incinerate tons of mustard gas agent manufactured to fill chemical bombs; says missile programs and biological research efforts are still under scrutiny; says illicit materials would probably be shipped to secure facilities in Britain or US; spokesman for International Atomic Energy Agency says American and British officials have met with Dr Mohamed ElBaradei and reached agreement under which agency will verify destruction and removal work (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Lithuania: Russian Diplomats Expelled
abstract: Lithuanian government expels three Russian diplomats suspected of trying to gain confidential information about President Rolandas Paksas's impeachment proceedings and his alleged ties to Russian organized crime (S)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Dept confirms death of service member in Iraq (S)

headline: President of G.M.'s European Unit to Take Top Post at Parts Maker
abstract: Dana Corp, auto parts supplier, names Michael J Burns, top General Motors executive, to lead company as it struggles to get back on its feet after fending off hostile takeover and enduring death of chairman Joseph Magliochetti; photo (M)

headline: In Florida Groves, Cheap Labor Means Machines
abstract: Florida orange growers turn to labor-saving technology as their best hope for survival; growers face increased competition from Brazil and glut of oranges on world markets; globalization is threatening to displace workers, mainly illegal Mexican immigrants; canopy shakers, huge machines, can shake loose more oranges in 15 minutes than four pickers could in full day; for first time in generation, farmers are working to replace hand laborers with machines, even as Pres Bush advances plan to invite legal guest workers into American fields; grain farmers have already cut labor costs with mechanization, and vegetable and fruit growers are rushing to catch up; photos; graphs (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: A Village Washes Its Cares Away
abstract: Kenya Times reports that Kapenguria (Kenya) villagers tied up and forcibly washed man who went 10 years without bath because they could no longer stand his oder (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon To Sell Stake In Indonesian Company
abstract: Verizon Communications is in talks to sell its 23.1 percent stake in Indonesian cellular operator Excelcomindo Pratama; negotiations with China Telecom and Telekom Malaysia were delayed during Excelcomindo's sale of $350 million in bonds to international investors; Telstra of Australia has also emerged as potential bidder (S)

headline: New Report Widens Parmalat's Debt
abstract: Parmalat releases figures showing its debt to be eight times amount reported in its financial statements, placing company's accounting discrepancy atmore than 12 billion euros ($15.1 billion); findings were made by new auditors PricewaterhouseCoopers; photo (M)4

headline: Radio Suspension Praised
abstract: Clear Channel Communications' suspension of Howard Stern's radio show draws praise at Congressional hearing where some television executives say bill to toughen penalties for indecency does not go far enough; Rep Fred Upton praises Clear Channel; Clear Channel president John E Hogan testifies (S)

headline: U.S. Image Abroad Will Take Years to Repair, Official Testifies
abstract: Margaret D Tutwiler, new State Dept official in charge of public diplomacy, acknowledges that America's standing abroad has deteriorated to such an extent that it may take years of hard work to restore it; agrees with main findings of independent panel that American outreach has suffered from budget cuts and neglect since end of cold war (M)

headline: Suicide Bomber Outside Shiite Mosque in Iraq Kills Four Worshipers
abstract: Suicide bomber blows himself up outside Shiite mosque in Baquba, Iraq, killing 4 other people and wounding 37; photos (M)

headline: Ford to Use Toyota's Hybrid Technology
abstract: Ford Motor Co will license hybrid technology from Toyota Motor Corp in deal that could help establish Toyota's system as standard for industry; Toyota has been trying to sell its hybrid system to variety of automakers to help offset its high development cost; Ford will incoporate Toyota technology into hybrid system it plans to introduce late this year in gasoline-electric version of its Escape sport utility vehicle (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Caviar Producers Warned
abstract: United Nations wildlife protection division warns Russia, Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan that if efforts to protect sturgeon in region are not improved nations may face international ban on caviar exports (S)

headline: Baghdad Bomb Kills at Least 5 At a Restaurant
abstract: Car bomb tears through popular Baghdad restaurant filled with New Year's Eve revelers, killing at leave five people and wounding more than 30, including three Americans; blast is worst of rash of bombings, confirming fears that insurgents would use holiday as occasion to mount attacks; rescue efforts described; photos (M)

headline: TALLY IS DISPUTED
abstract: Chen Shui-bian is declared to have won second term as president of Taiwan by razor-thin margin over Lien Chan, leader of Nationalist Party, but Lien calls for voiding of election, citing ballot irregularities, and suggests that Chen may have staged 11th-hour assassination attempt to get votes; top aides to Chen contend that assassination attempt was real and that there is no evidence of fraud in vote and no need for recount sought by opposition; Chen, whom Chinese officials have repeatedly accused of being willing to risk war to achieve greater independence for Taiwan, urges Beijing to respect election and cooperate with him; photo of demonstration by Lien's supporters (M)

headline: Union, but Not Unanimity, As Europe's East Joins West
abstract: First article in series The New Europe discusses implications of European Union's eastward expansion that will end 65-year divide caused by 20th century's hot and cold wars and transform 'plush club' of 15 like-minded nations into bazaar of 25 countries differing in wealth, stature and outlook; photo; map; chart; expanded Union could be stronger counterweight to US, but incoming members look more to Washington than to Berlin and Paris, which have led integration for 40 years; former Soviet republics, scarred by life in Russian shadow, tend to suspect distant bureaucracy but welcome Union handouts, tend to be idealistic about freedom but also cynical about politicians and accustomed to corruption in everyday life; Western Europe fears East will drain away wealth and jobs and open door to millions more migrants, including Muslims whom continent is already having hard time integrating; those in East resent restrictions to keep out workers for few years and fear Western products will push their own off shelves (M)

headline: Business People; Ouch! Schrempp Gets A One-Two Punch
abstract: German magazine Stern depicts Daimler-Chrysler chief executive Jurgen Schrempp, who battles suit by Kirk Kerkorian charging he knew that 1998 deal that created company was not going to be 'merger of equals,' as isolated while company's problems mount; suggests he could be ousted if company does not become solidly profitable; photo (M)

headline: Computer-Related Shares Lead Major Gauges Lower
abstract: Stocks drop, led by computer-related shares, as Nasdaq composite index has steepest drop since September; Nasdaq composite index loses 52.07 points, to 2,014.14, its sixth decline in seven trading days; S&P 500 sheds 9.51 points, to 1,126.52; Dow Jones industrial average slips 34.44 points, to 10,470.74; Treasury notes fall in New York; price of 10-year note loses 4/32, to 101 3/32; yield rises to 4.11 percent; graph shows Dow; tables (L)

headline: Roses Blue, Violets Red? A Tool to Calibrate Your Monitor Colors
abstract: Spyder from Pantone ColorVision plugs into computer, attaches to face of monitor and software automatically adjusts screen color settings to display images correctly for printing; photo (S)

headline: Business; Is the Aerospace Industry Ready for Mars?
abstract: New US effort to send astronauts back to moon and perhaps to Mars would benefit Boeing Co tremendously, but Pres Bush's call for such missions has met with some skepticism, and there are questions about how quickly they would help Boeing in its effort to broaden beyond commercial aviation and military work; skeptics question whether US aerospace industry is up to Bush's vision now that competition, lifeblood of innovation, has been diminished through consolidation in industry; say industry's aging engineers are retiring faster than they can be replaced; photo; drawing (M)

headline: Embattled Jewish Settlers in Gaza Pray for Miracles
abstract: Remote Jewish settlements in Gaza such as Kfar Darom have become thorn in side of Israeli government as it searches for way out of three years of violence; eroding political support for such settlements only strengthens resolve of their religious settlers to remain despite constant Palestinian threat; photo of Noga Cohen and her three children maimed in attack; map (M)

headline: Just-in-Time Hiring In a Growing Economy
abstract: Ken C Arnold letter comments on March 7 article on effect of rising productivity on hiring

headline: Ex-Arms Inspector Finds Himself in a New Place: The Center of a Political Maelstrom
abstract: Arms inspector David A Kay is perplexed by stir over his finding that there are no unconventional weapons in Iraq; seems surprised that some in Central Intelligence Agency are furious at him for criticizing agency that hired him and puzzled by Bush administration stand that inspections are still inconclusive, phone interview; photo (M)

headline: Harrison McCain, 76, King Of the Frozen French Fry
abstract: Harrison McCain, Canadian billionaire whose family-owned business grew to become world's largest producer of frozen French fries, dies at age 76; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Trader Faults Bank
abstract: David Bullen, former head dealer of currency options at National Australia Bank Ltd, says bank ignored or tolerated breaches of its currency trading rules; Bullen is at center of probe into losses of as much as 180 million Australian dollars ($140 million) (S)

headline: Vanguard Alters Trading Day
abstract: Vanguard Group lengthens trading day for index and international funds to give its less affluent clients the same advantages as its Flagship shareholders, who have more than $1 million invested (S)

headline: Latin Allies of the U.S.: Docile and Reliable No Longer
abstract: Analysis of what Pres Bush will face when he visits Mexico to confer with leaders from throughout hemisphere; says he will meet more assertive Latin America, where there is increasing resentment over American security and trade policies that some of them view as inimical to their interests (M)

headline: Reginald Harold Jones, 86, Dies; Led General Electric
abstract: Former General Electric chairman Reginald Harold Jones dies at age 86; photo (M)

headline: Lingering Job Insecurity Of Silicon Valley; In Productivity and Cost Cuts, a Selective Recovery
abstract: Job market computer scientists and engineers operate in has become toughest ever even as business has started to pick up again; upturn in demand for all kinds of workers, including those in technology, may be just around corner, economists keep saying, but software engineer David Friedman has seen no evidence of improvement so far; Friedman, who has last job ended in March 2001, has found little demand for kind of software design work that is his specialty; unemployment rate last year among computer scientists was 5.2 percent, highest level since government began tracking this work as occupation two decades ago; unemployment among electrical engineers last year, at 6.2 percent, was highest in 20 years; charts; photos (M)

headline: $6 Billion Loan Deal by Freddie Mac Examined by U.S.
abstract: The Department of Housing and Urban Development is examining an unusual $6 billion deal made last year by Freddie Mac to fulfill its federal requirements on loans for affordable housing.    In the transaction, Freddie Mac agreed to guarantee and securitize, or turn into bonds, about 8,000 mortgages on small apartment buildings, loans made by Washington Mutual, the sixth-largest American bank.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Reuters Decline Slows
abstract: Reuters says revenue at its main unit is declining at slower rate and fewer customers have canceled subscriptions, setting off 14 percent gain in its share price; graph (S)

headline: 11 Iraqi Police Officers Are Killed by Gunmen
abstract: Gunmen kill 9 Iraqi police officers in minibus in Hilla and two other officers, twin brothers, parking car in Kirkuk; photo of fire at gas station; US administrator L Paul Bremer visits Najaf to try to calm worries among local religious and tribal leaders about interim constitution (M)

headline: Online Advertising Bounces Back as Animations Increase
abstract: Interactive Advertising Bureau and PricewaterhouseCoopers report that online advertising rebounded in 2003, with revenue rising 20 percent, to $7.2 billion, $2.2 billion in fourth quarter alone; cites growth in online ad spending by Fortune 500 companies and growing market share for animated advertising, for which marketers pay premium (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.S. Online Gambling Policy Violates Law, W.T.O. Rules  The World Trade Organization, in its first decision on an Internet-related fight, has ignited a political, cultural and legal tinderbox by ruling that the United States policy prohibiting online gambling violates international trade law.    The ruling was hailed by operators of online casinos based overseas as a major victory that could force America to liberalize laws outlawing their business. But the Bush administration plans to appeal. [Page C5.]

headline: Alarm Raised Over Quality Of Uranium Found in Iran
abstract: UN nuclear inspectors have found traces of extremely highly enriched uranium in Iran, of purity reserved for use in nuclear bomb; finding increases urgency of determining uranium's source (S)

headline: Equity Offerings Scheduled
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:      Atheros Communications, an initial public offering of 9 million shares. Morgan Stanley and Lehman Brothers.

headline: A Better Night's Sleep, Flat Out at 35,000 Feet
abstract: Virgin Atlantic Airways, Qantas, Northwest Airlines, All Nippon Airways and Lufthansa have begun rolling out new seats and amenities in business class, to help weary executives on long-haul flights get some rest; latest models of seats that recline into beds discussed; diagram; photo (M)

headline: The Latest Box Score: 27 Points, 13 Rebounds, 3 Tattoos
abstract: Article discusses how National Basketball Assn requires statistics to be recorded; Harvey Pollack, statistician for Philadelphia 76ers, uses three networked laptop computers to record every play; he comments; photo (M)

headline: Taiwan's President Seems Secure Despite a Huge Rally
abstract: Taiwanese Pres Chen Shui-bian agrees to recount in disputed presidential vote after hundreds of thousands of Nationalist Party supporters rally in Taipei; welcomes forensic experts to task force investigating March 19 assassination attempt; Pres Chen won by 30,000 of 13 million votes cast, and likelihood of Nationalists winning on recount is slim; Nationalists are eager to protest, but wary of embarrassing Taipei's popular Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who is likely to be their next candidate for president in 2008; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Team in Baghdad Fights A Persistent Enemy: Rumors
abstract: Rumors, however ill founded, bizarre or malevolent, present obstacle to American project to build stable democracy in Iraq; almost no tale is too outlandish to be believed by some; to counter street chatter that is not all accurate, American-led team of Iraqis gathers rumors in order to respond to them; their daily intelligence document, called The Baghdad Mosquito, is distributed via e-mail to elite group of military officers and policy planners and is posted on military's classified Web server; Iraq, which under Saddam Hussein was closed society, is ideal hothouse for rumors and gossip; presence of occupying power only adds to Iraqis' natural suspicions; photo (M)

headline: Stung by Exiles' Role, C.I.A. Orders a Shift in Procedures
abstract: Senior United States intelligence officials say American intelligence officials who sifted through claims that Iraq had illicit weapons before war were generally not told that information came from defectors linked to exile groups that were promoting American invasion; largely unsubstantiated claims about weapons included those from defector who was identified in May 2002 as fabricator by Defense Intelligence Agency; reports based on his debriefings arranged by Iraqi National Congress found their way into documents and speeches used by Bush administration to justify war; intelligence officials say nondisclosure of source's connection to exile organization was 'standard practice' under procedures in place at time; that episode and others have prompted Central Intelligence Agency to order major change in its procedures (M)

headline: Inventor Wins a Round in Tokyo Court
abstract: Japanese inventor Dr Shuji Nakamura is awarded $189 million in patent lawsuit filed against his former employer Nichia Corp; Nakamura sued for patent rights to his semiconductor invention, which Nichia has licensed to other companies for millions of dollars; most Japanese firms retain strict control of patents developed by their employees, but Dr Nakamura's successful suit may inspire other Japanese inventors to file suit in order to share profits generated by their inventions; photo (M)

headline: Paul Sweezy, 93, Marxist Publisher and Economist, Dies
abstract: Marxist intellectual Paul M Sweezy dies at age 93; photo (M)

headline: Spending Habits of the Rich and Even Richer
abstract: Elite Traveler magazine survey finds spending by people who have $1 million to $5 million is fairly frugal, while those with $10 million or more spend more heavily on items like multiple residences and multiple golf club memberships; most with $10 million or more don't even pay own bills; graphs (S)

headline: Some Rental Cars Are Keeping Tabs on the Drivers
abstract: Some rental car company are keeping tabs on drivers; Jaehwa Son and his parents are challenging large bill from Payless Car Rental outlet that used tracking device to determine that Sons were in violation of their rental agreement when they drove outside of California; photo (M)

headline: 7 Held in South Korean Scandal
abstract: Six South Korean politicians of different parties and SK Group chmn Son Kil Seung are arrested on charges in connection with widening inquiry into illegal campaign contributions and bribery; arrests are troubling to President Roh Moo Hyun, who entered office on pledge to fight corruption (M)

headline: Parmalat Evidence Sought At Branch of U.S. Bank
abstract: Italian financial police search Milan offices of Bank of America as they seek evidence about role banks and auditors might have played in collapse of Parmalat; top Parmalat executive Giovanni Bonici returns to Italy from Venezuela to face questioning from prosecutors; Stefano Tanzi, son of Parmalat's jailed founder Calisto Tanzi, resigns as president of Parma AC soccer team; Stefano's cousin Paolo also resigns; photo (M)

headline: As Brands, Comcast and Disney Are Awkward Pair
abstract: Some advertising executives and analysts suggest names for combined Comcast Corp and Walt Disney Co; photo (M)

headline: Independent Producers Wary of Proposed Deal
abstract: Hollywood producers and consumer advocates, reacting to Comcast Corp's bid for Walt Disney Co, are sounding alarm that media consolidation will narrow ceative outlets for independent producers and upstart cable channels and ultimately reduce choice of viewing public; say combination of powerful company like Disney will increase financial pressures already squeezing independent producers struggling to stay afloat in consolidated industry (M)

headline: Magazine Advertising Falls for an 8th Month
abstract: Publishers Information Bureau says magazine ad pages fell 0.3 percent in January compared with month year earlier as pages fell in 5 of 12 major categories (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Media Empire Receives More Than a Dozen Bids  More than a dozen bidders, including the Barclay brothers of Britain, submitted preliminary offers for all or parts of Conrad M. Black's publishing empire, Hollinger International, executives involved in the auction said.    Among the potential suitors for at least some of Hollinger's assets, which include The Daily Telegraph of London, The Jerusalem Post, The Chicago Sun-Times and more than 100 smaller publications, are Gannett, the Tribune Company, Daily Mail and General Trust, the Carlyle Group, Axel Springer of Berlin and the billionaire Haim Saban. [Page C6.]

headline: In Shuffle, Oracle Gets New Chairman
abstract: Lawrence J Ellison steps down as chairman of Oracle Corp but will remain chief executive as part of executive realignment; chief financial officer Jeffrey O Henley will succeed Ellison as chairman; executives Safra A Catz and Charles Phillips are promoted to share position of president; photos (M)

headline: G.M. FINANCE UNIT TO OPEN BANK IN UTAH
abstract: General Motors Acceptance Corp plans to open federally insured bank in Utah to take advantage of state's favorable regulations and cut its borrowing costs (S)

headline: Personal Business; Those Dents and Demos Can Save You Dollars
abstract: Advise on buying electronics and other products sold at discount in stores or online as refurbished, reconditioned or remanufactured; many returned products are often found to need no repairs; many manufacturers contract with outside companies to do 'factory authorized' refurbishment; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Ivory Coast: Policeman Guilty Of Murder
abstract: Abidjan (Ivory Coast) police officer Theodore Dago Sery is convicted of murdering Jean Helene, French journalist for Radio France International, in October 2003; is sentenced to 17 years in prison (S)

headline: AARP aims to show marketers what they are missing in overlooking the consumer over 50.
abstract: AARP, in latest effort to attract advertisers to its AARP Magazine, opens advertising drive to convince marketers not to write off consumers over 50 years old; campaign argues that focused, attentive marketing to older Americans is more important than before; erosion of long-held belief among marketers that older Americans are too set in their ways to change brands could aid AARP drive; photo (M)

headline: G.E. Earnings Up 47%, Aided by Insurance Unit and More Industrial Orders
abstract: General Electric reports 47 percent increase in earnings for fourth quarter, compared with year-ago period; net income rose to $4.56 billion from $3.1 billion year earlier; sales rose about 4 percent, to $36.96 billion from $35.51 billion; chief executive Jeffrey R Immelt comments (M)

headline: Beyond Board Independence
abstract: Irving L Straus letter says crucial issue for mutual funds is quality of independent directors

headline: Putin Abruptly Fires Russian Premier and Most of Cabinet
abstract: Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin abruptly dismissed Prime Min Mikhail M Kasaynov and his cabinet; says he will name new government, holding voters deserve to know shape of new government before they vote Mar 14; names Viktor B Khristenko acting prime minister; Kasaynov dismissal is not expected to produce any immediate or significant policy changes; Putin's failure to immediately name successor injects unexpected degree of political drama into election season; lawmakers and political analysts differ wildly on Putin's motives; photo (M)

headline: Alan Bullock, 89, a British Historian Who Wrote a Life of Hitler
abstract: Alan Bullock, one of Britain's foremost historians, whose early biography of Hitler became scholarly yardstick on subject, dies at age 89; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: VITRO, Mexico's largest glassmaker, agreed to sell the 60 percent stake it owns in a fiberglass unit to its partner Owens Corning, Toledo, Ohio, for $71.5 million.    HEARST-ARGYLE TELEVISION INC., New York, agreed to buy WMTW-TV, an ABC affiliate serving Portland, Me., for $37.5 million in cash.

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: Arch Wireless To Acquire Metrocall For $281.3 Million
abstract: Arch Wireless, nation's biggest wireless-paging company, acquires Metrocall Holdings for $281.3 million in cash and stock; graph (S)

headline: For Retirees, a Step Forward, a Step Back
abstract: Kaiser Family Foundation survey of 408 large companies finds 10 percent have scrapped subsidized health benefits for future retirees in past year and 20 percent plan to do so within three years; other companies plan to increase retiree premiums, deductibles and co-payments; graph of expected changes (S)

headline: Killed in Iraq
abstract: Dept of Defense identifies two American service members killed in Iraq, bringing total of Americans killed since start of war to 506 (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Inquiry In Deadly Fire
abstract: Second investigation begins into 1981 deadly house fire that killed 14 black children and triggered race riots in Brixton (Great Britain) that injured 400 people; first inquest failed to establish cause of fire, which some families believe was arson (S)

headline: Haitian Leader Warns of Exodus and Appeals for Help
abstract: Haitian Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide warns of blood bath in Port-au-Prince and wave of refugees fleeing to Florida if rebels advancing against him are not stopped, news conference; urges international community to speed plans to intervene in deepening crisis; conflict pits rebel troops against Aristide's demoralized police force and fearsome gangs based in capital's shantytowns used to terrorize political dissidents; photos (M)

headline: A Suicide Bomber Kills 3 in Baghdad
abstract: Suicide bomber speeding through downtown Baghdad in ambulance swerves around concrete barrier to blow himself up, shearing facade off Shaheen Hotel, killing at least three people and wounding more than 15; photo; hundreds of Iraqi civic leaders gather at Palestinian Hotel across town for town-hall session on democracy sponsored by US occupation and Iraqi Governing Council; administrator Paul Bremer, separately, sees tough reaction to Kurdish terrorist groups using Iraq as refuge for attacks against Turkey (M)

headline: Judges Skeptical of U.S. Efforts to Ban a Tax Book
abstract: Federal Judges William A Fletcher and Arthur L Alarcon repeatedly express skepticism about government's efforts to ban sale of book The Federal Mafia: How the Federal Government Illegally Imposes and Unlawfully Collects Federal Income Taxes by Irwin Schiff that purports to show people how they can legally stop paying income taxes; judges are even more skeptical about whether Schiff can be required to give Internal Revenue Service list of everyone who bought book; Michael Stein, lawyer for Schiff and his bookstore Freedom Books, says that however wrong Schiff's arguments might be they are protected by First Amendment; Schiff, who has twice served prison sentences for tax crimes, is appealing order issued in July by Judge Lloyd D George that bars Schiff from selling book; Schiff, in separate case where Justice Department is trying to collect $2.5 million in taxes, interest and penalties, has filed papers by his psychiatrist, who concludes that Schiff is insane and holds deluded belief that he alone can properly interpret tax laws; Cindy Neun, Schiff's girlfriend, has sent Schiff's supporters e-mail message saying insanity claim is ruse intended to escape penalties on unpaid taxes; Justice Department lawyer Judith A Hagley says past rulings establish First Amendment does not protect fraud; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Special Forces in Haiti Seeking Out Rebel Leaders
abstract: US special forces arrive in Haiti to seek out rebel leaders; several hundred Haitians loyal to deposed Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide demonstrate against US marines at presidential palace in Port-au-Prince; photo (M)

headline: Giving a Major Lift to Denver's Winter Park Resort
abstract: Intrawest Corp, which struck deal in 2002 to lease Winter Park ski resort from city of Winter Park, Colo, will renovate it for $50 million; Winter Park general manager Gary J DeFrange comments; photo (M)

headline: Profit Increases 9.2% at Colgate
abstract: Colgate-Palmolive Co's fourth-quarter profit increased 9.2 percent, exceeding expectations; net income increased to $372.1 million from $340.9 million year earlier; sales rose 6.3 percent, to $2.57 billion, from $2.42 billion year ago (M)

headline: Challenger to Putin for Russian Presidency Is Missing
abstract: One of Vladimir V. Putins challengers in next months presidential election is missing, and the police and security services announced today that they had begun a search for him.

headline: Editor Critical Of Thai Leader Loses His Job
abstract: Veera Prateepchaikul,ÿ

headline: Despite Gains, Greeks Enter Election Season of Discontent
abstract: Greek Pan-Helenic Socialist Movement, which has guided country's accomplishments for most of last 25 years, may well be ousted from power in parliamentary elections in March, victim of rising expectations fueled by its own success (M)

headline: An M.R.I. Machine For Every Doctor? Someone Has to Pay
abstract: Some doctors in Syracuse have been installing imaging equipment in their offices instead of sending patients to radiologist or hospital; Blue Cross and Blue Shield Assn report finds that diagnostic imaging is approaching $100-billion-a-year business nationally, up about 40 percent since 2000; insurers are becoming increasingly concerned about imaging; five counties surrounding Syracuse have 27 magnetic resonance imaging machines, up from 20 just three years ago; radiologists complain that specialists are investing in machines as way to increase their incomes; there are signs that more machines may translate into too much imaging; it is fastest-growing component of physician services in Medicare program; graphs; photo (M)

headline: Research in Italy Turns Up a New Form of Mad Cow Disease
abstract: Italian study reports discovery of new form of mad cow disease in two Italian cows, both apparently healthy; scientists say strain may be cause of some cases of human brain-wasting disease and see more reason for US Agriculture Department to adopt more sensitive rapid tests used in Europe; photos of test results showing where prions collect in brain; Italian study is edited by Dr Stanley B Prusiner, who won 1997 Nobel Prize for prion work (M)

headline: Britain Says U.S. Planned To Seize Oil In '73 Crisis
abstract: Recently declassified British government document states that Pres Nixon was prepared to use military force to seize oil fields in Middle East during Arab oil embargo 30 years ago; embargo was imposed by Arab nations in retaliation for America's support for Israel in 1973 Middle East war; secret document says US considered launching airborne troops to seize oil fields in Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Abu Dhabi as 'last resort' if embargo was not lifted; embargo was lifted in Mar 1974 (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: COPPER PLUNGES. Copper fell after an index of service industries showed a decline for last month, signaling demand may be easing. In New York, copper for May delivery fell 6.95 cents, or 5.1 percent, to $1.3065 a pound.

headline: A Bright New Day for the Telecom Industry, if the Public Will Go Along
abstract: Verizon Communications deal to buy equipment that sends phone calls as digital data like that used over Internet from Nortel Networks gives huge lift to technology some industry executives call key development in public telecommunications; most of sales of equipment for Internet-based phone communications have been to big corporate users; Nortel wireless unit head Susan Spradley sees new technology offering chance to remap share of different equipment market competitors; Internet switching technology will let phone and cable companies use own networks and Internet 'backbone' networks as conduits for host of new voice, data and video services; market share graph; photo (M)

headline: Agency for Foxwoods Quits Account Review
abstract: Trahan, Burden & Charles resigns creative ad account of Foxwoods Resort Casino in Mashantucket, Conn, owned by Mashantucket Pequot Tribal Nation, by withdrawing from review for assignment; billings estimated at $25 million (S)

headline: After Furor, Janet Jackson Is to Be Cut From Grammy Awards
abstract: Janet Jackson, in latest reaction to furor surrounding breast-baring stunt during Super Bowl broadcast, will not appear as presenter at Grammy Awards ceremony on CBS on Feb 8; NBC announces that it will pull scene from tonight's episode of ER because 80-year-old woman's breast is briefly exposed; Justin Timberlake, Jackson's partner in Super Bowl performance, is scheduled to perform at Grammy's and is nominated for multiple awards (M)

headline: In a Capital Under Siege, Loyalists Brace for Battle
abstract: Rebels who have wrested nearly half of Haiti from government control now vow to march on capital; police and armed gangs loyal to Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide throw up roadblocks, bracing for siege on Port-au-Prince; map (S)

headline: An online travel company tries to revive its fortunes using a gnome and $80 million.
abstract: Online travel agency Travelocity, Sabre Holdings unit, plans $80 million advertising drive tracking world travels of garden gnome; drive is vital to financial well-being of money-losing service, which has lost ground to rivals Expedia and Orbitz; photo (M)

headline: GENZYME IS LEAD BIDDER FOR IMPATH CANCER-TESTING UNIT
abstract: Genzyme Corp is lead bidder for cancer testing business of Impath Inc; bids $215 million in cash for Impath's physician service unit (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Landslide Expected
abstract: Official vote count slows in Georgia one day after Presidential elections; Central Election Commission reports that Mikhail Saakashvili has 96.7 percent of vote with 25 percent of vote counted (S)

headline: Rumsfeld Praises Croatia as an Ally in Kabul and a NATO Hopeful
abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld stops in Zabreb, Croatia, during four-day European trip to promote country's efforts to join NATO and to pay tribute to Croatia's security forces, which are fighting terrorism in Afghanistan; Rumsfeld's visit comes less than three months after governing party regains power; under Prime Min Ivo Sanader party has purged extremists and has embraced pro-American foreign policy (M)

headline: In His Startling Leap to High Office, Socialist Takes Strong Stand Against 'an Unjust War'
abstract: Profile of Jose Luis Rodriguez Zapatero, Spain's newly elected prime minister; 43-year-old lawyer and politician became youngest member of Parliament at age 26 and has steadliy climbed in Socialist ranks; campaigned aggressively against Prime Min Jose Maria Aznar's decision to ally with United States and embroil Spain in Iraq war; pledges in victory speech to 'combat all forms of terrorism'; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Gamestop Sales Rise 17%
abstract: GameStop Corp reports sales of about $1.58 billion in fiscal year ended Jan 31, up 17 percent from previous year; sales at stores open at least year rose 0.8 percent; total sales in fourth quarter rose 20 percent, to $625.4 million from $520.4 million; same-store sales increased 3.9 percent dujring quarter (S)

headline: 7 at Chinese Paper Held After Articles on New SARS Case
abstract: The police stormed the offices of one of Chinas feistiest newspapers and detained the top editor and six other officials in what many journalists regard as retribution for aggressive reporting on a recent SARS case.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Teacher Shot And Killed; Student Held
abstract: Student in Hague (Netherlands) shoots and kills biology teacher in school's cafeteria; was suspended by teacher several days earlier (S)

headline: Citing Inquiry at TV Azteca, 3 Firms Tell Investors to Sell
abstract: Shares of TV Azteca, second-largest television broadcasting company in Mexico, fall more than 10 percent after brokerage firms Merrill Lynch, J P Morgan and Deutsche Ixe recommend selling stock because of investigation of debt sales involving company officials (M)

headline: Account Review Begins For Tanqueray Gin
abstract: Schieffelin & Somerset Co begins review

headline: U.S. Army Finds Its Suicide Rate in Iraq Is Higher Than for Other G.I.'s
abstract: Major Army study finds that suicide rate of soldiers in Iraq and Kuwait last year was much higher than in Army overall; finds suicide-prevention teams were left behind when units left their home bases to go to war in Iraq, mental-health workers felt untrained to treat combat stress and many soldiers seeking help for depression and emotional problems faced significant hurdles getting care; one startling finding in survey of 756 soldiers is that 52 percent of them said their personal morale was low or very low and 72 percent said their whole unit's morale was that bad; most of those surveyed had been in combat; senior Army medical officials say they found no connection between suicides and morale factors; note survey was taken at peak of fierce summer heat when many soldiers were still living in tents with no regular phone or e-mail access to their families (M)

headline: Hezbollah Missile Hits Israeli Bulldozer at Lebanon Border
abstract: The shooting, which killed an Israeli soldier, stirred tensions and raised the possibility of an Israeli military response.

headline: Mood Sours for Japan's Other Asian Students
abstract: Asian students studying in Japan typically leave with bad impression of country; Japan has hosted thousands of students since 1980's, intending to teach them about Japanese culture and heal wounds of Japan's imperial past; students complain of lack of warmth and friends among Japanese; Japanese, too, are dissatisfied with program; government has tightened visa requirements; photos (M)

headline: Barbara Gamarekian, Ex-Times Reporter, Is Dead at 78
abstract: Barbara Gamarekian, former reporter on arts and Washington society for The New York Times who was previously press aide in Kennedy and Johnson White Houses, dies at age 78; photo (M)

headline: Law Firm For Parmalat Under Scrutiny
abstract: Investigators looking into collapse of Parmalat are examining role its outside law firm Zini & Associates may have played in questionable transactions conducted by company; former Zini employees have told of numerous boxes of documents removed from firm's New York office in Dec, before government investigators first searched offices; former employees say Zini set up offshore companies for Parlamat and had its employees serve on offshore entity's board; documents show that at least once, firm served as point of contact for an investment bank contemplating complex transaction that would have provided financing to company on more favorable terms than a loan; Zini firm's principal, Gian Paolo Zini, was arrested in Italy in Dec in connection with investigation by prosecutors there of possible fraud at Parmalat; photo (M)

headline: U.S. and New York Look At Annuity Sale Practices
abstract: Regulators in New York and federal government are expanding their investigations into insurance industry to include certain sales of investments that produce new commissions for sales representatives but can be harmful to customers; new avenue in inquiries involves so-called churning, or unnecessary replacement, of old variable annuities with new ones; variable annuities are combination of insurance and stock and bond funds virtually identical to mutual funds; churning could cost customer up to 7 percent of investment, increase restrictions on future withdrawals and, in some cases, add to taxes (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: 2 Get Life In Apartment Bombings
abstract: Yusuf I Krymshamkhalov and Adam Dekkushev are convicted and sentenced to life in prison for 1999 bombing of three apartment buildings, in which 243 people were killed; critics of trial contend Russian secret service was involved in bombings, which took place in Moscow and Volgodonsk (S)

headline: BRITISH COMPANY TO BUY PLANT FROM JOHNSON & JOHNSON
abstract: Tate & Lyle, British maker of cereal sweeteners and starches, will buy plant from Johnson & Johnson for $134 million to increase sales of ingredients to food and drink companies (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Border Toll Rises
abstract: Pakistani officials announce that 15 paramilitary fighters have been killed in recent border battle with Islamic militants; 24 rebels are reported to have been killed as well (S)

headline: Roche Says Anticancer Drugs Helped It Turn a Profit in '03
abstract: Roche Holding returns to profit last year, spurred by strong sales of anticancer drugs and diagnostic tools; Roche posts profit of 3 billion Swiss francs, or $2.4 billion, for 2003, after loss in 2002 of 4 billion Swiss francs; revenue rises 6 percent, to 31.2 billion Swiss francs, or $25 billion (S)

headline: DataBank; Strong Profits Sustain a Winning Streak
abstract: Stock and bond market performance in week of Jan 12-16 noted; performance graphs and tables (S)(

headline: José López Portillo, President When Mexico's Default Set Off Debt Crisis, Dies at 83
abstract: Jose Lopez Portillo, who as president of Mexico from 1976 to 1982 brought his nation to brink of economic collapse, dies at age 83; photo (M)

headline: BCE TO BUY EQUIPMENT FOR INTERNET CALLING FROM CISCO
abstract: BCE Inc, Canada's biggest telephone company, will spend 200 million Canadian dollars ($154 million) on equipment from Cisco Systems Inc to upgrade its network for Internet-based calling (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: NEC Reports 77% Profit Rise
abstract: Japan's NEC Eletronics earned 8.3 billion yen ($78.3 million) in October-December 2003 quarter, rise of 77 percent from year earlier; sales declined 5.6 percent (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nextel Profit Falls
abstract: Nextel Communications reports fourth-quarter net profit of $637 million compared with $1.46 billion year earlier; revenue rose 29 percent (S)

headline: After I.B.M.'s Options Overhaul
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column hails International Business Machines Corp for switching to stock options for executives that can only be cashed in if IBM shares rise by at least 10 percent; notes move comes as other technology companies continue to battle efforts to treat options costs as expenses; notes handful of other companies have issued such premium options, most to small number of executives; see others likely to follow IBM's lead, in part because proposed new accounting rules favor such options; graph of amounts stock prices must rise to let executives cash in premium-priced options (M)

headline: Iraq Threat Deliberately Inflated, Kennedy Says
abstract: Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts today delivered a blistering indictment of President Bushs decision to go to war.

headline: 3M RAISES FORECAST OF QUARTERLY EARNINGS
abstract: 3M Co raises its first-quarterly profit forecast (S)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: HARDWARE.

headline: VISTEON'S CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER WILL RETIRE
abstract: Visteon Corp's chief financial officer Daniel Coulson will retire March 31 (S)8

headline: Tax Enforcement Seen as Underfinanced
abstract: Citizen Oversight Board that Congress created five years ago concludes that tax evasion is growing, but Internal Revenue Service cannot reverse trend and protect interests of honest taxpayers because its ability to enforce law is declining; notes Pres Bush's proposed budget for 2005 fiscal year represents 'fourth year in a row in which the administration has called for IRS staff increases while not covering pay raises or required expenses'; says on average each year, 1,450 tax-law enforcement jobs are propsoed but not created (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Bank Executive Resigns
abstract: National Australia Bank chairman Charles Allen resigns, joining chief executive Frank Cicutto in taking responsibility for foreign-currency trading losses of 252 million Australian dollars ($199 million); Graham Kraehe will become chairman; John Stewart succeeded Cicutto, who resigned two weeks ago; photo (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: More Troubles Await Microsoft in Europe  While the European Commission goes through the final steps this week to conclude its five-year case against Microsoft, the company's legal problems in Europe are far from over and appear to be accelerating, antitrust lawyers and officials said.

headline: AETNA RAISES FORECASTS FOR EARNINGS THIS YEAR
abstract: Aetna raises quarterly and full-year profit forecast as it says it is adding customers for first time in five years and controlling medical costs (S)û

headline: Apple Introduces a Smaller, Less Expensive IPod
abstract: Apple Computer introduces smaller, slightly less expensive version of its iPod digital music players for $249 and more powerful $3,000 to $4,000 server computer based on its new G5 microprocessor; announcement is made by Apple's chief executive Steven P Jobs on opening day of Macworld exhibition, San Francisco; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Berlusconi Acknowledges Eye Tuck
abstract: Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi admits that during his recent absence from public view he underwent cosmetic eye surgery (S)

headline: Cowboy Willpower
abstract: SCO Group chief executive Darl C McBride writes The Boss column on his life and career; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Veritas To Restate Results Again
abstract: Veritas Software Corp will restate some results for third time in 15 months and delay filing its 2003 report because of accounting errors; plans to restate 2002 and 2001 results; changes will cut sales in 2001 and 2003 and increase sales in 2002; expects to file its 2003 year report with Securities and Exchange Commission in second quarter (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: 18 Months To Elections, U.N. Envoy Says
abstract: Reginald Dumas, United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan's special envoy, recommends to Security Council that Haiti wait 18 months before elections are held and urges that peacekeeping force be established for extended stay of up to 20 years to ensure stability (S)

headline: Share Sale Raised $4.4 Billion for Belgacom
abstract: Share sale raises as much as 3.59 billion euros ($4.4 billion) for Belgacom, Belgium's dominant phone company (S)

headline: That Big Fat Budget Deficit. Yawn.
abstract: Concerns about mounting federal budget deficit have failed to spur big jump in bond interest rates; many economists say bond market's muted reaction is both symbol and cause of misplaced calm about deficits; say rapid fiscal swings of last 20 years have creaded false sense of security about deficits, possibly reinforced by accounting moves in Pres Bush's new budget that mask deficit's true size; budget and interest rate graphs; photos (M)

headline: Business People; How to Fight Boeing? Ask Airbus's Admiral
abstract: David R Oliver Jr, former under secretary of defense and retired admiral who recently worked for Iraqi governing authority, is named chief operating officer of EADS North America, promoting Airbus (S)

headline: Machida Journal; Japan Seeks Robotic Help in Caring for the Aged
abstract: Japan, world's most rapidly aging nation, experiments with new automated elder care products like 'human washing machine' enjoyed by residents of nursing home in Machida; photos; companies are also marketing items like 'robot suit,' battery-operated pants to help old people get around on their own, and mobile talking camera-robot used by working people to watch elderly parents at home; Japanese sales of domestic robots are now nearly $4 billion a year, and may reach $14 billion in 2010; Philippines and Thailand propose alternative route of allowing in tens of thousands of nurses, notion that falters in face of anti-immigrant sentiment (M)

headline: Big Investor in Tyco Gives Testimony at Trial
abstract: Kenneth Charles Feinberg, mutual fund manager at Davis Selected Advisers that bought almost $2 billion in Tyco International shares, tells jurors that he might have sold stock if bonuses paid to company's former chief executive L Dennis Kozlowski had been disclosed; says he never learned about bonuses that prosecutors contend were illegal as he bought more than 41 million Tyco shares beginning in 1998 (M)

headline: A Time for Finesse: Marketing Beef After a Mad Cow Discovery
abstract: Big players in the meat industry are walking delicate line in their marketing and communications efforts amid consumer concern over mad cow disease; while most food and restaurant companies and ranchers are depending heavily on Agriculture Dept to reassure public that American beef supply is considered safe so far, some companies are making moves to inform consumers that their individual products have not been tainted; Burger King Corp executives instruct their advertising creative team to retool new ads to include chicken Whopper along with beef Whopper; graph shows near-month contracts for cattle; photo (L)

headline: Changes in Agencies Aimed at Hispanics
abstract: Changes are being made at agencies devoted to reaching Hispanic consumers.    OMD Worldwide in New York, part of the Omnicom Group, formed a venture with a sibling, del Rivero Messianu DDB in Coral Gables, Fla., to create a Hispanic media agency called OMD Latino, with 12 employees at offices in New York and Miami.

headline: Diamonds Find a Friend in the Semiconductor Sector
abstract: What's Next column examines use of new generation of synthetic diamonds as alternative to silicon, which does not stand up well to high temperatures and stress; production of synthetic diamonds discussed; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: Thousands March; Aristide Set For Talks
abstract: More than 15,000 people march in Port-au-Prince (Haiti) demanding resignation of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide; protests, which have at times involved violent clases with police, are peaceful; photo (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Services: Verso To Post 4th-Quarter Loss
abstract: Computer network provider Verso Technologies Inc will report loss for fourth quarter amid sales that are at least 21 percent below company's forecasts (S)

headline: ALBERTO-CULVER TO SELL ILLINOIS PLANT AND CUT 70 JOBS
abstract: Alberto-Culver says it will sell plant in Melrose Park, Ill, and lay off 70 employees (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Loss At Chemical Maker
abstract: French chemical maker Rhodia lost 1.35 billion euros ($1.72 billion) last year and forecasts two more unprofitable years as it struggles to cut debt (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Profit At Noranda
abstract: World Business BriÔ

headline: Bush and Schröder Laugh Over Lunch, but Not All Weekend
abstract: Pres Bush and German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, in meeting at White House, agree to put behind them their bitter rift over Iraq and pledge to work together to fight terrorism and bring democracy and stability to Middle East (M)

headline: The Overleveraged Disneyland: Will Disney Take Losses in France?
abstract: Floyd Norris comment on Walt Disney Co's financial problems focuses on fact that company for first time will be required by new accounting regulations to put Euro Disney's huge debt on its own balance sheet and its losses will show up in Disney's operating results as well; says Disney's chief executive Michael D Eisner does not need more bad news, but Disney may have to swallow substantial write-down to get deal with banks that reduces Euro Disney debt to manageable level; graph (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Adelphia Pact With Former Unit Approved
abstract: Adelphia Communications Corp wins Federal Bankruptcy Judge Robert E Gerber's approval of $1.94 billion settlement with its former telephone and Internet subsidiary Adelphia Business Solutions, which is now known as TelCove; Adelphia will drop $842 million claim, pay $60 million in cash and buy $39 million of telecommunications services over five years from TelCove; TelCove will drop as much as $1 billion in claims against Adelphia (S)

headline: Business People; May I Sweeten That Latte With a Job Offer?
abstract: may i sweeten that latte wit

headline: 'Jimmy Kimmel Live' In a Deal With Coors
abstract: Coors Brewing division of Adolph Coors Co signs first major sponsorship deal for Jimmy Kimmel Live, late-night comedy-variety show by ABC television network; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Diving Into Darkness
abstract: Affilia

headline: DRUG MAKER AGREES TO PAY $175 MILLION IN LAWSUIT
abstract: GlaxoSmithKline agrees to pay $175 million to settle lawsuit contending that it blocked cheaper generic forms of its Relafen arthritis medicine, in violation of antitrust laws in United States; says fourth-quarter results would reflect $406 million in expenses to cover settled and pending Relafen claims (S)

headline: Judge Drops Key Count on 2 Ex-Chiefs at Tyco
abstract: But the judge left intact most of the 33-count indictment against Tycos former chairman and the former chief financial officer.

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: UZBEKISTAN: Mother Freed As Rumsfeld Visits; INDIA: Space Center Fire Killed 6;.

headline: Killed in Iraq
abstract: Defense Dept confirms deaths of three service members in Iraq (S)

headline: Former Boston Globe Columnist Is Returning, but to a Rival
abstract: Mike Barnicle, who resigned as Boston Globe columnist in 1998 after complaints about lapses in journalistic standards in two columns, is hired as columnist at Boston Herald, Globe's main rival (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Cognizant Profit Rises 94%
abstract: Cognizant Technology Solutions Corp says fourth-quarter net income rose to $17.7 million from $9.14 million year earlier; sales increased to $108.2 million from $67 million (S)

headline: MB FINANCIAL TO BUY FIRST SECURITYFED FINANCIAL
abstract: MB Financial Inc, holding company for MB Financial Bank, acquires First SecurityFed Financial Inc for $139.2 million (S)

headline: Powell, Too, Hints Haitian Should Leave
abstract: Sec of State Colin L Powell says Haitian Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide needs to make 'careful examination' of whether he should step down; remarks constitute most pointed indication yet that Bush administration views Aristide's determination to serve out his term as impediment to peaceful resolution of three-week-old uprising; Aristede, in television interview, says he will not resign; tensions mount in Port-au-Prince as rebel leaders say they are moving closer to assault; photo (M)

headline: U.N. Official Expects Return of Millions of African Refugees
abstract: The United Nations said today that the end of wars in a number of African nations should lead to a mass migration home of people who have long been languishing in refugee and displacement camps across the continent.

headline: 9 SOLDIERS DEAD IN CRASH IN IRAQ
abstract: American Black Hawk helicopter crashes in Iraqi village of Nuaymiya, near restive town of Falluja, killing all nine soldiers aboard; witnesses near mangled wreckage say helicopter was downed by missile; this is second American helicopter to be shot down in area in week; spokesman for Air Mobility Command says C-5 transport plane with 63 people on board was struck by ground fire but returned safely to Baghdad airport; attacks on Iraqis and occupation soldiers have continued with deadly efficacy since capture of Saddam Hussein on Dec 13; American military and civilian leadership maintains that Hussein's arrest prompted larger numbers of Iraqis to provide accurate intelligence about insurgency; so far, little seems to discourage stubborn insurgency, which is mainly concentrated in swath of territory west and north of Baghdad called Sunni Triangle; American-led occupation hopes its promise to release 500 Iraqis detained in recent months will be seen by Iraqis as gesture of goodwill; photos; map (M)

headline: Finance Chiefs to Chide Bush on Deficit
abstract: Bush administration will come under fire for plunging dollar and surging budget deficit when United States opens two-day meeting of finance ministers from Group of 7 industrialized nations; though officially still committed to strong dollar, Treasury Sec John W Snow is fending off European leaders who fear that dollar has fallen so far against euro that European exports will soon be in jeopardy (L)

headline: A.F.L.-C.I.O. To Press Bush For Penalties Against China
abstract: AFL-CIO will file unusual trade complaint to press Pres Bush to punish China, which it asserts has gained commercial advantage through violating workers' rights by suppressing strikes, banning independent trade unions and not enforcing minimum wage laws; complaint, timed to maximize pressure on Bush as presidential campaign heats up, asserts US has lost up to 727,000 factory jobs because labor violations that it says artificially lowered China's production costs and unfairly undercut American companies; AFL-CIO argues that this illegal repression of workers' rights translates into 43 percent cost advantage on average for China; is asking Bush to impose punitive tariffs of up to 77 percent on China or to elicit pledge to halt all such violations; photos (M)

headline: Serbs Break Parliamentary Deadlock, but Face West's Disapproval
abstract: Serbia appears on verge of forming new government after weeks of political deadlock; Vojislav Kostunica, moderate nationalist leader who has been trying to form new government, may get mandate (S)

headline: Israeli Attack On Militants Also Kills Boy
abstract: Israeli helicopter fires missile at car in Gaza City, wounding two members of Islamic Jihad; one, Aziz al-Shami, dies of wounds; nine Palestinian bystanders are also wounded, and 12-year-old boy dies; separately, four Palestinians are on trial in Gaza security court, charged with planting roadside bomb that killed three American security workers escorting United States diplomatic delegation in Gaza on Oct 15; photo (M)

headline: Cambodia Is Working to Escape Its Past
abstract: Cambodia is solidly on map of mainstream Asian tourism with Khmer Rouge years reduced to sinister displays rusting in museums; Cambodia recently won new international flights and new international hotels with temple complex of Angkor as main draw; tourists who take wrong turn while driving out to Khmer Rouge 'killing fields' will pass new water park, new factory district, new international school and new golf course; photo (M)

headline: Treasury Offerings For This Week
abstract: This week's schedule of Treasury autions includes the sale of new three- and six-month bills today and a four-week bill tomorrow.     At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 0.89 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 0.97 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 0.82 percent.

headline: France Mulls Future Role In Security For Iraqis
abstract: Foreign Min Dominique de Villepin says France is considering ways to help boost security in Iraq after US occupation ends and sovereignty has returned to Iraqi people; Defense Min Michele Alliot-Marie says France will not send troops to Iraq, but it is willing to participate in training of future army or police force (M)

headline: Plaintiffs Drop Appeal on Dow Corning Implants
abstract: Women drop claims that implants made them sick, resolving a major problem for the Dow Corning Corporation.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Auto Stake Sale
abstract: Mitsubishi Motors Corp of Japan will sell its stake in Malaysian carmaker Perusahaan Otomobil Nasional, or Proton, to help raise cash (S)

headline: First Summit for Mideast Leaders to Focus on Gaza
abstract: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel and his Palestinian counterpart, Ahmed Qurei, intend to hold their first summit meeting next week.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Norway: Heiress To The Throne
abstract: Norwegian Crown Princess Mette-Marit gives birth to baby girl, who is second in line for throne and likely to be nation's first reigning queen in more than 600 years; Prince Haakon, infant's father, is next in line after reigning King Harald V (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Industrial Production Rises
abstract: World Business Briefing: Germany: Industrial Production Rise

headline: Profits Rise 38% at Lukoil, Mainly From Overseas Sales
abstract: Russia's Lukoil reports 38 percent increase in earnings during its third quarter and says it plans to sell even more crude oil outside Russia and less at home to cash in on high global oil prices; net income was $701 million on sales of $6.04 billion, which was up from $4.43 billion; photo (M)

headline: Pakistani Store Blushes Over Nuclear Scandal
abstract: Islamabad businessman Salahuddin Khan, whose Good Looks Fabrics and Tailors is famous for making hand-tailored suits for luminaries, diplomats and tourists, fears Americans will not come now that detailed plans for nuclear bomb have been found in one of his store's plastic bags, in nuclear weapons facility in Libya; storefront photo (M)

headline: Bond Sales Scheduled for This Week
abstract: This week's schedule of Treasury auctions comprises the sale of new three- and six-month bills today and a four-week bill on Tuesday. At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 0.86 percent, the rate on the six-month issue was 0.93 percent and the rate on the four-week issue was 0.75 percent.

headline: Spain Confirms Inquiry Focuses On Moroccans
abstract: Spain confirms that Moroccan extremist group is prime focus of investigation into commuter train bombings; toll rises to 191 with death of another victim

headline: Powell and White House Get Together on Iraq War
abstract: White House and Sec Colin L Powell scrambled to present united front on Iraq war day after Powell said he was unsure he would have recommended invasion had he known Saddam Hussein had not stockpiled banned arms; Powell, in comments coordinated with White House, says Pres Bush made right decision; remarks highlight contrast between his sometimes measured support for war and full-throated justifications offered by Vice Pres Dick Cheney and Sec Donald Rumsfeld; photo (M)

headline: Grasso Refuses to Return Any of $139.5 Million Pay
abstract: Former New York Stock Exchange chairman Richard A Grasso refuses to return any of $139.5 million pay he received from exchange, but regulators are examining his conduct as outside director as well as his business relationships with former board members; regulators have been issuing subpoenas to former directors, asking about their business ties to Grasso and exchange; Grasso says he might sue exchange for about $50 million owed to him; photo (M)
