headline: No Outlet? Don't Worry, an Ethernet Cable May Do
abstract: What's Next column explores possibility of ethernet networks powering low-wattage devices; phones, cameras and wireless access points already use network connection for power; ethernet is worldwide common standard for power; drawing (M)

headline: Viacom Close To Deciding To Spin Off Blockbuster
abstract: Viacom reportedly nears decision to spin off its Blockbuster video-rental business, having so far failed to reach deal with buyer; analysts expect spinoff to involve exchange of stock between shareholders of Viacom and shareholders of 18 percent of Blockbusters already owned by public; say there is not enough demand for stock for Viacom to sell its 82 percent stake to public as newly issued Blockbuster shares; Viacom's shares have been affected by concerns over Blockbuster's outlook amid increasing competition in home video market and threat of video-on-demand offerings by cable operators (M)

headline: Powell Admits No Hard Proof In Linking Iraq to Al Qaeda
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L Powell concedes that despite his assertions to United Nations last year, he has no 'smoking gun' proof of link between government of Iraqi Pres Saddam Hussein and terrorists of Al Qaeda; says he thinks possibility of such connections did exist, and it was prudent to consider them at that time; his remarks are stark admission that there is no definitive evidence to back administration statements and insinuations that Hussein had ties to Al Qaeda; impression of such a link in public mind has become widely accepted--and something administration officials have done little to discourage; photo (M)

headline: A Lawyer's Role Must Be Defined, And Also the Fees
abstract: Executives and lawyers urge small businesses to manage their lawyers closely, defining scope of lawyer's role and keeping legal fees under control; cartoon (Special section: Small Business)

headline: LOCKHEED MARTIN PRESIDENT WILL ADD CHIEF ROLE
abstract: Lockheed Martin Corp says president Robert J Stevens will become chief executive on Aug 6, after retirement of chairman and chief executive Vance Coffman; Stevens will retain title of president; Coffman will continue as chairman until April 2005 (S)

headline: Criticism Mounting As Disney's Leader Faces Crucial Vote
abstract: Criticism of Michael D Eisner's leadership of Walt Disney Co heats up as growing number of large investors express lack of confidence in company's management; several state pension funds follow lead of two large California funds in saying they will not support Eisner in upcoming annual board election, and some mutual fund companies like T Rowe Price have also decided to vote against him; Eisner will still have sufficient votes to be re-elected to board, but sizeable vote of no-confidence would add to growing pressure on board to act on shareholder discontent; Eisner is visiting investors to counter campaign against him being waged by former board members by Roy E Disney and Stanley P Gold; chart of shareholders who have said they will not support Eisner (M)

headline: Chinas Chip Appetite
abstract: It is easy to forget that the Chinese can be avid consumers. Also: the most popular music, software, TV shows and movies.

headline: Waiter, There's a Guinea Pig in My Soup
abstract: Frequent Flier column on Deborah Szekely, founder of Rancho la Puerta and Golden Door Spa and creative director of Wyndham Hotels International, on her travel experiences; Szekely comments; photo (M)

headline: In Zimbabwe, Even the Farmers Are Going Hungry
abstract: Zimbabwe's farm output has plummeted from three years of drought and economic stagnation brought on by government of Pres Robert Mugabe; UN has raised estimate of Zimbabwe's 'food insecure' population from one half to two thirds of total; World Food Program officials say donations will feed only about 5.5 million of 7.5 million Zimbabweans who need food until harvest time; governing party holds 300,000 tons of grain seized from black market and restricts aid programs to its own rural strongholds; photo, map (L)

headline: Judge's Order Leads MONY To Delay Vote On Takeover
abstract: MONY Group delays next week's shareholder vote on planned $1.5 billion takeover by AXA Financial; decision comes after Delaware Chancery Court orders company to disclose details of $90 million in executive payouts (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Profit At Canon
abstract: Canon Inc earned 276 billion yen ($2.6 billion) last year, increase of 45 percent over previous year; sales rose 4.1 percent, to 3.2 trillion yen ($30 billion); graph (S)

headline: Second Top BBC Executive Quits; Blair Accepts Apology
abstract: The BBCs director general resigned today, saying that he hoped his departure would staunch the damage from a devastating report.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Forstmann Little & Co., New York, the leveraged buyout firm, plans to sell about one-fifth of its stake in Citadel Broadcasting Corp., Las Vegas, for about $400 million.    General Dynamics Corp., the military contractor, said that it had received two contracts worth a combined $672 million to make new armored vehicles and upgrade existing ones for the Spanish Army.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Advertising account changes noted (M)

headline: Inching to Reconciliation, Blair Plans Meeting with Qaddafi
abstract: British Sec Jack Straw, after he and Prime Min Tony Blair meet with Libyan Min Muhammad Abdul Rahman Shalghma, London, say Blair will meet Col Muammar el-Qaddafi 'as soon as convenient;' says talks focused on 'good progress' made since Qaddafi said he was ridding nation of nuclear, chemical and biological arms programs; Shalghma says Libya had equipment, material and know-how but decided not to produce unconventional arms; says he hopes families of victims of Libyan-sponsored terrorism understand that it is in everyone's interest to restore ties with Libya (M)

headline: Private Sector; From One Business to 23 Million
abstract: Profile of Hector V Barreto Jr, first entrepreneur to lead Small Businss Administration; he is at center of dispute between Congress and Bush administration, which has repeadely cut agency's budget even as it faces higher demand for loans; defends cuts, interview; photo (M)

headline: New SARS Study Stresses Need to Act Fast Against Epidemics
abstract: Chinese scientists analyze genome of SARS virus and document rapidity with which it evolved from animal pathogen into one capable of infecting humans; analysis, reported in journal Science, shows that virus's potency soared from being able to infect only 3 percent of people exposed to it to an infectivity rate of 70 percent only a few months later (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Economic Growth Surges
abstract: India's economy grew at its fastest pace in more than six years in the July to September quarter, helped by tax cuts and above-average rains, putting it on course for growth of more than 7 percent in the current fiscal year. The economy expanded 8.4 percent from a year earlier, accelerating from 5.7 percent growth in the three months to June 30, the government said.

headline: ALCOA SAYS IT WILL CUT $1.2 BILLION IN COSTS BY 2006
abstract: Alcoa plans to cut $1.2 billion in costs by 2006; plan will bring total savings to $3.3 billion since 1998, and will not involve job cuts (S)

headline: F.D.A. SEEKS MORE TESTING FOR BIOPURE BLOOD SUBSTITUTE
abstract: Biopure, unprofitable biotechnology company developing human blood substitute Hemopure, says Food and Drug Administration has asked for more testing before product can be approved (S)

headline: Business; A Spotlight on Deutsche Bank's Tax Shelter Role
abstract: Investigations of Deutsche Bank's role in facilitating aggressive, complex tax shelter schemes in late 1990's discussed; Thomas Denney recalls being sold shelter involving currency options traded by bank, investments on which he may have to pay back taxes and interest; he and others, including Indiana businessman Henry Camferdam, are suing bank and other firms over shelters later questioned by IRS; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Vought Aircraft Industries, Dallas, a maker of wings, fuselages and other aircraft parts, received a $35 million grant from Texas for an expansion that is expected to create 3,000 jobs in the state.    KB Toys, Pittsfield, Mass., the toy retailer, said it had won bankruptcy court approval to use as much as $350 million from a loan to finance its bankruptcy case.

headline: Kabul Sends Force to Quell Disorders After a Killing
abstract: Central government in Kabul is sending about 1,000 troops from new Afghan National Army to western city of Herat to maintain order after killing of government minister, the son of powerful provincial governor Ismail Khan; protesters supporting Khan fill streets, chanting 'Death to Karzai' and 'Death to America'; photo (M)

headline: Two Luxury Malls Vie for the Hearts of Upscale Shoppers in Miami
abstract: Bal Harbour Shops, open-air luxury mall in Bal Harbour, Fla, and new mall built on former industrial site by Rouse Co as part of Village of Merrick Park, $275 million project in Coral Gables, about 14 miles south of Bal Harbour, vie for upscale shoppers in Miami; centers detailed; map; photo (M)

headline: At Upscale Hotels, Women Have Power
abstract: Women have become main drivers in choosing hotels, whether as primary travelers themselves or as company travel managers or meeting-and-event planners; businesswomen take careful measure of hotel's amenities, design and service, and they compare notes with colleagues; drawing (M)

headline: G.E.'S PLAN TO TAKE OVER BRITISH COMPANY IS APPROVED
abstract: European Commission approves General Electric Co's planned takeover of Amersham, British diagnostic pharmaceuticals and biosciences company (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Merck Sells Affiliate
abstract: German drug maker Merck sells subsidiary VWR International, which is based in Pennsylvania, to Clayton, Dubilier & Rice for $1.68 billion (S)

headline: Russian Team Of Scientists Is Rescued From Ice Floe
abstract: Team of a dozen Russian scientists on ice floe 400 miles from North Pole is rescued by helicopters flown from Norwegian island of Spitsbergen; scientists were dropped at base, North Pole 32, in April 2003 and drifted in 1,700-mile loop until ice broke up their camp this week; Russia is only country to make practice of year-round ice observatories atop Arctic Ocean, but this was Russia's first such mission since collapse of Soviet Union (S)

headline: Closing Arguments in the Trial Start Today
abstract: Lawyers for Martha Stewart and Peter E Baconovic and prosecutors meet with Judge Miriam Goldman Cedarbaum to discuss instructions she will give jury that will decide whether defendants conspired to hide reasons for Stewart's sale of ImClone stock in December 2001; transcript of meeting, which was closed to public, offer preview of what prosecutors think their strongest arguments are and what weak points defense lawyers hope to exploit in their closing arguments, which are set to begin (M)

headline: In Germany, Shifting the Cost Of the Pension to the Worker
abstract: Analysis: German business ar

headline: U.S. Officials Plan to Release Iraqis Who Pose Just 'Some Risk'
abstract: US authorities in Iraq to release 506 detainees who still pose 'some risk' but have not engaged in violence against occupation forces (S)

headline: U.S. Orders Dramatic Reduction in Military Presence in Baghdad
abstract: The U.S. has been increasingly turning over to local forces the most visible role of policing the capital while U.S. troops pull back to a ring of bases at the edge of the city.

headline: On Bugging News, Annan Had Low-Key Reaction to Old Practice
abstract: UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan reacts to disclosure that British government conducted electronic surveillance of him prior to war in Iraq by merely saying he would be 'disappointed' if it were true; bugging was revealed by Clare Short, former member of Prime Min Tony Blair's cabinet who resigned in 2003; Annan photo (M)

headline: Investing; Finding an X Factor That Spurs Growth
abstract: Rohit Sah discusses his management of Oppenheimer International Small Company fund, which reported 85.1 percent return in 2003; interview; photo; graph (M)

headline: Airport Hurdles and the Nonflying Nuns
abstract: Joe Sharkey column on kind of 'nonphysical interference' with security screeners at nation's airports that can get passenger a hefty fine; also describes ordeal of four Roman Catholic Carmelite nuns who were tossed off American Airlines flight awaiting departure to Frenso, Calif, from Dallas after someone on board reported smelling sulfur; American Airlines has apologized for inconvenience and for miscommunication; drawing (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: War Crimes Inquiry
abstract: International Criminal Court chief prosecutor Luis Moreno-Ocampo, in response to request from Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni, announces possible inquiry into alleged right violations by Lord's Resistance Army rebels (S)

headline: House Passes Banking Overhaul Measure
abstract: US House, 392-25, approves bill to repeal federal banking laws that regulators call 'outdated' and burdensome to large and small banks; also amends bill to block Wal-Mart Stores and other retailers from buying industrial loan companies, which are similar to banks, and putting branches in their stores (S)

headline: Auditor's Papers Sought in Trial
abstract: Defense lawyers ask prosecutors to turn over response Tyco International's external auditor PricewaterhouseCoopers to wells notice by Securities and Exchange Commission; defense lawyers want to know what Richard Scalzo, partnerat PricewaterhouseCoopers, and his lawyers had to say in response to formal notice from SEC that it might file civil enforcement charges against Scalzo; Scalzo is prosecution witness in trial of L Dennis Kozlowski and Mark H Swartz (S)

headline: London Journal; The Sceptered Isle Is Appraised: $8 Trillion and Change
abstract: United Kingdom, including England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Island, is officially valued at $8.8 trillion; statisticians arrived at figure using new models and more detailed information measuring all private and public assets; some Britons are appalled at expenditure to arrive at valuation; photos (M)

headline: Big Parmalat Unit Files for Bankruptcy In Brazilian Court
abstract: Parmalat's Brazilian dairy unit files for bankruptcy protection, buckling under effects of accounting scandal at its Italian parent and legal actions in Brazilian courts; Brazilian unit owes $160 million to local banks (M)

headline: Incentives and New S.U.V. Help Chrysler Bolster Sales
abstract: DaimlerChrysler says its sales increased 9 perent in January compared with year earlier; Nissan's sales rose 25 percent, while Toyota sold 143,729 vehicles, its best January ever, and increase of 15.8 percent compared with year ago; General Motors' overall sales dropped 2 percent, as 17 percent decline in car sales overshadowed 13 percent increase in truck sales; market share slipped to 26 percent, well below 28 percent it had for all of 2003; Ford Motor Co's overall sales dropped 9 percent; sold 14 percent few cars than in January 2003; chart (M)

headline: Power Struggle Underscores Blair-Chirac Rift, Book Says
abstract: New book Tony Blair by Philip Stephens says that French Pres Jacques Chirac's strong opposition to Iraq war was motivated in part by wish to undermine Prime Min Tony Blair in struggle for leadership of Europe; photo; author is Financial Times columnist with access to Blair and aides; British intelligence reports portrayed Chirac deciding that Blair had 'usurped' his own position as 'natural leader of Europe'; book also describes Vice Pres Cheney as implacably opposed to working through UN on Iraq (S)

headline: Fresh SARS Cases in China Called Milder
abstract: World Health Orgn official says three cases of SARS that have been identified in Guangzhou, China, so far this winter appear to be milder strain of disease, and public health system seems well prepared to prevent larger outbreak (S)

headline: More Than a Dozen Bidders Express Interest in Hollinger
abstract: More than dozen bidders, including Barclay brothers of Britain, submit preliminary offers for all or parts of Conrad M Black's publishing empire Hollinger International; some bidders noted; Hollinger Inc, which holds Lord Black's controlling interest in Hollinger International, secures $7.4 million it needed to make interest payment that was due March 1 (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: New Gandhi In Politics
abstract: Rahul Gandhi, son of Sonia Gandhi and grandson of Indira Gandhi, will run for parliament in northern Uttar Pradesh; seat was held by his father and is now held by his mother; photo (S)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: List of Americans newly killed in Iraq

headline: An Unexpected Bump for UAL Shares
abstract: UAL Corp's shares rise 24 percent, to $3.53, trading as high as $3.70; stock is at its highest level since November 2002, soon before company filed for bankruptcy protection (S)

headline: F.T.C. Alters Role Of Comments
abstract: Federal Trade Commission is changing way it collects and handles consumer comments to better categorize and track complaints about advertising of violent movies, video games and music (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Ecuador: Indian Leader Attacked
abstract: National Indian Federation leader Patricia Gualinga reports failure of assassination attempt on federation head Leonidas Iza; Iza is unharmed, but three relatives, including his son, are injured; group opposes free-market reforms proposed by President Lucio Gutierrez; photo (S)

headline: Liberia Needs $500 Million, Report Says
abstract: United Nations and World Bank, preparing for donor conference, report Liberia will need $487 million in stabilization aid over next two years; Human Rights Watch calls for UN and donor nations to focus on rehabilitating child solders, including girls, who have been raped, conscripted as sexual slaves and enrolled as fighters; presses UN to probe recruitment and use of child soldiers by all three armed factions to seek accountability in future, including through war crimes tribunal (M)

headline: 'Lord of the Rings' Rules Yet Again After All
abstract: Final box-office figures for weekend show film The Lord of The Rings: The Return of the King earned $14.2 million to come in first with Big Fish finishing second with $13.8 million in its first weekend of wide release; earlier figures had Big Fish finishing in first place; Lord of the Rings' domestic total is $312 million since opening Dec 17; photo (M)

headline: Pakistan May Have Aided North Korea A-Test
abstract: Revelations about international nuclear trading by Pakistani scientist Abdul Qadeer Khan rekindles tantalizing question of whether Pakistan's 1998 underground nuclear weapons test was joint effort with North Korea, conducted using North Korea's plutonium; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Lithuania: Impeachment Delayed For Court's Ruling
abstract: Lithuanian Parliament proceedings to impeach President Rolandas Paksas are adjourned awaiting Supreme Court ruling on whether or not Paksas's dealings with Russian businessman linked to organized crime violated constitution (S)

headline: By reconsidering its message and its mission, the maker of Tylenol practices what it preaches.
abstract: Deutsch advertising agency has produced Tylenol's new ad campaign, which asks consumers to put pain reliever before pain; studies by McNeil Consumer and Speciality Pharmaceuticals, maker of Tylenol, show that consumers choose treatments based more on symptons that product says it treats and less on distinctions among brands or ever particular products; photo (M)

headline: KOHLBERG KRAVIS IS BUYING SEALY FOR $1.5 BILLION
abstract: Mattress maker Sealy is acquired by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts for $1.5 billion; Kohlberg Kravis and Sealy's management acquires about 92 percent of company; remaining 8 percent is held by shareholders (S)

headline: A Powerful Résumé Speaks To an Employer. Grins, Too.
abstract: Video resumes are starting to emerge as new weapon for job hunters; they range from 20-second presentations of job applicant directly addressing camera to four-minute mini-movies replete with graphics and photo montages; they can cost from pennies to thousands of dollars; photo (M)

headline: ANNALY MORTGAGE SAYS IT IS ACQUIRING INVESTMENT ADVISER
abstract: Annaly Mortgage Management acquires Fixed Income Discount Advisory for $40.5 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: EX-ARMS MONITOR URGES AN INQUIRY ON IRAQI THREAT
abstract: Former chief weapons inspector David A Kay calls for independent inquiry into prewar intelligence about Saddam Hussein's weapons programs but says he does not believe Bush administration pressured analysts to exaggerate Iraqi threat; White House turns aside calls for wide-ranging election-year probe of gap between intelligence cited by Pres Bush and cabinet in making case for war and Kay's conclusion that Iraq did not have any large stockpiles of chemical or biological weapons last year; Kay tells Senate Armed Services Committee what is most disturbing is that 'we were all wrong'; photo; he does note ambiguity on facts because of looting after US invasion and failure to establish immediate physical security; White House rejects inquiry until Iraqi Survey Group, now under Charles A Duelfer, completes work; Republican Sen John McCain reads pointed statements to elicit Kay's agreement on Hussein's earlier programs, while Democrat Carl Levin quotes at length from specific statements by Bush, Vice Pres Cheney, Sec Donald Rumsfeld and Sec Colin Powell that Hussein had stockpiles of unconventional weapons; Edward Kennedy charges data was manipulated (M)

headline: What Unions Can Gain From Immigration
abstract: Eduardo Porter column discusses organized labor's immigration-friendly stance as unions seek to organize immigrant workers; cites AFL-CIO's continued support for amnesty bill for illegal aliens; notes immigrant-heavy unions are growing as overall union membership dwindles (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Longer Presidential Term Rejected
abstract: Russian lower house of Parliament soundly rejects constitutional amendment that would extend President's term of office from four years to seven years; President Vladimir V Putin, highly favored to win March 14 election, publicly opposed amendment (S)

headline: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC REPORTS $42 MILLION IN STENT SALES
abstract: Taxus, drug-coated stent introduced March 8 by Boston Scientific Corp, has had $42 million in sales; company shipped about 92,000 Taxus units through March 19 (S)

headline: Lynn L. Seidler, 67, Director Of Shubert Arts Foundation
abstract: Lynn L Seidler, former executive director of Shubert Foundation, which provides grants to support live professional theater and dance, died at age 67 (M)

headline: Former Finance Chief of Enron Pleads Guilty to Conspiracy
abstract: Under the plea deal, Andrew S. Fastow would be sentenced to 10 years in prison and cooperate with the investigation.

headline: Congressman Says U.S. Should Lift Its Ban on Travel to Libya
abstract: Repr Tom Lantos, who led battle for sanctions against Libya, says he believes Col Muammar el-Qaddafi has turned corner in abandoning terrorism and illicit weapons and should be rewarded with improved US relations; calls for lifting of travel ban after meeting with Libyan leader, in which he urged Qaddafi to issue apology to families of 270 people who died in bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland (S)

headline: Safe-Driving Campaign Awarded to Bartle Bogle
abstract: Florida attorney general's office awards assignment to create national safe-driving campaign, aimed at owners of sport utility vehicles, to New York office of Bartle Bogle Hegarty; spending on campaign, one-time assignment, will be $27 million (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Lithuania: French Rock Star Gets 8 Years In Killing
abstract: French rock star Bertrand Cantat is given eight-year prison sentence by Lithuanian court for beating to death girlfriend and French actress Marie Trintignant; couple was staying at hotel in Vilnius (Lithuania) when she was killed; photo (S)

headline: Yukos to Pursue Merger Though Target Objects
abstract: Yukos, Russia's biggest oil company, to recommend that company's management resume merger talks with rival Sibneft; company's board hires Squire, Sanders & Dempsey as legal adviser and J P Morgan as bankers and financial consultants; Yukos completed $13 billion deal to acquire Sibneft last year, but after Yukos' chief executive Mikhail B Khodorkovsky was jailed Oct 25, Sibneft called off merger in November; announcement signals that Yukos is preparing to fight back even as it is boxed into corner by Pres Vladimir V Putin's government, as well as by Sibneft (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Sperm Donors To Lose Anonymity
abstract: British government plans to eliminate anonymity for those who donate eggs and sperm after April 2005; plan needs Parliamentary approval (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: WorldCom Names New Chairman
abstract: WorldCom names Nicholas deB Katzenbach chairman and says president Richard R Roscitt will leave as it prepares to exit largest bankruptcy in US history; chief executive Michael D Capellas will succeed Roscitt as president (S)

headline: Expectations Are Low for Progress at Americas Conference
abstract: Pres Bush and 33 elected leaders of the Americas will meet in Monterrey, Mex, without common vision for future of Western Hemisphere; expectations for great progress are low and friction on important proposals are high (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Inquiry At Ericsson
abstract: Ericsson's auditor, Carl-Eric Bohlin, confirms newspaper report that he quit his job at Oehrlings PricewaterhouseCoopers in November without signing Ericsson's 2003 accounts after prosecutors questioned him on whether Ericsson obstructed tax assessment; accounts were instead signed by Bohlin's assistant Jeanette Skoglund; investigation focuses on more than 2.5 billion kronor ($341 million) Ericsson paid to 33 so-called trading agents in 1998 and 1999 (S)

headline: Two Financial Groups Make Agency Decisions
abstract: Fidelity Investments, part of FMR Corp, decides to continue with Arnold Worldwide as creative ad agency of record; billings estimated at $75 million; TIAA-CREF names TargetCast TCM to handle media duties on its ad account, which had been handled by MindShare; TIAA-CREF plans to spend significantly more in 2004 than $25 million spent in 2003 (S)

headline: Risking Death, 2 Afghan Women Collected and Detonated U.S. Cluster Bombs in 2001
abstract: To protect their poor farming village, two women cleared dozens of cluster bombs with their bare hands and detonated them.

headline: Powell Sees No Enthusiasm for Sending Peacekeepers to Haiti
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell called urgently today for talks among opposing forces in increasingly chaotic Haiti.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    Today  None    Tomorrow  Consumer Confidence: Feb.

headline: Iranian Leader Refuses to Intervene in Vote Clash
abstract: Irans Supreme Religious Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei refused today to intervene in a confrontation between the conservative and reformist camps after a religious authority barred thousands of pro-reform candidates from running in Parliamentary elections.

headline: Fear of a Communist Rebellion Is Growing in the Philippines
abstract: The Communist rebellion in the Philippines has regained strength and, according to military estimates, now counts 10,000 fighters in its armed wing.

headline: Comcast Shareholders Have Little Difficulty Containing Enthusiasm
abstract: Comcast Corp's shareholders so far do not seem to be buying company's takeover offer for Disney; Comcast shares tumble for second day and are down nearly 12 percent since Comcast chief executive Brian L Roberts announced all-stock offer; offer, which placed 9 percent premium on Disney's shares and was valued at $54 billion, is now worth $48 billion, well below Disney's current value in open stock market; Disney's stock has risen 16 percent in last two trading days, as investors evidently expect higher offer--whether from Comcast or another bidder; Disney shares close at $28; Comcast executives insist bid is its best offer; predict two stocks will return to normal trading ranges again, once it becomes clear, as they expect, that there will be no bidding war for Disney; photo (M)

headline: People
abstract: Paul Steentjes is named to new post of worldwide chief creative director on Nestle advertising account at Publicis Worldwide (S)

headline: A niche no more: gay celebrities are in demand as endorsers for mainstream campaigns.
abstract: Growing number of advertisers are using openly gay and lesbian celebrities aimed not at homosexual market but at wider general audience; advertisers involved include American Express, Audi, Cartier, Chili's, Diageo, Marshall Field's, General Motors, Target, Volkwagen and Wrigley; are hiring personalities like singers K D Lang and Melissa Etheridge, designers Isaac Mizrahi and Todd Oldham, actor John Cameron Mitchell and former football player Esera Tuaolo, along with five members of cast of Queer Eye for the Straight Guy; photos (M)

headline: Down-to-Earth Directions For the Well-Shod Tourist
abstract: Fodor introduces map software designed for pedestrians, for use with Pocket PC and Palm operating systems; photo (S)

headline: Long After Guerrilla War, Survivors Demand Justice From Brazil's Government
abstract: Brazilian Pres Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva's government is resisting efforts to open inquiry into Araguaia guerrilla war, fought in northeastern Brazil from 1970-1974; military reportedly massacred 60 combatants from Communist Party of Brazil and score of peasants caught in crossfire; victims' families have sought full accounting, but commission created by government is viewed as ineffective and obstructive, and da Silva's government refuses to create tribunal to judge behavior of army during military dictatorship; photos, map (M)

headline: Expired: How a Credit King Was Cut Off; Co-Founder of MBNA Meets an Anxious Board, And Loses
abstract: Year-long confrontation between MBNA credit card company co-founder Charles M Cawley and board that reportedly led to his retirement as chief executive detailed; directors say they feared charges of being too cozy with free-spending executives they were supposed to keep in check; cite his unwillingness to stop acting as if he were running private company; he issues statement defending behavior; photos (M)

headline: Wolfowitz Gets an Earful on Ethnic Tensions
abstract: Deputy Sec Paul D Wolfowitz, on mission to highlight successes in Iraq, attends Kirkuk town council meeting and hears of ethnic and religious tensions that are vastly complicating American efforts for orderly turnover of sovereignty; holds all Iraq was Saddam Hussein's victim and that all Iraqis have equal stake in cooperating to build new and democratic nation; Maj Gen Raymond T Odierno addresses objections of Shiites and other groups to caucus system planned by United States to select initial new government (M)

headline: Economic Memo; Even for Financial Experts, Analyzing the Job Market Is an Adventure
abstract: Many economists say Pres Bush may be running for re-election with stronger economy than is widely understood and that Federal Reserve might raise interest rates more rapidly than many investors expect; number of people receiving state jobless benefits has fallen by almost 500,000, or over 13 percent, since September; survey of executives suggests that companies in service sector are increasing their employment at fastest rate since 2000; Conference Board survey shows amount of help-wanted advertising being placed across country has risen more than 10 percent since May; graphs (M)

headline: New Darlings for Some Inflation-Wary Investors
abstract: Treasury Inflation Protected Securities, or TIPS, are being bought by individual investors as well as pension funds and others who are concerned that inflation could erode their returns in coming years; fear is that consumer prices may be poised to rise in coming months and years ahead if economy continues to rebound; low fixed returns offered on standard bonds will have even less buying power if goods and services become more expensive; securities pay investor set interest rate, and their principal gains in value along with rise in Consumer Price Index; TIPS market has nearly $200 billion in circulation; graph (M)

headline: Business; Unions Aim to Share in the Success of Reality TV
abstract: International Alliance of Theatrical Sª

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: EUROPE.

headline: Israelis Say Jordans King Visited Sharon
abstract: King Abdullah of Jordan and Prime Minister Ariel Sharon discussed Israels plan for "disengagement" from the Palestinians.

headline: Reading (Sort of) and Driving at the Same Time
abstract: With a digital player, a user can now download an audiobook for less than it would cost to buy a book, audiocassette or CD.

headline: North Korean Candor to Be Central to New Nuclear Talks
abstract: The United States, North Korea and four other nations prepared to begin talks on Wednesday about stopping North Koreas nuclear program.

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: RWANDA: Ex-Minister Gets Life In 1994 Genocide; IVORY COAST: Policeman Guilty Of Murder;.

headline: Corruption Accusations Rise From Brazil Mayor's Death
abstract: Brazilian Worker's Party has accused right-wing death squads of Jan 20, 2002, kidnapping and murder of Santo Andre Mayor Celso Daniel, but police concluded Daniel was victim of ordinary crime; case was reopened in Dec 2003 because of new information, which suggested Daniel was killed for trying to end corruption in his office; opposition parties seek to open congressional inquiry into matter; governing Worker's Party says it welcomes investigation, yet is slow to cooperate with prosecutor's office; photo; map (M)

headline: ALLIANT TECHSYSTEMS WINS ARMY MORTAR CONTRACT
abstract: Alliant Techsystems wins contract to develop laser-guided mortar for US Army that it says will be more accurate than current weapons; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: A Chirac (She, Not He) Is Campaigning for Re-election
abstract: Bernadette Chirac, wife of French Pres Jacques Chirac, who has been local official in Correze for 25 years, opens re-election drive; has made her mark on area in concrete but small ways; does not seem to need or want her husband to campaign with her; map; photos (M)

headline: The Iraqi Police Get to Confront an Old Boss
abstract: Muhammad Zimam Abd al-Razzaq, former Iraqi interior minister under Saddam Hussein and No. 41 on American occupation force's most-wanted list in Iraq, is arrested in Baghdad and then denounced by members of police force he once commanded; photo (M)

headline: GOLDEN STATE VINTNERS TO BE BOUGHT BY ITS CHIEF EXECUTIVE
abstract: Golden State Vintners Inc agrees to be acquired by O'Neill Acquisition Inc led by its chief executive Jeffrey O'Neill for about $96 million in cash (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sanyo Cuts Forecast
abstract: Sanyo Electric Co warns that profit will fall short of its earlier forecast because of weak sales of home appliances (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Applied Materials Posts Income Of $82.4 Million
abstract: Applied Materials says first-quarter net income was $82.4 million; sales increased 48 percent, to $1.56 billion; orders rose 32 percent from fourth quarter, to $1.68 billion, beating company's forecast for 20 percent gain (S)

headline: Oscar-Nominated Films Hold Up Against Super Bowl Competition
abstract: INHD, startup television network, shows video and film of Olympic Games going back to 1948 that have been converted to HDTV format; photo (M)

headline: PEABODY ENERGY TO BUY 3 MINES FROM GERMAN COMPANY
abstract: Peabody Energy Corp acquires two coal mines in Australia and one in Colorado from RAG of Germany for $441 million (S)

headline: FitzGerald to Retire as Unilever Chairman
abstract: The Anglo-Dutch conglomerate lowered expectations as it presented year-end results today and said that its co-chairman Niall FitzGerald would step down.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Aircraft Parts Contracts
abstract: Airbus chooses Japanese manufacturers Koito Industries, Matsushita Avionics System, Sumitomo Precision Products and Jamco Corp to supply parts for its A380 jumbo jet; 18 Japanese suppliers have been awarded contracts worth total of $4.25 billion (S)

headline: WorldCom Trial Delayed
abstract: By Bloomberg News.

headline: The Oil Company as Social Worker
abstract: The Oil Co

headline: 8 Children Among 17 Killed in Afghan Blast
abstract: As many as 17 people are killed and dozens injured, including many children, in double bomb blast in Kandahar, day after adoption of new Afghan constitution; authorities blame Taliban; Pres Hamid Karzai says victims include at least eight children (S)

headline: Dot-Com Survivor Hits on Right Plan
abstract: Profile of Intranets.com, company that survived bursting of dot.com bubble by retooling, reinventing and repackaging itself; Intranets.com, of Woburn, Mass, went through two makeovers, and two names, before it hit on what appears to be winning formula: setting up and running intranet sites of other companies; table; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Soldier Is Killed as Helicopter Is Shot Down in Iraq
abstract: Iraqi insurgents shoot down US military helicopter near Falluja, killing one crewman; angry Iraqis gather outside one of Baghdad's principal Sunni Muslim mosques to protest raid in which US troops arrested Imam Mahdi al-Sumaydai, prominent cleric, and 31 others; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Verisign Files Antitrust Suit Against ICANN
abstract: Verisign, which assigns and administers more than half of world's 60 million Internet addresses, files federal antitrust lawsuit against Internet Corp for Assigned Names and Numbers, seeking to free itself from at least part of Icann's control; suit asserts among other things that Icann has exceeded boundaries of contract it signed with Verisign in May 2001, authorizing Verisign to provide 'registry services' to companies that sell domain names with popular .com and .net suffixes, among others; Verisign says Icann has illegally prevented it from selling services that do not fall under Icann's purview, as it is set forth in companies contract (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: EarthLink Cutting Jobs
abstract: EarthLink will close call centers in California and Pennsylvania and cut its work force in Atlanta to lower expenses; about 1,300 jobs will be cut (S)

headline: Fear of a Communist Rebellion Is Growing in the Philippines
abstract: Communist rebellion in Philippines that began 35 years ago foundered but has regained strength; military estimates there are 10,000 fighters in its armed wing, New People's Army; Philippine military spokesman says Communists are 'utmost security concern' even though they have been overshadowed by Muslim insurgents; says they are much bigger threat than Abu Sayyaf, Moro Islamic Liberation Front or Jemaah Islamiyah (M)

headline: Leading Hollywood Talent and Marketing Companies Merge
abstract: The Firm, Hollywood talent management company, merges with Integrated Entertainment Partners, entertainmentment management company led by veteran Hollywood executive Rich Frank; combined company will be called The Firm; will continue to be run by Firm chief executive Jeff Kwatinetz (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago       Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.25       Federal Funds   1.00   1.02   1.26       3-month Libor   1.11   1.11   1.29       3-month T-bills   0.92   0.91   1.11       6-month T-bills   0.97   0.96   1.11       10-yr. T-infl.   1.38   1.32   2.01       10-yr. T-note   3.83   3.74   3.90       30-yr. headline: Business People; A Labor of Love From Russia
abstract: Kevin Hennessey, co-publisher and co-editor of guide to trade and investment in Russia's 89 regions, describes work on book, published with Council for Trade and Economic Cooperation US-Russia (S)

headline: Auto Bosses Are Spotted In a Bread Line
abstract: Auto Bosses.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Europewide Ban On U.S. Poultry
abstract: European Union bans importing of all live poultry and eggs from United States until March 23 because of outbreak of avian influenza in Texas (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Porsche's Profit Rises
abstract: Porsche earned 118 million euros ($148 million) in its first quarter ended Jan 31 from year earlier; revenue rose to 2.82 billion euros ($3.5 billion) (S)

headline: Opening Address to the 129th Meeting of the OPEC Conference
abstract: The following is an official transcript of the opening address to members of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries as it appeared on the organization's Web site on February 10, 2004.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Exports Rise
abstract: Singapore's nonoil domestic exports rose 2.7 percent in January compared with year earlier (S)

headline: Making Accounts More Flexible
abstract: H7

headline: Ad Agencies Make Executive Changes
abstract: Lynne F Seid, executive vice president and chief client officer at BBDO, is joining Foote Cone & Belding as president of New York office; will assume duties from Jeff Tarakajian; Foote Cone presidents-chief executives Scott Hollingsworth and Ben Barnes are being promoted as Harry Reid retires as president of Foote Cone & Belding International; BBDO says agency will distribute Seid's responsibilities among other executives; hires John Osborn as president-chief executive, succeeding Bill Katz, who is leaving (M)

headline: WATERS, A LAB EQUIPMENT MAKER, TO ACQUIRE NUGENESIS
abstract: The Waters Corporation, which makes laboratory equipment, agreed to acquire the closely held NuGenesis Technologies Corporation for $43 million. NuGenesis sells software to help scientists organize data. The acquisition, which is expected to close in the first quarter, will not affect Waters's earnings, the company said. Waters is based in Milford, Mass., and NuGenesis is based in Westborough, Mass.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cray To Buy OctigaBay For $115 Million
abstract: Cray acquires OctigaBay Systems Corp for about $115 million in stock and cash (S)

headline: Putnam Faces Big Penalties For Improper Fund Trades
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission is seeking payment from Putnam Investments of several hundred million dollars for improper trading in its mutual funds; SEC, in legal brief on March 15, does not indicate precise figure it was seeking from Putnam in fines and forfeited profit; Putnam says SEC wants too big a penalty relative to its actions; administrative law judge who will hear arguments in April from Putnam and SEC on amount to be paid could ultimately decide on much lower figure; settlement between regulators and Janus Capital could be reached as early as end of March (M)

headline: TWO AGENCIES MAY CUT E.D.S. CREDIT RATINGS
abstract: Moody's Investors Service says it might cut credit rating of Electronic Data Systems Corp to a level below that of investment grade, move that could force company to forfeit $400 million credit rating; Standard & Poor's says it is also considering a cut (S)

headline: A Savvier Search for a Magic Carpet
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column discusses purchasing room size rugs on the Internet; Web sites noted; drawing (M)

headline: A Choice of Bad or Worse, in an Impassive World
abstract: Charles Herold Game Theory column reviews Deus Ex: Invisible War and Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne; photos (M)

headline: It's Comeback Time For Luxury Watches
abstract: Luxury watches are back, especially if they are encrusted with diamonds or endorsed by celebrities; pollsters, retailers and watchmakers say this Christmas brought return of buyer who wants more than just something to tell time; America's Research Group chairman C Britt Beemer says sales of high-priced watches rose 35 percent over last Christmas; consumers were buying jeweled timepieces by Tiffany and Harry Winston and sports models by Tag Heuer and Breitling; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Trade Restrictions Eased
abstract: India announces series of measures that will relax import duties and restrictions for several sectors of economy in attempt to increase exports; will eliminate duties on professional equipment for services industry and on fuel for manufacturing industry; restrictions on gold and silver imports by jewelers and by bullion traders are also eased; government hopes measures help it meet goal of 12 percent increase in exports this year (S)

headline: Financial Scandal Hits Hong Kong
abstract: Investigators arrest 20 people in Hong Kong in financial scandal involving accusations of bribery and rigging of share prices by corporate executives, fund managers, research analyst and securities broker; UBS has been caught up in controversy, while anticorruption investigators in Hong Kong say employees at three more financial institutions and two publicly traded companies have been arrested; UBS suspends analyst Nicholas Tan after he is arrested; Taiwan-based KGI Asia says it is cooperating with probe; investigators are examining conduct of KGI employees and not company itself (M)

headline: Chief of Michigan Shop Retiring From BBDO
abstract: Mike Vogel, chairman and chief executive for last three years at Troy, Mich, office of BBDO Worldwide, is retiring (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Microsoft Antitrust Deal Is Said to Fall Short  Two separate reports suggest the antitrust consent decree reached between Microsoft and the Justice Department has neither fostered significant competition nor changed Microsoft's anticompetitive behavior.      The government's agreement with Microsoft to settle its antitrust lawsuit has ''fallen short'' of its goal of creating competition, according to the plaintiffs' report. [Page C2.]

headline: The Shifting Burden of Emergency Care
abstract: Health care giant HCA has found itself, rather oddly, in thick of battle between self-service and specialty hospitals; full-service institutionsl, often with deep roots in communities, say that hospitals specializing in cardiac care, orthopedics and other lucrative areas siphon away profitable patients, but shirk burden of providing emergency care; specialty hospitals counter that their rivals fear competition; HCA would seem unlikely standard-bearer for community hospitals; company, which operates OU Medical Center in Oklahoma City, is in same situation as other full-service hospitals competing with specialty operations; proliferation of specialty hospitals has worsened shortage of specialists who are willing to cover emergency rooms, causing other hospitals to send more and more patients to OU; Congress has put temporary ban on construction of specialty hospitals; full-service hospitals say these hospitals, often owned by doctors providing lucrative care, remain significant threat; photo (M)

headline: Blair Fields Criticism, and Heckling, as He Defends War
abstract: Prime Minister Tony Blair said today that freedom and democracy in Iraq were more important than any mistaken intelligence.

headline: CLINICAL DATA ADDS $6 MILLION TO BID FOR MOORE MEDICAL
abstract: Clinical Data Inc is adding about $6 million, or $2 per share in cash, to its $37 million bid for Moore Medical in attempt to trump offer by McKesson (S)

headline: Reading (Sort of) and Driving at the Same Time
abstract: Basics column discusses audio books that can be downloaded from Web sites and recorded onto DVD or portable audio players; various sites noted; drawing (M)

headline: Tax Withholding Proposed for Independent Contractors
abstract: Tax advocate Nina E Olson proposes that taxes be withheld from payments to independent contractors, from truck drivers to freelance writers, and that alternative minimum tax be repealed or at least revised so that it no longer applies to middle class; also says it is vital that Internal Revenue Service develop serious research capability to understand how changes in economy are affecting taxpayers, amounts they pay and how some people escape taxes; Congress created taxpayer advocate office in 1998 after hearings into whether IRS has been abusing taxpayers (M)

headline: Greece Struggles to Reach Olympics' Finish Line
abstract: Greek organizers of 2004 Olympics are in frantic race to get major projects finished before Summer Games begin on Aug 13; new soccer arena is not close to ready; main Olympic stadium still awaits mammoth dome; several essential mass-transit systems have yet to be tested, let alone put into operation; Greek government officials and Olympic organizers say none of this is surprising, that most projects are on schedule and that Athens has recovered from early delays that consigned some key endeavors to very tight timetables; International Olympic Committee officials who are monitoring Athens's progress are palpably nervous; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: SBC To Offer Wi-Fi Net Access At UPS Outlets
abstract: SBC Communications will offer high-speed wireless Internet access in United Parcel Service stores this year to attract more business customers; service will be available at 1,500 UPS and Mail Boxes Etc locations by year's end and in 3,000 stores by end of 2005 (S)

headline: China to Give Up $41 Billion Stake in 2 Big Banks
abstract: China's Ministry of Finance is preparing to help Bank of China and China Construction Bank by writing off its $41 billion stake in them in bid to cleanse their balance sheets of nonperforming loans and prepare them to issue stock; move is latest in series of steps by China to fortify its banking system ahead of what could be difficult year for Chinese economy; China's central bank says inflation at wholesale level continued to accelerate in December, with prices up 6.3 percent from year earlier, increasing pressure on central bank to slow economy; photo (M)

headline: Providian Said to Be Talking With Barclays About Merger
abstract: Barclays Bank reportedly discusses buying Providian Financial; Providian, credit card company, has changed its business model to focus on customers with better credit records and is trying to entice them with new products (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Adecco Investigation
abstract: Zurich stock exchange opens formal investigation into Adecco, large employment services company, to establish whether Swiss group failed to provide investors with timely market-sensitive information (S)

headline: Next Target in the French Headgear Debate: The Bandanna
abstract: The proposed French law prohibiting the wearing of religious symbols in public schools was expanded today to include bandannas worn by girls.

headline: U.S. Rescinds Ban on Bids By WorldCom
abstract: U.S. Rescinds Ban on Bido

headline: Israeli Soldiers Thwart a Boy's Suicide Bombing Attempt
abstract: Israeli troops on high alert at West Bank checkpoint near Nablus after finding bomb last week carried by 11-year-old boy, thwart suicide bombing attempt by Palestinian youth Hussam Abdo, who had bomb under his sweater; much of drama is recorded by television news cameraman, a Palestinian, who was among those waiting to cross checkpoint; Israel, swift to highlight Palestian use of youths barely in their teens, immediately invites journalists to scene; map (M)

headline: MEMO PAD
abstract: Soaring fuel costs are hitting airlines hard; Air Transport Association says number of planes taking off and number of passengers flying last month, among top 14 US carriers, were up 4.1 percent and 6.3 percent, respectively, over February 2003; revenue per available seat mile grew only 0.7 percent in February for domestic trips; crude oil prices for first quarter of year are projected to average $35 per barrel, compared with $31 in 2003; Omni San Diego hotel has scheduled its opening for April 7, day before San Diego Padres and San Francisco Giants play first game in city's new ballpark Petco Park; $124 million Omni Hotels property is connected by skybridge directly to adjacent ballpark in city's Gaslamp Quarter, and many of rooms have views of field; Reagan National Airport in Washington remains closed to corporate jets because of security concerns; National Air Transport Association president James K Coyne told House Aviation Subcommittee last week that continued closing unreasonably and unlawfully discriminates against corporate jets and charters, which are arguably more secure mode of air transportation than airlines, when considering new security requirements imposed on them by federal government; chart (Memo Pad column) (M)

headline: Mix-Up Over Sale of 'Silence' Cleared Up With a Little Talk
abstract: Apple Computer director for music programming Alex Luke says Apple's iTunes Music Store will reverse earlier decision and allow customers to buy song by rock band Sonic Youth, 63-second stretch of silence called Silence, separately; Sonic Youth objected when iTunes sought to restrict sale of song to people who bought entire album; photo (S)

headline: 5 Detained by U.S. at Guantánamo Arrive Back in Britain
abstract: Four of the five were arrested under terrorism laws on board the plane shortly after it landed, the police said. The fifth was detained under separate regulations.

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: LIBERIA: Ex-President Sues Tribunal; SOUTH AFRICA: Religion Honor;.

headline: U.S. Calls for Sunni and Kurdish Rights After Turnover
abstract: L Paul Bremer III, head of American occupation authority in Iraq, argues strongly for democratic system that protects minority rights, speech at rite marking 100-day countdown to dissolution of occupation authority and return of sovereignty to Iraq; responds indirectly to Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani's demands for majority rule that would dilute Sunni and Kurdish rights; United States holds firm to June 30 handover date despite increasing attacks on Iraqis working with Westerners, including those working for Western news organizations; major oil pipeline ruptures in Fao, reportedly because of poor maintenance, spilling oil that catches fire and sends out vast plumes of smoke; photo (M)

headline: Shiite Ayatollah Is Warning U.N. Against Endorsing Charter Sponsored by U.S.
abstract: Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani warns of 'dangerous consequences' if United Nations endorses American-sponsored interim constitution for independent Iraq that was adopted over Shiite protests two weeks ago; says his followers, by far most powerful political bloc in Iraq, could move to paralyze American plans for smooth transfer of sovereignty on June 30 unless Shiite terms for changing interim constitution are met; at issue in interim constitution are elaborate minority guarantees that Shiites object to; senior American officials in Iraq are uncertain how far Sistani is prepared to go to realize his demands; photo (M)

headline: Bombing Leaves a Northern Iraqi City Feeling Vulnerable
abstract: Iraqis in Kirkuk are frightened in aftermath of bombing of police station; at least ten people died, with 50 others, many civilians, wounded; photos; one of most diverse cities in Iraq sits on fault line between Kurds and Arabs, and deadly attacks are sharpening tensions just as leaders debate city's future (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: White House Backs Away From Recent Jobs Forecast  The Bush administration backed away from a forecast it made last week predicting average job gains of more than 300,000 a month for 2004 but said it was confident of robust though unspecified job growth for the year.     The White House press secretary, Scott McClellan, repeatedly declined to endorse the forecast, which was included in a report sent to Congress last week under President Bush's signature. The shift opened the door to an attack by Democrats. [Page A14.]

headline: Options Trading Surged for Bank
abstract: Trading in Bank One optior

headline: For Bank Chief, Buying Big Rival Is Only the First Part of the Deal
abstract: Bank of America's $48 billion acquisition of FleetBoston Financial is most brazen move yet by Bank of America chief executive Kenneth D Lewis; Bank of America's stock price has lagged that of its peers over concerns that Lewis is overpaying for FleetBoston and because of bank's role in series of financial scandals; Lewis takes step to restore credibility by announcing two banks will jointly pay $675 million to resolve probe into trading in their mutual funds, eliminating one cloud over merger; Lewis must prove FleetBoston is worth price; Bank of America is paying 40 percent premium to FleetBoston's price before merger was announced; graph; photo (M)

headline: Corporate Tax Bill Hits Wall in Senate After Debate on Overtime
abstract: Bill to overhaul corporate tax laws and resolve $4 billion trade battle with European Union stalls on Senate floor after Democrats and Republicans fight to standoff over unrelated amendment that would block Bush administration from changing rules that govern overtime pay; Republicans accuse Democrats of election-year grandstanding, while Democrats say they want chance to vote on rules that they say could eliminate overtime pay for millions of white-collar workers; if Congress fails to pass broader legislation, most immediate practical consequence would be that European Union will continue to impose as much as $4 billion in annual tariffs on American products (M)

headline: Single, but Laying Down Roots
abstract: sA

headline: U.S. Muffles Sweeping Call To Democracy In Mideast
abstract: Bush administration, yielding to European and Arab protests, sets aside plan to issue sweeping call for economic, political and cultural reform in Middle East; June conference of major industrial nations will instead endorse reforms already under way in region; Jordanian Min Marwan Muasher meets with Sec Colin Powell and reports Powell accepts modification (M)

headline: Oil Giants In Russia Reach Pact On Breakup
abstract: Largest shareholders of Russia's Yukos and Sibneft sign protocol to reverse $13 billion merger of two companies; actual transfer of money and shares has yet to be worked out (M)

headline: MEDIMMUNE SAYS CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER HAS LEFT
abstract: MedImmune's chief financial officer Gregory S Patrick resigns; controller Lota S Zoth will be acting chief financial officer (S)

headline: Lord Black Pursued Contrary Sale Strategies, Court Told
abstract: Louis G Zachary Jr and Richard C Breeden, advisers to Hollinger International, testify that even as Conrad M Black was spearheading effort last fall to sell company's assets, he was engaged in secret talks to undermine that process by selling his controlling stake in company; Lord Black, then company's chairman, asked investment bank Lazard to oversee any sale of assets by Hollinger; Black then opened his own negotiations to sell his stake to Barclay brothers; photo (M)

headline: The Collections / Paris : Horses and boys bring shift in pace
abstract: The neigh of a horse and the strut of a boy were the two surprise elements of the Paris fashion season, which closed the monthlong international collections this week. The equestrian ride from designers as diverse as Ann Demeulemeester, Jean Paul Gaultier and Helmut Lang, proved how creative minds think alike. And the fact that leading designers — starting with Chanel — put males on their runways emphasized a change of fashion pace. After the girly, fluttery and barely-there sexually titillating fashions since the start of the millennium, designers are going back to something much more substantial.

headline: Prosecutor Says Martha Stewart Spun Web of Lies About Shares
abstract: Opening statements are made in Martha Stewart trial; Karen Patton Seymour, prosecutor, says Stewart traded ImClone Systems stock on tip from her broker, Peter E Bacanovic, and they together created elaborate web of lies to conceal truth from investigators; says Stewart also made affirmative statements about her innocence to assure investors in her media company and prop up its value; Stewart's attorney says that despite her working as stockbroker in past, Stewart could not have been expected to know that information she received would get her in trouble; says it is bizarre for Stewart to face securities fraud simply for having denied doing anything unlawful; Becanovic's lawyer insists his client is innocent and acted only as responsible stockbroker in his dealing with Stewart; photo (M)

headline: G.M. LAYS OFF 350 WORKERS AT PLANT IN NEW JERSEY
abstract: General Motors to lay off 350 of 1,350 hourly workers at Linden, NJ, plant as it shifts production of midsize pickups to newly renovated Louisiana factory (S)

headline: Greek Conservatives' Victory Ends Long Rule by Socialists
abstract: Conservatives sweep to power in parliamentary elections in Greece, ending over decade of Socialist rule; George Papandreou concedes defeat for his party after exit polls and early results give solid lead to center-right New Democracy; New Democracy leader Costas Caramanlis vows to deliver 'immediately' on his campaign pledges for social reforms; appeals for Papandreou's support; both leaders pledge support for Athens Olympics, where preparations lag (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Chinese Activists Released
abstract: Seven Chinese activists, detained for landing on Senkakus (Japan) or Diaoyus (China), remote island chain claimed by both China and Japan, are released from Japanese custody (S)

headline: In Thailand, High Hopes For Its Rubber Industry
abstract: Thailand's Surat Thani Province is in midst of rubber boom; rubber supplies are short and prices are soaring thanks largely to Chinese demand; rubber boom is part of broader surge in global commodity prices that is doing wonders for fertile developing nations like Thailand; rubber boom has also stirred debate about merits of economic policies of Prime Min Thaksin Shinawatra, which have pushed his popularity rating up along with country's consumer-led recovery; map; photos (M)

headline: China Takes Over Shenzhen Brokerage Firm
abstract: Chinese securities regulators and Shenzhen government report taking over financially ailing Southern Securities, Shenzhen-based brokerage firm, charging 'illegal and irregular operations and disorderly management;' firm's collapse may further hurt confidence in China's equity markets (S)

headline: New Targets: Attackers Shift Their Sights to the Iraqis
abstract: Analysis: fourth deadly suicide bombing in Iraq in less than two weeks suggests that insurgency that has bedeviled Americans and Iraqis since collapse of Saddam Hussein's government is changing in important ways; attacks against American soldiers have dropped since November, as insurgents increasingly focus on Iraqi civilians, particularly those who are seen to be collaborating with American-led occupation; suicide bombings have aimed to inflict maximum damage on Iraqi institutions like police and military that are central to American effort to turn over reins of government by June 30; some American and Iraqi officials call these changes evidence that insurgency is being sustained by foreign fighters with links to international terrorist groups like Al Qaeda, as ranks of Hussein's cadre are thinned by capture or death; photo (M)

headline: Annan Is Said To Have Doubt On Iraq Voting
abstract: United Nations diplomats say Sec Gen Kofi Annan believes interim Iraqi government to take office this summer cannot be chosen by direct elections, but will not make his recommendations yet; says his special envoy Lakhdar Brahimi found setting up credible elections by June 30 deadline is not feasible but felt that more time is needed to develop clear options for returning sovereignty to Iraqis (M)
