headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: IDT Buys Stake In Archie Comics
abstract: IDT Corp acquires 5 percent stake in Archie Comics Entertainment, including right to produce animated programs based on comic-book characters (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Fourth-Quarter Earnings Nearly Double at Citigroup  Fourth-quarter profits at Citigroup nearly doubled on the strength of its credit card business and lower litigation costs. The results included a $242 million after-tax charge for loan and trading losses tied to Parmalat. Revenue rose 13 percent, to $20.15 billion.     Citigroup also announced a 14 percent increase in its quarterly dividend, to 40 cents a share. [Page C4.]

headline: MediaTalk; Prince Becomes Online Retailer, Selling His Songs From His Site
abstract: Prince opens own online store to sell music for which he owns master recordings; some of his best-known albums will not be available; he hopes store will increase membership in his NPG Music Club, which offers fans exclusive songs, early access to concert tickets and other benefits; photo (M)

headline: Shinsei Bank Will Be Listed On Tokyo Stock Exchange
abstract: Shareholders of Japanese Shinsei Bank, which include Ripplewood Holdings, Citigroup and Deutsche Bank, will sell 440 million shares of Shinsei on Tokyo Stock Exchange and elsewhere; pricing of Shinsei shares, which is estimated to be $4.07 per share, will take place on Feb 9, and will be listed on Feb 19; initial public offering could raise as much as $1.8 billion for Shinsei's investors (M)

headline: ImClone's Cancer Drug Is Back, And U.S. Approval Is Expected
abstract: ImClone System Inc's cancer drug Erbitux is expected to receive Food and Drug Administration approval by end of week; doctors say drug will be important therapy, initially for patients with colorectal cancer who have run out of options; investors have bid ImClone shares up to over $41, far above stock's low of $6.11 in fall of 2002; Dr John Mendelsohn, co-founder of Erbitux, has resigned from board of ImClone Systems; photo (M)

headline: Internet Providers Sue Hundreds Over Unsolicited E-Mail
abstract: The suits by America Online, Earthlink, Yahoo and Microsoft are among the first to invoke the federal Can-Spam Act.

headline: $41 Billion Deal, But What's in It For Consumers?
abstract: Industry analysts say merger of Cingular Wireless and AT&T Wireless, and consolidation of wireless industry to five major competitors from six, may not lead to higher consumer prices for mobile phone service anytime soon; say merger could spur better quality of service; consumer groups plan to challenge merger on grounds that it could reduce competition in South and Southwest US, where BellSouth and SBC, Cingular's parents, are dominant; Consumers Unions says acquisition of AT&T Wireless and its 22 million customers could give those two telephone giants excessive power in their local markets; group plans to lobby Federal Communications Commission and Justice Department to reject deal as currently constructed; chart; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Gateway To Sell Laptops In Office Depot Stores
abstract: Gateway will sell some laptop computers in Office Depot stores; Gateway 200X notebook will cost as little as $1,400 after $200 mail-in rebate; Office Depot also agrees to begin selling Sony notebook computer (S)

headline: DIRECTV SELLS STAKE IN XM SATELLITE FOR $230 MILLION
abstract: The DirecTV Group, the satellite television service, sold its remaining stake in XM Satellite Radio Holdings to exit a business unrelated to consumer television. DirecTV sold nine million shares of XM, the satellite radio provider, for about $230 million, a DirecTV spokesman, Bob Marsocci, said. DirecTV is shedding assets unrelated to its consumer satellite service, Mr. Marsocci said. The company sold some of its XM holdings in January and has said it may sell its 81 percent stake in the PanAmSat Corporation, another commercial-satellite operator.

headline: Business People; Memo to Spouse: I Really Do Care
abstract: Jim Jenkins, president of Creative Visions Consulting, executive coaching firm, says he has been getting a lot of calls recently from high-powered executives who want to 'reignite the flame' with their spouses (S)

headline: Taiwanese Leaders Survive Shooting Incident Ahead of Vote
abstract: The president was shot today and the vice president was slightly wounded on the eve of bitterly contested national elections.

headline: U.S. Withdraws a Team of Weapons Hunters From Iraq, Saying That Its Work Is Done
abstract: Bush administration has quietly withdrawn from Iraq 400-member military team whose job was to scour country for military equipment, suggesting it no longer expects to find caches of chemical and biological weapons that White House cited as principal reason for invasion; separate team for disposing of such materiel remains part of 1,400-member Iraqi Survey Group but is 'still waiting for something to dispose of' (M)

headline: Gates Predicts That Spam Will Go Away
abstract: Microsoft Corp chairman Bill Gates says company is working on three ways to enable e-mail users to keep spam out of their computers, speech to World Economic Forum, Davos, Switzerland; says problem of junk e-mail will be gone within two years, television interview (S)

headline: U.S. Asks China to Trim Threat to Taiwan
abstract: American Under Sec for Defense Douglas J Feith, in Beijing, tells Chinese leaders that they should withdraw missiles aimed at Taiwan, stressing that burden of reducing tensions across Taiwan Strait falls heavily on Beijing; his comments may pour cold water on China's hopes that United States would intervene decisively to stop Taiwan from holding referendum on cross-strait issues in tandem with its Mar 20 presidential election (M)

headline: A New Direction For Fast-Food Rivals
abstract: Burger King, seeking reverse sales slump, is reviving theme from 1970's, 'Have it your way,' in ad campaign by Crispin Porter & Bogusky; Wendy's International is starting ad campaign by McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising that introduces characters including 'Mr Wendy,' unofficial spokesman for company that appoints himself evangelist for Wendy's (M)

headline: Russia Told It Understates Dependence On Oil Sales
abstract: World Bank sayø

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: ADC To Acquire Krone Group For $291 Million
abstract: ADC Telecommunications acquires Krone Group phone-gear business of GenTek Inc for $291 million; will assume $59 million worth of Krone's liabilities (S)

headline: RAYOVAC ANNOUNCES LAYOFFS AND A MOVE TO ATLANTA
abstract: Rayovac Announces Layoffs and A M7

headline: Bank Money Accounts
abstract: Annual percentage yields, in percent, on money market accounts, three-month certificates of deposit and six-month C.D.s expected at selected institutions on Wednesday, December 31, 2003. Yields are based on the method of compounding the interest rate stated for the lowest minimum to open an account, but minimums may vary. Higher yields may be offered for larger deposits. C.D. figures are for fixed rates only. Rates subject to change without notice.

headline: Big Changes Are Planned In Game-Software Strategy
abstract: Microsoft announces new software development strategy that aims to blur distinction between its personal computer game and Xbox video game console businesses; under strategy, which company calls XNA, developer of game software would be able to write single program that could be translated for use on Windows PC's, on Xbox video game consoles or on mobile hardware systems; Microsoft describes its new strategy at Game Developers Conference in San Jose, Calif (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Tekelec To Acquire Taqua For $85 Million
abstract: Tekelec, maker of telecommunications switches, agrees to buy Taqua Inc for $85 million in cash (S)

headline: Caution in Online Bill Paying
abstract: Janet Hays letter on Jan 18 article cites her electronic bill paying strategy of stipulating that payment date be one day before due date

headline: Europe And U.S. Near Accord On Auditing
abstract: European Commission signals that it may settle longstanding dispute with United States and move toward joint supervision of accounting profession; at issue is information that US authorities would try to seize during an investigation; commission wants American authorities to agree to involve European audit regulators in any such inquiry (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: European Commission Scolds France
abstract: European Commission scolds France for not making enough effort to reduce its budget deficit; commission says Britain, Greece, Italy and Netherlands also risk breaching deficit ceiling, which is 3 percent of gross domestic product (S)

headline: Care and Feeding of Cyberpets Rivets Tag-Along Marketers
abstract: Children's Web site neopets.com delivers advertising to its users and creates detailed reports about behavior and preferences of its users; by caring for virtual pet, child is confronted with series of choices about products and services, data which is provided to marketers; privacy concerns noted; photos (M)

headline: At Shell, New Accounting and Rosier Oil Outlook
abstract: Article on turmoil over accounting and reserve reporting by Royal Dutch/Shell, oil giant that traces roots to Dutch oil company and English seashell importer in 1890's; Sir Philip Watts, who rose to top three years ago with program to increase reported reserves, has been ousted amid revelations that company increased its oil and gas reserves not by discovering new sources but by changing accounting to add reserves that may not be usable; estimates of proven reserves have now been cut by 20 percent, 3.9 billion barrels, and SEC is investigating on behalf of American investors; internal documents and interviews with industry experts describe company that in 1990's was under market pressure to show 'correct performance' on reserves that were actually declining because discoveries did not keep pace with production; retired manager Colin Allcard recalls defined targets and 'motivational schemes' as company came under pressure of low prices and competition from larger rivals BP Amoco and Exxon Mobil, which were building reserves with discoveries, mergers and strategic alliances; photo (M)

headline: To Convict Kozlowski, Jury Must Find Intent, Judge Says
abstract: Judge Michael J Obus, who is presiding over fraud and larceny case against former Tyco International chief executive L Dennis Kozlowski, says jurors need to find that he 'acted with larcenous intent' in order to convict him; tell jurors they must acquit Kozlowski if they conclude that he 'believed he was authorized' to take $170 million in bonuses and loans that he and his co-defendant, former chief financial officer Mark H Swartz, are accused of stealing; jurors ask to see several trial exhibits, including reports to Securities and Exchange Commission, company news releases announcing earnings, annual reports and minutes of Tyco compensation committee meetings (M)

headline: Anti-U.S. Kurdish Militants Rebounding, Officials Say
abstract: Kurdish and American officials say Ansar al-Islam, militant Kurdish Islamic group routed by United States-led invasion, is making resurgence, branching out from its former mountain strongholds to cities across Iraq; captured Ansar members say mission has expanded from terrorizing local villagers to planning suicide bombings against occupation; American officials now blame Ansar for many of recent attacks; say it recently allied with Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, Jordanian suspected of ties to Al Qaeda; report killing one of Zarqawi's top aides, bomb maker named Abu Muhammad Hamza, in shootout in Habbaniya; map; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Canary Wharf Bid Raised
abstract: Toronto property company Brascan Group shocks London markets by saying it will make higher-than-expected bid of $2.9 billion for Canary Wharf, commercial real-estate complex that has become London's financial hub (S)

headline: In Beijing, Nuclear Talks Seem Mired In Discord
abstract: United States and North Korea, at talks in Beijing with four other nations, make scant progress in resolving their differences over scope of North Korea's nuclear program, steps that would have to be taken to abolish it and timing of any aid packages; North Korea convenes news conference to denounce 'hard line stance' of United States for impeding progress (M)

headline: As Far as Jobs Go, Bush Can Only Wait
abstract: Analysis: Labor Department's report on December unemployment shows little job growth, despite Pres Bush's optimism that unemployment will begin to fall; economists say administration has exhausted fiscal and monetary options for stimulating job growth, and must now wait and hope for unemployment to fall; net job loss, which totals more than two million since Bush took office in 2001, continues to be major political weakness for administration (M)

headline: Tyson Foods Leaves DDB Worldwide
abstract: Tyson Foods drops Chicago office of DDB Worldwide as its ad agency after ConAgra Foods selects agency to handle its Banquet line; shifts account to Arnold Worldwide (S)

headline: Spain Says It Holds Half of Group That Bombed Trains
abstract: Spanish investigators believe that they have identified core group of Islamic militants who carried out deadly train bombings in Madrid and that over half of those involved are in custody; are trying to determine who was behind plot, which was carried out by eight or nine Moroccan extremists; assessment comes as Spain announces it has provisionally charged another Moroccan in connection with attacks, bringing to 12 number of people who have been formally accused of involvement in bombings; at least 20 have been arrested in case, and 17 remain in custody; several of Moroccans arrested have ties to militants who had been identified in various countries as members of Al Qaeda; some of militants have been blamed for series of bombings in Casablanca in 2003 (M)

headline: Polio Cases In West Africa May Thwart W.H.O. Plan
abstract: World Health Organization blames Nigeria for spread of polio to at least six other West African countries in recent months; seeks to halt spread of disease through immunization of children in affected area, but acknowledges that this puts strain on countries that had already eradicated disease; chief obstacle to immunization program has been opposition by some Islamic leaders in Nigerian state of Kano; outbreak threatens WHO's goal of total eradication of polio by 2006 (M)

headline: Judge Says Maker Of OxyContin Misled Officials To Win Patents
abstract: Federal Judge Sidney H Stein says Purdue Pharma, maker of highly profitable painkiller OxyContin, delibately misled federal officials to win patents protecting its drug; ruling helps clear way for cheaper generic version and could lead to more lawsuits; decision comes in response to suit brought by Purdue against Endo Pharmaceuticals Holdings, which filed application to sell generic version of OxyContin; Purdue Pharma to appeal (M)

headline: Patents; By correcting inaccuracies, a professor tries to deliver a fuller picture of the lives of African-American inventors.
abstract: Interview with Prof Rayvon Fouche on his new book, Black Inventors in the Age of Segregation, possible first full-fledged scholarly examination of black inventors in America; book focuses on three inventors: Shelby J Davidson (1868-1930), Lewis H Latimer (1848-1928) and Granville T Woods (1856-1910); photo (M)

headline: U.N. Finds Flight Recorder Linked to Rwanda Investigation
abstract: Officials disclosed that the U.N. was unknowingly holding an airplane black box from the 1994 crash that killed the presidents of Rwanda and Burundi.

headline: Private Sector; A Supporting Role Earns Praise
abstract: Profile of Writers Store, founded by Dan Douma and wife, Gabriel Meiringer, which caters to computer and other needs of Hollywood scriptwriters; photos (M)

headline: Car Bomb Kills 15 Near Main U.S. Compound in Baghdad
abstract: A large bomb exploded at the main gate of the American occupation headquarters in Baghdad on Sunday morning, killing and wounding people in a crowd gathering to enter the heavvily fortified compound. The attack appeared to be an effort by terrorist bombers to strike as close as they could approach to the heart of American authority in Baghdad.     The bomb killed at least 15 people and wounded at least 25, Reuters reported.

headline: Jurors Report Possible Deadlock in Trial of Tycos Ex-Chief
abstract: The jurors in the trial of L. Dennis Kozlowski told the judge in the case that they might have reached an impasse today.

headline: Sharon Hints Israel Might Alter Route of West Bank Barrier, but Not to Meet Outside Demands
abstract: Prime Min Ariel Sharon says Israel might alter route of its separation barrier in West Bank, acknowledging that barrier has caused difficulties for ordinary Palestinians; says that in making alterations, his government would not be swayed by demands made by Palestinians, United Nations or International Court of Justice in The Hague; Israel says barrier is intended as security measure against suicide bombers and other Palestinian attacks; Palestinians say it amounts to confiscation of West Bank land they are demanding for future state; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: A Real-Life Debate On Free Expression In a Cyberspace City
abstract: Little-known netherworld of popular computer game genre known as 'massively multi-player online role-playing games' prompts debate on free expression after paying subscriber's account is terminated; subscriber, Peter Ludlow, says decision of Electronic Arts to terminate his account on The Sims Online is 'clearly censorship,' but Electronic Arts claims Ludlow was kicked out because he broke one of game's main rules by including link on his profile to his Alphaville Herald Web site, which in turn links to sites that tell people how to cheat; Ludlow says he was nabbed on a technicality, and many players agree that company enforces rule selectively; case described; photo (M)

headline: Parmalat Worker Was Listed as a Chief
abstract: Italian investigators say Antonio Ugolotti, employee in charge of Parmalat's switchboard and package deliveries, is listed as chief executive of more than 25 affiliated companies; disclosure that low-level employee is used--apparently unwittingly--to represent top executive indicates lengths Parmalat went to hide true state of its finances through complex web of subsidiaries (M)

headline: Business People; Trump's Next Move: From 'Apprentice' To Global Master
abstract: Donald Trump says his Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts will change its name to Trump International after it completes major refinancing that will replace him as majority shareholder; Trump, who will remain chairman, plans to build new towers for two Atlantic City properties and possibly expand abroad (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: S.E.C. Uncovers Payments For Selling Mutual Funds  Federal officials announced a new front in the investigations into the mutual fund industry, saying that they had uncovered widespread instances of brokers receiving payments for steering investors toward specific funds.    Officials described a kind of mutual fund payola, or deals in which a number of brokerage firms and mutual funds have provided cash and other compensation to the brokerage houses that sell fund shares. [Page A1.]

headline: Liberty Media Fuels Speculation By Adding to News Corp. Stake
abstract: One day after Liberty Media Corp, controlled by John C Malone, said it was increasing its voting stake in News Corp, investors are still wondering what Malone is up to; company has been quietly increasing its stakes in number of properties where it already has investment; Malone is positioning himself to play greater role at News Corp by increasing his voting interest to about 9 percent; Australia law says Liberty, as foreign investor in Australian company cannot buy controlling stake without government permission; Liberty spokesman Michael Erickson says Malone is not actively seeking board seat at News Corp (M)

headline: U.S. Rebuked On Afghans In Detention
abstract: Human Rights Watch charges American forces in Afghanistan detained at least 1,000 Afghans and other people in last two years in 'climate of almost total impunity' that violates international human rights law; calls on United States military to release results of probe into deaths of three Afghans in American custody in 2002 and 2003; cites numerous reports of American forces relying on faulty intelligence or using excessive force that resulted in avoidable civilian deaths and detention of innocent people; warns US policies on detaining terrorism suspects in Afghanistan and elsewhere have harmed public opinion of US around world; Lt Col Bryan Hilferty says American forces act properly (M)

headline: Bouncing Back, as a Writer
abstract: John S Koppel letter reflects on emergence of former stock analyst Henry Blodget as journalist covering Martha Stewart trial

headline: Branded Specialist Is Joining Omnicom
abstract: Omnicom Group in New York hires Robert Riesenberg, specialist in so-called branded entertainment programming, from Interpublic Group of Companies (S)

headline: COURT APPROVES HOMESTORE'S $91 MILLION SETTLEMENT
abstract: Homestore Inc receives court approval for its $91 million settlement on shareholder lawsuit brought by California State Teachers' Retirement System, which accused company of falsifying financial statements (S)

headline: MediaTalk; The Unorthodox System: First Build a Fan Base, Then Record an Album
abstract: Particle, Los Angeles band that plays disco-flavored, instrumental jam music, has built devoted following during three and a half years on concert tour and is only now releasing its first CD, Launchpad; never even had demo CD to sell on tour; photos (M)

headline: Malaysian Company Tied To Nuclear Trade Network
abstract: Publicly traded Malaysian oil and gas conglomerate that supplied high-quality nuclear components to Libya is latest link to emerge in rogue nuclear trading network stretching back to Abdul Qadeer Khan, creator of Pakistan's atom bomb; western and Malaysian investigators say components were ordered from Scomi Precision Engineering of Malaysia by Khan, who made periodic trips to Malaysia over past few years, not always traveling under his real name; Western official says components ordered from Scomi were to be used in centrifuges to make weapons-grade uranium (M)

headline: A right to vote:Many U.S. youths abroad are denied
abstract: PARIS:—  Many overseas Americans — possibly thousands — may not be able to vote in this year's presidential election because of an omission during the latest round of U.S. electoral reform, according to U.S. officials and organizations representing Americans abroad.

headline: An Austrian Advantage
abstract: Thomas G Stemberg, chairman and co-founder of Staples, comments on his childhood, education and how he came to start Staples; photo (The Boss column) (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank To End Pension Contributions
abstract: Germany's Commerzbank AG will cease making pension contributions for employees as of Jan 1, 2005 (S)0

headline: Accord Said to Be Near in Viacom-EchoStar Dispute
abstract: Viacom Inc and EchoStar Communications Corp executives say they are close to ending dispute that kept signals of Viacom's 16 CBS stations and its 10 cable channels, including MTV and Nickelodeon, off EchoStar's satellite TV service since March 9; deal will resolve amount EchoStar pays to receive channels; terms undisclosed; effort seems timed to ensure that 1.6 million EchoStar customers in 16 cities will not be prevented from seeing second night of CBS's prime-time programming; Viacom executives expected that EchoStar would not hold out past March 10 because its subscribers would have been denied two of most popular show on television, Survivor and CSI, which are broadcast on Thursdays (M)

headline: When You Don't Want to Miss That Call, or Even If You Do
abstract: Cidco's Merge integrates cellphone and home phone to receive calls on any phone in house; photo (S)

headline: At a Mountain Monastery, Old Texts Gain Digital Life
abstract: St Catherine's Monastery, Mount Sinai, Egypt, houses collection of early Christian documents including some of world's oldest Bibles; monks are using digital technology to preserve texts; plan is to have entire collection digitized in 10 years if financing holds out; selection of artifacts and manuscripts will be on display at Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, March 23-July 4; photos (M)

headline: MediaTalk; Why a Big Player In Telecom Added Archie and Jughead To His Holdings
abstract: Howard Jonas, founder and chairman of IDT, telecommunications company, acquires 5 percent stake in Archie Comics Entertainment and intends to bring Archie and his comic book friends to life in animated video and film; photo (M)

headline: FOOTSTAR CONSIDERS FILING FOR BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
abstract: Footstar will file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection if it cannot secure financing or sell assets to ease shortage of cash; is being investigated by Securities and Exchange Commission (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: New DVD Models
abstract: Matsushita Electric Industrial Co hopes to raise its share of global market for DVD recorders to 50 percent this year from 40 percent last year as it unveils new line of devices under its Panasonic brand; plans to introduce six new DVD recorders in Japan by July (S)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: AFGHANISTAN: 2 U.S. Soldiers Killed; CHINA: Photographer To Be Freed;.

headline: Molecular Devices in Deal
abstract: Molecular Devices Corp agrees to buy Axon Instruments (S)

headline: Report Shows Consumers Are Optimistic
abstract: University of Michigan's preliminary measure of consumer sentiment rose to 103.2 in January from 92.6 in December; Federal Reserve says December factory production rose 0.3 percent, fourth monthly gain, while total industrial production rose 0.1 percent; Commerce Department says inventories rose 0.3 percent, while sales rose 0.5 percent; inventory-to-sales ratio held at 1.35 months, lowest on record; graph (M)

headline: FreeMarkets Agrees to Buy Auction Unit of Covisint
abstract: FreeMarkets, which makes Internet-auction software, is buying auto parts auction business of Covisint, venture of General Motors, Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler (S)

headline: Achieving Balance in Body, Soul and Trigger Finger
abstract: Charles Herold Game Theory column reviews The Journey to the Wild Divine: The Passage, by The Wild Divine Project, Time Crisis 3, by Namco and Karaoke Revolution, developed by Harmonix, by Konami Digital Entertainment; photo (L)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Its Taste Was Worse Than Its Bite
abstract: British environmental officials report four-inch red-bellied piranha was been found dead on deck of boat moored on Thames River; London Aquarium curator Paul Hale suggests private aquarium owner released fish that was then picked up by sea gull, who spit out fish; Thames is too cold for Amazonian species of fish like piranha; photo (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Cargill and IMC Global To Combine Fertilizer Units
abstract: Cargill will merge its fertilizer business with IMC Global, to create one of world's largest fertilizer companies; Cargill will control two-thirds of new company, and shareholders of IMC will have stock in other third, assuming deal gets shareholder and regulatory approval (M)

headline: With Health System in Tatters, Zimbabwe Stands Defenseless
abstract: Health care in Zimbabwe, like rest of country's economic and social fabric, is dissolving; three years of economic free fall and inflation, now averaging 620 percent a year, have left country desperately short of even basic drugs and medical equipment, and pushed once robust network of hospitals and hundreds of rural clinics close to ruin; experts say decay portends potentially far more serious problems, including outbreaks of infectious diseases that spread when preventive measures are poor, and deadly childhood epidemics which exist only when public health defenses are down; country once had one of best public health systems in sub-Saharan Africa; Zimbabwe's government does not discuss details of its public health problems and bars medical professionals from speaking to media; nevertheless, national medical association stated last month that 40 percent of doctors have left Harare and 60 percent have left Bulawayo, moving to other countries; United Nations-financed study finds fewer than 900 doctors remain in nation of 11.6 million people; photos; map (M)

headline: Rules to Strengthen Vehicle Roofs Are Weighed
abstract: Congess and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration are weighing separate proposals to bolster minimum requirements for strength of roofs of cars and trucks; roof strength has become increasingly scrutinized issue because of increase in deaths, now more than 10,000 annually, related to rollover accidents, which have risen because of booming sales of sport utility vehicles; dozens of models of heaviest sport utility vehicles are exempt from any roof strength regulations because rules were developed long before truck boom; House Energy and Commerce Committee members are exected to scrutinize more than dozen new auto safety regulations backed by Sen John McCain that are part of $318 billion highway financing bill (M)

headline: Gamer's Death Blow
abstract: Deborah Gedney letter suggests alternatives to forcing game characters who 'die' to leave game (March 4 article)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Bank's Profit Rises
abstract: Spain's Santander Central Hispano earned 2.6 billion euros ($3.24 billion) last year, increase of 16.2 percent, despite decline of nearly 15 percent in net interest income; chairman Emilio Botin comments; photo (S)

headline: Aristide Presence in Jamaica Will Harm Haiti, U.S. Warns
abstract: United Syates ambassador to Haiti, James B Foley, warns that exiled Haitian Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide's presence in Jamaica could destabilize Haiti; Aristide still has large following among Haitian poor, many of whom believe US forced Aristide out; Haiti's new Prime Min Gerard Latortue is negotiating with Jamaican Prime Min P J Patterson to limit Aristide's stay in Jamaica; Jamaica has made clear its intentions to cooperate with new government in Haiti (M)

headline: The East Joins the Low-Fare Bazaar
abstract: thØ

headline: Israel and Libya Discussed Ties at Meeting
abstract: Israeli officials report secret talks in December with Libyan officials on possibility of establishing relations, at time when Col Muammar el-Qaddafi is trying to end Libya's diplomatic isolation; separately, Israeli forces kill three Palestinian gunmen in West Bank (M)

headline: S.E.C. Investigating Shell's Restatement of Oil and Gas Reserves
abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell says Securities and Exchange Commissin has begun formal probe into company's surprise restatement of its oil and natural gas reserves in January; development raises pressure on Shell's chairman Sir Philip Watts, who has been sharply criticized for way company handled reclassification; Shell announced on Jan 9 that it had overstated its proven oil and gas reserves by 20 percent, or 3.9 million barrels (M)

headline: Tighter Gas Supply Is Expected to Send Prices Even Higher
abstract: Fear of disruption in oil supplies and stricter environmental regulations are expected to push retail gasoline prices at gas pump even higher than at present this spring and summer; Energy Information Administration says that gasoline supplies declined by 800,000 barrels last month, to 5 percent below five-year running average; that lifts price of next month's gasoline futures contract on New York Mercantile Exchange nearly 3 percent; crude oil increases nearly 2 percent, to a 13-year high; map shows states that require specially formulated gasoline; graphs show gasoline supply and prices; photos (L)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Volvo Sells Shares In Rival
abstract: Volvo sells 63.7 million Class B shú

headline: G.I.'s May Be Targets of Kidnappers and Rebels Posing as Policemen
abstract: US military officers warn that troops arriving in Iraq are being singled out for kidnapping by insurgents who may use them as symbols or to win release of Iraqi prisoners; also warn of new tactic of posing as police officers; security reminders for newly arrived soldiers quoted (M)

headline: Massachusetts Sues Brokerage Firm
abstract: William F Galvin, Massachusetts secretary of commonwealth, files civil complaint against Cantella Securities Inc, contending it did not supervise James Pangione and Timothy Rassias, brokres accused of selling unregistered hedge funds to unqualified buyers; says 41 individual investors lost almost all of $3.5 million they invested in hedge funds created by brokers, who are no longer with firm (S)

headline: Judge Closes Doors on Selection of Stewart Jury
abstract: Judge Miriam Goldman Cedarbaum, citing possible 'chilling effect' on criminal trial of Martha Stewart and her former stockbroker, issues unusual order barring reporters, courtroom artists and others from attending sessions at which prospective jurors would be questioned by lawyers for both sides (S)

headline: Bush Team Revising Plans for Granting Self-Rule to Iraqis
abstract: Bush administration is revising its proposed process for handing over power to interim Iraqi government by June 30, in effort to overcome new resistance on political and security fronts there; urgent meetings are held in Washington and Baghdad in wake of Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani's rejection of administration's complex plans to hold caucuses around country to select interim legislature and executive in newly self-governing Iraq; administration officials also express concern about separate part of Sistani's statement that demanded that any agreement for American-led forces to remain in Iraq be approved by directly elected representatives; twin setbacks raise questions about who would have to reach agreement with US that would allow more than 100,000 American troops to remain in country after power is handed over to Iraqis this summer (M)

headline: MORE ON IRAQ
abstract: PROTEST MARCHES -- Demonstrators in Manhattan and cities around the world protested the Iraq occupation.   PAGE 27

headline: Italians find the shoe fits in Britain
abstract: LONDON—  With a favorable British pound and a new wave of independent British fashion retailers choosing quality rather then quantity, things are looking up for Italian accessory designers wanting to boost sales in Britain.

headline: In Post-U.S.S.R. Russia, Any Job Is a Good Job
abstract: Conditions at Apatit fertilizer factory in Arctic town of Kirovsk, Russia, reflect disruptions caused by post-Soviet society's tumultuous encounter with capitalism; few of Apatit's 14,000 workers want to stay, but even fewer have better options; production at factory lags far behind levels during Soviet era; Apatit is owned by jailed tycoon Mikhail B Khodorkovsky, who is charged with defaulting on payment in his 1994 acquisition of company, among other things; Khodorkovsky's defense points to massive capital investment in Apatit; photo (M)

headline: Halliburton Will Repay U.S. Excess Charges for Troops' Meals
abstract: Pentagon says Halliburton Co will repay government for estimated $27.4 million in overcharges for meals served by its Kellogg Brown & Root unit to American troops at five military bases in Iraq and Kuwait in 2003; says its auditors are reviewing 53 other dining facilities in Kuwait and Iraq run by unit; Halliburton does not admit wrongdoing; says auditors question way unit estimates number of meals it serves; unit says it has agreed to cut future bills to make up for any overcharges (M)

headline: Catholicism Meets Jewish Orthodoxy in Exchange of Ideas
abstract: In a study hall filled with the hubbub of Talmudic debate, the men wearing scarlet sashes, crimson skullcaps and large crosses made their way between tables, sometimes sitting to chat with the young scholars, sometimes marveling at the intensity of study.

headline: Pakistan Asks Tribes to Seek Surrender by Qaeda Fighters
abstract: Pakistani military turns to tribal elders to try to persuade hundreds of Qaeda fighters surrounded in mountainous border region to surrender after five days of fierce fighting and heavy casualties on both sides; military officials are distancing themselves from earlier suggestions that Al Qaeda's second in command Ayman al-Zawahiri could be among cornered fighters; photo (M)

headline: The Nuclear Market: An Array of Vendors
abstract: Analysis of relative threats posed by illicit nuclear weapons programs in Iraq, North Korea, Iran, Libya and Pakistan finds Iraq, against which Pres Bush acted first and most decisively, posed smaller proliferation risk than other countries; notes even some of Bush administration intelligence experts now acknowledge that other countries' programs are more advanced than Iraq's and consequently pose greater threat of passing technology to terrorists; Pres Bush still defends invasion of Iraq given uncertainty about country's weapons programs; photo (M)

headline: Your Taxes; Form 6251: Alternative Minimum Tax
abstract: Step-by-ste

headline: China Grants an Early Release of Tibetan Nun
abstract: The nun had been a political prisoner for more than 14 years and had become known as one of the "singing nuns" of Drapchi Prison in Tibet.

headline: Palm's Marriage Of Convenience To Handspring Shows Promise
abstract: Palm's acquisition of rival Handspring, completed in October, has helped Palm, renamed PalmOne, move its product line away from calculator-sized 'personal digital assistants' and toward so-called smart phones, mobile phones that have appointment calendars and address books of PDA's but also advanced functions like ability to run spreadsheets, connect to corporate databases, access e-mail messages, download music and take photographs; Handspring, which was founded five years ago by former Palm executives who had helped develop PalmPilot, has been pioneer in high-end market for multipurpose handheld devices; photos of Todd Bradley, president of PalmOne, and of Ed Colligan and Kenneth Wirt, with Treo and Tungsten devices that helped develop (L)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Your Web surfing is being interrupted to bring you a paid video commercial. Advertisers think you will stick around.
abstract: Commercials from major marketers that are identical to those seen on television will be shown on dozen Web sites in six-week test that some analysts and online executives say could herald start of new era of Internet advertising; new ad technology invisibly loads commercial while unwitting users read Web page, and then displays ads across entire browser area when users click to new page; evades pop-up blockers, but user can skip ads by clicking a box; Unicast, which developed technology, say move is being made now because high-speed connections have reached significant number; photo (M)

headline: Advocates for Immigrants Scorn Bush Policy on Haitian Refugees
abstract: More than two dozen Democrats in Congress and advocates for immigrants assail Bush administration for continuing to return Haitian refugees to country in turmoil, saying access to American asylum process is being denied; number of Haitians fleeing by sea is surging, and Coast Guard says 695 refugees have been picked up this month; government officials say they plan to continue deportations, holding overwhelming majority are fleeing poverty, not political repression; chart show number of Haitians intercepted at sea annually since 1982 (M)

headline: Irving Crespi, 77, Poll Expert Long Associated With Gallup
abstract: Dr Irving Crespi, public opinion pollster, professor and market researcher long associated with The Gallup Organization and author of books on polling, public opinion and democracy, dies at age 77 (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Yahoo Makes Deal With Rogers Cable
abstract: Yahoo to take its high-speed broadband service to Canada in deal with Rogers Cable, largest cable television system in country; terms of agreement undisclosed (S)

headline: MOODY'S RAISES TWO DEBT RATINGS OF YUM BRANDS
abstract: Moody's Investors Service raises ratings on $2.1 billion of debt of Yum Brands Inc, operator of Taco Bell, KFC and Pizza Hut restaurants (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Insurer Reports Profit
abstract: French insurance company AXA says net income increased 6 percent in 2003 to 1 billion euros ($1.24 billion), while operating profit rose 21 percent to 2 billion euros ($2.5 billion); chief executive Henri de Castries comments (S)/

headline: Polo-Related Costs Cut Jones's Profit
abstract: Jones Apparel Group says fourth-quarter profit fell 19 percent because of costs to end licensing accord with Polo Ralph Lauren; net income declined to $41.8 million from $51.6 million year earlier; sales rose 1.6 percent, to $980.1 million from $964.5 million (S)

headline: Your Message Here
abstract: Article discusses Google bombing, a group sport taking advantage of Web-indexing algorithms used by Google; perpetrators recruit accomplices to link from their Web sites to target site using specific anchor text; Web sites noted; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: AFGHANISTAN: Judges Protest Female Singers; THAILAND: Leaders Concede Separatist Activity;.

headline: Greenspan Warns Congress Not to Create Trade Barriers
abstract: Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan enters political battle over jobs and trade by warning Congress not to create trade barriers; Greenspan aligns himself with Pres Bush on day when Bush continues to spar over trade and jobs with Sen John Kerry, presumptive Democratic presidential nominee; disagrees with Kerry's proposal to link free-trade agreements with commitments by other countries to enforce tougher protections for workers and environment; Kerry has vowed to subject trade treaties to immediate 120-day review if he is elected president; Sen Charles Schumer says Greenspan is ignoring need to fight unfair trade practices by China and other countries (M)

headline: Auto-Parts Retailer Posts 16% Increase in Profit
abstract: AutoZone Inc., the retailer of auto parts, said yesterday that second-quarter earnings rose 16 percent, helped by sales to garages.     Net income increased to $91.7 million, or $1.04 a share, in the quarter ended Feb. 14, from $79.3 million, or 79 cents a share, a year earlier.

headline: Slide Shows That Dazzle On HDTV
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column reviews Roku HD1000 that displays slide show on high definition television monitor; sources include photos stored on memory stick or home network or images purchased from Roku; photo; drawing (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Kashmir Separatists Asked To Talks
abstract: Indian Deputy Prime Minister Lal Krishna Advani plans to meet with All Parties Hurriyat Conference, Kashmir separatist coalition, leaders in New Delhi; meeting is first such gathering in 15-year insurgency (S)

headline: Hussein's Regime Skimmed Billions From Aid Program
abstract: Saddam Hussein's government systematically extracted billions of dollars in kickbacks from companies participating in United Nations program under which Iraq was permitted to sell oil to buy food and other relief goods; Taha Yassin Ramadan, vice president in August 2000, informed government ministers to tell companies involved in program to inflate their contracts 'by biggest percentage possible' and secretly transfer those amounts to Iraq's bank accounts in Jordan and United Arab Emirates; sanction-busting has long been open secret, but dimensions of corruption have only lately become clear; Iraqi Provisional Government has reviewed $8.7 billion in outstanding oil-for-food contracts and found that 70 pecent of suppliers had inflated their prices and agreed to pay 10 percent kickback; some companies balked at demands, but most accepted suggestion that they find trading company -- usually Russian or Arab -- to act as intermediary, deal with Iraq and make required kickback; Hussein also bestowed contracts and gifts on those who praised him, with frequent result that Iraq received shoddy, even useless, goods in return; photos of Iraqi documents (L)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Glaxo Estimates Tax
abstract: Britain's drug maker GlaxoSmithKline says decade-long tax dispute with US might cost it more than $5 billion and that company intends to contest claim; Internal Revenue Service is demanding $2.7 billion in taxes on profit company earned from 1989 to 1996, before merger formed company; Glaxo says it will be responsible for another $2.5 billion in interest if IRS is successful; graph (S)

headline: Technology
abstract: Shares of Gateway fell 12.9 percent on Tuesday after the company said that fourth-quarter sales had fallen more than forecast.

headline: INVESTING WITH: Michael H. Winer; Third Avenue Real Estate Value Fund
abstract: Interview with Third Avenue Real Estate Va

headline: MEDTRONIC SAYS SALES FELL SHORT OF PROJECTIONS
abstract: Medtronic, world's largest maker of devices that regulate heartbeats, says quarterly sales rose less than expected, setting off 9 percent decline in share price; sales in third quarter, ended Jan 23, rise 15 percent, to $2.2 billion (S)

headline: WorldCom Could Be Sued by States for Taxes, Report Says
abstract: WorldCom could be sued for hundreds of millions of dollars in back taxes by states in which it had operated since late 1990's; if WorldCom is forced to make payments to states when it comes out of bankruptcy in February, it has strong case for seeking compensation from KPMG, its tax consultant in 1997 and 1998, for its advice that accounting practices that gave rise to liability were legal; Richard L Thornburgh, whom Judge Arthur J Gonzalez appointed in August 2002 to lead analysis, also concludes that WorldCom has grounds to sue former chief executive Bernard J Ebbers and Salomon Brothers (and its successor Salomon Smith Barney) for damages to company from their dealings with each other; report also concludes that WorldCom could file accounting malpractice, negligence or breach of contract action against Arthur Andersen, which was its outside auditor in years 1999 to 2002 (M)

headline: The Mullah and Democracy
abstract: To counter the threats made by Shiite leader Sistani, the Americans, at a loss, are now turning to the United Nations again. They want the UN to help bring peace to Iraq.

headline: MediaTalk; 2 Donalds and a World of Self-Confidence
abstract: Deutsch advertising agency head Donny Deutsch competes for screen time with Donald J Trump in upcoming episode of reality television program The Apprentice; both have reputations for being supremely assertive and self-confident; they comment; photo (M)

headline: PRIVATE EQUITY FIRM TAKES OVER MAIDENFORM
abstract: Ares Management acquires women's lingerie maker Maidenform (S)

headline: Aristide Says He Was Duped By U.S. Into Leaving Haiti
abstract: Exiled Haitian Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide, in Central African Republic en route to Jamaica, renews charge that US tricked him into fleeing country; United States denies accusation and says Aristide left willingly; Aristide's own lawyer suggests matter is misunderstanding; Aristide's letter of resignation notes his desire to avoid bloodshed in Haiti (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Under Investor Pressure, Disney Picks New Chairman  In a remarkable vote of no confidence against a once unassailable executive, shareholders owning an estimated 43 percent of the Walt Disney Company withheld their support to re-elect Michael D. Eisner, the chairman and chief executive, to the board.    The mounting shareholder dissent prodded the board to strip Mr. Eisner of the chairman's title and give it to George J. Mitchell, Disney's presiding director and a former United States senator. [Page A1.]

headline: Arab Summit Meeting Collapses Over Reforms
abstract: Host nation Tunisia insists on postponing Arab League summit meeting, saying that Arab states are not sufficiently committed to reforms for their 22 foreign ministers to reach any agreement on common goals; some ministers object to words like 'democracy', 'parliament' and 'civil society', others feel it is wrong to emphasize reform when peace process is in disarray, and many are upset that American proposal of blueprint for reforms was leaked before any Arab leader was aware of contents (M)

headline: Before Business School
abstract: Whitney Ransome and Meg Milne Moulton letter on encouraging girls to seek business degrees

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Monetary Tightening
abstract: Bank of Mexico tightens monetary policy for first time in nearly year, citing concerns over rising inflation expectations and wage increases; its inflation target this year is 3 percent (S)

headline: Revlon Announces Deal to Cut Its Debt Load
abstract: Ronald O. Perelman, the majority owner of Revlon, has struck a refinancing deal to help cut the cosmetic giants $1.9 billion debt load almost in half.

headline: New Conductor Guides Data Along the Fiber Optic Route
abstract: Anne Eisenberg What's Next column discusses optical nanowire developed by Harvard University research team; nanowire allows light to flow on the outside of a glass fiber; nanowire could be used for higher speed connections in mulitplexers and sensors; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Profit At Biotech Concern
abstract: Swiss biotechnology company Serono says profit rose 37 percent in fourth quarter, to $111.6 million, from period year earlier; sales rose 17 percent; profit rose 22 percent, to $390 million, for 2003 and sales rose by greater-than-expected 31 percent (S)

headline: Executive Leaving London Unit of WPP
abstract: Lee Daley unexpectedly resigns as co-chief executive and chief strategy officer at WPP Group's Red Cell division; he comments, phone interview; Andy Berlin will be unit's only chief executive (S)

headline: Hague Hearing on West Bank Barrier: A Contest of Bitter Voices
abstract: International Court of Justice to open hearing sought by United Nations General Assembly into legal consequences of planned 450-mile barrier of ditches, watch posts and concrete walls Israel is erecting in and around West Bank; Israel calls barrier defense against suicide bombers and has sent grieving parents and singed shell of bombed bus to Hague hearings; Palestians have sent farmers cut off from their land; Israel holds court has no jurisdiction; United States and European Union have criticized barrier's planned path, but prefer to see diplomatic rather than legal solution; photo (M)

headline: New Officers Chosen for Terms at Four As
abstract: New Officers Chosen.

headline: Belfast Journal; Intolerance in Northern Ireland: Religion, and Now Race
abstract: Belfast, once scene of violence between Catholics and Protestants, is now scene of racism and violence aimed at new immigrants from Asia, India and Pakistan, who have been trickling into city since Good Friday Agreement, looking for jobs; city was 99 percent white as recently as 2001; politicians plan to toughen hate crime laws, and city is busy forming new groups to deal with racism; larger problem is getting laws enforced and people to cooperate; photos (M)

headline: Supreme Court to Review a Tax Dispute Over Judgments
abstract: US Supreme Court grants government's request to review and settle dispute two disputes over Internal Revenue Service rule that financial judgment received in discrimination case is taxable income for both lawyer and client; one case involved man who settled employment discrimination case for $464,000 sum that included fee of $150,000 to his lawyer; IRS contended that entire amount was income to client John W Banks II, position that Tax Court upheld when Banks challenged determination; US Appeals ruled in Banks' favor, holding lawyer's share could be excluded from client's gross income; another case involved Sigitas J Banaitis, vice president of Bank of California, who sued that bank and Mitsubishi Bank for interference with his employment agreement and wrongful discharge; settlement check for $3.9 million went directly to plaintiff's lawyers under contigent fee agreement, while Banaitis received $4.9 million for himself; IRS said entire amount should be counted as gross income to Banaitis, view rejeced by Appeals Court (M)

headline: MediaTalk; Final Novel in Evangelical Christian Series Is a Best Seller Before Going on Sale
abstract: Tyndale House, evangelical Christian publisher of the best-selling Left Behind series of novels, says bookstores have already bought entire initial print run of 1.9 million copies of The Glorious Appearing by Tim LaHaye and Jerry B Jenkins, 12th and last book in series (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Bank's Profit Rises
abstract: ABN Amro Holding reports 43 percent rise in 2003 net income, to 3.16 billion euros ($3.92 billion); photo (S)

headline: One-Stop Shopping Approach to HDTV
abstract: PanAmSat, satellite operator that beams television programming to local cable operators, has switched many of its HDTV channels to new Galaxy XIII satellite, hoping operators will be more likely to offer high-definition programming if they can find programs all in one place; president Joseph R Wright Jr says smaller programmers will want to use satellite in future because of presence of HBO and other programming anchors (M)

headline: Treasury Bills Scheduled For This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and four-week bills on Tuesday. According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 0.92 percent, the rate on the six-month issue was 0.97 percent and the rate on the four-week issue was 0.92 percent.    The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week:

headline: Top General Says U.S. Lags In Aiding Iraqis Under Fire
abstract: Gen Richard B Myers, chairman of Joint Chiefs of Staff, says deadly attack on Iraqi police station in Falluja on Feb 14 revealed problems in American military support for newly trained Iraqi security services; attack has prompted review of how US troops respond when Iraqi forces come under fire; many of Iraqi police officers and militia now operating independently or in tandem with American forces still lack basic equipment, like radios and patrol cars, and some of them have expressed fear that they will be outgunned by supporters of Saddam Hussein if American troops leave prematurely (M)

headline: Hewlett-Packard Is Suing Gateway in a Patent Dispute
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co files lawsuit in patent licensing dispute with Gateway; suit covers six patents for desktop, portable and server computers that had previously been licensed by eMachines, South Korean maker of personal computers that Gateway acquired in January for $266 million (M)

headline: US Airways Presses Its Plea for Pay Cuts
abstract: US Airways chief executive David N Siegel says carrier faces threat to its survival from Southwest Airlines, which is soon to invade its Philadelphia hub, and needs third round of labor contract concessions; says formal contract talks will begin in April; only pilots' union has agreed to open talks; machinists' union reiterates its stand against more wage and benefits cuts (M)

headline: First Boston to Pay Fine Over Stock's Debut
abstract: Credit Suisse First Boston agrees to pay fines of $170,000 and restitution of $606,537 in connection with way it handled hectic first-day trading of hot new offering Mp3.com in 1999; agrees to NASD penalties without admitting or deny wrongdoing; First Boston sold for its own account 331,190 shares of Mp3.com for $100.50 and ignored sell orders it had received from some customers; sell orders were filled later in day, as price declined, at prices of $64.50 to $95 per share; customers who got lower prices will receive reimbursement for price difference (M)

headline: Ready or Not, Here Comes Earnings Season
abstract: Interview with Thomson First Call research analyst Joseph Cooper on outlook for corporate earnings in quarter and rest of year; photo (M)

headline: From Dramatic to Decorous for a Witness
abstract: Douglas Faneuil, prosecution's key witness in Martha Stewart trial involving her sale of ImClone Systems shares, sounds like lawyer in his third day of cross-examination; Faneuil is polite, grave and measured, especially on Feb 9, when he often pauses and seems to weigh his words; photo (M)

headline: Some Iraqi Leaders Now Balk at Giving U.N. a Big Role
abstract: Several members of Iraqi Governing Council raise objections to allowing United Nations to return to Iraq to help it prepare for return of sovereignty on June 30; say they were disappointed by failure of team of UN experts who visited recently to help schedule early elections; about-face prompts concern among American officials (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Puma Doubles Profit
abstract: Puma posts profit of 179 million euros ($222 million) in 2003; sales rose 40 percent, to 1.7 billion euros; Adidas-Salomon reports 14 percent increase in profit, to 260 million euros; sales fell 4 percent, to 6.3 billion euros; graph (S)

headline: Sequel; The IPod's Little Brother Makes a Big Splash
abstract: New iPod Mini has similar options to iPod, but smaller hard disk has less storage and lower price; photo (M)

headline: Factory Orders and Service Index Show Economy Keeps Growing
abstract: Institute for Supply Management says its index for nonmanufacturing businesses jumped to 65.7, highest since survey's inception in July 1997; Commerce Dept reports that orders placed with manufacturers in December rose 1.1 percent; chart shows factory orders (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: New Premier Takes Charge Of Olympics
abstract: Costas Caramanlis, Greek prime minister-elect, appoints himself Culture Ministry head in charge of summer Olympic Games in Athens; photo (S)

headline: Economics Adviser Learns the Principles of Politics
abstract: Council of Economic Advisers chairman N Gregory Mankiw finds himself at center of firestorm on issue of enormous political importance to Bush administration: jobs; drew fire from Republicans and Democrats for saying that outsourcing jobs to foreign countries is another form of free trade that will ultimately be plus for US; had to stand by while Pres Bush and Treasury Sec John W Snow scrambled to distance themselves from forecast by council that nation would add 2.6 million jobs this year; has been lampooned for suggesting that working at McDonald's might constitute form of manufacturing; White House senior official says Mankiw still has Bush's full support; Mankiw is trying to fight off image as both cold-hearted apologist for corporate outsourcing and Ivy League academic who knows too little of real world; photo (M)

headline: Deutsche Bank Chief Calls Pay Law Unfair
abstract: Deutsche Bank chief executive Josef Ackermann, facing breach of trust charges for his role in approving 57 million euros in payments to Mannesmann executives four years ago, says German laws are unfairly punishing business people; says it is crucial that companies are able to pay bonuses based on performance; Ackermann and three other former Mannesmann directors are accused of approving payments to persuade managers to drop objections to Vodafone Group's record 154 billion euro acquisition of company in 2000; Mannesmann's former chief executive Klaus Esser, who received more than quarter of money at issue, and former employee Dietmar Droste are charged as accessories; all defendants deny wrongdoing; photo (M)

headline: Unilever Cuts Its Forecast; A Top Official Is Leaving
abstract: Unilever lowers its forecasts for sales growth as it presents year-end results; net profit was 811 million euros in fourth quarter; sales dropped 4 percent to 11.9 billion euros; net profits were up 38 percent, to 2.94 billion euros; co-chairman Niall FitzGerald will step down in September; Patrick Cescau, who heads company's flagship food division, will succeed him; photo (M)

headline: A Micromanager (or Craftsman) Seeks To Repair Damage at Gruner & Jahr
abstract: Axel Ganz, interim chief executive of Gruner & Jahr USA Publishing, takes over day-to-day control of magazine publishing company that is no bigger or more competitive than it was five years ago, when now-ousted chief executive Daniel B Brewster Jr arrived; he insists parent Bertelsmann remains committed to American market, interview; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Suspected Skinheads Attack Tajik Family
abstract: Gang of reportedly drunken skinheads in St Petersburg (Russia) attacks family from Tajikistan, stabbing 9-year-old girl to death and severely wounding her father and 7-year-old cousin; attackers escape (S)

headline: Swiss to Vote on Sisters Bid to Alter Law on Child Rapists
abstract: If a measure proposed by two sisters passes, Switzerland will be forced to put into effect one of Europes harshest laws on violent criminals and pedophiles.

headline: Belgian Faces Trial at Last In Sex Killings
abstract: Trial of accused pedophile and murderer Marc Dutroux finally begins in Belgium, more than seven years after two terrified girls were rescued from dungeon under terraced house in Charleroi; girls, aged 12 and 14, survived ordeal but four others died in gruesome circumstances; Dutroux had been released from prison in 1992 after serving half of 13-year sentence for multiple rape; two eight-year-old victims were kidnapped three years later in Liege and two teen-agers disappeared two months after that in Ostend; police incompetence in probe recounted (M)

headline: Report Eases Some Fears That Rates Will Rise Soon
abstract: Stocks and bonds rally on January jobs report that offers something for investors in both equities and Treasuries; while government reports addition of 112,000 jobs, increase is less than 175,000 expected, positive for bonds because slower growth means interest rates will rise more slowly; price of 10-year note rises 23/32, to 101 12/32; yield falls to 4.08 percent from 4.17 percent (M)

headline: Tyco Jury Hears Of Ex-Chief's Bills
abstract: Tammy Cross, former secretary at Tyco International who helped manage personal matters for former chief executive L Dennis Kozlowski, tells juror she paid his bills and arranged company loan that he used for $5 million wedding ring; trial resumes for Kozlowski and former chief financial officer Mark H Swartz after two-week hiatus (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Ratings Raised
abstract: Standard & Poor's raises short-term rating on Japan's Shinsei Bank; bank will hold public share offering on Feb 19 (S)

headline: Kodak to Cut Up to 15,000 Jobs in Its Shift to Digital Imaging
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company said today that it was speeding its transition to digital imaging while cutting costs in its film business.

headline: Afghanistans Constitutional Council Adjourns in Disarray
abstract: The constitutional grand council adjourned in disarray, leaving the entire process to draw up a new constitution badly damaged.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Acxiom To Buy Consodata Companies
abstract: Acxiom Corp, which makes software for database management, offers to buy some of Seat Pagine Gialle SpA's Consodata companies for about $37.5 million (30 million euros) in cash to expand in Europe; graph (S)

headline: British Official Cites Good Grounds for Flight Cancellations
abstract: A senior British official defended today the recent cancellations of three commercial flights to Washington and Riyadh.

headline: The Fed Statement on Rates
abstract: Text of statement released by Federal Reserve after Fed's monetary policy panel Federal Open Market Committee decides to leave interest rates unchanged (M)

headline: Albertsons Buying Shaw's, New England Grocery Chain
abstract: Seeking a strategy that skirts the widening influence of Wal-Mart Stores in the grocery business, Albertsons said yesterday that it would spend $2.47 billion to buy the New England-based Shaw's chain of supermarkets from its British parent, J Sainsbury.     The deal, a buyout of the holding company that owns Shaw's using a combination of cash, stock and debt, will give Albertsons a presence for the first time in densely populated New England. It will add 202 stores, bringing its total to about 2,500 stores, and sales will increase to about $42 billion. Sales at Shaw's, which is ranked first or second in revenue in most of its markets, totaled $4.6 billion last year.

headline: Costco Says Profit Was Up in Quarter
abstract: The Costco Wholesale Corporation, the warehouse club chain, said yesterday that second-quarter profit increased 25 percent, helped by surging overseas sales and reduced health care costs.     Net income climbed to $226.8 million, or 48 cents a share, from $182.1 million, or 39 cents, a year earlier, said the company, which is based in Issaquah, Wash.

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: Hewlett To Acquire Trulogica
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co agrees to buy software maker TruLogica for undisclosed price (S)

headline: Kinetic Energy
abstract: The Boss interview with Robert B Goergen on his career as ad executive, venture capitalist and, currently, chief executive of Blythe Inc, candle maker in Greenwich, Conn; photo (S)

headline: Al Qaeda Rebuffs Iraqi Terror Group, U.S. Officials Say
abstract: US officials say Ansar al-Islam, most active terrorist network inside Iraq, appears to be operating mostly apart from Al Qaeda; say US intelligence has picked up signs that Al Qaeda members outside Iraq have refused request from group for help in attacking Shiite Muslims in Iraq; say request was made by Ansar's leader Abu Musab al-Zarqawi and intercepted by US; Bush administration has portrayed Al Qaeda and Ansar as close associates and used link as part of its justification for war against Saddam Hussein's government (M)

headline: POWELL DISPLAYS TOUGH U.S. STANCE TOWARD RUSSIANS
abstract: Sec Colin Powell, in Moscow, criticizes curbs on free elections and news media, as well as military campaign in Chechnya; comments in meeting with Pres Vladimir Putin and in Izvestia are toughest public stance toward Russia to date by Bush administration official; Powell's concerns include arrest of businessman and Putin rival Mikhail Khodorkovsky and seizure of his assets, as well as parliamentary elections in which several parties complained of lack of access to news media; newspaper article markedly increases pressure at time of Democratic criticism but also avoids putting Pres Bush and Putin directly at loggerheads; Izvestia article says Russia has yet to achieve balance of powers and political power is not yet 'fully tethered to law'; Powell, at news conference with Min Igor Ivanov, says he is not trying to interfere with Russian political life (M)

headline: Accounts and People of Note
abstract: Accounts.

headline: U.S. Pizza Makers Accused of Unfair Trade
abstract: Canada is investigating complaint by McCain Foods Ltd that companies in US are selling frozen pizzas with self-rising crust at illegally low prices (S)

headline: China Ponders Interest Rise as Economy Heats Up
abstract: China's central bank is considering increase in interest rates as economy appears to be overheating; producer prices rose 3.5 percent in January from year earlier, up from 3 percent in December and sharp rise from 1.9 percent increase in November; consumer price index rose to annual pace of 3.2 percent in January for second consecutive month; graph; photo (M)

headline: Vodafone Said to Be Preparing a Bid for AT&T Wireless
abstract: Vodafone Group is preparing to make offer worth as much as $35 billion for AT&T Wireless; Vodafone's chief executive Arun Sarin is planning to present company's offer to board members in conference call before deadline for bids Feb 13 (M)

headline: Stocks Jump as Investors Return from Holidays
abstract: Stock prices registered a solid advance today, as investors remained upbeat about the outlook for 2004.

headline: GENERAL DYNAMICS TO BUY MAKER OF SATELLITE PARTS
abstract: General Dynamics Corp acquires Spectrum Astro Inc, maker of satellite components, to gain business in missile defense and space technology (S)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Standard & Poor's predicts US ad spending will increase 7 percent in 2004 from 2003, suppored by increased consumer spending and business growth (S)

headline: CITIGROUP CHOOSES GLOBAL INVESTMENT BANKING CHIEF
abstract: Citigroup Ch

headline: Delta President Leaving to Join Virgin Groups U.S. Project
abstract: Delta Air Lines president Frederick W. Reid said today that he would leave April 1 to join Virgin and oversee its planned American low-fare carrier.

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction: Feb 8 article on mutual fund expenses referred imprecisely to one fund's fees

headline: An Emboldened Investor Class Is Not Likely to Go Away Soon
abstract: Walt Disney Co's chairman and chief executive Michael D Eisner will face emboldened investor class at annual meeting, one armed and ready to challenge managers more sharply than at any time in recent memory; many shareholders appears to believe that in post-Enron era, criticism of companies is warranted, especially on executive pay practices and overly compliant boards; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: ITALY: Red Brigades Guerrillas Seized In Egypt; GERMANY: Rains Tilt U.S.-Flagged Cruise Ship;.

headline: GAP NAMES JEFF JONES HEAD OF MARKETING FOR GAP STORES
abstract: Gap Inc names advertising executive Jeff Jones, head of marketing for its Gap stores, filling post that has been vacant for more than year (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Recording Industry Countersued
abstract: Michele Scimeca of New Jersey, one of hundreds of people accused of copyright infringement by Recording Industry Association of America, countersues big record labels, accusing them of extortion and violations of federal antiracketeering act; suit is one of handful of countersuits; even critics of recording industry view suit as long shot but one worth trying, and as sign that lawyers are working on arguments against recording association (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: Corvis To Buy Focal For $101 Million
abstract: Corvis Corp acquires Focal Communications Corp for $101 million in stock (S)

headline: Low Turnout in Iran May Aid the Hard-Liners
abstract: Disqualification of more than 2,000 liberal candidates for Iran's parliamentary elections splits reform camp into one segmant that will boycott elections and another that will heed appeals by Mohammad Khatami, reformist president, to cast votes for substitute candidates; Khatami's opponents hope that conservatives will predominate among those who are motivated to turn out, and are confident that lack of enthusiasm among reform camp will secure victory for supporters of clerical rule; photo (M)

headline: Increasingly, American-Made Doesn't Mean in the U.S.A.
abstract: Sales from overseas operation of American-controlled companies have continued to grow, generating jobs abroad, but not at home; most American manufacturing companies contend that such moves are essential to keep American industry competitive in global market; Anthony F Raimondo, chief of Behlen Manufacturing, defends setting up production plant in China, but criticism from campaign of Sen John Kerry, who is likely Democratic presidential nominee, cost Raimondo job of assistant secretary of commerce for manufacturing in Bush administration; graphs; photo (M)

headline: Pakistani's Nuclear Earnings: $100 Million
abstract: Bush administration says that clandestine network created by Abdul Qadeer Khan, Pakistani nuclear scientist, netted $100 million for technology sold to Libya alone; high-speed centrifuges and other advanced materiel that Khan marketed to Libya, as well as to other countries, are now stored at Oak Ridge National Laboratory; photo; Energy Sec Spencer Abraham trumpets administration success in getting Muammar el-Qaddafi to disarm; (M)

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: SUDAN: Plane Bombs Chad Side Of Border; UGANDA: War Crimes Inquiry;.

headline: Pakistani Said To Have Given Libya Uranium
abstract: Malaysian investigators report finds that network led by Pakistani nuclear scientist Abdul Qadeer Khan shipped partly enriched uranium directly to Libya aboard Pakistani airplane in 2001, providing fuel stock in addition to designs and technology to make nuclear bomb; provides evidence that businessmen and engineers from Turkey, Germany, Switzerland, Britain, Dubai and Malaysia were closely involved in Libya's clandestine nuclear program; report is based primarily on Malaysian authorities interrogation of B S A Tahir, middleman in Khan's global nuclear trading network; International Atomic Energy Agency report confirms that Libya received shipment in Feb 2001 (M)

headline: Put it on the Tab? Not on This Vacation
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column on Internet sites offering listings of vacation condos and time-share rentals; drawing (M)

headline: Anglicans' former leader angers Muslims with criticism of Islam
abstract: MILAN:—  George Carey, the former archbishop of Canterbury, has incensed Muslims by criticizing Islam for being "associated with violence throughout the world."

headline: Ex-Guantánamo Detainee Charges Beating
abstract: Jamal al-Harith (Udeen), one of five British detainees released from Guantanamo Bay, says he was beaten and humiliated by US military police; four others remain in seclusion (M)

headline: Auto Sales in February
abstract: Chart on auto sales in February

headline: Iran Train Wreck Leaves Hundreds Dead and Injured
abstract: A runaway train carrying a cargo of chemicals and fuel derailed today in Iran, setting off fires and an explosion.

headline: DELAYS AND SPLIT ON IRAQI COUNCIL IMPERIL U.S. PLAN
abstract: Powerful cleric's demand for quick elections is undermining Bush administration's plan for political transition in Iraq, delaying drafting of interim constitution and creating serious new split in Iraqi Governing Council; entire timetable for American transfer of power to Iraqi government by June 30 could be disrupted without interim constitution; divide in Governing Council presents American authorities with new complication in pushing their plan for caucus-style process for selecting transitional national assembly; many Shiite Arab council members support direct elections demanded by Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, while Sunni Arab and Kurdish members say it is impossible to hold them; American officials and reclusive ayatollah say they are counting on United Nations to send team to Iraq to determine whether direct elections are possible, given continuing insurgent war and lack of voter rolls; Secretary General Kofi Annan is expected to announce whether he will send such a team shortly (M)

headline: Officials Trying to End Electoral Turmoil in Venezuela
abstract: The Organization of American States met with electoral officials and opposition leaders to find a solution to the turmoil.

headline: Designing a Clock Radio That Hotel Guests Like
abstract: Article on new user-friendly clock radios designed by SDI Technologies Inc that are being used in some rooms of Hampton Inns, midpriced bran do Hilton Hotels Corp (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Business Confidence Slips
abstract: German Ifo Institute's business confidence index fell to 96.4 in February from 97.5 in January (S)0

headline: Letter About Disney Raises Question About Columnist
abstract: Peter Bart, editor in chief of Variety and one of its columnists, denies that he ever sent Michael Ovitz, former president of Walt Disney Co, an article prior to publication so that Ovitz might correct its tone or content; such a charge is made in letter Michael D Eisner, Disney chairman and chief executive, sent to Ovitz in 1996; letter was released by judge presiding over shareholder lawsuit questioning Ovitz's severance package (M)

headline: Another Painful Issue: On-the-Job Coverage
abstract: Small-business owners say they are straining under workers' compensation premiums, which have risen by average of 50 percent nationwide; one part of problem is growing number of small businesses that evade requirement to carry workers' compensation coverage; their workers can still file claims when injured, but costs are usually passed along to companies with insurance, which pay higher premiums as result (Special section: Small Business) (M)

headline: In Aristide's Words: Plea for Democracy
abstract: Excerpts from interview with Haitian Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide (S)

headline: Stewart Appears at Court for Probation Hearing
abstract: Newly convicted Martha Stewart arrived at a courthouse today to meet with a probation officer, the first step toward her sentencing for lying about a stock sale.

headline: U.S. Negotiating to Release Many Held at Guantánamo
abstract: State Dept official Pierre-Richard Prosper says Bush administration is negotiating release of many of 660 prisoners at Guantanamo Bay naval base to custody of their home governments over next several months (M)

headline: Gauging Reserves: Room for Interpretation
abstract: Recent cuts in estimates of oil and natural gas reserves at Royal Dutch/Shell, El Paso Corp and other energy companies have raised questions about how companies could suddenly have far less potential oil and gas than they initially reported; answer is mixture of imprecise regulations, geological guesswork and corporate culture that go into accounting of such reserves (M)

headline: Brazil's Soaring Space-Age Ambitions Are Shy of Cash and Sapped by Calamity
abstract: Second of three articles on expanding space race in developing world focuses on Brazil's unfulfilled space-age ambitions; country has tried three times to launch satellite on its own rocket; in most recent failure, in Aug, satellite rocket exploded on its launching pad, killing 21 scientists and technicians; that catastrophe provides vivid warning to other developing nations tempted to reach for grand ambitions in space on budgets already stretched thin by earthly needs; critics call such space programs vanity projects for poor nations still struggling to feed themselves; Brazilian officials, like those from India to China, describe their steadily expanding space effort as commercial and strategic necessity, as well as matter of national prestige; photos; map (L)

headline: Iranians Appear to Warm to Easing Tensions With U.S.
abstract: American aid to Iran, granted after the devastating earthquake in the city of Bam, could bring an improvement to the two countries long-frigid relationship.
