headline: For IPod, 6 Flavors Of Flattery
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column reviews iPod and similar portable music players; compares iPod to devices from other manufacturers; features and prices noted; photos; drawing (M)

headline: Time Plans A Magazine To Be Sold At Wal-Marts
abstract: Time Inc to publish magazine All You, which will initially be sold only at Wal-Mart beginning in September; magazine will focus on everyday concerns of American homemakers; will be filled with recipes and how-to articles on topics like crafts, all delivered in generally positive outlook; Isobel Bella Price will serve as editor (M)

headline: Prestige or Pixels?
abstract: In 1994, I was young and in love. I had just proposed to a lovely med student named Jennifer O’Sullivan—and she had accepted.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Nationwide Health Properties Inc., Newport Beach, Calif., a real estate investment trust specializing in health care facilities, said it had agreed to buy as many as 24 assisted-living centers from Emeritus Corp., Seattle, for about $187 million.    Expedia, Bellevue, Wash., the travel booking Web site, said it would purchase Activity World, Maui, a reseller of tours and activities in Hawaii. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Critics Continue Push Against Disney's Eisner
abstract: Roy E Disney and Stanley P Gold, former directors of Walt Disney Co, pursue their campaign to oust chief executive and chairman Michael D Eisner; Disney and Gold, in letter to Disney shareholders, reiterate their call for votes to remove Eisner and cite growing list of public and private investors who have said they do not intend to support Eisner; Ohio Public Employees Retirement System says it will withhold its votes for Eisner at Disney's annual meeting March 3 (M)

headline: Cleric's Sentence Is Reduced by Indonesian Court
abstract: Indonesian Supreme Court reduces prison sentence of Abu Bakar Bashir, suspected spiritual leader of terrorist group Jemaah Islamiyah, on eve of visit by Sec Tom Ridge; US disapproved (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: L'Oréal's Profit Rises
abstract: L'Oreal reports that its net income rose 16.7 percent in 2003, to 1.5 billion euros ($1.2 billion); net operating profit excluding good will and exceptional items rose to 1.7 billion euros ($1.3 billion) (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Network Associates Revises Profit
abstract: Network Associates, maker of McAfee antivirus software, says profit was 3 cents per share higher in 2003 than previously reported because of change in accounting international sales; sales were $936.3 million, not $932.5 million stated initially; graph (S)

headline: Citing Rocket Fire, Israeli Army Raids Gaza, Killing 15
abstract: Israeli Army raid in Gaza City and second raid in southern Gaza Strip ignite some of fiercest fighting in months, leaving 15 Palestinians dead and about 50 injured; Israel says raids are response to sustained Palestinian rocket and mortar fire from Gaza; Prime Min Ariel Sharon said last week that he is considering plans to withdraw most of 7,500 Israeli settlers from Gaza Strip; Palestinians and Israelis had predicted that Israel would step up operations in Gaza before any Israeli withdrawal, so that pullout would not be interpreted as sign of weakness; photos (M)

headline: Does Anybody Really Know What Time It Is? Or Really Care?
abstract: News Watch column discusses clock from ThinkGeek based on binary numbering system; photo (S)

headline: Deep Price Cuts Help Nintendo Climb to No. 2 in Game Sales
abstract: Industry data set for release will show that Nintendo, using deep price cuts to spur holiday sales, squeezed back into second place in United States video game console market behind Sony, edging out Microsoft's Xbox; Nintendo was only console maker to sell more game players in 2003 than in 2002; overall industry sales, including consoles and software, fell 2.9 percent, to $10 billion (M)

headline: Tyco Says It Wants to Stay in Bermuda
abstract: Tyco International advises shareholders to vote against moving company's legal headquarters from Bermuda to US; estimates that move could lower Tyco's total worth by as much as 10 percent, or $5 billion (S)

headline: U.N. Names Canadian Judge and Ex-Prosecutor to Rights Post
abstract: Louise Arbour, Canadian Supreme Court justice who as war crimes prosecutor indicted former Yugoslavia Pres Slobodan Milosevic, is named by Sec Gen Kofi Annan as United Nations high commissioner for human rights; she succeeds Sergio Vieira de Mello, who served as Annan's envoy to Iraq and was one of 22 people killed on Aug 19 when UN office in Baghdad was bombed; Arbour photo (M)

headline: Condé Nast's Florio Plans to Step Down As Chief Executive
abstract: Conde Nast Publications chief executive Steven T Florio will step down in February after 10 years of overseeing publishing company; will be succeeded by Charles H Townsend, chief operating officer of Conde Nast and Advance Magazine Group, which runs back-office functions of all magazine divisions within parent company Advance Publicaitons; chart; photos (M)

headline: PAKISTAN CALLED LIBYANS' SOURCE OF ATOM DESIGN
abstract: Bush administration officials and other Western experts say Libya was able to make major strides in last two years in enriching uranium for use in nuclear weapons because of centrifuge design technology it got from Pakistan; officials emphasize they have no evidence that government of Pres Pervez Musharraf knew about technology transfer to Libya; timing of transfer of centrifuge design from Pakistan calls into question Musharraf's ability to make good on vow he made to Pres Bush shortly after 9/11 terror attacks to rein in Pakistani scientists selling their nuclear expertise around globe; main aid to Libya appears to have come since that time, suggesting that Pakistani scientists ignored Musharraf's explicit warning; senior official in Washington notes Pakistan also aided nuclear programs of North Korea and Iran (M)

headline: Business; The Rising Value Of Play Money
abstract: Article on popularity of Cashflow, $195 board game created by Robert T Kiyosaki, which fans say teaches tools for gaining wealth; photo; groups of players gather for weekly games, with New York area having more than 270 members (M)

headline: Iraqis Receive U.S. Approval Of Constitution
abstract: American officials say administrator L Paul Bremer III will approve temporary Iraqi constitution, which would serve as framework for new state, even though Iraqi leaders have put off many intractable issues; negotiators strike several key compromises, including ones on women's rights and role of Islam, but defer issues like disarming of private militias, composition of interim government and mechanism for elections; Sec Colin Powell and senior Iraqi figuer Adnan Pachachi hail achievement; interim constitution, in force probably until end of 2005, grants broad protections for individuals within federal system, recognizes relative independence of Kurdish judiciary and legislature; designates Islam as official religion and 'primary,' but not 'only' source of law, and guarantees religious freedom; sets nationwide elections by Jan 2005, spells out broad individual freedoms and calls for women to hold at least 25 percent of seats in national assembly; photos of Shiite holiday celebration (M)

headline: Former Insider Seen as Pivotal In Rigas Trial Starting Today
abstract: James R Brown, former vice president for finance for Adelphia Communications, is set to testify against four former Adelphia executives, and his testimony when he pleaded guilty to conspiracy and fraud charges in November 2003 provides preview of what may prove to be most damaging testimony of trial; he testified that he, along with other company principals, falsely characterized company's financial health to investors, analysts and banks; on trial are John J Rigas, Adelphia's former chairman and chief executive, Timothy J Rigas, former top financial officer, Michael J Rigas, former executive vice president for operations, and Michael Mulcahey, former director for internal reporting; photo (M)

headline: 2 More Suspects Arrested in Philippines Antiterror Effort
abstract: The Philippine police said today that they had arrested two more people suspected of belonging to an Islamic extremist group that, according to the government, was plotting large-scale terror attacks.

headline: Misconduct Charges Sully Image of Canadian Police
abstract: The raiding of a reporters home was the latest in a series of episodes that have caused the Canadian police to be accused of abusive practices or corruption.

headline: A Lure to Leap Time Zones; As foreign phone carriers eye U.S., questions about potential for profit
abstract: Vodafone of Britain or NTT DoCoMo of Japan could well become wireless carrier of choice for frequent international business travelers if either were to acquire AT&T Wireless, creating globe-girdling cellular network, but it is uncertain whether there are enough such customers to justify $30 billion cost; two major factors propelling prospect of overseas bid for company are falling dollar, which makes it less expensive for foreign buyer to acquire American operations, and fact that European and Asian wireless markets are more saturated than American market; some expert also look forward to big growth in US in use of phones to transmit data, which is more lucative than voice (M)

headline: A Web Refugee Turns to Music And Says, 'Give the Lid a Spin'
abstract: Jeffrey T Arnold and his LidRock have reached deal with major record companies to place music CD's in lids of cups of plastic soda cups sold in movies, fast-food chains and sporting events; companies plainly view lids as vehicle for selling records, not merely promotional tool; some artists have declined to have their songs placed in lids and there are some questions about pricing; majority of artists involved get some compensation, but each deal is structured differently; Arnold's career noted; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Airline Grows
abstract: Ireland's Ryanan

headline: Correction
abstract: An article on Feb. 22 about new road tests of sport utility vehicles misstated results of a study of accident deaths in 2000 and 2001 carried out by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. For every million registered vehicles, there were 18 percent fewer deaths - not 22 percent - in the safest category of cars than in the safest category of S.U.V.s and pickups. (A decade earlier, that difference was 25 percent.).

headline: An Extra Eye in Combat, and Maybe Aboard Airplanes
abstract: A new video surveillance system has captured the interest of military authorities after its successful use in the Iraq war. The Pentagon has ordered tests of more advanced versions for use in unmanned tanks and reconnaissance planes, encouraging the inventor, a small Scottish company, to pursue other security applications, both military and civilian.    The technology, an encoding device and software developed by Essential Viewing in Glasgow, compresses video data and sends it with virtually no delay over just about any communication network, even low-capacity military radio systems. Its use in Iraq allowed commanders far from the action to see what their troops and special forces in the field were seeing.

headline: Shareholders In Yukos Oil May Yield To Kremlin
abstract: Major shareholders in Russian oil giant Yukos offer to cede control of company in exchange for release of former chief executive Mikhail B Khodorkovsky, who was arrested last October on charges including tax evasion and fraud; prosecutors dismiss offer, which also calls for freeing Platon Lebedev and Aleksei Pichugin of Yukos (M)

headline: China Studies Complaint On Computer Chip Taxes
abstract: Lawyers and analysts in China say China might be ill prepared to take on fight against US before World Trade Organization over way it taxes computer chips; US files case against China at WTO, demanding it stop taxing imported chips at higher rates than domestically produced chips; Chinese trade officials and semiconductor industry representatives respond with mixture of caution and indignation (M)

headline: Drug Discount for Elderly May Confuse as Well as Help
abstract: Consumer advocates warn that millions of elderly Americans will face a bewildering array of new government-approved drug discount cards this spring, and Bush administration officials acknowledge that major effort will be needed to clear up confusion; administration officials say that 106 health industry companies--unexpectedly large number--met deadline last week for applying to sponsor new cards; cards will be available to 10 million Medicare beneficiaries who do not have drug coverage, as precursor to prescription drug benefit scheduled to begin in 2006; photos (L)

headline: Car Talk Site Switching Software Allegiance
abstract: Web site for Car Talk, Tom and Ray Magliozzi's radio show, is switching software that online listeners use from version made by RealNetworks to one by Microsoft, reportedly in response to large number of complaints from people who have had trouble trying to download free RealPlayer software necessary to listen to program on Internet (M)

headline: S.E.C. LOOKS INTO FIRING OF TWO BOEING EMPLOYEES
abstract: Boeing Co says Securities and Exchange Commission probes events leading to firing of chief financial officer Michael Sears and Darleen Druyun, former Air Force official he had hired; says Pentagon probes whether Druyun helped Boeing get favorable terms on $17 billion deal to sell or lease refueling planes to Air Force; says Sears offered Druyun job while she was negotiating for Air Force; reports it could face $310 charge if government withdraws $5.3 billion contract to lease refueling tankers (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: RUTH'S CHRIS STEAK HOUSE INC., New Orleans, said it had appointed Craig S. Miller to the position of president and chief executive.    WARBURG PINCUS, New York, the investment firm, said it had agreed to buy a minority stake in ScanSoft Inc., Peabody, Mass., a maker of speech and imaging software, from Xerox Corp., Stamford, Conn., the maker of office equipment, for $80 million.

headline: Spain Sentences Imam for Book Offering Advice on Wife-Beating
abstract: Barcelona court sentences Muslim imam Mohamed Kamal Mustafa to 15 months in prison for book advising men on how to beat their wives without leaving scars (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Parmalat Meets With Creditors
abstract: Enrico Bondi, the administrator of Parmalat, left, held his first meeting with creditors to outline a plan to save the insolvent food company from liquidation. The plan, first made public last week, calls for asset sales outside of Italy and the conversion of most of Parmalat's $18 billion in bonds and bank debt into shares. The asset sales would cut Parmalat's work force in half, to about 17,000 employees, according to the chairman of the consumer group Adoc, Carlo Pileri, who attended the meeting in Milan with Mr. Bondi. A final version of the plan is subject to approval by Parmalat's creditors.   Eric Sylvers (NYT)

headline: Carnage Yields Conflicting Clues As Officials Search for Culprits
abstract: Flood of conflicting evidence emerging from carnage of Madrid train bombings points in very different directions, either at ETA Basque separatists or at Islamic terrorism, given that Osama bin Laden has named Spain as Al Qaeda target; ETA has used same explosive and is believed to have planned major attack before Spanish elections, but senior official wonders if ETA would wantonly kill so many innocents, most of them working people to whom ETA has appealed; scale of carnage, at least 192 dead, is also 'off the charts' for group; photo; chronology of deadly terrorist attacks in Europe over last 30 years (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Employment Rises
abstract: Canada's employment rose in December for fourth consecutive month, pushing jobless rate down to 7.4 percent from 7.5 percent in November; Canadian dollar rises to slightly more than 78 US cents, highest level in more than decade (S)

headline: OPEC Plans Million-Barrel Cut in Output
abstract: OPEC seeks to strengthen its grip on world oil markets with announcement of cuts in production, aggressively displaying its desire to maintain oil prices at their highest sustained level in two decades; prices rise in response, up more than 3 percent in New York, to $33.87 per barrel; formal reduction in output by OPEC, intended to withdraw one million barrels of crude oil per day from market beginning in April, would lower group's objective to 23.5 million barrels per day; OPEC members also call for stricter adherence to their own quotas in effort to reduce overproduction by further 1.5 million barrels per day; graphs; photo (M)

headline: Unemployed Iraqis Say New Jobs Will Pay Off in Greater Security for All
abstract: Economic recovery and security are inextricably linked in Iraq; recent poll of Iraqis in six cities found 98 percent say job creation would be 'very effective' in improving security, but investment that could produce new jobs is not likely amid current violence and chaos, and unemployment rate is estimated at 22 percent to 30 percent; United States will direct half of $18.7 billion reconstruction funding to local employers rather than foreign contractors, creating up to one million jobs over next few years; photo (M)

headline: In Big Deals, Know Your Role And Your Limits
abstract: Small companies can thrive by building relationships with big ones, but they are more frequently relegated to commercial limbo when such relationships fail to develop; experts offer advice on how small businesses should deal with big ones; cartoon (Special section: Small Business)

headline: Compressed Data; Legendary Voice for Hire. No Live Gigs.
abstract: Tag lines recorded by Ernie Anderson, late television and radio announcer, may be licensed by radio stations (S)

headline: On the Witness Stand, Friendships Can Also Face a Trial
abstract: Theme of friendship features prominently in Martha Stewart trial as Mariana Pasternak, friend of Stewart's, testifies against her for second day and two friends of Douglas Faneuil boster his testimony against Stewart and her co-defendant, Peter E Bacanovic; Pasternak, under cross-examination by Stewart's attorney, confesses to memory problems that might help Stewart's case (M)

headline: Do Falling Interest Rates Cause Investors to Take Dangerous Risks?
abstract: Floyd Norris comment on whether falling interest rates will cause investors to take dangerous risks in wake of International Monetary Fund decision to force Argentina to promise to negotiate its credit that is backed by private investors, not banks; graph (M)

headline: Pension Fund And Proxy Firm Join Critics Of Disney Chief
abstract: California Public Employees' Retirement System will withhold its votes for Walt Disney Co's chief executive Michael D Eisner, saying it has lost complete confidence in Eisner's strategic vision and leadership in creating shareholder value in company; proxy adviser Glass, Lewis & Co issues no-confidence vote for Eisner and urges shareholders to withhold votes for him; news comes day after court documents are unsealed in case in Delaware related to Eisner's firing of Michael Ovitz, former Hollywood agent who received $140 million in severance package after he was ousted as president in December 1996; documents include report that suggests that Disney's board did not properly oversee hiring and firing of Ovitz; Eisner, in letter to Ovitz, details why Ovitz had to leave, including his attempts to hire chef and demands for costly office renovations; Eisner also said Ovitz was preoccupied with controlling news media, including Variety's editor Peter Bart, and objected to paying for all costs of his daughter's bat mitzvah, which was held at House of Blues, where Disney is part owner; photo (M)

headline: Nine Iraqi Policemen Killed by Gunmen South of Baghdad
abstract: The attack followed a spate of bombings in recent months at Iraqi police stations, which have killed scores of police officers.

headline: Tackling the Mystery of the Missing Game
abstract: Charles Herold Game Theory column reviews URU: Ages Beyond Myst, The Black Mirror, Law & Order II: Double or Nothing and Runaway: A Road Adventure; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Disney Gets Debt Extension
abstract: Euro Disney says creditors have given it two more months to renegotiate its loans, providing unprofitable company time to avoid default (S)0

headline: RITE AID REASSIGNS EXECUTIVE BECAUSE OF S.E.C. TALKS
abstract: Rite Aid reassigns chief financial officer Chris Hall because he is in settlement talks with Securities and Exchange Commission over accounting probe at his former employer Ralphs Grocery; Hall is named senior vice president for real estate and planning; is replaced by John T Standley (S)

headline: Visa applications rise as 'dirty politics' drains idealism : Despair drives Philippine exodus
abstract: MANILA:—  A few weeks ago, Lloyd Mendoza applied for a visa at the U.S. Embassy, and he has been eagerly waiting for his application's approval. "I can hardly wait to leave," he said.

headline: Shaken Trust: The Netherlands Rethinks an Offshore Industry
abstract: Host of outside interests, ranging from European Union to FBI, have become increasingly concerned about possible abuse of shell companies in Netherlands and elsewhere for fraud money laundering; alleged fraud at Parmalat SpA raises questions about role that trust industry plays in finances of company that issued some $6 billion in bonds through its shell subsidiaries in Netherlands; bonds are now worthless; no one in Netherlands has been accused of any wrondoing in Parmalat scandal, and Andre Nagelmaker, board member of Association of International Management Services, trade group, bridles at suggestions that his industry bores any responsibility for what sent wrong at company; trust industry in Netherlands is about to be scrutinized as never before; new regulations will take effect on March 1 that government hopes will restore confidence in industry without threatening hundreds of trust office jobs it creates and billions of dollars in taxes it pays to Netherlands; central bank will have formal authority to oversee entire industry (M)

headline: Microsoft and Europeans in Standoff; Restrictions Likely
abstract: Microsoft and European Union regulators have failed in last-ditch talks to agree on an antitrust settlement.

headline: Warner Picks Urban Music Leader to Run North America Unit
abstract: Warner Music Group, recently acquired by private investors, names urban music pioneer Lyor Cohen chairman of United States recorded music (M)

headline: Suit Against Ex-Kmart Officers Is Dismissed
abstract: Judge Paul D Borman dismisses Securities and Exchange Commission suit accusing former Kmart Corp executives Joseph A Hofmeister and Enio A Montini Jr of violating accounting policies at company before its bankruptcy protection filing (S)

headline: Bond Swap By Fidelity Helps Revlon Cut Its Debt
abstract: Ronald O Perelman, financier and majority owner of Revlon Inc, strikes deal with Fidelity Management and Research to help cut his company's $1.9 billion debt almost in half by swapping bonds for company shares; refinancing will reduce debt by $930 million; company reports revenue was $1.3 billion for year, increase of 16 percent over 2002, and net loss narrowed to $154 million from $287 million in 2002; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sprint Profit Falls On Wireless Unit Loss
abstract: Sprint Corp says fourth-quarter net income fell 2.6 percent; net income dropped to $38 million from $39 million year earlier; sales rose 2.1 percent, to $6.68 billion, from $6.54 billion (S)

headline: US Airways Is Granted Revised Terms for Loan Guarantee
abstract: Air Transportation Stabilization Board amends terms of $900 million in loan guarantees to US Airways, saving airline from defaulting on its agreements; carrier would have immediately been in default of original terms of its loan guarantees because of dire assessment by its auditors KPMG that airline's future is in question; loan guarantees provide basis of airline's $1 billion restructuring plan, which was completed in April 2003 (M)

headline: A Greenberg, 3rd in Family, To Be Chief Of an Insurer
abstract: Evan Greenberg is named chief executive of his Bermuda-based insurer Ace Ltd, succeeding Brian Duperreault, who will remain chairman; Evan Greenberg becomes third member of his family to head insurance company; his brother Jeffrey is chief executive of Marsh McLennan & Cos and his father Maurice runs American International Group; photo (M)

headline: Delta President Leaving to Join Virgin Groups U.S. Project
abstract: Delta Air Lines president Frederick W. Reid said today that he would leave April 1 to join Virgin and oversee its planned American low-fare carrier.

headline: Profit Rises at DSP Group
abstract: DSP Group Inc says profit rose to $5.5 million to $6 million in fourth quarter from $3.6 million year earlier; revenue was $38 million (S)

headline: Editors' Note
abstract: Editors' Note: Feb 1 article on coming battle between Google and Microsoft over Internet search business should have noted that Nancy Blachman, computer scientist quoted, is married to Google software engineer

headline: More Tactics Than Theatrics at the Stewart Trial
abstract: Douglas Faneuil, former broker's assistant who is government's main witness in trial of Martha Stewart and her stockbroker Peter E Bacanovic, says he never formally conspired with Stewart and Bacanovic to commit crimes or conceal them from investigators; cross-examination of Faneuil by Stewart's lawyer Robert G Morvillo lays foundation for argument that Faneuil simply could not know or did not remember whether Stewart engaged in any cover-up; Faneuil does not budge from claim that he went along with cover-up of reasons for Stewart's stock trade because he felt intimidated by Bacanovic; lawyers assessing Faneuil's four days of testimony say it hurt Bacanovic, Faneuil's former boss, more than it hurt Stewart; photo (M)

headline: If Only for a Night, Wall St. Fallen Idol Is One of the Boys
abstract: Richard Grasso, former head of New York Stock Exchange, mixes with old friends at annual black-tie dinner of Kappa Beta Phi, secretive Wall Street society which claims more than 250 of Wall St's executives and former chiefs; sole purpose of society is to allow some of biggest egos in finance to poke fun at themselves and to induct new members in campy rite dating back to 1929; among inductees is Diana L Taylor, New York State banking superintendent and companion of Mayor Michael Bloomberg; new members perform skit lampooning Wall St's many scandals in past year and sing series of songs poking fun at Grasso's pay before he was forced off New York Stock Exchange; photos (M)

headline: Investing; China's Web Portals Open a Door to Risk
abstract: Outlook for investing in soaring Nasdaq-listed shares of Chinese Internet portals discussed; some analysts warn shares are likely to fall sharply, much as American Internet stocks did in 2000; investors celebrating rapid growth in number of Chinese Internet users drown out such warnings for now; stock price graph; photo (M)

headline: GROWTH IN JOBS IS STILL SLUGGISH DESPITE FORECAST
abstract: Job creation all but stalled in February, surprising Wall Street forecasters and giving Democrats economic ammunition to use against Pres Bush as he begins his re-election campaign; Labor Dept reports that economy added just 21,000 jobs, down sharply from Jan's increase and far below gains that were common in 1980's and 1990's; unemployment rate held steady at 5.6 percent, mostly because many people have stopped looking for work since late last year, removing them from government's official count of jobless; economists say that at no other point since World War II has economy grown for such long period without adding jobs at healthy pace; graphs (M)

headline: Talking Loudly but Carrying a Small Stick in Paris
abstract: Analysis of Sanofi-Synthelabo's takeover bid for Aventis focuses on French government's support of merger; says government's backing would have signified powerful political muscle lined up to assure deal would go through for most of France's modern history, but it may add up to little more than verbal posturing; says even though Aventis estimates takeover by Sanofi-Synthelabo could result in elimination of 10,000 to 12,000 jobs, many of them in France, French government is in favor of combining two companies; French Prime Min Jean-Pierre Raffarin has told French entrepreneurs that it is very important in France, but also in Europe, to have capacity to maintain few big champions per sector, world champions who are able to lift whole economy of small corporations behind them; photos (M)

headline: Executive Life; Putting a Formal Stamp on Mentoring
abstract: Dell co6

headline: Kennedy Gives Bush Stinging Rebuke on War
abstract: Sen Edward M Kennedy, in speech to Council on Foreign Relations, delivers blistering indictment of Pres Bush's decision to go to war in Iraq; accuses Bush of deliberately exaggerating threat posed by Saddam Hussein's government; says CIA dir George J Tenet failed to correct statements by Bush that described Iraqi threat as 'urgent' and 'grave'; Rep Jane Harman, in speech at American Enterprise Institute, accuses Bush administration of remaining in 'deep state of denial' about flaws in country's intelligence system; Kennedy photo (M)

headline: Gauging Performance Of Hedge Funds
abstract: Robert Schulman letter comments on Nov 30 column on hedge fund performance

headline: 2 American Civilians Killed by Fake Iraqi Policemen
abstract: Two American civilians and Iraqi interpreter are killed by terrorists posing as Iraqi police officers; three were traveling to Baghdad from work in Karbala; Polish troops later arrest five suspects (M)

headline: Prince Alfonso Hohenlohe-Langenburg, 79; Built Resorts
abstract: Resort developer Prince Alfonso Hohenlohe-Lnagenburg dies at age 79; photo (M)

headline: Optimism on Intel Leads Advance in Technology Shares
abstract: Nasdaq composite index gains 20.31 points, or nearly 1 percent, to 2,077.68; Dow Jones industrial average declines 9.63 points, or nearly 0.1 percent, to close at 10,529.03; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advances 2.66 points, or 0.24 percent, to 1,126.33; US Treasury prices rise; Treasury sells $16 billion in five-year notes, to yield 3.26 percent; price of 10-year note gains 7/32, to 100 2/32; yield falls to 4.24 percent from 4.27 percent; graph; chart (M)d

headline: Venezuelan Ambassador to the U.N. Resigns
abstract: Milos Alcalay said he could no longer support a government he accused of violating democratic principles and human rights.

headline: With Computers, Shop Carefully And by Need
abstract: Small businesses often make mistakes in choosing computer system: buying too little or too much; experts offer advice on what small businesses need in terms of technology; cartoon (Special section: Small Business)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cases Of Infant Death To Be Reopened
abstract: British Court of Appeal states it plans to halt all prosecution of deaths that could have been caused by sudden infant death syndrome and will review past convictions; 258 British adults have been convicted of killing child under age 2 and more than 50 are still in prison (S)

headline: A Few Leftovers
abstract: This column is, after all, called "From the Desk of David Pogue." So by my calculations, that ought to mean that anything on my desk is fair game –- including Post-Its. Herewith, a few scraps I've been saving up, none worth a whole e-column, but worthy items as a group.

headline: Wakkanai Journal; A Cold War Listening Post Tries to Become a Trading Post
abstract: Japan's northern port city of Wakkanai is evolving quickly into modern-day commercial bridge with Russian island of Sakhalin, 100 miles away; ferry cargo from Wakkanai to Sakhalin tripled last summer from previous year; last year Wakkanai was Japan's top port for Russian fishing boats, and Japan's largest overseas construction contracts awarded worldwide were for work in Sakhalin; Japan increasingly sees Russia as ally in dealing with China; photos; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank Sells Unit
abstract: HSBC of Britain sells its US factoring business to CIT Group of Livingston, NJ (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ex-Financial Officer of Tyco Takes the Stand at His Trial  In his first day of testimony in his trial on criminal fraud charges, Mark H. Swartz, left, the former chief financial officer of Tyco International, told jurors that he had never broken the law while at the company.      Meanwhile, lawyers for L. Dennis Kozlowski, Tyco's former chief executive and Mr. Swartz's co-defendant, rested his defense without calling any witnesses. [Page C3.]

headline: The Joyless Recovery
abstract: Continuing erosion of factory jobs in places like Rockford, Ill, underscores fact that current economic resurgence will not lift manufacturing jobs back to pre-slump levels and higher because jobs are going abroad; manufacturers have trimmed 2.8 million jobs over last three years alone, and more than half of those job losses stemmed from structural changes that are likely to be permanent; new jobs will eventually replace the old, and workers' incomes can still rise, but outlook for short and medium term remains grim; Rockford, city synonymous with manufacturing, is reinventing itself to adjust to new economic realities; photos; graphs (L)

headline: U.S. Units of Parmalat Seek Bankruptcy
abstract: Parmalat's dairy subsidiaries in US file for bankruptcy protection, saying they were trying to protect their assets while preparing for possible sale that could help settle parent company's debts; included in filing are Parmalat USA Corp and its Farmland Dairies and Milk Products of Alabama units; Parmalat USA has assets of $414 million and debts of $316.5 million; parent company has $17.8 billion in debt; more than dozen representatives from Securities and Exchange Commission and US Justice Department meet with Italian prosecutors investigating Parmalat; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: CYPRUS: Turkey Pushes New Talks; EUROPE MAY LIFT BAN ON ARMS SALES TO CHINA; RUSSIA: Tycoon Takes A New Name; ITALY: Media Concentration Criticized;.

headline: Aristide's Foes Rule Out Plan To Share Power
abstract: Haitian opposition leaders reject United States proposal for power-sharing deal accepted by Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide, increasing pressure on Bush administration to send security forces to stabilize nation; opposition leader Maurice Lafortune demands Aristide resign; stand surprises Bush administration officials who drafted plan; comes despite plea from State Sec Colin L Powell; plan called for neutral government acceptable to all sides and would have left Aristide in office until his term ends in 2006; Roger F Noriega, State Department's point man for Haiti, faces sharp questioning in closed Congressional session as several senators charge Bush with dithering in face of growing crisis; administration says it is in contact with French and Canadian diplomats; French Min Dominique de Villepin asks European Union to approve funds for peacekeeping force; France invites representatives of Aristide and opposition to Paris for talks; photo (M)

headline: BANKRUPTCY JUDGE REFUSES TO FORCE LIQUIDATION OF FAO
abstract: Judge Joel B Rosenthal, who is overseeing bankruptcy case for toy retailer FAO Inc, refuses to appoint administrator to handle company's liqudidation; orders company to submit plan to pay creditors within 60 days (S)

headline: British Drowning Case Reveals Abuse of Immigrants
abstract: Nineteen Chinese immigrants drown while digging for shellfish on tidal flats of Morecambe Bay in northwest England; local cockle harvesters have complained in recent years that work-gang masters use unlicensed immigrant labor with no regard for safety or welfare; 14 Chinese workers and two Europeans from same work gang are being questioned by authorities, who expect arrests of gang masters soon (M)

headline: Indictments In the Works For Officials At Parmalat
abstract: Italian prosecutors must move quickly to file charges in Parmalat case if they hope to get immediate trial, one that speeds lengthy preliminary hearing stage; deadline is March 19; court documents show that as many as 27 top executives will be charged with manipulating company's stock price, obstructing investigation by Italy's market regulator, and falsifying accounts at its foreign units; among them Parmalat's founder Calisto Tanzi, and three of company's former chief financial officers: Fausto Tonna, Luciano Del Soldato and Alberto Ferraris (M)

headline: Britain Joins Others in Europe In Limiting Immigrant Workers
abstract: Britain joins other Western European countries in announcing new controls on workers from Central Europe whose countries will become members of European Union on May 1; workers from those countries will have to be listed on register and will not be entitled to most benefits until at least 2006; restrictions are not as severe as those set by France and Germany (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Telecom Acquisition
abstract: Indian mobile phone company Idea Cellular acquires mobile operations of Escotel Mobile Communications for $276 million; Escotel Mobile is 49 percent owned by First Pacific Co (S)

headline: Paris Journal; Garçon! The Check, Please, and Wrap Up the Bordelais!
abstract: French government's crackdown on unsafe driving is having sobering effect on wine consumption at restaurants and bars throughout country; one enterprising bistro owner in Paris is offering doggie bags for wine; photos (M)

headline: SHARES PLUNGE FOR VISX, A MAKER OF VISION LASERS
abstract: Visx Inc says first-quarter earnings probably will be less than analysts expected, setting off 23 percent decline in its share price (S)

headline: So You Want to Be a Star? Help for Your Audition Tape
abstract: Official American Idol Audition Kit software includes features and equipment for user to create Web site contest; price noted; photo (S)

headline: Wide search for suspects in bombings is under way : A million mourners march in Madrid
abstract: MADRID:—  Spaniards turned out in huge numbers Friday evening to protest against a synchronized series of explosions on city commuter trains here on Thursday that claimed almost 200 lives.

headline: Sharon May Shift Gaza Strip Settlers to the West Bank
abstract: The prime minister envisions a swap of sorts — giving up most of the Gaza Strip, but holding on to large chunks of the West Bank.

headline: What Cholesterol Studies Mean For Stocks
abstract: Deutsche Bank analyst Barbara A Ryan discusses implications for drug companies of studies on cholesterol drugs; photo; Bristol-Myers, which sponsored study pitting its Pravachol against Pfizer's Lipitor, is losing market share because outcome was more favorable to Lipitor (M)

headline: Mohegan Sun Begins Creative Agency Review
abstract: Mohegun Sø

headline: New Troops Get Ready to Assume Iraq Mission
abstract: A major force rotation involving almost 250,000 American soldiers is underway in Iraq.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Police Release 3 Held In Rail Threats
abstract: French police release two men and one woman detained in connection with AZF blackmail threats against national railway; report three people are not involved with terrorist group (S)

headline: Where's the Innovation In Biotechnology?
abstract: Scott Davidson letter on Feb 29 article holds price controls on drugs discourage innovation by biotechnology and pharmaceutical industry in general

headline: Miscellany
abstract: AT&T, DaimlerChrysler and Samsung Electronics are signed by CNN as sponsors of its yearlong election coverage under 'America Votes 2004' banner; financial terms undisclosed; Media Analysis Plus acquires for undisclosed terms media auditing division of Hawk Media; division will be merged into Media Analysis Plus and will operate under Hawk name; Media Analysis is owned by Cable Audit Associates; Bell Pottinger Commnications, part of Chime Communications, opens US office in Cambridge, Mass (S)

headline: Stewart Trial Focuses On Message From Broker
abstract: Ann E Armstrong, assistant to Martha Stewart, says Stewart sat down at her, Armstrong's, computer month after selling ImClone System shares and deleted part of record of phone message from her stockbroker Peter E Bacanovic after telephone conversation with her lawyer; Armstrong says that within moments of altering message, Stewart asked her to 'put it back the way it was'; Armstrong's testimony supports prosecutors' accusations that Stewart tried to cover up information about her sale of nearly 4,000 shares of ImClone, company founded by her friend Samuel D Waksal, who is serving seven-year sentence for securities fraud and other crimes; Securities and Exchange Commission investigator Helene Glotzer describes interviewing Stewart about her stock trade, citing that phone message in particular; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Democracy Side Step
abstract: Donald Tsang, Hong Kong's second highest government official, reports that Chinese President Hu Jintao has expressed concern over proposed democratic changes for Hong Kong and has conveyed doubts to Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa; officials in Beijing have requested further discussion and Hong Kong committee has been appointed to meet with minland government (S)

headline: Berlusconi Adopts a Low Profile: Are There Other Alterations?
abstract: Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi of Italy has spent month out of spotlight, spawning flurry of rumors that he is staying out of public view while he heals from cosmetic surgery; aides and associates say repeatedly that he is not dealing with any serious health problems, but they refuse to comment on recent newspaper article detailing his alleged visit to Swiss clinic for facelift (M)

headline: Kodak to Reduce Its Work Force by Up to 15,000
abstract: Eastman Kodak Co is speeding its transition to digital imaging while cutting costs in its film business by eliminating up to 15,000 jobs worldwide, more than fifth of its work force; expects changes to save $800 million to $1 billion per year by 2007; digital sales in 2003 totaled $4 billion, 30 percent of Kodak's revenues; chairman-chief executive Daniel A Carp comments; Kodak reports fourth-quarter profit fell 83 percent, to $19 million from $113 million year earlier; sales rose 10 percent, to $3.78 billion, from $3.44 billion year ago; graph; photo (M)

headline: An Iraqi Factory Reflects U.S. Recovery Effort
abstract: Cigarette factory reopens in buildings on edge of Baghdad's Sadr City slum that American marines wrested from snipers; site is used as observation post, but part of compound has been walled off, and factory is producing 300 to 400 cases per day; Coalition Provisional Authority hopes that providing jobs to Iraqis will encourage stability and shift interests from insurgency to economic prosperity; side effect of program is labor unrest as workers strike over unpaid wages and wage disparities; factory is operating well below capacity because spare parts were looted; photo (M)

headline: Suicide Bombers Attack Israeli Port; Talks Called Off
abstract: Two Palestinian suicide bombers blew up moments apart in an industrial port, killing themselves and 10 others.

headline: Recent Slide in Stocks Steepens, With Dow Falling 160
abstract: Shares continue their recent slide as investors seem increasingly worried about weakness in economy and prospects for growth in profits; week's drop has wiped out year's gains for Nasdaq composite index and Dow Jones industrial average, though Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is still up slightly for year; several big investors say stocks, while no longer cheap, are still reasonably valued and that possibility of steep pullback appears slight; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 16.69 points, or 1.5 percent, to 1,123.89; Nasdaq composite index falls 31.01 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,964.15; Dow Jones industrial average declines 160.07 points, or 1.7 percent, to 10,296.89; graph; chart (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Playstation 2 Sales Surpass 70 Million
abstract: Sony Corp says worldwide sales of its PlayStation 2 game console surpassed 70 million, despite year-to-year drop in holiday sales; sold 7.83 milion units worldwide in November and December (S)

headline: South Africa Is Criticized For Delay in AIDS Treatment
abstract: South African government is criticized for not moving swiftly enough on its promise of last November to provide free antiretroviral medication to AIDS victims; has only recently begun to solicit proposal from pharmaceutical companies that supply drugs, pushing back treatment for thousands of patients; critics say delays are symptomatic of lack of political will to confront AIDS in South Africa, which has one of biggest AIDS epidemics in world, with estimated five million people infected with HIV, 12 percent of population (M)

headline: In Blow to U.S. Plans, Top Shiite Demands Direct Elections
abstract: The most influential Shiite cleric in Iraq said today that members of an interim assembly had to be chosen through direct elections. Americans had proposed caucus-style polls.

headline: Iran Chides Critics as Hard-Liners Make Gains
abstract: Iran's religious hard-liners seem poised for sweeping victory in parliamentary elections from which most reform candidates are barred; domestic and foreign critics call vote setback for democracy; voter turnout appears substantial despite boycott called by reformers; various hard-line factions, while split on many issues, are united in their support for absolute rule of Ayatollah Ali Khamenei (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Central Banker's Outlook
abstract: Toshihiko Fukui, Bank of Japan governor, says Japan's economy is gradually recovering, helped by strong capital spending and increasing exports; warns that there is still no end in sight to falling consumer prices (S)

headline: Court Voids Fees From Dairy Farmers
abstract: Federal appeals court rules that fees collected from dairy farmers to finance 'Got Milk' ads are unconstitutional; suit was brought by Institute for Justice, which represented two Pennsylvania dairy farmers; National Dairy Board collects $80 million in fees each year; David Pelzer, spokesman for Dairy Management, organization for 75,000 farmers, says fees willc continue to be collected (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Vodafone Stake Sold
abstract: Spanish building firm Acciona sells its remaining shares in Vodafone Group, raising about 727 million euros (S)

headline: Opening Word Files On a PC With Linux
abstract: Q. Can I open Microsoft Word documents on a Linux computer?    A. While Microsoft does not make a version of its Office suite of business programs (Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Outlook and so on) for the Linux system, there are alternatives. Many of these Linux programs not only can open Word files but are also inexpensive or in some cases free.

headline: People
abstract: Jan Valentic, vice president for global marketing at Ford Motor Co, is leaving to join Young & Rubicam Brands as executive vice president and global client leader; her Ford duties will be realigned under group vice president James O'Connor; Starcom USA names Steven Feuling chief marketing officer and promotes executive vice president John Muszynski to managing director; Rapp Collins Worldwide names Gary VonKennel chairman and chief executive, succeeding Malcolm Speed, who retires (S)

headline: A Deal That Involves Playing With Far More Than a Full Deck
abstract: United States Playing Card Co, maker of playing card brands like Bicyle and Hoyle, is being sold to Jarden Corp for $232 million; photo (M)

headline: British Manager of Jailed Russian Tycoon's Company Dies in Crash
abstract: Stephen Curtis, British lawyer who oversaw business interests of Mikhail B Khodorkovsky, jailed Russian tycoon, dies in helicopter crash in southern England (S)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: BOSNIA: Birthday Warning For Outlaw; DENMARK: Free City To Be Anytown; DENMARK: Ethics Panel Withdraws Critique; IRELAND: Move To Restrict Citizenship Rights; BRITAIN: Prison For Woman, 81;.

headline: Telefónica Seeking BellSouth's Latin Assets
abstract: Spain's Telefonica is in talks to buy Latin American assets of BellSouth Corp for as much as $6 billion (M)

headline: Ex-Directors of Disney Again Urge Eisners Ouster
abstract: Two days before a critical shareholders meeting of Walt Disney, two former directors aggressively pursued their campaign today to oust Michael D. Eisner and three other directors.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Jobless Rate Steady
abstract: Statistics Canada reports that Canada's unemployment rate stood at 7.4 percent in January, unchanged from previous month (S)

headline: 'Liberty or Death' Is a Grim Option for the Local Councils in Iraq's Young Democracy
abstract: Local councils in Iraq continue to meet and caucus to choose representatives for new government, despite on-going attacks from insurgents; there are great dangers in many areas from appearing to cooperate with American occupation, and revenge killings are not uncommon; those who attend caucuses are eager to participate and are resolving disputes pragmatically; councils are vetting former Baath party members among candidates; success is also contingent on losers of elections accepting decision; photo (M)

headline: Productivity Growth Slowed In Last Quarter
abstract: Labor Department reports worker productivity grew in fourth quarter at slowest pace in year, suggesting that companies might increase hiring as economy strengthens; per-hour output of work rose at 2.6 percent annual rate, down from 9.5 percent in third quarter; first-time claims for unemployment insurance fell by 7,000 for week, to 345,000; Commerce Department says factory orders rose 1.4 percent in January after rising 1.9 percent in December; Wal-Mart, Target and other chain retailers say February sales at stores open at least year rose more than expected; graphs (M)

headline: Car of Acclaimed Muslim Appointee Is Bombed in France
abstract: Bomb destroys car of Aissa Dermouche four days after he is appointed France's only foreign-born and Muslim prefect, or department governor; no one takes responsibility for explosion, and there are no injuries reported; Pres Jacques Chirac condemns bombing and Interior Min Nicolas Sarkozy and Prime Min Jean-Pierre Raffarin telephone Dermouche to offer their support; car was parked on street near Dermouche's home in Nantes; Dermouche's recent appointment attracted extraordinary amount of attention because country is embroiled in divisive debate on whether its large immigrant population, particularly its Muslims, could be better integrated into society through affirmative action; photo; map (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.25       Federal Funds   1.00   1.00   1.29       3-month Libor   1.11   1.11   1.27       3-month T-bills   0.93   0.94   1.09       6-month T-bills   0.98   0.99   1.08       10-yr. T-infl.   1.44   1.42   1.94       10-yr. T-note   3.89   3.89   3.81       30-yr. T-bond   4.81   4.81   4.83       Telephone bd.   5.93   5.93   5.90       Municipal bds.   4.62   4.61   4.96          (Sources by Bloomberg News; Telerate; The Bond Buyer; British Bankers' Assoc.)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Profit In Consumer Goods
abstract: Hindustan Lever Ltd says profit rose 3 percent, to 5 billion rupees ($110 million) in fourth quarter; sales rose 2.2 percent; graph (S)

headline: Pakistani Scientist Is Focus Of Atomic Sale Investigation
abstract: Pakistani officials investigating sale of nuclear technology to Iran focus on Abdul Qadeer Khan, father of Pakistan's atomic bomb; set up security to prevent him from leaving country, although government may not have political will to bring charges; nuclear smuggling network is called 'hydra-headed monster' around world, with many large bank accounts said to be controlled by Khan (M)

headline: MediaTalk; After 11 Years, a Quiet Goodbye to Seattle
abstract: Television series Frasier is expected to quietly end 11-season run in May; NBC has been holding back on making final call, apparently hoping for deal for one last season; show's producers have already invited reporters to farewell fete; ratings for costly program have dropped sharply; photo (M)

headline: Aristide Raised Haiti's Hopes, Then Shattered Them
abstract: Jean-Bertand Aristide rose from his priesthood in Haiti's slums to presidency by preaching democracy, only to dash hopes of many who hailed him as champion of oppressed; his last three years as president were made more miserable by increasingly tough opposition of United States, same nation that helped reinstate him decade ago; many who backed him blame Aristide's authoritarianism; his career reviewed; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Middle East
abstract: SAUDI ARABIA: A Human Rights First; SYRIA: Retort To U.S.; ISRAEL: Rabbis Strike; ISRAEL: Spy ChiefS Phone Stolen;.

headline: Protecting the Cellphone User's Right to Hide
abstract: What's Next column discusses Privacy-Conscious Personalization software for cellphones developed by Bell Labs division of Lucent Technologies; users set preferences and can choose to restrict knowledge of their location; drawing (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Premier Reacts
abstract: Sri Lankan Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe, in broadcast on several private television channels, accuses President Chandrika Kumaratunga of jeopardizing Tamil rebel cease-fire and economic recovery; speech is first one by Wickremesinghe since Kumaratunga dissolved Parliament (S)

headline: Gaza Mother, 22, Kills Four Israelis in Suicide Bombing
abstract: Reem al-Reyashi, 22-year-old Palestinian mother of two young children, feigns limp, asks for medical help and then blows herself up at Palestinian workers' checkpoint in Gaza, killing four Israelis and wounding seven other people; Hamas leader Sheik Ahmed Yassin suggests tactical reason for using woman for first time; Israel closes down industrial zone, sending home 4,000 Palestinian workers; woman says in video that wish to 'meet God in paradise' is greater than her love for her children; photo (M)

headline: Sumitomo Will Repay 1999 Loans From Japan
abstract: Sumitomo Trust and Banking Co will repay last of public money that it borrowed in 1999, latest sign that Japan's financial industry is slowly returning to health; will buy back 100 billion yen ($941 million) in preferred shares government bought in 1999 on Jan 13; will then sell shares to 29 companies close to Sumitomo Trust for 138 billion yen ($1.3 billion); Sumitomo on Jan 14 will use cash on hand to repurchase 100 billion yen in subordinated bonds it issued to government, and repay 2.4 billion yen ($22.5 million) in interest (M)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: AFGHANISTAN: Tv Ban On Women Revived; SOUTH KOREA: New Foreign Minister; SOUTH KOREA: Japan Protests Island Stamps; VIETNAM: W.H.O. Reports Bird Flu Death; INDIA: 4 Top Guerrillas Killed In Kashmir;.

headline: COMPANIES LIMIT HEALTH COVERAGE OF MANY RETIREES
abstract: Employers have unleashed new wave of cutbacks in company-paid health benefits for retirees, with growing number of companies requiring retirees to pay full cost to retain coverage; experts expect trend, driven by fast-rising cost of health care, to continue despite billions of dollars government will pay companies that maintain retiree coverage when new Medicare drug benefit begins in two years; companies are not obligated to set aside funds to pay for retirees' health benefits, and health plans can usually be changed or ended at company's choosing; companies that offer retiree benefits typically have subsidized about 60 percent of premium; many companies dropping subsidies push retirees into insurance pools separate from those of younger, healthier workers, cutting company's costs for insuring current workers, while further raising premiums charged retirees; graph of companies offering retiree health care benefits; photo (M)

headline: Personal Business; The Right Résumé for a Bodyguard
abstract: Advice on qualifications to consider in choosing bodyguard (S)r

headline: Freddie And Fannie: Healthy or Overweight?
abstract: Interview with analyst Jonathan E Gray (Sanford C Bernstein & Co) on outlook for home mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac; photo (M)

headline: Cleansing Iraqi Bomb Victims Takes Its Own Toll
abstract: In a large white room where the air was damp from open water faucets and the stunned grief of a few women, Khalila Sharif washed away the bitter past from the body of a 20-year-old schoolteacher from Baghdad.    The young woman's name was Aida Jabber. When suicide bombers detonated their explosives at the Khadamiya mosque in Baghdad on Tuesday, they took with them, among so many people, this woman who was described by her friends and relatives as gentle and devout.

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Name listed of American soldier newly confirmed dead in Iraq; 550 US service members have died there since start of war

headline: Pentagon Opens Criminal Inquiry of Halliburton Pricing
abstract: Pentagon opens criminal fraud investigation of Halliburton on 'potential overpricing' of fuel brought into Iraq by Kuwaiti subcontractor; division is Kellogg Brown & Root (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: EMC Speeds Up Top Machines
abstract: EMC Corp, maker of data-storage computers, doubles speed of its top machines (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Alcatel To Build Iran's First Broadband Network
abstract: France's Alcatel signs deal to build Iran's first private high-speed Internet network; Alcatel, in partnership with Iran's AsreDanesh Afzar, plans to install 100,000 broadband DSL lines over next three years, with 23,000 by May (S)

headline: Cheapening the Dollar
abstract: Analysis: Treasury Sec John W Snow's message to finance ministers from Europe and Japan is that dollar's plunge against euro is acceptable and that dollar should now decline more rapidly against Asian currencies as well; Bush administration has made calculated economic and political choice to condone and even encourage cheap dollar to provide big push to American exporters by making their products less expensive to foreign markets (M)

headline: Telavi Journal; Georgia's Huddled Children, Bleakly Awaiting Tomorrow
abstract: Dismal conditions at Telavi orphanage, unheated building held together by metal bands, illustrate underlying reasons for wave of public fury that drove Georgian Pres Eduard Shevardnadze from office, over and above anger at stolen elections, corruption and repression; people in once-comfortable land, rich with fruits and vineyards, are cold, hungry and jobless; photos; map; their hopes rest for now with young, American-educated leader Mikhail Saakashvili (Telavi Journal) (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Authorities in Turkey Seize Companies of Uzan Family  Turkish financial authorities intensified pressure on the powerful Uzan family by seizing a large number of its companies in an effort to recover debts totaling nearly $6 billion. The state news agency, Anatolian, put the number of concerns, whose interests range from media to cement, at 219.    Turkey has accused leading members of the family, including the patriarch, Kemal Uzan, of involvement in a multibillion-dollar bank fraud. Authorities are seeking their extradition from the United States, where they are said to have gone into hiding. [C5.]

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Lawmaker Sees Peril for Corporate Tax Bill
abstract: House Ways and Means Committee chairman Rep Bill Thomas warns that bill to overhaul corporate tax law and avert $4 billion in tariffs on American exports to Europe is in danger of being defeated by feuding business interests; at issue is legislation to repeal longstanding tax break for 'foreign sales corporations,' provision that benefits American exporters but has been deemed illegal subsidy by World Trade Organization; European Union, which has been attacking tax break, began imposing tariffs this month on many American exports (M)

headline: Mock Village Helps Troops Learn Skills For Iraq Duty
abstract: American soldiers train at mock Iraqi village at Fort Polk, La, in preparation for deployment; conditions are made as realistic as possible, with Arabic street signs, livestock wandering free, and cast of 1,200 actors playing villagers, clerics, translators, insurgents and foreign fighters; soldiers must deal with confusing crowd situations and unfamiliar customs; many of those helping train soldiers are Iraqis who fled their country and are now eager to see it stabilized again; photos (M)

headline: Q & A
abstract: Q. When an Internet intruder attacks my computer, my firewall gives me the offender's I.P. address. I have notified the Federal Trade Commission and my Internet service provider, but nobody seems to care. What should I do with this information? And where can I learn more about computer security issues?    A. If your firewall logs show that attempts have been made to break into your system, there are a few ways to report the situation. Getting as much information as possible about each incident is important for tracing the source of the attacks. In addition to the Internet protocol, or I.P., address -- the unique number assigned to each computer connected to the Internet -- you should record the date, time and time zone of each attack in your firewall log.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Chile; Argentine Retailer Acquired
abstract: Cencosud, Chilean retailer, acquires Supermercados Disco, Argentine chain, from Royal Ahold (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Managing The Deficit With Plans To Spend
abstract: Edmund L Andrews column says bill just adopted by House Budget Committee, with strong support of Pres Bush, gives appearance of imposing fiscal restraint on federal government, but would allow it to make Bush tax cuts permanent, overhaul alternative minimum tax, provide prescription drug program for Medicare recipients and pass supplemental spending bills to pay for war in Iraq, all without regard to tremendous effect this would have on deficit; says measure would place burden of reducing deficit primarily on domestic discretionary programs: housing vouchers for low-income families and public housing, grants to local police and fire departments and block grants for child care assistance (M)

headline: DataBank; A Quiet Week (Except for That Verdict)
abstract: Stock market performance in week of Mar 1-5 noted; tables graphs (S)7

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Court Upholds Teacher's Suspension For Anti-Gay Writings
abstract: British Columbia (Canada) Supreme Court rules that one-month suspension given Chris Kempling, high school guidance counselor in Quesnel who wrote series of anti-gay letters published in local newspaper, was fair and did not infringe on his freedom (S)

headline: Cable and Wireless To Sell U.S. Units
abstract: Cable and Wireless of Britain will sell its American units to Savvis Communications Corp for $155 million in cash, plus assumption of $12.4 million in debt; price tops $125 million bid in sale announced last month by Gores Technology Group (S)

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Manhattan; Midtown and Upper East Side Lure More Art Dealers
abstract: Growing number of high-end art dealers, spurred by strengthening business conditions, expiring leases and relatively attractive rents, are looking for space in traditional neighborhoods for trade in Midtown and Upper East Side sections of Manhattan; gallery owner Maxwell Davidson's decision to relocate to Fifth Avenue, between 56th and 57th Streets, discussed; photo (M)

headline: Are Origins Of Italian Star Found in Hills Of Kentucky?
abstract: Western Kentucky University's mascot, known as Big Red,is about to land university and Mediaset, television company controlled by Italy's Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi, in court; university says mascot for Mediaset's program Striscia la Notizia is carbon copy of Big Red, and it is suing company for $250 million for trademark and copyright infringement; two sides have preliminary hearing March 3 in Ravenna, Italy; Western Kentucky's lawyers contend that since Mediaset introduced its mascot Gabibbo in 1990 company has been illegally exploiting image of Big Red, which was created in 1979; Mediaset has filed countersuit against Adfra, company based in Ravenna that has license to distribute character's image in Italy; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Coke And Pepsi To Pull Soda From Schools
abstract: Canadian soft drink manufacturers will discontinue distribution of soft drinks, including Coca-Cola and Pepsi, for vending machines in Canadian elementary and junior high schools; pressure from politicians, educators and parents to present healthier choices for children precipitated change; high schools will still offer soft drinks (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; In Theory, the Bears (Huh?) Won Super Bowl XXXVIII*
abstract: 'Super Bowl theory' holds that market is in trouble in years when team from old American Football League, like New England Patriots, wins game; rising prices are expected when team from old National Football Legue wins title (Market Place column) (M)

headline: List of Suitors Said to Narrow For Mobile Giant
abstract: Cingular and Vodafone are expected to submit bid for AT&T Wireless; Nextel is long shot but could submit offer for stock; NTT DoCoMo is not expected to participate (M)

headline: Big Mergers Have a Long History of Failure and Troubles
abstract: Article on history of some failed and troubled megamergers in light of J P Morgan Chase's acquisition of Bank One (M)

headline: Aventis Chief To Take Case Into the Open
abstract: Aventis chief executive Igor Landau is expected to make his strongest case yet for spurning $60 billion hostile bid from Sanofi-Synthelabo as he presents company's 2003 results at hotel ballroom in London on Feb 5; photo (M)

headline: Europe and U.S. Respond Differently to Killing of Sheik
abstract: The Israeli attack that killed the founder of the Hamas militant group drew wide condemnation in Europe today as illegal and provocative.

headline: Following Attacks, Spains Governing Party Is Beaten
abstract: Spains opposition Socialists ousted the center-right party of Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar in a groundswell of voter anger and grief.

headline: CYTYC TO BUY MAKER OF MEDICAL DEVICE FOR $311 MILLION
abstract: Cytyc Corp acquires Novacept for $311 million to add to its women's health products (S)

headline: ABBOTT LABORATORIES TO CUT 400 JOBS
abstract: Abbott Laboratories said it would cut about 400 jobs and close an office in Bedford, Mass., to prepare for its planned purchase of TheraSense. Operations at Abbott's MediSense unit in Bedford will be combined with the diabetes business of TheraSense, an Abbott spokeswoman, Melissa Brotz, said. The employees who lose their jobs will be offered severance or retirement packages. About 100 people will be offered other employment within the company. Shareholders of TheraSense, which is based in Alameda, Calif., will vote on the acquisition next month. Abbott is based in Abbott Park, Ill.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: A Laptop in the Bush.

headline: Link to Qaeda Cited in Effort To Assassinate Pakistan Chief
abstract: Pakistan Pres Pervez Musharraf says investigations into two attempts on his life last December point to Libyan with Al Qaeda ties; meets in Peshawar with more than 500 tribal leaders from Afghan border region, seeking support for military operation against Taliban and Qaeda remnants (M)

headline: Sanofi Holder Sets Meeting About Aventis
abstract: French cosmetics maker L'Oreal calls board meeting to discuss prospect of hostile takeover of pharmaceutical maker Aventis by Sanofi-Synthelabo; L'Oreal is one of Sanofi's largest shareholders and can exert considerable influence over Sanofi's potential bid (M)
