headline: Record Gas Pump Prices Expected in Spring
abstract: The fear of disruptions in oil supplies and stricter environmental regulations are expected to push prices at the gas pump to record levels in the coming months.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Administration Defends Worldwide Free Trade  The Bush administration, still sparring with Senator John Kerry over the issue of trade, said the practice of exporting work overseas had little to do with the loss of jobs in the United States. John W. Snow, the Treasury secretary, said that the practice of moving American jobs to low-cost countries ''is part of trade'' and that ''there can't be any doubt about the fact that trade makes the economy stronger.''      Mr. Snow's comments reflect a growing willingness by the Bush administration to defend global free trade even in hard-hit industrial states like Ohio. [Page C7.]

headline: HEALTHSOUTH SAYS COURT BLOCKED FASTER NOTES PAYMENT
abstract: HealthSouth Corp, accused of $2.7 billion accounting fraud, says Alabama court granted its request to prevent bondholders from getting accelerated payments; says speeding up notes would have caused 'substantial harm' to its value and to its shareholders (S).

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Army Chief Quits
abstract: German army head Lt Gen Gert Gudera asks for early retirement; will be replaced by Hans-Otto Budde (S)

headline: GENZYME WINS APPROVAL TO SELL A DRUG IN JAPAN
abstract: Genzyme Corp wins Japanese approval for its drug Fabrazyme, which treats rare enzyme deficiency called Fabry disease; will sell drug as soon as Japanese government sets price (S)

headline: For the Multitasking Motorist, a Third Eye
abstract: What's Next column describes chip-based camera system that analyzes physical data in effort to prevent automotive accidents; truckers may become first to benefit from technology (M)

headline: Two Newcomers From Nikon Boast a Sharp Eye for Detail
abstract: News Watch column reviews Nikon Coolpix 8700 and D70 cameras; both are digital cameras, but D70 is single lens reflex and accepts most lenses made by Nikon; photo (S)

headline: A few upscale brands are proud to ignore the vagaries of seasonal fashion
abstract: PARIS—  Fashion, by its very nature, is a cyclical phenomenon. Short skirts follow long, tight tailoring follows soft; the '50s follows the '70s (yet again), as we all get ready for an imminent '90s revival.

headline: At Least 25 Die in Attack on Shiites in Pakistan
abstract: Unidentified gunmen lobbed grenades and sprayed bullets at a procession of Shiite Muslim worshippers in the city of Quetta in southwestern Pakistan today.

headline: Official Afghan Report Says 10 Civilians Died in U.S. Raid
abstract: Afghan government team sent to investigate Jan 17 airstrike in Uruzgan province concludes that at least ten civilians were killed; United States military denies any civilian died in raid; maintains AC-130 gunship fired on and killed five armed militants (S)

headline: JOHNSON OUTDOORS GETS $68.4 MILLION OFFER
abstract: Johnson Outdoors Inc, which makes Eureka tents and Old Town canoes, receives offer from its largest shareholder and his daughter, company's chief executive, to buy rest of Johnson Outdoors for $68.4 million; Samuel Johnson and chief executive Helen Johnson-Leipold will pay $18 a share for 3.8 million shares that Johnson family and its affiliates do not already own (S)

headline: The creator of 'Bo knows' offers Nike a different campaign, with a multitude of stars.
abstract: Nike will begin advertising campaign carrying theme 'What if?' that will feature tennis star Andre Agassi playing baseball for Boston Red Sox, cyclist Lance Armstrong boxing, pitcher Randy Johnson as professional bowler, runner Marion Jones as gymnast, footbal players Brian Irlacher and Michael Vick as hockey teammates and tennis star Serena Williams playing beach volleyball; campaign was developed by Wieden & Kennedy; photos (M)

headline: Africa Quandary: Whites' Land Vs. the Landlessness of Blacks
abstract: Intense conflict over land in South Africa pits tens of thousands of white landowners, beneficiaries of system that denied blacks property rights, against millions of nonwhites left landless by colonialism; landless have been waiting for close to decade for democracy to end that disparity; their growing impatience threatens black-white compact that has been linchpin of South Africa's stability; upon ending apartheid in 1994, government leaders pledged to use treasury and law to transfer 30 percent of white-owned farmland to nonwhites in five years; 10 years later, they have transferred only 2 percent; more than 90 percent of commercial farmland remains in hands of 50,000 white farmers; experts agree that many white farmers would willingly sell for fair price, but that nation's black-run government has given land reform back seat to other priorities, such as AIDS and crime; photos; map (L)

headline: From Rogue Nuclear Programs, Web of Trails Leads to Pakistan
abstract: Investigations into nuclear programs of North Korea, Iran and Libya reveal that Pakistan has been intellectual and trading hub of loose network of hidden nuclear proliferators; A Q Khan Research Laboratories in Kahuta has been peddling advanced nuclear technology for years, quietly circulating sales brochure to aspiring nuclear weapons states and network of nuclear middlemen around world; network is global, stretching from Germany to Dubai and from China to South Asia, and involves many middlemen and suppliers; experts say what is striking about string of recent disclosures is how many roads appear ultimately to lead back to Kahn Research Laboratories, where Pakistan's own bomb was developed; photos of Abdul Qadeer Khan, father of Pakistani bomb, and of brochure from Khan's Research Laboratory; map shows original nuclear nations, and new group; drawing shows how uranium is enriched (L)

headline: Investing; Real Estate Funds: Tough Act to Follow
abstract: Kenneth D Statz of Security Capital US Real Estate fund discusses his prediction of 10 to 12 percent annual returns for real estate investment trusts over next five years; interview; photo; graph; broad areas of REIT investments noted (M)

headline: Several States Investigate Importing Canadian Drugs
abstract: Minnesota and Wisconsin will ask other states to join them in screening online drugstores in Canada in move to counter warnings from pharmaceutical industry and Food and Drug Administration that imported prescription drugs could be unsafe; Dr Mark B McClellan, FDA commissioner, has expressed concern for American patients; photo (M)

headline: For Italian City Saddened by Scandal, a Night to Rejoice
abstract: Parma, Italy, is momentarily diverted from financial scandal at Parmalat when local soccer team scores 1-0 victory over favored Milan team; photo of Stefano Tanzi watching his last game as club president; Tanzi's family controls embattled Parmalat company (M)

headline: Researchers Retract a Study Linking Autism To Vaccination
abstract: Ten of the 13 scientists who produced a 1998 study linking a childhood vaccine to several cases of autism retracted their conclusion yesterday.    In a statement to be published in the March 6 issue of The Lancet, a British medical journal, the researchers conceded that they did not have enough evidence at the time to tie the measles, mumps and rubella vaccine, known as MMR, to the autism cases. The study has been blamed for a sharp drop in the number of British children being vaccinated and for outbreaks of measles.

headline: A TV That Cuts All Cords
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on Sharp Aquos 15-inch liquid crystal television that connects wirelessly to home entertainment system; photo; drawing (M)

headline: Change in Chairman And Name at Merkley
abstract: Parry Merkley, last founder of Merkley Newman Harty & Partners, is giving up leadership as chairman in reorganization; becomes chairman emeritus while remaining partner; agency is being renamed Merkley & Partners to better reflect its leadership; managing partner Alex Gellert is named chief executive; executive creative directors Andy Hirsch and Randy Saitta are named chairmen and chief creative officers; Douglas Atkin, director for strategic planning, is named chief strategy officer (S)

headline: Israel Strikes for 2nd Day in Gaza, Killing 4, Palestinians Say
abstract: Palestinian officials charge that Israeli attack helicopters struck for second straight day in Gaza Strip and killed four people in southern town of Rafah (M)

headline: Health Care Heights
abstract: Rising cost of health insurance has become No. 1 issue for owners of small businesses; 26 percent of companies with fewer than 200 workers reported rate increases for health insurance of more than 20 percent last year, compared with 20 percent at large companies; only about 47 percent of small companies now offer health insurance, compared with 98 percent at businesses with more than 200 employees on payroll; rising rates confront employers with choice of either absorbing higher costs at time when they cannot raise their prices or alienating employees with cuts in benefits; drawing; graph (Special section: Small Business (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Restrictions For Nuclear Whistle-Blower
abstract: Israel's Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's office announces that Mordechai Vanunu, who is finishing 18-year sentence for divulging details of nuclear facilities to British newspaper, will be placed under government supervision after his release from prison; contends restrictions are to preserve national security; photo (S)

headline: Cambodia Battles Pedophiles by Deporting Them
abstract: Cambodia, whose postwar opening for tourism went as far as to include child prostitution, has begun a campaign against suspected pedophiles.

headline: Mexico Seizes Official in 'Dirty War' Case of 70's
abstract: Miguel Nazar Haro, former chief of Mexico's secret police, is arrested on charges of kidnapping Jesus Piedra Libarra, leftist leader who was arrested in 1975, beaten, tortured, transported to military camp and held in secret for years; Piedra was last reported alive in 1984, and his body has never been found; Nazar Haro is first former government officials arrested in connection with crimes committed during Mexico's 'dirty war' against left; was important liaison for CIA during 1970's and early 1980's, providing US with information on leftists throughout Mexico, Central America and Caribbean (M)

headline: Dual career couples : Trailing spouse's job needs start to get more company time
abstract: VIENNA—  Ruth Whitby loves her husband, Ben — and she also loves her job. When he was transferred to Japan, Whitby, a British medical doctor, struggled for a year to get a license to practice in Japan. She eventually succeeded and built a thriving medical practice in Tokyo, only to see her diplomat husband transferred again. This time all attempts at practicing medicine in their new home of Vienna failed.

headline: Pakistan Chief Says It Appears Scientists Sold Nuclear Data
abstract: Pakistan Pres Pervez Musharraf says scientists from his country appear to have sold nuclear designs to other nations; denies that government knew of sales; diplomats and US officials say documents recently obtained from Libya and Iran relating to their nuclear activities undercut years of Pakistani denials; believe that Pakistan received missile parts from North Korea in return for nuclear aid; International Atomic Energy Agency dir gen Mohamed ElBaradei comments; Musharraf photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Telecom Sale Proposal Revived
abstract: Australian government resubmits draft legislation that would allow it to sell its 51 percent stake in telephone operator Telstra (S)

headline: Killed in Iraq
abstract: List of three Americans newly confirmed dead in Iraq; 486 service members have died since war began

headline: MAKER OF MOBILE PLATFORMS TO RESTATE EARNINGS
abstract: JLG Industries Inc will restate its earnings for fiscal 2003 after $8.7 million in revenue from transaction was recognized prematurely; might also restate results for first quarter of fiscal 2004 ended Oct 31; sale of equipment was erroneously recorded in July 2003 before deal was completed (S)

headline: Campaign for Control of Disney Is in Full Swing
abstract: Michael D Eisner is facing aggressive movement to remove him as chief executive of Walt Disney Co; former board members Roy E Disney and Stanley P Gold are running campaign, using T-shirts, bumper stickers and Web site, to promote their message; Eisner has met with more than 40 institutional investors, analysts and corporate governance expert sin attmept to quiet any criticism of his company's performance and his managerial style; graph; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: TOMMY HILFIGER, New York, the clothing retailer, had its debt ratings reduced to below investment grade by Standard & Poor's because of concern about sales amid intense competition.    MISYS, London, a maker of financial software, said it had bought a banking software business from Deutsche Bank, Frankfurt, for $40 million in cash.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Network Appliance Says Earnings Rose
abstract: Network Appliance reports net income increased to $40.2 million in third quarter ended Jan 30 from $19.7 million year earlier; sales rose 30 percent, to $297.3 million from $228.95 million year ago; operating expenses rose 13 percent (S)

headline: Rats Are Next Target as Killing of Civets Continues in China
abstract: The civet sweep came as officials trying to prevent a new outbreak of SARS announced plans for a "patriotic campaign" to eradicate rats.

headline: Cheney's Davos trip is just 2nd appearance overseas
abstract: WASHINGTON:—  When Vice President Dick Cheney leaves Friday for the Davos economic conference in Switzerland, he will be undertaking only his second trip abroad since taking office.

headline: Beijing Says Only 'Patriots' Are Fit to Rule Hong Kong
abstract: Chinese leaders, concerned that Hong Kong is becoming difficult to control, say they will decide who is sufficiently patriotic to govern Hong Kong and how soon democracy can be introduced there; issue is developing into stern test of Beijing's ability to manage Hong Kong's six million people, many of whom have been demanding greater say in choosing their own leaders; some Chinese officials say that demands to freely elect chief executive in 2007, earliest date permitted under territory's mini-constitution, are unrealistic (M)

headline: Vodafone Says It May Seek AT&T Wireless
abstract: Vodafone is considering making bid for AT&T Wireless; has not yet decided whether it will submit offer by Feb 13 deadline (M)

headline: BANKRUPTCY JUDGE REJECTS EXIDE'S REORGANIZATION PLAN
abstract: Bankruptcy judge refuses to approve reorganization plan for Exide Technologies, world's biggest maker of car batteries, agreeing with creditors that it has undervalued assets (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: WorldCom Seeks Extension
abstract: WorldCom has asked US Bankruptcy Court in New York for 60-day extension of Feb 28 deadline for completing its reorganization (S)

headline: The Issues Before the F.C.C.
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission plans this week to begin considering rules for new Internet telephone systems, a process that could have a lasting economic impact on the telephone, cable and computer industries. Here are some of the major issues that new rules would need to address and some of the related industry petitions pending at the F.C.C.

headline: British Doctor Who Killed 215 Hangs Himself
abstract: Harold Shipman, the suburban doctor who won his patients trust before killing at least 215 of them, committed suicide in his prison cell today.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: New Athlon Released
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices turns up heat on Intel by releasing desktop chip and three notebook processors; new chips will probably intensify battle for desktop supremacy between two companies (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Canon Raises Forecast
abstract: Canon, camera and office equipment maker, forecasts net profit of 90 billion yen ($827 million) for quarter ending March 31 (S)

headline: Head of France Télécom's Cell Unit Is Out
abstract: Solomon D Trujillo, former chief executive of US West regional phone company, is stepping down as head of Orange, wireless arm of France Telecom; will be succeeded by Sanjiv Ahuja, who joined Orange last year as chief operating officer; Trujillo's departure is part of larger reorganization that means that Orange will be reintegrated into its parent (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: NORTHERN IRELAND: Unionists Quit Talks; BRITAIN: Coke Questioned On Bottled Tap; BRITAIN: Weapons Inquiry To Continue; RUSSIA: 7 From GuantÁNamo Charged; ITALY: Power To The Islanders;.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Executives at Shell Knew Of Shortfalls, Notes Say  The new head of the Royal/Dutch Shell Group and its current chief financial officer, as well as the chairman ousted last week, were advised of huge shortfalls in proven oil and natural gas reserves in 2002, two years before they were publicly disclosed, according to company memorandums and notes of executive discussions.     But rather than disclose the problems to investors, senior executives in a July 2002 memorandum came up with -- and later carried out -- what it described as an ''external storyline'' and ''investor relations script'' that tried to ''stress the strength'' of existing resources, and minimize the significance of reserves as a measure of growth. [Page A1.]

headline: No Longer On the Brink, American Air Is Still in Peril
abstract: American Airlines is long way from profitability despite gaining $2 billion in concessions from its unions and cutting its costs to 9.5 cents a seat-mile in fourth quarter; is also saddled with $21 billion debt, as well as ballooning pension and health care costs that it has few options to address; chief executive Gerard J Arpey comments; chart; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit In Semiconductors
abstract: Wolfson Microelectronics says full-year net income rose to $9.24 million from $2.41 million year ago; sales rose to $75.7 million from $33.7 million (S)

headline: Ambivalence From Iraqis in Poll on War
abstract: Public opinion poll of Iraqis year after US invasion finds deep ambivalence, but upbeat sense among most that their lives are better now (S)

headline: Your Taxes; Filling Out the 1040
abstract: Step-by-step guide to filling out federal income tax form 1040, summary of income, adjustments to income, deductions and credits; photo (M)1

headline: The Collections PARIS : Neocons and new romantics
abstract: New romantics — some rebounding from the 1980's, others today's neo-conservatives — are the fashion heroes of the Paris menswear season. Dashing capes, tactile velvets, flower prints and plaids have added a spoonful of sugar to plain tailoring that has made a comeback for the winter season.

headline: As Group of 7 Gathers, Europe Looks Like an Outsider
abstract: Finance ministers of Group of 7 leading industrial countries are about to convene in Boca Raton, Fla, where European delegation may find itself stranded on sidelines; fall of dollar against euro has frustrated exporters and political leaders in Europe, and there is little hope that they can reverse policies of either Bush administration, which seems content to let market push dollar downward, or Asia's central banks, which have intervened heavily to curb rise of their currencies against dollar; Thomas Mayer, chief European economist for Deutsche Bank in London, says that US and Asia have entered symbiosis, in which Asia is financing American recovery; graphs show euro against dollar and euro against Japanese yen (M)

headline: Cardinal Franz König, a Bridge to the East, Dies at 98
abstract: Cardinal Franz Konig of Austria, Vatican's longest serving cardinal and tireless bridge-builder between East and West, dies at age of 98; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Foster's Executive To Retire
abstract: World Business Briefing: Foster's E

headline: That Big-Screen Shrine
abstract: Alexandra Steinberg Barrage letter scores idea of making big-screen televisions center of social life (Feb 5 article)

headline: Coming Down to the Wire, Afghan Talks Stall on a Word
abstract: Afghan constitutional grand council, or Loya Jirga, deadlocks over question of official use of minority languages in addition to Pashtun and Dari; language question is last unresolved issue before assembly; Tajiks, Uzbeks, Turkmen and Hazara fear loss of culture if their languages are excluded; delegates reach agreement on parliamentary elections, which will be held six months after presidential election (M)

headline: U.S. Marine Wounded in Haiti; Aristide Arrives in Jamaica
abstract: US marine is wounded by snipers during patrol in Port-au-Prince; ousted Haitian Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide arrives in Jamaica from Central African Republic (S)

headline: Business People; A Flair for Freud
abstract: a flair for f

headline: Navigating Berlin's Past and Its Future
abstract: Berlin is struggling to put itself back on manp as major destination for business travelers and tourists and tries to ignore its World War II past; government officials and developers say Berling is exciting world capital vibrating with creative energy and economic potential 13 years after fall of wall and expensive reunification of Germany that ensued; drawing (M)

headline: Microsoft Nears End of Settlement Talks
abstract: Microsoft's chief executive Steven A Ballmer, in effort to reach settlement with European regulators, meets with Europe's top antitrust official Mario Monti, just over week before regulators are expected to find that Microsoft abused its dominance in operating software; photos (M)

headline: Making Drugs, Shaping the Rules
abstract: Article on drug industry's funding of new guielines developed by Texas to treat schizophrenics, often with costlier new drugs developed by same companies; 10 companies contributed and several then paid for meetings around country to urge other states to follow Texas lead; probe developed after Pennsylvania investigator Allen L Jones looked into bank account set up by state officials to collect grants from drug companies; Jones, who says he was removed from probe because of industry influence, brought information to Health and Human Services Department, which requested FBI investigation; Texas guidelines advise doctors to use one of five new anti-psychotics unless they explain in writing why older drug is better; drug costs have ballooned as result; photos of Allen Jones and Dr Anthony F Lehman, who led panel that wrote alternate guidelines without industry financing; role of industry executives and Jones's own lawsuit detailed (M)

headline: The New Europe:Slovakia : Bratislava vies to turn itself into strategic hub
abstract: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia—  For decades during Communist rule, this small city at the southern edge of what was then Czechoslovakia was a dusty industrial town, best known for a massive oil refinery and a vast wilderness of decaying concrete apartment blocks on the north.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Telecom Profit
abstract: Strengthening Australian dollar helps Singapore Telecommunications nearly triple its net profit in most recent quarter; net profit in quarter ended Dec 31 rises about 188 percent, to 854 million Singapore dollars ($504 million) (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Finland: Licence, Registration And Portfolio, Please
abstract: Millionaire heiress Jussi Salonoja is fined $216,000 for driving 50 miles hour in 25-mile-per-hour zone in Helsinki; Finland traffic violation fines are based on offenders ability to pay (S)

headline: Top Bush Aides Say Attack Wont Shake Europes Resolve
abstract: Top Bush administration officials said today that they felt confident the devastating bombing attacks in Madrid would not shake European determination to continue fighting terrorism.

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia And New Zealand: Australia: Bank Seeks Director's Ouster
abstract: National Australia Bank will ask shareholders to dismiss a nonexecutive director, Catherine Walter, after she refused to resign from the board. Ms. Walter, 51, was removed as head of the board's audit committee after PricewaterhouseCoopers reported this month on currency trading losses of 252 million Australian dollars ($187 million). That report, and another by the Prudential Regulation Authority of Australia, were critical of the audit committee. The chairman, Graham Kraehe, said Ms. Walter had lost the trust of the other nonexecutive directors. The currency losses led to the firings of four traders and their boss and the dismissal of three executives after the PricewaterhouseCoopers report said loopholes allowed employees to hide losses and protect bonuses.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Growth Rate Is Up
abstract: Canada's economic growth rate accelerated to 3.8 percent, adjusted for inflation, in final quarter of 2003 from 1.3 percent in previous three months; growth rate for year was 1.7 percent, down from 3.3 percent in 2002 (S)

headline: As Pixar's Chief Vents, Disney Answers in Kind
abstract: Pixar Animation Studios chief executive Steven P Jobs shows level of his animosity toward Walt Disney chairman Michael Eisner during Pixar's quarterly earnings call, in which he describes two of Disney's recent animated films, Treasure Planet and Brother Bear, as 'bombs'; asserts Disney's sequels to The Lion King and Peter Pan were 'embarrassing'; Disney says it is unfortunate that Jobs has 'grossly mischaracterized good-faith negotiations to reach agreement on an extension of present, successful partnership'; photos (M)

headline: Face of AIDS in Romania Is Often Kept From View
abstract: Girl, 16, who serves as public face of AIDS in Romania, doing television interviews, appearing in schools and sending encouraging messages to other infected children, uses pseudonym and does not let her face be photographed because of strong prejudice against AIDS patients; she comments, interview; many other young AIDS patients face even harsher realities (M)i

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Cellphone Dead Spots.

headline: U.S. Commanders Keep Their Guard Up as Forces Move
abstract: Largest American troop movement since World War II is in progress under high alert in Iraq, as huge rotation involving nearly quarter-million troops enters what commanders warn will be complicated and dangerous three-week period; troops rotating in and out are at high risk of attack from insurgents; when rotation is done, 110,000 new troops should have replaced 130,000 who have served 12 months in Iraq; tanks and armored vehicles in transit on truck-back are manned and ready to fight at any time, and truck drivers have undergone special combat training to ensure readiness for any surprises; photo, map (M)

headline: A Trade Battle Is Brewing Over U.S. Antidumping Fees
abstract: European Union takes its objections about way US calculates antidumping duties to World Trade Organization; US moves quickly to block ruling, but its action can only delay issue by month, when European Union will probably raise its objection again; European Commission says US overcharged when it set antidumping duties on 31 different products imported from European Union; asks WTO to set up panel to examine legality of US policy, which it says affects hundreds of millions of dollars in imports from Europe; European trade commissioner Pascal Lamy criticizes fees; photo (M)

headline: Report Says Europe Is Behind on Single-Economy Goal
abstract: European Commission report says European Union's goal to build seamless single market out of 15 disparate economies is running out of steam; commission's president Romano Prodi says union's more specific aim of becoming most competitive knowledge-based economy in world by 2010 is on course to fail (M)

headline: Fed Statement About Rates
abstract: Text of statement released by Federal Reserve after Fed's monetary policy panel Federal Open Market Committee decides to leave interest rates unchanged (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: The Netherlands: Asian Acquisition
abstract: ING Groep, Dutch financial

headline: Wholesale Inventories Up 0.6%, The Biggest Increase in a Year
abstract: Commerce Department reports wholesale inventories rose 0.6 percent in December, biggest rise in year; increase, to $294.5 billion, is lead by autos and petroleum; sales climbed 1 percent after 0.6 percent rise in November; inventories relatives to sales dropped to 1.17 months' supply from 1.18 in November (S)

headline: BANKRUPTCY JUDGE DELAYS SALE OF CONE MILLS
abstract: Federal bankruptcy judge temporarily stops $90 million sale of Cone Mills to financier Wilbur Ross at request of company's bondholder committee (S)

headline: U.S. Helicopter Shot Down in Iraq; Soldiers Kill 2 Civilians
abstract: The developments were striking signs that large swaths of Iraq are still violently opposed to the U.S. occupation a month after Saddam Husseins capture.

headline: CHARLES SCHWAB TO OFFER NEW INVESTMENT SERVICES
abstract: Charles Schwab Corp is overhauling its services to individual investors to win more business from customers with $100,000 to $1 million in assets; will let customers who do not want advice choose from two levels of discount brokerage services with quarterly fees (S)

headline: The Pornography Industry vs. Digital Pirates
abstract: Pornography industry is finding novel ways to deal with online piracy threat; has been dealing with Internet copyright issues since 1980's; many companies seek ways to turn technologies that threaten them to their advantage; some give away pictures to other sites in bid to turn freeloaders into subscribers; photos (M)

headline: Greek Prime Minister Says He Will Step Down After Election
abstract: Greek Prime Min Costas Simitis will call parliamentary election in March, month early, and resign next day, after eight years of leading ruling party (M)

headline: Fatal Error
abstract: Richard Clarke, Washingtons director of counter-terrorism for many years, has delivered a devastating condemnation of the Bush administration with his sensational revelations.

headline: Business People; Tenants Provide Rent, And Ideas, for Filmmakers
abstract: GreeneStru

headline: In Rebel City, Guns Are Power And No One Wants to Let Go
abstract: Wilfort Ferdinand, who serves as unofficial rebel police chief of Gonaives, Haiti, says his men cannot disarm until militant supporters of ousted Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide do so, interview; disarming thousands of men on both sides of conflict that has roiled Haiti for past month is daunting and key task; nation is awash in weapons, many held by men nursing deep grudges; streets have quieted in Gonaives, but city is far from pacified; photo (M)

headline: Yahoo Posts Strong Profit On Strength Of Ad Sales
abstract: Yahoo reports strong profit and revenue for fourth quarter, meeting analysts' expectations; earned $75 million, up 62 percent from previous year; revenue was $511.3 million, up 79 percent (M)

headline: Kurdish Region in Northern Iraq Will Get to Keep Special Status
abstract: Bush administration decides to let Kurdish region remain semiautonomous as part of newly sovereign Iraq, despite warnings from Iraq's neighbors and many Iraqis not to divide country into ethnic states; American and Iraqi officials say position on Kurdish area was effectively dictated by Nov 15 accord with Iraqi leaders that established June 30 as target date for Iraqi self-rule; say rapid timetable leaves no time to change autonomy and unity of Kurdish stronghold of north; administration and Iraq officials insist that leaving Kurdish autonomous region intact does not preclude country's consolidating itself without ethnic states in future when Iraq writes its own constitution; say Bush administration will press Iraq not to divide itself permanently along ethic lines; issue of whether Iraq is to be divided into ethnic states in federation-style government is of great significance both inside country and throughout Middle East, where there is widespread fear that dividing Iraq along ethnic or sectarian lines could break country up and spread turmoil throughout region; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: European Officials Meet On Agenda
abstract: Irish Prime Minister Bertie Ahern, who has just assumed post of European Union President, meets with European Commission President Romano Prodi of Italy to discuss future of European Union's constitution; two leaders disagree on time frame necessary to complete process; photo (S)

headline: Earnings Up at AnnTaylor
abstract: AnnTaylor Stores Corp says fourth-quarter profit almost doubled to $31.5 million as sales rose and it sold more items at full price; net income increased to 65 cents a share for quarter ended Jan 31, from $16.1 million, or 35 cents a year, in year-earlier quarter; net income for year was $100.9 million compared with $80.2 million in 2003; sales in quarter increased 27 percent, to $448.7 million, from $352.2 million year ago (S)

headline: United States and France: Together Again Over Lunch
abstract: Colin L. Powell, the U.S. secretary of state, and Dominique de Villepin, the French foreign minister, were back together again at the U.N. on Friday.

headline: Dubious Victories
abstract: Most Britons view Blairs triumph over the BBC, which the Hutton report presented to him on a golden platter, as an undeserved gift.

headline: E-Mail on Wheels
abstract: O Siengle, Cambodian village without wires for electricity or phones, is taking part in development project set up by American Assistance for Cambodia and run by Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Media Laboratory to connect 13 rural schools to Internet; motorcycles equipped with wireless Wi-Fi chips drive by schools regularly, creating Internet hot spots that allow for e-mail exchanges; system, developed by First Mile Solutions, uses receiver box powered by motorcycle's battery; school's computers are powered by solar panels; system lets schools cut costs by sharing satellite dish and uplink fee in country where government monopoly inflates dish prices and fees; map; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Drug Test To Expand
abstract: Elan Corp says antegren, treatment for autoimmune disorders that it was developing in partnership with Biogen Idec, will begin trials for rheumatoid arthritis in first half of year (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: An article last Sunday about Hummel, the soccer equipment and clothing company based in Denmark, misstated the name of the soccer league that includes the Aston Villa club, which recently struck a deal with the company. It is the English Premier League, not the British Premiere League.

headline: Ad From Apprentice Will Get Real Use
abstract: A fake advertisement created on a reality series is becoming a, well, reality.

headline: Market Place; Is It the Sale of a Media Empire, Or a Desperate Negotiating Ploy?
abstract: Article on whether Canadian media mogul Lord Conrad M Black's decision to sell controlling stake in his Hollinger International Inc to brothers David and Frederick Barclay actual sale or desperate negotiating ploy by Black to prevent Hollinger's board from recovering more than $200 million that it has accused Black of misappropriating (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Investing; Best Foreign Stock? Here Are Some Nominees
abstract: Sampling of foreign stocks traded in United States recommended by experts who specialize in foreign markets; graph showing foreign stocks have outperformed domestic equities over past year; photos (M)

headline: Yahoo to Charge for Guaranteeing a Spot on Its Index
abstract: Yahoo will start charging companies that want to ensure that their Web sites are included in its Web index from which research results are selected; practice, called 'paid inclusion,' has long been part of many search engines; Google, which last year surged to become largest site for searching on Internet, disdains practice as misleading; sites will pay from $10 to $49 for each Web page indexed and from 15 cents to $1 each time Yahoo user clicks on link to their sites (M)

headline: H.I.V.-Positive on TV
abstract: Next month on ''The Parkers,'' a comedy on the UPN network, one of the lead characters will meet the girl of her dreams, only to find out that she's H.I.V.-positive. The story may have been dreamed up by the show's writers, but they got a little nudge from Mel Karmazin, president and chief operating officer of Viacom Inc., which owns CBS, MTV and Showtime, as well as UPN.

headline: Photo Editors, Beware
abstract: Stephen M Hart letter says technology to alter photographs puts burden on news organizations to ensure integrity of pictures they use (March 11 article)

headline: The Education of an Iranian Reformer
abstract: Interview with Mohammad Reza Khatami, leader of Iran's main reformist party and brother of Pres Mohammad Khatami, who is among over 2,000 candidates barred by Guardian Council from running for office; he deplores brother's hesitancy in current crisis and acquiesence in flawed election he and many of brother's supporters shun; is among growing ranks of architects of Iran's 1979 Islamic revolution who challenge system they helped create, warning it veers toward religious despotism; photo (M)

headline: Chinese SARS Hero Urges Party To Admit Error for '89 Massacre
abstract: Dr Jiang Yangong, retired military physician who became folk hero when he helped expose China's initial cover-up of SARS outbreak last year, is now urging Communist Party to admit it was gravely wrong in violently cracking down on Tiananmen Square pro-democracy protests in 1989; holds most Chinese feel use of military force was wrong, but are afraid to speak out; he confirms writing letter to party, phone interview; letter calls students attacked patriots protesting official corru

headline: Iraq war looks like a dud in Spain vote
abstract: MADRID:—  In the Socialist Party's keynote television campaign commercial, a young woman leads a parade of dissatisfied Spaniards, accompanied by decent-folks-on-the-march background music, to a translucent ballot box.

headline: How to Define 'Sweatshop Free'?
abstract: Prof Gary Chaison letter on Dec 14 article on problem of defining 'sweatshop free' apparel manufacturing shops

headline: Plan supported by Mexico; leaders try to mend Iraq rift : Fox backs Bush on immigration
abstract: President Vicente Fox of Mexico gave a strong endorsement Monday at a summit meeting to the immigration plan presented by President George W. Bush, as the two also moved to put differences on Iraq behind them.

headline: Martha Stewart, Near Trial, Arranges Her Image
abstract: Martha Stewart has used focus groups and retinue of advisers in million-dollar campaign to arrange her defense and improve image prior to going to trial on charges of misleading investigators and investors about her trade of 4,000 shares of Imclone Systems shortly before company announced disappointing news; will appear in court on Jan 20 to watch selection of jury; her legal team has carefully tested government's case--and her own reputation--before sampling of kind of people who will be deciding her fate; she also has Web site which presents her side of case; lingering question is whether or not campaign has reached potential jurors (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Airbus Deliveries
abstract: Airbus becomes world's largest maker of commercial aircraft by delivering 305 planes last year, topping Boeing, which has 281 deliveries (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Denmark: Brewer Buys Out Partner
abstract: World Business Briefing: Denmark: Brewer Buys Out Partner**

headline: Former Chechen Leader Killed in Car Explosion in Qatar
abstract: Zelimkhan Yandarbiyev, an Islamic extremist linked to Chechen separatists, was killed today when his car exploded.

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: EUROPE.

headline: Regulators Said To Be Focusing On Board's Vote For Grasso Pay
abstract: Regulators preparing lawsuit against former New York Stock Exchange chairman Richard A Grasso may question validity of board vote that gave him right to $139.5 million payout; legal tactic, if successful, would not only void contract that gave Grasso his pay, but it could also compel him to return large amount of money to stock exchange; Grasso would be forced to provide another justification for keeping full amount; NYSE interim chairman John S Reed has demanded Grasso repay $120 million and has turned matter over to New York State Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer and Securities and Exchange Commission; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Unisys Posts 25% Profit Increase
abstract: Unisys Corp says fourth-quarter profit increased 25 percent; net income rose to $111.5 million from $89.1 million year earlier; sales rose 5.1 percent, to $1.64 billion, from $1.55 billion year ago; graph (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Puma Forecasts Growth
abstract: World Busines

headline: Algerian Explosion Stirs Foes of U.S. Gas Projects
abstract: Explosion that flattened large part of Algerian port of Skikda on Jan 19, killing 30 people and injuring 70 more, has shaken plans to build dozens of liquefied natural gas terminals in US to address forecast shortage of natural gas; environmentalists in California, Massachusetts and Alabama have challenged safety of proposed LNG terminals; blast at Skikda, port responsible for about quarter of LNG exports from Algeria, is deadliest incident in more than 30 years for industry; Algeria's national oil and gas company Sonatrach attributes explosion to accident at steam boiler, and administration of Pres Abdelaziz Bouteflika has promised official inquiry; Algeria's Finance Min Abdellatif Benachenhou says nation could lose as much as $300 million in export revenue this year if Skikda remains shut for extended period; photo (M)

headline: The Coming Search Wars
abstract: Microsoft's and Google's intense interest in each other heralds new round of competition between industry giant and Silicon Valley; Bill Gates acknowledges threat from search engine that now provides main results for almost 80 percent of Web searches in US; photos of key figures in both companies; graph (M)

headline: For Iraqis in Harm's Way, $5,000 and 'I'm Sorry'
abstract: American military commanders in Iraq are just now reckoning with volume of civilian casualies streaming in for assistance; do not have precise figures or even estimates of number of noncombatant Iraqis killed or wounded by American-led forces, but nonprofit groups' estimates of Iraqi civilians killed range from 3,200 to more than 5,000, and that number grows as civilians continue to be cut down by American forces in checkpoint shootings and crossfires, accidents and mishaps; groups fault military for its continued use of cluster bombs; masses of grieving, injured and disfigured Iraqis line up twice a week at Baghdad Convention Center seeking treatment and compensation; Capt Jonathan Tracy forces $5,000 on man who watched his wife burn to death and his three children die after American missile hit his house a year ago, acknowledging that it cannot bring any of them back but saying that this is all US can do for now; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: UZBEKISTAN: 36 Believed Killed In Plane Crash; U.N. Official Dead; INDIA: Kashmir Separatists Asked To Talks; CHINA: Sars False Alarm; SRI LANKA: President Abdicates Peace Role;.

headline: Florio to Step Down as Chief at Condé Nast
abstract: Steven T. Florio, chief executive of CondÀe Nast Publications, home to magazines like Vogue and Vanity Fair, will step down next month after 10 years.

headline: South Korea Aide Resigns in Rift Over U.S. Ties
abstract: The foreign minister accepted responsibility for a rift between pro-American diplomatic officials and members of presidents staff.

headline: AT&T Wireless Says It Wants a Suitor
abstract: AT&T Wireless issues earnings report that shows that technological and operational problems took toll in fourth quarter, hampering its subscriber growth; also formally announces that it is considering buyout offers; chief executive John D Zeglis says company's decision to entertain buyout offers grew out of sweeping changes affecting industry; company reports loss of $84 million in fourth quarter compared with loss of $131 million year earlier; sales were $4.22 billion, slightly lower than analysts expectations; photo (M)

headline: ECHOSTAR WINS COURT ORDER AGAINST VIACOM
abstract: EchoStar Communications Corp, which owns Dish satellite television network, wins court order that prevents Viacom from withholding CBS and its other networks from Dish customers; Federal Judge Claudia Wilkin says EchoStar showed that it would suffer irreparable damage if Viacom refused to continue honoring contract to allow Dish to carry signals of local CBS stations (S)

headline: Georgian Leader to Lift Economic Blockade of Province
abstract: Georgian Pres Mikhail Saakashvili says he has won important concessions from Aslan Abashidze, leader of renegade province of Adzharia, and will lift four-day-old economic blockade; Abashidze will reportedly allow parliamentary elections to proceed on Mar 28, review cases of imprisoned opponents and disarm his militias; photo; map (M)

headline: Call-Up Notice for National Guard Units
abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld orders 18,000 National Guard soldiers alerted for possible duty in Iraq starting this fall or early 2005 (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Panel Approves Duties On Pigment
abstract: US International Trade Commission gives preliminary approval to steep antidumping duites on imports of industrial color additive from China and India that is used in paints, plastics and printing ink; case was brought by Sun Chemical of Cincinnati and Nation Ford Chemical of Fort Mills, SC; Sun is subsidiary of Tokyo-based Dainippon Ink and Chemical(S)

headline: INSTINET SAYS IT WILL LAY OFF 185 WORKERS IN A REVAMPING
abstract: Electronic stock brokerage firm Instinet Group will lay off 185 employees, or 15 percent of its work force, and reduce office space because of its decision to split company's operations (S)

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.25       Federal Funds   1.00   1.01   1.21       3-month Libor   1.13   1.13   1.35       3-month T-bills   0.90   0.91   1.13       6-month T-bills   0.97   0.99   1.15       10-yr. headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Parties Move To Impeach President
abstract: Two main South Korean political parties file motion to impeach President Roh Moo Hyun for breach of election rules; national elections commission has ruled that Roh committed minor violation of presidential neutrality with his comments supporting Uri Party, but analysts contend he is not likely to be impeached; photo (S)

headline: Lights, Camera, Action! (And Jobs, Too)
abstract: Movie and television production industry in New York City is rebounding after a period of recession; data from 2003 suggest rise in number of film, television and commercial shooting days; photo of scene from television show Law and Order (M)

headline: Comrade Couturier Finds Fame in Russian Rag Trade
abstract: Profile of couturier Slava Zaitsev notes that at age 66 he is considered patriarch of Russian fashion; photo (M)

headline: The Mysterious 2 Percent
abstract: Ed Pleasants letter on interview with Georgia-Pacific chief executive Pete Correll

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Corporate Shelter Warning
abstract: European Commission sends German government final warning to change its so-called Volkswagen law, which is intended to protect carmaker from hostile takeover, or face court action; action is part of campaign to force member countries to abandon protectionist measures that prevent cross-border investment (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Peace Accord Review Starts
abstract: British and Irish governments and Northern Ireland's political parties meet to begin review of 1998 Good Friday Agreement, which established power-sharing Northern Irish Assembly; assembly has been suspended since October 2002; American envoy to Northern Ireland Martin Reiss also meets with concerned parties (S)

headline: Putin's Dubious Allure: 'He's Not Making Things Worse'
abstract: Russians living in Kostroma and nearby rural town mostly say they will vote for Pres Vladimir V Putin's re-election, interviews; show remarkable lack of enthusiasm but welcome his understated strength and decisiveness they see as bringing stability; oppose change; Putin is less popular with area's very small middle class; photos (M)

headline: United's Discount Airline Will Fly From Dulles
abstract: Ted, new low-fare carrier from United Airlines, will begin flights from Washington Dulles International Airport in April, two months after making its initial flight, out of Denver on Feb 12; announcement of new service for Ted comes as Delta Air Lines confirms that its low-fare airline, Song, will pull out of Dulles airport in April; photo of Sean Donohue, United's executive for Ted (M)

headline: Group Therapy Helps Ease Burden of AIDS in Uganda
abstract: New group-therapy program in rural Uganda addresses depression afflicting people who have seen relatives die one after another of AIDS; some of Africa's earliest AIDS cases were discovered twenty years ago in villages along Lake Victoria, and fertile landscape is now dotted with graves; Josephine Namaganda explains how counseling has enabled her to care for grandchildren; photo; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Beer Output Falls
abstract: German beer production fell 2.1 percent to 105.5 million hectolitres ($2.78 billion gallons) from previous year, eighth decline since 1994, when breweries produced 115.7 million hectolitres (3.05 billion gallons) per year; domestic beer sales dropped 3.4 percent, to 93.2 million hectolitres (2.46 billion gallons), but beer exports rose 9.1 percent, to 12.3 million hectolitres (325 million gallons) (S)

headline: Accounts and People of Note
abstract: Andrea Burke was named marketing manager in the new business development department at ISM , Boston. She had been assistant marketing manager for new business development at Arnold Worldwide, Boston, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners division of Havas.

headline: Investors File Suit in Parmalat Inquiry
abstract: Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach files lawsuit against Parmalat, which seeks class-action status, on behalf of Southern Alaska Carpenters Pension Fund; suit names Parmalat's founder-former chairman Calisto Tanzi and former chief financial officer Fausto Tonna as well as its auditor in Italy, Deloitte & Touche, and former auditor Grant Thornton; suit also names Citigroup and law firm that advised Parmalat, Zini & Associates (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: New Blockade Threatened
abstract: Georgia's President Mikhail Saakashvili warns factious Adzharia Province that blockade of area port will be reinstated if regional leader Aslan Abashidze continues to shun last week's agreement (S)

headline: Deep Unease Over the Future Gnaws at Moroccans in Spain
abstract: Arrest of three Moroccans and increasing evidence of Al Qaeda involvement in Madrid terrorist attack puts Spain's Muslim population in state of profound unease; perhaps hardest hit are hundreds of thousands of Moroccans, who walk fine line between acceptance and rejection in Spain and say they are bracing for backlash; photo (M)

headline: The Murdoch Empire Looks to Italian TV
abstract: Ne

headline: HSBC Says Profit Jumped 41% in 2003
abstract: HSBC Holdings reports earnings of $8.77 billion in 2003, 40.5 percent increase from year before; pretax profit was up 33 percent, to $12.8 billion, and revenue increased 54 percent, to $41.1 billion; photo (M)

headline: Grand Jury Is Investigating KPMG's Sale of Tax Shelters
abstract: Federal grand jury is investigating sale of tax shelters by KPMG to corporations and wealthy individuals who used them to escape at least $1.4 billion in federal taxes; disclosure of inquiry comes one month after KPMG shook up its tax practice and removed three senior executives in wake of widening scrutiny by Congress, Internal Revenue Service and lawsuits by clients whose shelters failed; no subpoenas hae been issued, indicating inquiry is in early stages (M)

headline: AHOLD TO SELL 2 SOUTHEASTERN U.S. SUPERMARKET CHAINS
abstract: Dutch food retailer Royal Ahold intends to sell its BI-LO and Bruno's supermarket chains in southeastern US to cut debt and recover from $1.2 billion accounting scandal (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: 'Lotto Lout' Sentenced To Drug Treatment
abstract: Michael Carroll, 20, who won $18-million British lottery jackpot, is ordered to undergo counseling after conviction for drug possession; photo; Carroll, called 'Lotto Lout' by tabloid newspapers, has long history of disorderly conduct (S)

headline: On the Rails: Rolling Without Roaming
abstract: Some travelers prefer railroad travel because cellphone use is permitted; test results of six cellular services on Amtrak train from New York to Washington noted; photos (M)

headline: Halliburton Won Contract After Pentagon Warning
abstract: Halliburton was awarded a $1.2 billion contract in Iraq just three days after Pentagon auditors warned about "systemic" problems in its cost controls.

headline: Stage Is Set For Key Day Of Testimony In Stewart Case
abstract: Prosecutors in trial of Martha Stewart prepare for testimony of crucial witness Douglas Faneuil, assistant to Stewart's former stockbroker and co-defendant Peter E Bacanovic, while Stewart's lawyers try to undermine anticipated testimony through their questioning of other government witnesses; Faneuil is expected to tell jury that he was ordered to tell Stewart to sell her 3,928 shares in ImClone Systems in late December 2001, just before company announced that much-anticipated drug Erbitux had run into serious regultory obstacles; Stewart does not face charge of criminal insider trading, but is charged with lying to investigators about what prompted her to sell her stock; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Parcel Bomb Injures 3 Officers
abstract: Parcel bomb, discovered in Perugia (Italy), explodes wounding three police officers investigating package; several package bombs have recently been sent to politician and journalists in Italy (S)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Nielsen Media Research, New York, signs agreement with TiVo, Alviso, Calif, digital video recorder company, to deliver information on TiVo use to television network and ad agency execs (S)

headline: U.S. to Mediate in Haiti Crisis; Urges Americans Leave
abstract: Bush administration, under growing pressure from relief agencies and human rights, takes more active role in trying to broker political settlement to rebellion spreading in Haiti; works with allies in region and France to put together plan that calls on Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide to appoint new government, strengthen police and release detainees, while requiring that his opponents disarm and enter political dialogue; Sec of State Colin L Powell says Aristide's resignation is not part of plan, but leaves open possibility that president might step down under negotiated settlement; Aristide says he will not step down; State Department urges Americans to leave country and restricts movements of its employees there; photo of anti-government rally in Gonaives (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: WHOLE FOODS MARKET INC., Austin, Tex., the largest natural-foods grocer in the United States, said it had agreed to buy Fresh & Wild Holdings Ltd., London, operator of organic food stores in Britain, for about $38 million.    KB TOYS INC., Pittsfield, Mass., the toy retailer, won bankruptcy court approval to tap into a $350 million loan from FleetBoston Financial Corp., Boston, to finance operations while it reorganizes.

headline: U.S. Adds Fewer New Jobs Than Expected; Jobless Rate Falls
abstract: The American economy added 112,000 jobs in January while the unemployment rate fell to its lowest level in two years.

headline: Frankfurt Journal; A New Spine-Tingler From the Impresario of Cadavers
abstract: Dr Gunther von Hagens comments on latest controversy involving his traveling exhibit of corpses in athletic poses, interview; exhibit includes muscles, organs, bones and skin flayed to reveal inner workings of human anatomy; he denies knowingly buying bodies of executed Chinese prisoners; Body Worlds, part science project, part freak show, displays corpses injected with molten plastic that hardens and preserves them in lifelike color; has become multimillion-dollar franchise with ravenous appetite for fresh cadavers; photos (M)

headline: Spanish Judge Holds 3 Moroccans on Murder Charges
abstract: Spanish Judge Juan del Olmo orders that three Moroccans and two Indian men be held in Madrid train bombings; investigators uncover details suggesting that Europe's deadliest terrorist attack in 25 years was carried out on slim budget by men who used stolen van and explosives they got free; accused Moroccans are Jamal Zougam, Mohammed Chaoui and Muhammad Bekkali; Zougam is believed to be important link between Al Qaeda cell in Spain and group of militants aligned with Moroccan Islamic Combat Group (M)

headline: Tenet Losses Increase
abstract: Tenet Healthcare Corp says fourth-quarter loss rose to $954 million from a loss of $31 million a year ago; revenue declined 8.9 percent, to $3.18 billion (S)

headline: Testimony on Bonuses to Ex-Tyco Executives
abstract: Brad McGee, former head of investor relations at Tyco International, testifies that investors were not told of millions of dollars of compensation paid to former executives L Dennis Kozlowski and Mark H Swartz (M)

headline: Intel Rejects Chinas Deadline on New Wireless Standard
abstract: Intel took a hard line today with the Chinese government in declaring it would not meet Chinas deadline for adhering to a new standard for wireless computing.

headline: GERMAN JUDGES ORDER A RETRIAL FOR A 9/11 FIGURE
abstract: German appeals court orders retrial for Mounir el-Motassadeq, only person successfully prosecuted for involvement in Sept 11 terrorist attacks, on grounds that crucial evidence was withheld by German and US authorities; throws out conviction and 15-year sentence for more than 3,000 counts of accessory to murder, citing US refusal to allow captured suspect Ramzi bin al-Shibh to testify; case against Abdelghani Mzoudi collapsed over same issue, suggesting conviction in German courts may be impossible unless US allows testimony or transcripts; similar issues threaten case against Zacarias Moussaoui in US; German prosecutor appeals on television for US to reconsider; letter from US intelligence sources has bin al-Shibh claiming that neither Mzoudi nor Motassadez knew of plot; German police faxed letter to court despite US condition that it not be turned over (M)

headline: Libya Discloses Mustard Gas Program and Stockpiles
abstract: Libya disclosed in a formal declaration today that it had produced and stored over 20 tons of deadly mustard gas.

headline: Appalled by a Celebrity Press, Britons Conceive a New Paper
abstract: Small group of journalists and managers in Britain seeks $29 million to start new paper called The World; it would aim at intellectuals and other serious readers, niche occupied in France by its namesake, Le Monde (M)

headline: Isupovo Journal; All Around, Dying Villages, Lodging the Forsaken Old
abstract: Mass migration has emptied out more than half of Russia's villages, heart of Russian life for centuries; in modern Russia, cities are growing and nation's population is shrinking; movement from villages has been under way for decades; it has found new impetus since collapse of Soviet Union in 1991, when collective farms, state enterprises and defense-industry plants that provided rural jobs and services shrank or disappeared, leaving stranded settlements behind; mostly elderly have stayed behind; photo; map (M)

headline: MGM MIRAGE AGREES TO BUY WEMBLEY, A RACETRACK OWNER
abstract: MGM Mirage acquires racetrack owner Wembley for 270 million pounds ($490 million); deal will give MGM foothold in Britain, where Wembley operates greyhound tracks in Wimbledon, Manchester, Birmingham, Oxford and Portsmouth (S)

headline: Surge in Cost of Metal Squeezes Pricing and Profits
abstract: Prices for metals like copper and nickel have risen sharply, driven partly by booming demand in China, and this is putting cost pressure on industries in US that use them; price of copper soared to eight-year high of nearly $3,000 per metric ton on London Metal Exchange last week, almost twice level in June; nickel, used in stainless steel, has more than doubled in last year; price of hot-rolled steel, one of most widely used types, has soared by more than 80 percent in last year, and by almost half since December, selling for about $480 per ton; graphs; photos (M)

headline: Anxious Time for Parmalat Bondholders Outside Italy
abstract: Parmalat SpA bondholders outside Italy have been nervously watching since company filed for bankruptcy, saying reorganization of company may be watershed event hat determines whether they will invest in Italy in future; many investors are concerned that Italian banks will be given preferential treatment in bankruptcy process; such decision could cool recent boom in Italian bonds (M)

headline: Cheney Sees Pope, Who Makes Plea for Peace
abstract: Vice Pres Dick Cheney, wrapping up overseas trip intended to rally support for drive against terrorism, meets with Pope John Paul II at Vatican and later visits American soldiers involved in Iraq war at two military bases in northern Italy; seeks to temper widespread image in Europe of United States as stubbornly independent and sometimes arrogant superpower; Pope, opponent of war in Iraq, does not mention Iraq, instead stressing importance of peace; photo (M)

headline: PeopleSoft Rejects Oracles $9.4 Billion Takeover Offer
abstract: The announcement from PeopleSoft came a week after Oracle raised its bid to $26 a share, which Oracle said represented its best and final offer.

headline: On the Therapist's Couch, a Jolt of Virtual Reality
abstract: Article on use of 3-D imaging software from Virtually Better; software used with helmet incorporating video display and earphones lets mental health professionals help people confront and deal with problems and phobias; photo (M)

headline: BUSH TO ESTABLISH PANEL TO EXAMINE U.S. INTELLIGENCE
abstract: Pres Bush plans to set up bipartisan panel to examine American intelligence operations, including study of possible misjudgment about Iraq's unconventional weapons; panel will also probe failures to penetrate secretive governments and stateless groups that could attempt new attacks on United States; decision follows rising pressure from both Democrats and many ranking Republicans to deal with errors that overstated Iraq's stockpiles of chemical and biological weapons and its progress toward developing nuclear arms; administration officials describe plans for broader examination of intelligence shortcomings to retool intelligence-gathering for new era of terrorism and nuclear proliferation by rouge scientists and nations that may provide arms for groups like Al Qaeda; panel will not report back until well after Nov elections (M)

headline: Chip Designer Accuses Intel And Dell of Patent Violations
abstract: A chip design company that was once one of Silicon Valley's highfliers filed a patent infringement suit yesterday against Intel and Dell, contending the companies have copied its technology for multimedia computing.    The lawsuit was filed in Federal District Court in Marshall, Tex., by MicroUnity Systems Engineering, which was founded in 1988 by John Moussouris, a physicist and computer designer.

headline: Hamas Names Hard-liner as New Leader in Gaza
abstract: Hamas named Abdel Aziz Rantisi as the new leader of the Islamic movement today following the killing of the groups founder.

headline: Masterfoods Shifts Work to MediaVest
abstract: Masterfoods USA division of Mars Inc is consolidating bulk of media planning and buying for its candy, food and pet-food brands and awarding assignment, with billings estimated at $300 million to $350 million, to Starcom MediaVest Group unit of Publicis Groupe (S)

headline: Europeans Reject Offer By Microsoft
abstract: European antitrust regulators rebuff offer by Microsoft Corp to include audio- and video-playing software of its competitors in form of CD-ROM's in boxes of new personal computers; proposal indicates Microsoft is actively pursuing resolution of long-running antitrust case; European antitrust officials in January drafted and circulated within European Commission final ruling that Microsoft had abused its dominant position in operating software (M)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Euro RSCG Worldwide acquires Grupo Vale, Mexico City; agency will be renamed Vale Euro RSCG (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cigarette Maker's Profit Rises
abstract: The Gallaher Group, the maker of Benson & Hedges and Silk Cut cigarettes, said profit rose 13 percent in the second half as it sold more cigarettes in Eastern Europe and in Ireland. Net income climbed to £145 million ($265 million) from £128 million a year earlier, according to Mark Rolfe, finance director of the company, which is based in Weybridge, England. Gallaher is trying to overcome falling consumption at home by expanding in countries like Russia and Kazakhstan, where some smokers are switching to Western brands. The acquisitions of Liggett-Ducat and Austria Tabak have also increased Gallaher's share of the Russian market.
