abstract: World Business Briefing: The Netherlands: Insu

headline: Press Release From Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia
abstract: Following is the announcement released by Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, Incorporated.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: 9/11 Prisoner Seeks Retrial
abstract: Lawyers for Moroccan Mounir el-Motassadeq, who was convicted of involvement in Sept 11 terrorist attacks and sentenced to 15 years in prison, request Germany's highest court overturn verdict; court will review case and decide by March 4 if a retrial should be ordered; German trial of Abdelghani Mzoudi, who is charged as accessory to attacks, is ongoing (S)

headline: Battle Is Looming Over Cotton Subsidies
abstract: Brazil has first case challenging agricultural subsidies before World Trade Organization, accusing US of breaking trade rules by giving American cotton growers and agribusiness $1.54 billion in annual subsidies; Bush administration's refusal to turn over documents to WTO could increase chances of ruling in favor of Brazil; subsidies have helped make US world's top cotton producer, with 40 percent of global market; graph; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: HAITI: One Dead In Clash Near U.S. Consulate; CANADA: Inquiry In Deportation Case; COLOMBIA: Venezuela Leader Met With Guerrillas;.

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: GREECE: Foreign Minister Seeks LeaderS Post; GERMANY: Students Chase SchrÖDer From Building; GEORGIA: Region Imposes Emergency; BRITAIN: Tuition Raises Proposed; BRITAIN: Viking Hopes Cruelly Dashed;.

headline: Cutting and Pasting
abstract: Berta Brooks letter on Dec 28 article notes she has been recording social events of her life in scrapbooks since 1937

headline: Hazardous Assignments Killed 36 Journalists in '03
abstract: Committee to Protect Journalists reports that number of journalists who died on assignment in 2003 rose to 36 from 19 in 2002, largely because of their work in Iraq; 19 journalists died in Iraq; 13 were killed by hostile actions, and six died as result of traffic accidents or illness (M)

headline: Trials, Trials, Trials, and Then What?
abstract: Analysis of upcoming trials of some iconic corporate executives, including Martha Stewart and WorldCom's Scott D Sullivan, and possible guilty plea from Enron's former chief executive Andrew S Fastow questions whether litigation will be beginning of end of corporate scandal season or will it be end of white-collar crime wave's beginning; photos (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: List of Americans newly confirmed dead in Iraq; 543 American service members have died since start of war

headline: ELI LILLY WINS F.D.A. APPROVAL FOR TUMOR MEDICATION
abstract: Eli Lilly & Company says that it had won federal approval to sell medicine that fights tumors linked to asbestos exposure; FDA clears Lilly's Alimta medication to treat cancer in lining of lungs often caused by asbestos fibers (S)

headline: U.S. General Escapes Injury in Iraq After Attack by Rebels
abstract: It was not immediately clear if Gen. John Abizaid, commander of all American forces in the Middle East, was the target of the attack.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Belgacom Shares Rise On First Trading Day
abstract: Belgium's dominant telephone company Belgacom's shares rise 4.8 percent in first day of trading of Europe's largest initial public offering in more than three years; stock climbs 1.17 euros, to 25.67 euros ($31.76) from offering price of 24.50 euros (S)

headline: Business; Now, a Man's World Is at the Spa or Salon
abstract: Market researchers are taking closer look at men's consumer behavior; find men increasingly blend traditional macho atttitudes with heightened focus on their appearance; hold they are breaking new ground and need some direction; Iconoculture co-founder Mary Meehan says men born after mid-1960's are changing definition of what it means to be man; graph; photos (M)

headline: Time Life Music Operation Will Have New Owners
abstract: Time Inc is selling Time Life Inc, its direct-marketing music division that uses ubiquitous cable commercials to sell music collections to Direct Holdings Worldwide, partnership of investment firms ZelnickMedia and Ripplewood Holdings; financial terms undisclosed (M)

headline: Egyptian Charter Jet Crashes in Red Sea, Killing 148
abstract: Flash Airlines Boeing 737 en route to Paris crashes shortly after take-off from Sharm el-Sheik, Egypt, killing all 148 people on board, mostly French, Japanese and Moroccan tourists, plus Egyptian crew; crash is tentatively blamed on technical failure, rather than terrorism, though flight recorder has not been recovered; this is third crash of Egyptian commercial airliner in four years; photo, maps (M)

headline: Libya Discloses Production Of 23 Tons of Mustard Gas
abstract: Libya, in formal declaration to Organization for Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, discloses that it had produced and stored some 23 tons of deadly mustard gas over decade ago; State Dept-chartered ship loaded with over 500 metric tons of equipment from Libya's nuclear and other weapons programs prepares to leave Libya (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Smoking Ban
abstract: Irish Health Minister Micheal Martin announces smoking ban for workplaces, including bars and restaurants, will take effect on March 29 (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: G.M. To Buy Assembly Plant
abstract: General Motors said it had offered to buy an assembly plant in India from the South Korean automaker, the Daewoo Corporation, to expand in the small-car market there. General Motors, which has less than 3 percent of India's vehicle market, said that it intended to acquire all the car-making assets of Daewoo, which is under bankruptcy protection, for undisclosed terms. The factory will help General Motors to double its sales and produce a new generation of cost-competitive vehicles, the company said. General Motors said it expected to roll out cars with the Chevrolet nameplate from Daewoo's assembly plant next year.   Saritha Rai (NYT)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Group in Britain Seeks Money for New Daily Paper  A small group of journalists and managers in Britain is seeking $29 million to start a paper called The World. It would aim at the niche occupied in France by its Gallic namesake, Le Monde.    The effort is a break from current trends as the blue-collar tabloids -- and some of the white-collar broadsheets -- seek to expand circulation with articles about would-be and real celebrities. [Page C5.]

headline: Bird Flu Alert for China; Falcon Found Dead With Virus
abstract: The dead falcon is the first sign that the disease spreading in chicken flocks in Vietnam, South Korea and Japan may also be present in China.

headline: A Criminal Indictment Against Skilling of Enron Is Said to Be in the Works
abstract: A Criminal Indictment Against

headline: Ericsson, in a Surprise, Reports a Profit
abstract: Telecommunications equipment maker Ericsson surprises markets by reporting its first quarterly profit since 2001 and says that worldwide demand for its products may grow in 2004; photo (M)

headline: Hussein's Fall Leads Syrians To Test Government Limits
abstract: Fall of Iraqi Pres Saddam Hussein has spawned sort of 'what if' process in Syria in which some people are openly questioning government doctrine and challenging state oppression; it would have been inconceivable year ago for citizen of Syria, run by Baath Party of Pres Bashar al-Assad, to make documentary film with working title Fifteen Reasons Why I Hate the Baath; Omar Amiralay says watching overthrow of Hussein across border in Iraq prompted him to do just that; Syrian Baath Party remains firmly in control, ruling through emergency laws that basically suspend all civil rights, but subtle changes have begun; Syrians do not know what locked doors they can push open, but they are trying to find out; photo (M)

headline: Raid Causes Experts to Question Readiness of Iraqi Security Forces
abstract: Iraqi security forces cannot guarantee safety after the planned transfer of sovereignty to an Iraqi government on June 30, a range of specialists concluded on Sunday.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Securities Merger Possible
abstract: British security firm Securicor and Danish firm Group 4 Falck are in discussion about merger that would create company with market capitalization of $3.1 billion; graph (S)

headline: Libyan Casts Doubt on Plane-Bombing Guilt, Ending Thaw for Now
abstract: Prime Min Shukri Ghanem brings thaw in Libyan relations with West to sudden standstill by suggesting Libya was not responsible for bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988 and other major terrorism acts, even though Libya has agreed to pay compensation to victims' families and accept responsibility in writing, radio interview; also claims Libya was not responsible for death of British policewoman, Yvonne Fletcher, in front of Libya's London Embassy in 1984 even though it has accepted general reponsibility as part of accord to re-establish ties with Britain; Bush administration demands retraction; some of Ghanem's colleagues say he may be forced to resign over remarks (M)

headline: Private Sector; From Showdown to Good Times
abstract: from showdown to go

headline: COACH RAISES PROFIT FORECAST ON STRONG SALES
abstract: Coach Inc will have fiscal second-half earnings of least 52 cents per share; profits in third and fourth quarters will rise from total of 33 cents per share year earlier; third quarter ends March 27 (S)

headline: Airport Medical Resources Are Far From Standard
abstract: Article on medical facilities available at various airports in US; Dr Steven Garner, chief medical officer of St Vincent's Catholic Medical Centers, comments; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Judge in Tyco Case Rejects Defense Motion for Mistrial  In an effort to keep the six-month-long corporate theft trial of two former top executives of Tyco International from ending without a verdict, the judge in the case rejected a motion for a mistrial by defense lawyers, who said that the naming of a juror by the news media had compromised the deliberations.      Justice Michael J. Obus of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, who has had to contend with increasing evidence of infighting in the jury room, instructed the jury to continue its deliberations, noting that ''while we certainly cannot pretend to operate in a vacuum, we cannot let what is published in the newspaper determine what happens here.'' [Page A1.]

headline: People
abstract: Larry Tolpin is named to posts of president and chief creative officer at Yesawich, Pepperdine, Brown & Russell; managing partner Peter Yesawich is named chairman and chief executive; Casey Jones is named executive vice president and global strategy director at McCann-Erickson Worldgroup; Amanda Walsh is named to new post of chief executive for Europe at Red Cell (S)

headline: CMS ENERGY AGREES TO RESOLVE TRADING ACCUSATIONS
abstract: CMS Energy Corp, owner of Michigan's largest utility, and former executives Terry Woolley, Preston D Hopper and Tamela C Pallas are accused by Securities and Exchange Commission of engaging in more than $5 billion in sham energy trades (S)

headline: China Blames State-Owned Company in Gas Blast That Killed 233
abstract: China's State Administration of Work Safety has cited state-owned China National Petroleum Corp for negligence in Dec 23 gas-well disaster in Chongqing that killed 233 people; verdict on accident, China's biggest industrial disaster of recent years, was publicized just 10 days after it happened, as authorities moved with unusual speed to assess responsibility for accident that spewed toxic fumes over farming villages in 10-mile radius; accident capped another horrendous year for industrial safety; authorities say 11,499 people died in workplace accidents in first nine months of 2003, up 10 percent from year-earlier period (M)

headline: This Year, More Boards Feel Pressure To Show Up
abstract: Several large corporations, including Morgan Stanley and Dana Corp, have adopted policies that encourage their directors to show up, and some companies have abandoned practice of holding their meetings in out-of-the-way locations; one cause for shifts is Sarbanes-Oxley Act, which requires companies to publish their policies on directors' attendance at annual meetings (M)

headline: Israeli Report Faults Intelligence on Iraq
abstract: A parliamentary subcommittee said Israels intelligence services overestimated Iraqs weapons programs prior to last years war.

headline: Corrections
abstract: Corrections of Jan 11 table from Morningstar Inc (Mutual Funds Report) listing best- and worst-performing mutual funds in many categories

headline: Creative Director Quits Bartle Bogle Hegarty
abstract: Kevin McKeon has left the New York office of the London agency Bartle Bogle Hegarty, where he had been executive creative director since March 2001.

headline: ImClone Cancer Drug Behind Martha Stewart Trial Is Approved by F.D.A.
abstract: ImClone Systems Inc's cancer drug Erbitux wins approval from Food and Drug Administration, more than two years after initial rejection set off stock-trading scandal that sent company's former chief executive Samuel D Waksal to prison and put his friend Martha Stewart on trial; drug, given intravenously, is approved as last-ditch treatment for cancer of colon or rectum that has spread to other parts of body; ImClone and its marketing partner Bristol-Myers Squibb say drug will be available within two weeks (M)

headline: Your Taxes; Form 8829: Expenses for Business Use Of Your Home
abstract: Step-by-step guide to filling out federal income tax form 8829, which covers expenses for business use of home; photo (S)

headline: Poverty and Turmoil Cripple Iraq Schools, Driving Students From Learning to Labor
abstract: Wars and sanctions crippled Iraq's education system, but major deterrent to education in last quarter century of Saddam Hussein's rule has been impoverishment of Iraqi families; poverty and upheaval have driven many children from school to work to help support families; boys are needed to work, and girls are needed to look after siblings; many children are in position of having to leave school so that younger siblings can continue studies; Education Minis ry hopes for more funding from United Nations and World Bank; photo (M)

headline: OBITUARY : Arky Gonzalez, 75, writer
abstract: Arturo Gonzalez, 75, a widely published writer and former executive for many publications, including the International Herald Tribune, died Thursday of malignant melanoma.

headline: GLAXOSMITHKLINE LOSES BID TO BLOCK A GENERIC DRUG
abstract: GlaxoSmithKline loses legal bid to block Impax Laboratories from selling generic version of its antidepressant Wellbutrin SR; US Appeals Court upholds lower court ruling that Impax does not infringe Glaxo patents for drug; Impax has agreement with Andrx Corp, first company to file regulatory approval of generic version of Wellbutrin, that allows it to go to market with drug (S)

headline: MSNBC Is Said to Have a New Chief
abstract: NBC decides to replace Erik Sorenson, who has been president and general manager of its MSNBC cable channel since 2001, with Richard N Kaplan, senior vice president of ABC News and former CNN's United States operations (M)

headline: Hollinger Board Accused of Lax Supervision
abstract: Newly unsealed suit by Cardinal Value Equity Partners, major Hollinger International shareholder, charges Hollinger board repeatedly approved deals that hurt shareholders and benefited then chairman and chief executive Conrad M Black and other executives without independent analysis, fairness opinions or extensive discussion; says board rubber-stamped sales of assets to companies controlled by Black and other executives, paid them noncompete fees or raised their compensation without question in series of deals that cost company at least $300 million; board had many prominent members in time covered by suit, including Henry A Kissinger, A Alfred Taubman, Marie-Josee Kravis and Black's wife, Barbara Amiel Black; company and Cardinal have asked that suit not proceed until special committee named by new chief executive Gordon A Paris completes review of management and board actions (M)

headline: Business People; A Cheer for Girls: Give Me a Big C-A-R-E-E-R
abstract: Smith Barney chairwoman and chief executive Sallie L Krawcheck comment on advice she will give girls when she works as principal for day at Brooklyn high school as part of program that brings executives into New York City schools (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Jobless Rate Falls
abstract: Germany's Federal Labor Agency reports number of jobless people fell seasonally adjusted 21,000 from November to 4.34 million; unemployment rate declined to 10.4 percent from 10.5 percent (S)

headline: ARCHIBALD CANDY FILES FOR CHAPTER 11 PROTECTION
abstract: Archibald Candy files for bankruptcy protection, just weeks after announcing sale of its Fannie May and Fanny Farmer brands and closing of its manufacturing plant and its 238 retail stores (S)

headline: Report Says Internet Voting System Is Too Insecure to Use
abstract: A panel of computer security experts said today that a system to allow soldiers and other Americans overseas to vote via the Internet is inherently insecure.

headline: Israeli Company Proudly Enters the Handset Market, but It Starts Small
abstract: Emblaze Ltd is set to introduce first Israeli-designed mobile phone handset, which is also part digital recorder, part camcorder and part MP3 player; hopes to offer mobile operators custom-developed phone to sell under their own label; Israel's Partner Communications is first moble operator to begin selling phone; photo (M)

headline: Bush to Establish Panel to Examine U.S. Intelligence
abstract: The bipartisan commission will examine American intelligence operations, including a study of possible misjudgments about Iraqs unconventional weapons.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: EBay Vigilantes Try to Fight Growing Auction Fraud  A number of eBay members are stepping in to fight online auction fraud -- a problem they say is getting worse by the week -- because they believe that the company does not do enough policing of its own.    But in eBay's view, these vigilantes are pariahs. Rather than embrace these virtual posses, eBay discourages them, occasionally going so far as to suspend the vigilantes' accounts. [Page A1.]

headline: ONLINE DIARY
abstract: Pamela LiCalzi O'Connell Online Diary column discusses online catalog of five million burial places; discusses Web site to find obscure songs; discusses World Internet Project collecting data on how people from around the world use the Internet; Web sites noted; Drawing (M)

headline: Zimbabwe's White Farmers Start Anew in Zambia
abstract: White Zimbabwean farmers fleeing political and economic turmoil at home are relocating to Zambia; white Zimbabweans see Zambia as law-abiding and moderate land of racial harmony; 60 percent of the land is arable, but only 10 percent is actively farmed; Zambia has only 450 commercial farmers, including about 140 newcomers from Zimbabwe; Zambia hopes influx of prosperous white farmers will breathe new life into moribund farm economy, which has been mired at rake-and-hoe level since mid-1970's, and spur growth of black-owned commercial farms; photo, map (M)

headline: At Least 14 Palestinians Killed in Israeli Raid in Gaza Strip
abstract: The deadliest single Israeli raid in more than a year came a day after a Palestinian assault on an Israeli-controlled boundary crossing.

headline: 2 Palestinians Are Killed and Dozens Wounded in Clashes With Israeli Troops Over Barrier
abstract: Israeli security forces reportedly kill two Palestinians and wound dozens more in West Bank villages of Biddu and Beit Surik as they clash with protesters in confrontation linked to Israel's separation barrier; protests highlight hearing on barrier's legality underway at International Court of Justice at The Hague; two Palestinian gunmen kill Israeli soldier in northern Gaza Strip and are themselves killed by other soldiers; Palestinian Prime Min Ahmed Qurei demands return of millions of dollars sezied by Israel in Feb 25 raid on Palestinian banks; map; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ZALE CORP., Irving , Tex., the jewelry retailer, said that Richard Marcus, director and former Neiman Marcus Group Inc. chief executive, would succeed Robert DiNicola as chairman on July 31.    MCG CAPITAL CORP., Arlington, Va., a financing and investment company, said it had bought Kagan World Media, a media research firm, from Primedia Inc., New York, the media company. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: A Touch of High Drama and Some Rather Odd Details
abstract: Douglas Faneuil, who testified against Martha Stewart in trial involving her sale of ImClone Systems shares, injects note of high drama and some odd details about himself and his work habits at Merrill Lynch; photo (M)

headline: Bush Lifts Some Libya Curbs, but Senators Issue a Warning
abstract: Pres Bush issues executive order that will allow American companies to begin negotiating return to Libya; action had been widely anticipated after Libya agreed in December to dismantle its nuclear weapons program; administration officials tell Congress that 55,000 pounds of 'sensitive Libyan equipment' has been flown to US, including centrifuges from A Q Khan Research Laboratories in Pakistan (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Alcatel And Draka Form Fiber Optic Venture
abstract: Alcatel and Draka Holding plan to combine their optical fiber units in joint venture with sales estimated at $856 million (S)

headline: Nokia Turns Bullish on Its 4th-Quarter Estimates
abstract: Nokia, world's largest maker of cellphones, unexpectedly raises its earnings and revenue estimates for fourth quarter, citing significantly better business at its telecommunications network unit as well as improved handset sales; chief executive Jorma Ollila comments; photo (M)a

headline: Bond Sales Set For This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular auction of new three- and six-month bills and a four-week bill auction tomorrow. At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was at 0.89 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was at 0.95 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue at 0.87 percent.

headline: Mostar Journal; An Effort to Unify a Bosnian City Multiplies Frictions
abstract: Bosnian city of Mostar remains divided along ethnic lines and has two sets of nearly everything, including hospitals, schools, and most public services; Lord Ashdown of Britain, top international official overseeing affairs in Bosnia, is trying to end divide in Mostar and elsewhere, but is encountering resistance from residents; map; photos (M)

headline: Getting to Know Me, Getting to Know All About Me: Web Personality Tests
abstract: Tickle.com, Web site developed by James Currier, offers range of tests on personality, careers and sex, some modeled after standard measures like IQ test, Myers-Briggs test and Rorschach-style inkblot test and others just for fun, like quiz that purports to say what breed of dog you are are or what the theme song of your life should be; has been profitable for two years, is making acquisitions, raising more venture capital and expanding overseas; three-quarters of revenues come from fees for test scores and dating services, the rest from ads; photos; graphs (M)

headline: DataBank; As Stocks Slip, S.&P. Enters the Red for '04
abstract: Financial markets' performance for the week reviewed; tables and graphs (S)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: MEXICO: Government Employees Held In Smuggling Ring; VENEZUELA: Judges Reverse Recall Ruling;.

headline: EU envoys press Manila to end death penalty
abstract: MANILA:—  The ambassadors of European Union states visited the Philippines' death row on Thursday, an unprecedented move that opponents of capital punishment viewed as a rebuke to the government on its death penalty policy.

headline: U.S. TEAM IS SENT TO DEVELOP CASE IN HUSSEIN TRIAL
abstract: Justice Department is sending high-level team of prosecutors and investigators to Iraq to assemble and organize evidence to be used in Saddam Hussein's war crimes trial, which will ultimately be run by Iraqis; responds to previously undisclosed directive from national security adviser Condoleezza Rice; photo (M)

headline: Cheney Calls for More Unity In Fight Against Terrorism
abstract: Vice Pres Dick Cheney, at World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, calls on Europeans and other traditional allies to strengthen global partnership against terrorism and other security threats; asks allies to join United States in promoting democracy in Middle East as antidote to anger and radicalism; strikes conciliatory tone in Bush administration's most significant appeal yet to disaffected allies who opposed war in Iraq; some listeners welcome remarks, but others are skeptical about his motives (L)

headline: Lawyer for Russian Tycoon Dies in Crash
abstract: A lawyer helping to represent the business interests of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the jailed Russian oil tycoon, died today in a helicopter crash in southern England.

headline: Recording The VCR's Swan Song
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on demise of video cassette recorder in favor of set-top digital versatile disk recorders; new DVD recorders, manufactured by Gateway, Magnavox, Polaroid and others, are inexpensive, but lack controls of more expensive models; photo; drawing (M)

headline: Experts' Report at Vatican Faults Sex Abuse Policy in U.S.
abstract: Vatican report on child sexual abuse finds fault with American bishops' new zero-tolerance policy on removing priests; sees overreaction to public outcry in US and says abusive priests pushed away from church might be more likely to continue such behavior (M)

headline: Automakers Unveil Plans for More Hybrid Models
abstract: Number of fuel-efficient hybrid models available in US will more than double in next year, to seven from three, with entries coming from Toyota, Honda and Ford Motor; two of new vehicles are announced at North American International Auto Show in Detroit; photo (M)

headline: Merger Would Mean New Style As Well as New Bosses at Disney
abstract: If Comcast succeeds with its hostile takeover of Walt Disney Co, Disney employees will be introduced to profoundly different management style, one that is far less centralized and more willing to delegate authority to division leaders; that could mean major changes in how Disney's movie studios, theme parks and cable channels are run; currently, Disney is so centralized under Michael Eisner that no creative decision is too small for his consideration; he is accustomed to being obeyed, acclaimed and despised in about equal measure; photo (M)

headline: Average U.S. Gasoline Price at Pump Reaches Record High
abstract: The increase, to an average price of $1.74 per gallon for regular gasoline, exceeds by one-tenth of a penny the record set on Aug. 30.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Molina Healthcare Inc., Long Beach, Calif., which provides managed care for Medicaid recipients, said it had agreed to buy closely held Health Care Horizons, Albuquerque, for $69 million.    FindWhat.com, Fort Myers, Fla., which owns an Internet advertising service, said it had agreed to buy Comet Systems Inc., New York, a maker of software, for as much as $33.5 million.

headline: Helsinki Journal; A Word to Finns: 'For Your Own Good, Blow Your Top'
abstract: Helsinki Journal on efforts to get famously silent, stoic Finns to express anger for their own well-being; Turo Heralo, theater director with bent for therapy, makes little headway with proposal for 'anger venting' classes; photos; psychologists explain cultural taboos in country where car accidents lead to polite exchange of information and restaurant diners often eat in silence, which is considered to reflect wisdom and good manners rather than boredom or half-wittedness (M)

headline: U.S. Military Describes Findings at Guantánamo
abstract: American military officials say some prisoners at Guantanamo Bay Naval Base have given actionable intelligence on Al Qaeda's recruitment in Europe, its chemical and biological weapons efforts, training of suicide bombers and fund-raising through Islamic charities; officials deny allegations of mistreatment of prisoners; say about 50 of 610 prisoners are 'ardent jihadists' with no intention of cooperating; photo (M)

headline: Patents; The advent of voice-over-Internet telephone technology is giving inventors a rich vein to mine.
abstract: Advent of voice-over-Internet telephone technology is giving inventors a rich vein to mine; inventor working for Lucent Technologies designs phone handset that can switch back and forth between two technologies; some other inventions noted; drawing (M)

headline: LOOT: Along the Antiquities Trail; An Illicit Journey Out of Egypt, Only a Few Questions Asked
abstract: Court records and dozens of interviews and documents about funeral stele excavated in Akhmim, Egypt, in 1994 and seized by federal agents in New York two years ago provide rare, detailed account of smuggling, marketing and selling of high-end antiquities; worldwide trade in looted antiquities usually begins and ends in silences, with few questions asked; stele's progress shows how seamlessly looted objects can blend into legitimate market, whether dealers are aware of it or not; stele was key prosecution weapon in conviction of American dealer Frederick Schultz for conspiring to sell stolen artifacts, even though he never sold, or even saw, stele; stele is now in Cairo Museum, trophy of Egypt's drive to reclaim its stolen treasures; photos (L)

headline: Nestlé Posts 18% Drop In Earnings for 2003
abstract: Nestle says earnings declined 18 percent in 2003; consolidated profit dropped to 6.2 billion Swiss francs, or $5 billion, compared with 7.56 billion Swiss francs in 2002; sales declined slightly, by 1.3 percent, to 87.98 billion Swiss francs, or $69.85 billion; chief executive Peter Brabeck comments; photo (M)

headline: Deserted by Doctors, India's Poor Turn to Quacks
abstract: Rampant absenteeism among government doctors and nurses is open secret across India and much of developing world, with medical personnel rarely disciplined for not showing up; India's vast primary health care system is often just skeleton, spurring poor to turn to untrained private 'doctors,' with sometimes deadly results; fissures in public health system are emerging as main obstacle to United Nations drive against range of diseases; debate is heating up about whether multibillion-dollar infusions of foreign aid or politically sensitive domestic reforms are more central to repairing public health systems; India's health system is both starved for resources and desperately in need of reform; situation in villages in Rajasthan cited; map; photos (M)

headline: Federal Appeals Court Upholds Do-Not-Call Registry
abstract: A court today upheld the governments right to help people shield themselves from unwanted calls from telemarketers.

headline: Boeing Forms New Unit
abstract: Boeing Co creates office to develop weather-prediction tools, going after what it says may be $5 billion annual market in five years (S)

headline: China Moves Toward Another West: Central Asia
abstract: International political analysts, Chinese and regional officials say China's bid to secure oil from Central Asia is part of bold but little noticed push to increase its influence vastly in part of world long dominated by Russia; China's thrust into Central Asia comes as extension of its ambitious effort to populate and develop Xinjiang, far-western region, in bid to neutralize threat of separatism by province's Islamic Uighur minority; new role as economic engine and model for region empowers China to hold neighbors to pledges not to support Islamic militancy or Uighur separatism; China's authoritarian politics and central planning also have strong appeal for many of region's former Soviet republics; maps; trade graph; photos (M)

headline: FIDELITY NATIONAL TO BUY SANCHEZ COMPUTER
abstract: Fidelity National Inc acquires Sanchez Computer Associates for about $184 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: Stylish or Chicken Scratch, Your Handwriting as a Font
abstract: Fontifier.com turns handwriting sample into scalable font for those who want their digital output to have more personality; photo (S)

headline: It's Not Enough to Be Just a Phone Company
abstract: Sale of AT&T Wireless to Cingular Wireless highlights transformations in telecommunications, as consmer markets for traditional phone services, data transmission, mobile calling and even television converge into one industry; ability to bundle services is particularly important in volatiile, fiercely competitive market where subscribers can easily switch providers whenever slightly better deal comes along (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Energy Company Plans To Split Up
abstract: Denison Energy plans to separate its mining and energy operations as part of plan that may also involve acquisition of Calfrac Well Services for 228 million Canadian dollars ($177 million) (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Old Navy, part of Gap Inc, narrows to three finalists a review for outside agency to help its internal advertising team; General Nutrition Centers names Cramer-Krasselt, Chicago, as creative agency of record on its ad account (S)

headline: The Thrill of Heroics in a War Unquestioned
abstract: Charles Herold Game Theory column reviews Call Of Duty, Medal of Honor: Rising Sun, Commandos 3: Destination Berlin and Secret Weapons Over Normandy; photo (M)

headline: Doctor in Italy Tries to Ease Pain of an African Tradition
abstract: Dr Omar Abdulcadir of Florence, Italy, treats African victims of female genital cutting; has asked local health officials for permission to perform less severe and largely symbolic operation under hospital conditions to lessen pain and risks of infection; issue is part of larger debate on rights of Europe's immigrant community to continue traditional practices; those who cling to tradition either take their daughters to Africa for procedure or have it done illegally in Europe; photo (M)

headline: 8 Are Killed as Ethnic Fighting Flares in Kosovo
abstract: United Nations officials described the clashes as the worst violence in Kosovo since the world body took over its administration almost five years ago.

headline: Germany's Big Brown Delivery Van Contender
abstract: DHL chairman Klaus Zumwinkel embarks next week on trip to US that will include meetings with analysts, bankers, investors, journalists and politicians; Zumwinkel believes his company can be first in its field by 2005; administrative law judge at US Transportation Department rejected petition by United Parcel Service and FedEx that it declare Deutsche Post's main cargo carrier in US illegal, because it is effectively controlled by German company; department still must consider law judge's December ruling; photos (M)

headline: European Regulators Meet Today on Proposal to Brand Microsoft a Monopolist
abstract: Top European Union antitrust regulators are set to meet in Brussels to discuss draft ruling that finds Microsoft guilty of abusing its dominance in operating software, imposes fine of $100 million to $1 billion and orders company to make fundamental changes to way it sells software in Europe; greatest effect of ruling against Microsoft would be evident in way company sells its music and video-playing software program Media Player; Microsoft lawyers say any legal remedy imposed on its European operations might be extended to all Windows programs in all regions, including US, but some analysts see indications that company could tailor version of its software for Europe; photo (M)

headline: Serenity on the Slopes
abstract: Horizon Organic president and chief executive Chuck Marcy writes The Boss column on his life and career; photo (M)

headline: Big Media, Please Meet Wide Distribution
abstract: Analysis of Comcast Corp's $66 billion hostile bid for Walt Disney Co; says logic of Comcast's bid is that there are lucrative advantages to melding Disney's media content--movies, television, music, news and entertainment--with distribution network of nation's largest cable television operator; photos (M)

headline: Burnett decides one way to address its troubles is to poach a top executive from a shaky competitor.
abstract: Leo Burnett Worldwide has wooed Tom Bernardin from Lowe & Partners Worldwide where he has been chief executive for New York office since last February; Bernardin is joining Burnett as number 2 manager behind chairwoman-chief executive Linda Wolf; will be chief executive for US operationsand president for worldwide operations; photo (M)

headline: They Come to Praise the Carb, Not Bury It
abstract: Producers of foods high in carbohydrates are attempting to counter trend of low-carbohydrate diets by offering campaigns about benefits of high-carb foods as sales of such products decline; Florida Department of Citrus has introduced $1.8 million advertising and marketing campaign to promote benefits of oranges after discovering that orange juice consumption has dropped 5 percent over last two years; United States Potato Board is undertaking $4 million advertising and marketing campaign to promote potato; photos (M)

headline: 2 French Citizens Are Killed by Gunmen on Iraqi Road
abstract: Two French citizens are killed after vehicle breaks down on highway west of Baghdad (S)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Names of Americans recently confirmed dead by Defense Department; 568 American service members have died since start of war (S)

headline: UNION PACIFIC SAYS PROFIT WILL NOT MEET FORECAST
abstract: Union Pacific Corp, owner of nation's largest railroad, says profit in first quarter will lag forecasts because of crew shortages, cold weather and loss of appeal to reverse $30 million court verdict (S)

headline: Russia Seizes 2 Athletes In a Dispute With Qatar
abstract: Qatar reports Russia has detained two wrestlers from Qatar as they traveled via Russia to Olympic qualifying tournament in Serbia; move adds to diplomatic dispute over Qatar's arrest of two Russian secret agents for assassination of exiled Chechen leader Zelimkhan Yandarbiyev in Feb 13 bomb blast in Doha; Russia has repeatedly demanded release of agents; Qatar's government-owned newspaper scores Russian retaliation (M)

headline: GRIEVING CROWDS IN SPAIN SEETHE AT TRAIN ATTACKS
abstract: Millions of people in Spain stream into streets in nationwide demonstration against violence that left nearly 200 people dead and over 1,400 wounded in explosions on four commuter trains in Madrid; government asserts that Basque separatist group ETA and not Al Qaeda is responsible for attack, although evidence is confusing; political stakes in uncovering identity of terrorists are high; Spain's voters will elect new government on March 14; Prime Min Jose Maria Aznar's decision to join US war effort in Iraq and send 1,300 troops there was overwhelmingly opposed by people; it could affect elections outcome if Al Qaeda is shown to be involved in bomb attacks; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Alcan's Profit Rises
abstract: Alcan aluminum and packaging group reports net fourth-quarter earnings of $143 million, up from $26 million year earlier; operating earnings grew by 9 percent (S)

headline: U.S. and Brazil Fingerprinting: Is It Getting Out of Hand?
abstract: Brazil and US are holding fast to their insistence on photographing and fingerprinting visitors from other country; what began as minor spat is threatening to sour relations between two countries; dispute grew out of new US security program that applies to all foreigners entering country who are required to have visas; US has identified border region where Brazil, Argentina and Paraguay come together as haven for Islamic terrorists (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Retailer Surges On Bid
abstract: Shares of Royal Vendex KBB, Dutch department store owner, rise 15 percent after company says it is in talks with unidentified private equity companies that might lead to takeover bid; graph shows share price (S)

headline: Death of Sheik Raises Question Of Hamas Fate
abstract: Deadly helicopter strike that killed Sheik Ahmed Yassin has generated such rage among Palestinians that many in Israel fear surge of retaliatory strikes; Israel had hoped to so weaken Hamas with Yassin's death that it would be unable to retaliate; question is which will prove more important, leader who was slain or following he inspired; most Israelis supported decision to kill Yassin, whom they saw as archterrorist whose group not only rejected Israel's right to exist, but was also bent on its destruction; Hamas's large following and its ability to carry out bombings consistently gave it ability to disrupt, if not derail, potential comprises it opposed (M)

headline: Editors Note
abstract: An article last Sunday described the coming battle between Google and Microsoft over the Internet search business. It quoted Nancy Blachman, a computer scientist, as saying that Google had an advantage in the race because it had the most current users. The article also identified Ms. Blachman as the author of an independent guide to using Google but should have noted that Ms. Blachman, though not affiliated with that company, is married to a Google software engineer.

headline: IRAQI AYATOLLAH INSISTS ON VOTE BY END OF YEAR
abstract: Powerful Shiite cleric Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani drops his insistence on holding nationwide elections before United States transfers sovereignty to Iraqis on June 30, but says they must be held by end of year; calls for resolution by United Nations Security Council or other 'clear guarantees'; says interim government should only be in control for short time period, and should be largely limited to setting up elections; remarks increase pressure on United States, United Nations and Iraqi leaders to come up with firm plan for caretaker government and managing elections; several other devisive issues are also looming, including deadlines for interim constitution and status-of-forces agreement for continuing presence of American troops (M)

headline: Colombians, With U.S. Aid, Tracked Rebel For Months
abstract: Colombian agents, working with American intelligence operatives, tracked top Colombian guerrilla commander Ricardo Palmera for months before he was arrested on busy street in Quito, Ecuador; Palmera was leading negotiator in peace talks that failed in 2002; Colombian government is calling his capture a major blow against Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, Marxist rebel group, and proof that Pres Alvaro Uribe's efforts to weaken rebels is working; photo (M)

headline: Notions for the Seasonal Needlewoman
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column finds Web sites that offer information on sewing; sites noted; drawing (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.25       Federal Funds   1.06   1.04   1.33       3-month Libor   1.12   1.12   1.33       3-month T-bills   0.94   0.92   1.17       6-month T-bills   0.99   0.98   1.17       10-yr. T-infl.   1.45   1.52   1.71       10-yr. T-note   3.99   3.98   3.67       30-yr. T-bond   4.84   4.85   4.67       Telephone bd.   6.28   6.28   5.90       Municipal bds.   4.45   4.46   4.97          (Sources by Bloomberg News; Telerate; The Bond Buyer; British Bankers' Assoc.)

headline: Agency Says Morgan Stanley May Face New Sex-Bias Suit
abstract: Agency Says Morgan Stanley May Face

headline: Toyota becomes the first exclusive auto sponsor on EBay.
abstract: Toyota Motor Corp agrees to become first exclusive automotive sponsor on eBay in deal that promotes Toyota cars and trucks on special eBay pages and in online charity auctions; photo (M)

headline: Hotwire Shifts Some Of Account to McCann
abstract: Hotwire.com, discount travel Web site owned by InterActive Corp, expands its relationship with McCann Worldgroup by shifting creative part of its account to San Francisco office of McCann-Erickson Worldwide from DeVito/Verdi (S)

headline: Fed Governor Defends Call To Hold Rates At Low Level
abstract: Federal Reserve Board governor Ben S Bernanke defends board's policy of holding down interest rates to spur economic recovery, speech, Allied Social Science Associations, San Diego; notes inflation rate is near bottom of acceptable range (M)

headline: After selling millions of grills, George Foreman is putting his big smile behind men's fashions.
abstract: George Foreman, former heavyweight boxing champion and electric grill salesman, appears as model in $26 million ad campaign for his new Comfort Zone clothing line for Casual Male Big & Tall; campaign is created by Averett, Free & Ginsberg in New York; photo (M)

headline: As Its Ex-Bosses Await Their Fate, Tyco Continues Comeback
abstract: Tyco International management and work force focus on company's recent run of profitable quarters rather than trial in which L Dennis Kozlowski, former chairman and chief executive, and Mark H Swartz, former chief financial officer, are charged with looting company of more than $600 million; Tyco's story is surprisingly upbeat compared with tales of other companies tarred with scandal's brush, in no small part because Tyco is conglomerate in which Kozlowski's role at holding company was far removed from operating units; share price, which traded in $50's in early 2002 and dropped to $8.25 by July of that year, closed at $27.95 on March 19; much of success is credited to Edward D Breen, who succeeded Kozlowski as chairman and chief executive; photos; graphs (M)

headline: Spain's Losing Party Plans to Sue Movie Director for Slander Over a 'Coup' Accusation
abstract: Spain's defeated Popular Party says it is going to sue Pedro Almodovar, country's most celebrated movie director, because he accused government of trying to hatch 'coup d'etat' day before election; Aldomovar referred during March 16 press screening to Internet report that government petitioned King Juan Carlos on eve of election to postpone voting and that king refused request, saying it would constitute de facto coup d'etat; government has flatly denied rumor, and all political parties say there is no truth in it; Jose Luis Rodriguez Zapatero, incoming prime minister, says he will listen to Pres Bush'a appeal to stand firm in Iraq, but says he is sticking with plan to withdraw Spanish troops from Iraq if UN has not taken control by June 30; says occupation is turning into fiasco; Aldomovar photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Equity Offerings for Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:      Annaly Mortgage Management, 15 million shares. UBS Warburg and Merrill Lynch & Co.

headline: Exploring the Country For Lower Costs of Living
abstract: George Twohig letter on Fred Brock's Feb 8 column on retiring in small towns notes retirees are not only ones who may want to move to areas with lower living costs

headline: In a quest to increase sales, a fast-food restaurant does a very quick ad agency turnaround.
abstract: Burger King Corp unexpectedly fires Young & Rubicam Advertising as its lead creative agency, and names Crispin Porter & Bogusky to take over account, which has billings estimated at $350 million; Burger King executives hope change will reverse disappointing results in November and December; photo (M)

headline: Bush Names Panel to Examine Intelligence on Iraq Weapons
abstract: President Bush named former Senator Charles Robb of Virginia and senior federal Judge Laurence H. Silberman co-chairmen.

headline: For Those Who Can't Wait for the Future to Arrive
abstract: Intel creates concept laptop computers, intended to inspire and direct industry toward next generation of laptops; photo (M)

headline: This Baghdad Gunfire Celebrates Love, Not War
abstract: Wedding of Shayma Hamid, 21, and Ali Dakhil Alwai, 36, is one of many in Baghdad for young couples who were forced to wait out most turbulent moments of Iraq war; photos (M)

headline: MEMO PAD
abstract: Boyd Group predicts number of passengers boarding planes in US will total just over 740 million in 2009, down from Federal Aviation Administration's 2000 estimate of 931 million for 2010; also estimates that barring catastrophic events or sharp rise in oil prices, passenger traffic will grow from 2.2 percent to 2.7 percent this year; Business Travel Coalition study shows corporate travel managers are not happy with Northwest Airlines for secretly providing personal passenger information to government for security study; Delta Air Lines will begin boarding passengers by staggered zones Jan 21 in domestic airports; passenger in coach section will get boarding passengers with zone number corresponding to one of six sections of cabin; coach cabin boarding will be called by zone, in contrast to previous procedure of boarding plane from rear of aircraft forward; first-class passengers will continue to be first to board; report by Meeting Professionals International and American Express shows US meetings planners expect 11 percent rise in number of international meetings in 2004 over 2003; Transportation Security Administration will let passengers who set off metal detectors at airports because of overlooked coins in their pockets to have second chance to correct problem by depositing metal objects in tray; previously, setting off metal detector meant automatic secondary screening; report by Office of Inspector General in Transportation Department shows only 3 of 31 largest domestic airports had increases in scheduled air service capacity as of last month over December 2002 (Memo Pad column) (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: EBay To Acquire Mobile.de For $152 Million
abstract: EBay acquires Mobile.de of Germany, which runs Web sites for selling used cars, for about $152 million (S)

headline: HAITIAN REBELS ENTER CAPITAL; ARISTIDE BITTER
abstract: Armed rebels sweep into Port-au-Prince, Haiti, and occupy national police headquarters, staking claim to power as US forces keep watch at international airport and presidential palace; cheering and dancing greet rebels but no clear leader takes charge; photos; map; Chief Justice Boniface Alexandre is sworn in to head transitional government until elections in 2005; deposed president Jean-Bertrand Aristide lands in Central African Republic, charging he was overthrown by US, claim that White House calls 'complete nonsense'; Pres Bush considers multinational peacekeeping force; France and Canada pledge help; Sec Colin Powell says rebels include figures US does not wish to see around; at least four Aristide backers are found executed; rebels, followed by throngs, occupy army headquarters, vowing to revive military that was known for brutality; several rebel leaders were part of death squads and army that ran violent junta until ousted by US in 1994; rebel leaders Louis-Jodel Chamblain, former death-squad member and convicted assassin, and Guy Philippe, former police chief, thank US for restoring security now (M)

headline: ARCH CHEMICALS AGREES TO BUY MAKER OF POOL SANITIZERS
abstract: Arch Chemicals acquires unit of Avecia Group that makes chlorine-free sanitizers for pools and spas for about $210 million (S)

headline: Newspaper Editors Move To Tighten Safeguards
abstract: At least 10 American newspapers have confirmed instances of plagiarism or fabrication since New York Times reported in May 2003 that Jayson Blair had made up or copied portions of at least three dozen articles; it is impossible to say for sure whether more reporters are cutting corners or whether those that do are now being detected through safeguards against journalistic fraud that newspapers have established in last 10 months; photos (M)

headline: Seminyak Journal; Bali's Richness Offered to the World, by Onetime Hippies
abstract: Eclectic group of American, Canadian and European hippies who were drawn to Bali in 1970's by its elaborate Hindu ceremonies have stayed on, and some have become millionaire businessmen specializing in promoting Bali's culture to Westerners; most hippies-turned-businessmen live in enclaves like one in Seminyak beach village; biggest problem for these businessmen who want to fill orders is very thing that charmed them in first place: relaxed pace of life and Balinese desire to observe their religion in all its elaborate, and decorative manifestations; photo; map (M)

headline: F.C.C. Begins Rewriting Rules on Delivery of the Internet
abstract: The new rules are expected to profoundly alter both the way the Internet is delivered and used in homes and businesses.

headline: PENNEY TO CLOSE TELEMARKETING CENTER AND CUT 475 JOBS
abstract: J C Penney plans to close telemarketing center in Austin, Tex, cutting 475 jobs, and take over management of six warehouses to reduce costs (S)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Dept confirms death of one American service member in Iraq (S)

headline: Russian Growth Accelerates, Stoked by Oil
abstract: Russia's economy grew 6.8 percent in 2003 bolstered by higher oil prices; oil remains crucial factor underpinning Russia's economic boom, rising oil prices, combined with Pres Vladimir V Putin's policies, spurred growth of 6.1 percent; oil helped Russia set export record of $134.4 billion, up 25 percent from 2002; graph; photos (M)

headline: No 'Auld Lang Syne' for Jailed Russian Oilman
abstract: Prison warden says Russian oil billionaire Mikhail B Khodorkovsky will be allowed to usher in New Year by watching television, but will not be permitted to sing or drink champagne (M)

headline: Official Killed as Strife Grows in Afghanistan
abstract: Ismail Khan, one of Afghanistan's most powerful warlords, survives attack but his son Mir Wais Sadeq is killed as he leads advance on Herat headquarters of government commander whom he blamed for assault on his father; violence is some of worst in country since fall of Taliban more than two years ago; Khan's firm hold on power and unwillingness to permit free political activity is seen in Kabul as obstacles to free and fair elections; his refusal to submit fully to rule of central government has been viewed as barrier to rebuilding country; photo (M)

headline: Distressed or washed-out, jeans are a must for every man
abstract: PARIS—  Take a look at the first dozen men you see on the street in Tokyo, London, Los Angeles or New York. How many of them are wearing jeans? The five-pocket, in destroyed denim, waxed canvas, washed-out corduroy or leather, is the pant of choice for men of all ages, shapes and tastes. For them, jeans are comfortable, young, sexy, natural and iconic.

headline: For Better HDTV Displays, It's All About the Chip
abstract: How It Works column on high-definition television technology; series of illustrations shows how liquid crystal on silicon works; (M)

headline: Why an S.E.C. Hurdle Won't Stop Fund Speculators
abstract: why an s.e.c

headline: The Old Block of Ice And a Few New Chips
abstract: Ice carvers are increasingly using computer-driven carving machines to produce intricate sculptures traditionally made by chefs or artisans; John Bayley, founder of Iceculture, developed one of first computer-driven machines; process and equipment described; prices noted; photos (M)

headline: Rebels, Many in Teens, Disarm in Sudan's South
abstract: Disarming of young fighters in southern Sudan stirs hope for ending twenty-year conflict, although fighting rages explosively in east, where government is laying waste to communities controlled by rivals; photos; map (M)

headline: An Unexpected Visit by Powell to Baghdad Sets Off an Angry Walkout by Journalists
abstract: Sec of State Colin L Powell makes unannounced visit to Iraq, intending to highlight progress under way on first anniversary of start of war; 30 Iraqi and other journalists for Arabic news media walk out of briefing by Powell in Baghdad in protest over deaths of Ali al-Khatib and Ali Abdul Aziz, journalists working for Arabiya satellite network who were killed in shooting episode with US forces; photo (M)

headline: Terrorist Groups
abstract: Intelligence and counterterrorism officials around the world and a United Nations monitoring group estimated that there are 30 to 40 terrorist groups worldwide affiliated in some way with Al Qaeda. Here are some:

headline: A Virtual Cash Register Rings Up Tiny Transactions
abstract: New software could make small online transactions less of a drain on the sellers pocketbook.

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: EASIER TO BE EUROPEAN; FRANCE: Railway Bomb Scare; GERMANY: Corpse Exhibitor Cleared;.

headline: METLIFE SAYS S.E.C. IS INVESTIGATING SALES OF LIFE INSURANCE
abstract: metlife says

headline: Canada's Liberals May Be Learning How the West Is Lost
abstract: Canada's Liberal Party allegedly handed out $75 million in public money to advertising firms in Quebec Province that were big contributors to party; kickback scandal almost certainly buried any hope that Prime Min Paul Martin had of making inroads in elections expected in May in four western provinces; opinion polls show that Martin is having hard time convincing Canadians, particularly westerners, that he did not know about payouts when he was finance minister in government of his predecessor Jean Chretien; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Caremark Rx Inc., Birmingham, Ala., a manager of prescription drug benefits, said it had won a three-year contract with a Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association plan to help supply about 3.9 million government employees with mail-order medicines. Financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: Sense of Mortality Gave Push to India-Pakistan Talks
abstract: Pakistan's decision to end state support for Islamic militants in Kashmir followed eight months of secret talks and assassination attempt that seems to have confirmed Gen Pervez Musharraf's decision; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: AMERICAS.

headline: Pakistani Judge Releases Pair Of Journalists
abstract: Two French journalists sentenced to six months in jail for traveling to Pakistani city of Quetta without government's permission are freed on appeal; Pakistani journalist working with them is missing and believed to be in government detention; Pakistani officials had accused journalists of staging film about resurgent Taliban in Quetta, but never formally charged them in relation to those accusations; under policy begun last year, Pakistan's Interior Ministry issues journalists restricted visas that bar them from traveling to Quetta, Peshawar and certain other spots without government permission (M)

headline: GRYPHON BUYS EIGHT O'CLOCK COFFEE FROM GREAT ATLANTIC
abstract: Gryphon Investors completes $107.5 million purchase of Eight O'Clock Coffee Co from Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co (S)

headline: Iraq Bombings Seem to Aim at Voting Plan
abstract: Back-to-back suicide bombings in Iraq that killed more than 100 people occur as visiting United Nations delegation examines whether early elections could be held there; member of Iraqi Governing Council says terrorists want UN to give up on idea of elections; whatever attacks' effect on UN team, Iraqi people seem unbowed; photo (M)

headline: Correction
abstract: An article last Sunday about Financo Global Consulting, a team of former retail executives, misidentified the headquarters location of one of its clients, Innovative Marble and Tile, and misstated the companys age. It is in Hauppauge, N.Y., not Brooklyn, and was founded in 1981. (It is not a new company.).

headline: Ex-Director Explains Fee From Tyco
abstract: A former director of Tyco said on Wednesday at the trial of the companys former chief executive that he was paid $20 million for brokering the purchase of the CIT Group and was asked by the chief executive to keep it a secret.

headline: Pentagon Pays Iraq Group, Supplier of Incorrect Spy Data
abstract: Pentagon is paying $340,000 a month to Iraqi political organization led by Ahmad Chalabi for 'intelligence collection,' even though much of its information before US invasion was useless, misleading or fabricated; CIA reportedly must get Pentagon permission before interviewing informants from Iraqi National Congress, which has close ties to Bush administration (M)

headline: U.S. Leads Suit to Stop Oracle Bid for PeopleSoft
abstract: Justice Department and seven states file lawsuit to block Oracle's $9.4 billion hostile takeover of PeopleSoft Inc; Justice Department says deal would violate federal antitrust laws, reduce competition and lead to higher prices for customers; agency joins suit by attorneys general of Hawaii, Maryland, Massachusetts, Minnesota, New York, North Dakota and Texas; Oracle's chief executive Lawrence J Ellison says it will fight lawsuit; PeopleSoft chief Craig A Conway says Oracle should withdraw its bid; chart; photos (M)

headline: Warhead Blueprints Link Libya Project To Pakistan Figure
abstract: Libya recently turned over to United States warhead designs that it says it bought for over $50 million from dealers who are part of underground network linked to Abdul Qadeer Khan, creator of Pakistani nuclear bomb; designs are first hard evidence that network sold its customers far more than just technology to turn uranium into bomb fuel; blueprints and capability to enrich uranium could have given Libyans all they needed to make nuclear bomb; experts say designs closely resemble warheads China passed on to Pakistan decades ago; there is no evidence that Libyans produced sufficient fuel or warheads; American officials stress they have no evidence Pakistani government was aware of sales; experts question whether Pakistani nuclear secrets could have been exported without knowledge of some in military and intelligence services, especially since some shipments were made on military planes; American officials say international network of nuclear middlemen and parts producers is being broken up; fear network sold bomb designs and materials to others (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Profit In Building Materials
abstract: Ireland's CRH reports 2.8 percent increase in yearly net profit, to 640.6 million euros ($782 million), and 3 percent rise in yearly revenue, to 11.1 billion euros ($13.5 billion) (S)

headline: Phat Fashions Is Being Sold To Kellwood for $140 Million
abstract: Phat Fashions, clothing business co-founded by hip-hop impresario Russell Simmons, will be bought by Kellwood for $140 million, plus performance incentives; Simmons praises Kellwood's chief executive Hal J Upbin and president Robert C Skinner Jr; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ALCOA INC., Pittsburgh, the aluminum maker, sold its packaging-equipment business to American Industrial Partners, San Francisco, a private equity firm, for $45 million in cash.    GRAPHIC PACKAGING CORP., Marietta, Ga., which makes cartons used in food packaging, said it would close a folding-carton plant in Garden Grove, Calif., by the end of the second quarter, affecting about 131 employees.

headline: S.E.C. Is Investigating Titan On Payments to Consultants
abstract: Titan Corp, which had expected its acquisition by Lockheed Martin Corp to be completed next month, says Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating payments it made to foreign consultants; Lockheed has asked for all information related to investigation ahead of March 16, when Titan shareholders are scheduled to vote on purchase; Lockheed will conduct its own review of payments to determine whether merger terms will be satisfied; representatives of both companies have met with Justice Department and SEC; Titan says probe concerns whether agreements with international consultants and payments in foreign countries were against law (M)

headline: Sharon Says He Plans to Remove 17 Settlements From Gaza
abstract: Israels prime minister said he was "working on the assumption that in the future there will be no Jews in Gaza."

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Telecom Resignations Offered
abstract: SK Telecom chief executive-president Pyo Moon Soo, chairman Son Kil Seung and chairman Chey Tae Won offer to resign, ending standoff with minority shareholders; photo (S)

headline: Novartis Puts Conditions on Any Bid for Aventis
abstract: Novartis says in will stay out of bidding for Sanofi-Synthelabo unless officials stop promoting hostile takeover by Aventis and Aventis invites offer; Novartis chairman Dr Daniel Vasella says implentation risks have greatly increased due to negative attitude of French government toward Novartis (M)

headline: And the Band Played On, Online
abstract: Article discusses availability of music from rock concerts downloadable from Internet hours after concert; bands and record companies hope to make money and nurture ties to fans; photo (M)

headline: MONSANTO SAYS LOSS WIDENED BUT LESS THAN EXPECTED
abstract: Monsanto Co says its net loss widened to $97 million in fiscal first quarter ended Nov 30 compared with loss of $18 million year earlier; revenue rose 22 percent, to $1.03 billion (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Pentagon Announces End Of Helicopter Program  The Pentagon announced the cancellation of the $38 billion Comanche helicopter program, a weapons system from the cold war era that became a victim of new technology and rising concerns over military costs and the federal budget deficit. The decision, which must be approved by Congress, would bring a close to a program that began in 1983 and has, so far, cost $8 billion but has yet to produce a single operational craft.    The Comanche program is a joint venture of the Boeing Corporation and the Sikorsky Aircraft subsidiary of United Technologies. Shares of both companies declined on the news. [Page A1.]

headline: FleetBoston Expects to Pay U.S. $59 Million
abstract: FleetBoston Financial expects to pay $59.4 million to settle Securities and Exchange Commission charges of trading abuses by its New York Stock Exchange market-making unit (S)

headline: The Pull of Pork
abstract: Larry Penner letter on Feb 8 article on calm in bond market and elsewhere about budget deficit; scores Republicans and Democrats in Congress for greasing wheels of their re-election drives by loading up budget with pork-barrel projects

headline: Verizon Wireless Announces Finalists in Creative Review
abstract: Verizon Wireless Picks.

headline: Aristide, Speaking to Reporters, Denounces 'Political Abduction'
abstract: Exiled Haitian Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide, in first public appearance since arriving in Central African Republic, urges supporters to peacefully resist what he calls his 'political abduction' by United States, news conference; says he is victim of American-driven coup; recants his earlier charge that he is being held prisoner; his lawyer reportedly says he plans to sue US and France for kidnapping him (M)

headline: Business People; Who Picks the Critic?
abstract: Investors' lawsuit charges that Howard G Capek, former UBS research analyst, was hand-picked by Richard M Scrushy, founder and former chairman of HealthSouth, to cover his company; Capek was last analyst to remain bullish on HealthSouth, whose executives were found last year to have engaged in sweeping accounting fraud; Capek's lawyer says Capek was unaware of any fraud at HealthSouth (S)

headline: World Business
abstract: ASIA.

headline: Canada Lowers Its Key Interest Rate
abstract: Bank of Canada lowers its benchmark interest rate from 2.5 percent to 2.25 percent, underlining pressure on biggest trading partners of US to counteract dampening effect their strong currencies are having on their domestic economic growth; much of slowdown in Canada has been ascribed to shrinking exports, chiefly caused by 22 percent appreciation of Canadian dollar against American dollar in 2003; consumer spending has also slumped in recent months; graph (M)

headline: Defied in Vote, Disney Leader Loses One Post
abstract: In a remarkable vote of defiance against a once unassailable executive, shareholders owning an estimated 43 percent of the Walt Disney Company declined on Wednesday to support the re-election of Michael D. Eisner, the chairman and chief executive, to the board.    The mounting shareholder dissent prodded the board to strip Mr. Eisner of the chairman's title Wednesday night and give it to George J. Mitchell, Disney's presiding director and a former senator. Disney board members hope the split of the chairman and chief executive titles will pacify investors disgruntled about an underperforming stock price and Mr. Eisner's autocratic management style, according to three people close to the board's deliberations.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 10 on Jerusalem Bus
abstract: The attack came as a top U.S. diplomat visited the region and a day after Israeli forces killed 9 Palestinians in Gaza.

headline: At Least 40 In Pakistan Die in Attack On Holy Day
abstract: Three assailants lob grenades and spray bullets at procession of Shiite Muslim worshipers marking holy day in Quetta, Pakistan, killing at least 40 people and wounding over 150 others; two of attackers then blow themselves up in crowd; third is captured; fighting breaks out between Sunnis and Shiites in city, with angry Shiites ransacking shops and setting cars and public property on fire; police and paramilitary forces impose curfew; one Shiite is killed and several hurt in exchange of gunfire between members of two sects in Mandi Bahauddin (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Cancels Bond Sale
abstract: Japan's UFJ Holdings cancels planned bond sale amid reports financial regulators are investigating way bank classifies its nonperforming loans; graph (S)

headline: Ex-Arista Chief Is Said to Talk With Def Jam
abstract: Antonio Reid, former chief executive of Arista Records, is reportedly in negotiations to join Island Def Jam Music Group as chief executive (S)

headline: Sharp gains follow 2-year losing streak : U.S. economy's strength lifts dollar
abstract: LONDON:—  A resurgent dollar has risen to its highest level against the yen since November as traders turn their attention back to signs of strength in the U.S. economy and of persistent weakness elsewhere.

headline: At Least 18 Killed in Bomb Attack in Baghdad
abstract: A large car bomb exploded near the U.S. occupation headquarters in Baghdad today, killing at least 16 Iraqis and two employees of the U.S. Department of Defense.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Big Polio Immunization Campaign
abstract: Massive house-to-house polio immunization campaign by World Health Organization begins in Nigeria and Niger and will expand to immunize 63 million children in 10 countries; polio has recently spread from Kano region of Nigeria, where Islamic leaders halted immunization because they believe polio vaccine causes sterilization in girls; WHO is optimistic Kano will participate in current program (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Securities Fraud Charge Thrown Out in Stewart Case  Dealing a setback to prosecutors in the Martha Stewart case, the judge overseeing the trial threw out the charge of securities fraud, the most serious one against her. Judge Miriam Goldman Cedarbaum of Federal District Court in Manhattan wrote in a 23-page opinion that ''a reasonable juror could not, without resorting to speculation and surmise, find beyond a reasonable doubt'' that Ms. Stewart was guilty of the charge.    Closing arguments in the case are expected to begin Monday, with the final version of the instructions to be read to jurors on Wednesday. [Page A1.]

headline: Powell Wants Pakistani Help In Chasing Taliban Remnants
abstract: Sec Colin L Powell, opening visit to South Asia, says in New Delhi that he will press Pakistan Pres Pervez Musharraf to do more to track down Taliban remnants on Afghan border and tell US more about his military's role in nuclear proliferation activities of A Q Khan; notes current thaw in India-Pakistan relations; photo (M)

headline: Group of Private U.S. Experts Visits North Korea Nuclear Plant
abstract: Private delegation of US experts arrives in Beijing, China, after five-day visit to North Korea in which they interviewed top officials and visited nuclear plant at Yongbyon (M)

headline: Oil Consultant Is Charged
abstract: Mercator Corp chairman James Giffen, oil consultant accused in 2003 of paying $78 million in bribes to officials in Kazakhstan, is charged with filing false tax returns that omitted $2 million in income; is also accused of conspiring with unidentified senior executive of Mercator to evade taxes by reporting only half of his $800,000 bonus (S)

headline: Pension Fund Trustees Taking Aim at Safeway
abstract: Four state and municipal pension funds will lead battle against management and board of Safeway PLC, which has suffered 60 percent dropin its stock price in last five years; New York State Comptroller Alan G Hevesi says management decisions have failed, news conference; Hevesi is joined by pension fund trustees from New York City, Connecticut and Illinois; group also says Safeway's board has longstanding conflicts of interest that blinded it to company mismanagement; Safeway spokesman Brian Dowling says there are no conflicts on board and Safeway management has become target because of its unyielding position in recent strike against supermarket chains in California; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Syria: Abu Abbas To Be Buried Near Damascus
abstract: Palestine Liberation Front spokesman Wasel Abu Yussef reports that group will likely bury Palestinian militant Abu Abbas near Damascus; Israel refused group's request to allow his body to be buried in West Bank; Abbas was mastermind of 1985 attack on cruise ship Achille Lauro (S)

headline: Iranian Train Explosion Kills at Least 195
abstract: Runaway train carrying chemicals and fuel derails near Neyshabur, Iran, setting off fire and explosion that kills at least 195 people and injures hundreds more; Interior Ministry sends team to investigate, but rules out sabotage; firefighters and local officials who rushed to scene are among dead; map; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: PanAmSat To Transmit Fox Programming
abstract: PanAmSat Corp will transmit programming for News Corp's Fox television networks, raising speculation that News Corp will sell its controlling stake in PanAmSat (S)

headline: Seinfeld and Superman join forces again in spots for American Express, this time on the Web.
abstract: American Express Co reteams Superman with Jerry Seinfeld for Web-only ads; agency is Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide; movie-director Barry Levison makes his advertising debut directing two Superman-Seinfeld shorts; photo (M)

headline: C.I.A. Says Russia Could Try to Reassert Itself After a Putin Victory
abstract: Central Intelligence Agency and Defense Intelligence Agency suggest that Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin's expected election victory will make Russia more assertive in attempts to reclaim great power status; Putin has consolidated power, pushed war in Chechnya and is taking greater interest in neighboring countries like Georgia and Ukraine; CIA director George Tenet still characterizes Russia's relations with US as 'more cooperative than not', but expresses concerns about government's strengthened oversight of oil sector (M)

headline: With a Recovering Economy, The Day of the Big Deal Is Back
abstract: Big merger deals are on upswing again as economy revives; investment banks and law firms are not hiring in droves yet, but sense that heady days are here is giving lift to stocks and spurring speculation about all kinds of deals that would not have been possible year ago; executives and bankers credit renewed confidence; some experts argue confidence is misplaced; graph and table of merger deals (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Economy Stalls
abstract: Canada's gross domestic product was unchanged in November from previous month; economy grew 1.8 perent in first 11 months of 2003, compared with period year ago (S)

headline: U.S. Proposes Rules to End Tax-Avoidance Transactions
abstract: US Treasury moves to make it more difficult for large corporations to hide abusive tax-avoidance transactions; proposes new rules governing differences between profits that companies report to shareholders and (usually smaller) figures they report on their tax returns; Treasury and Internal Revenue Service officials say proposed changes should cut down on number of tax audits of corporations whose returns turn out to be acceptable as filed (M)

headline: Bank Service Convicted Of Illegal Transfers
abstract: Beacon Hill Service Corp is convicted of illegally receiving and transferring billions of dollars from shell companies, private investors and exchange houses to offshore accounts, cheating government out of millions of dollars; Beacon Hill shut down in February 2003 after officials from Manhattan district attorney's office said they obtained search warrant and found that company had been illegally tranferring money abroad for years (M)

headline: Gunfight in the Gaza Strip
abstract: Palestinian residents say Israeli forces operating in Rafah, in southern Gaza Strip, shot and killed Palestinian woman and wounded two of her family members; Israeli military says it came under fire from Palestinian gunmen and shot back (S)

headline: A Life Of Boots And Blades
abstract: Rich Liebenow My Job article on his career selling ice skates; photo (M)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Higher prices for domain names are one more hopeful sign that the economy may be turning around a bit.
abstract: Dot-com domain names are again commanding respectable prices after more than three years of attracting scant interest; rising prices not only help sellers of domain names but also industry that supports use of domain names; uptick seems to follow economic turnaround that US and rest of world is starting to see; is also helped by improving Internet economy; photo (M)

headline: Strong Credit Card Portfolio Helps Spur Citigroup Profit
abstract: Fourth-quarter profit at Citigroup nearly doubled on strength of its credit card business and low litigation costs; net income was $4.76 billion, up 96 percent from $2.43 billion year earlier; revenue rose 13 percent, to $20.2 billion; bank announces 14 percent dividend increase, to 40 cents per share; chief executive Charles O Prince comments (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Seized Plane Adds To Coup Jitters
abstract: Zimbabwe, Equatorial Guinea and South Africa investigate background of plane recently detained in Zimbabwe; Equatorial Guinea claims plane's occupants are part of failed coup attempt (S)

headline: An Interim President for Haiti Is Sworn In
