abstract: Boniface Alexandre is installed as Haiti's interim president as hundreds of supporters of exiled Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide march through Port-au-Prince demanding Aristide's return; Alexandre appeals for unity; seven-member council set up to restore civil authority under Caribbean Community plan interviews candidates for prime minister; United States Amb James B Foley deplores death of opposition marchers and foreign journalist attacked by pro-Aristide gunmen; lauds response by US marines and French troops; says city's security situation is rapidly improving; Haiti's new police chief, Leon Charles, cites disarming militants on both sides as key priority, interview; graph compares bribes paid to Haitian officials with government spending; photo (M)

headline: LEUCADIA REVISES TAKEOVER BID FOR PLAINS RESOURCES
abstract: Leucadia Revises Takeover Bid for Pla

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Feb 1 article: Deutsche Bank

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: SAP Revenue Falls
abstract: German software maker SAP warns that its revenue declined 3 percent in fourth quarter compared with period year earlier, but that it is slightly better than analysts expected (S)

headline: Powell, Back After Surgery, Defends His Call for Iraq War
abstract: In a rare, wide-ranging news conference, the secretary of state addressed new criticism even as some American weapons inspectors have left Iraq empty-handed.

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Long Island; Well-Situated Large Property Is Breaking Old Price Levels
abstract: Commercial real estate brokers are optimistic that sales on Long Island will continue to increase this year, following pattern of 2003, when seeral large properties changed hands at significantly rising prices; Long Island buildings in 2003 containing three million square feet of office space sold for total of $470 million--increase from 2002, when 1.8 million square feet sold for total of $252 million; photo (M)

headline: SMITHFIELD INVESTS IN SPANISH MEAT PROCESSOR
abstract: Smithfield Foods Inc, world's biggest pork producer, buys 15 percent stake in Campofrio Alimentacion, Spain's biggest meat processor, for 69.8 million euros ($88 million) (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Lawyer Says Account Holds Parmalat Funds  An Italian lawyer provided new details about a Bank of America account in New York that he said holds 7 billion euros missing from the company.      The lawyer, Carlo Zauli, said Italian banks transferred the money to a Bank of America branch in New York for Calisto Tanzi, Parmalat's former chairman, and some of his closest associates. Parmalat said that Bank of America denied its branch had the account but that it would investigate. [Page C2.]

headline: 2 MIDSIZE BANKS IN TALKS ON $6 BILLION DEAL
abstract: Regions Financial Corp of Birmingham, Ala, is in talks to buy Union Planters Corp of Memphis for about $6 billion in stock (S)

headline: U.S. Soldiers Kill 2 Iraqis After Bomb Explodes Near Convoy
abstract: American soldiers killed an Iraqi man and a boy tonight and wounded four others in a car that was driving behind their convoy after a roadside bomb went off nearby.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: New Nato Chief Takes Over
abstract: Former Dutch Foreign Minister Jaap de Hoop Scheffer takes office as secretary general of NATO succeeding Lord Robertson; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hope For Credit Card Concern
abstract: South Kore

headline: The Weight of the World on Our Shoulders
abstract: Daniel Akst column says global economy's dependence on American market is more worrisome than outsourcing of high-skill jobs to developing countries (M)

headline: Pakistanis Clash With Militants in Heavy Border Fighting
abstract: Hundreds of Islamic militants and Pakistani government paramilitary troops fought heavily for more than six hours at a fort in the Pakistani tribal areas.

headline: BBC Director Resigns as Fallout Over Iraq Report Builds
abstract: British Broadcasting Corp director general Greg Dyke resigns in wake of report castigating BBC's journalistic practices in connection with questions about government's handling of intelligence about weapons of mass destruction in Iraq; hundreds of BBC employees walk off their jobs in spontaneous protest; resignation follows by one day departure of Gavyn Davies, BBC board chairman; critical report issued by Lord Hutton was political triumph for Prime Min Tony Blair, but backlash is developing over what some see as Hutton's blanket bias in favor of government; photos (M)

headline: Revised Rules On Mortgages Are Scuttled
abstract: House and Urban Development Department withdraws proposal to overhaul rules on closing home loans because of opposition from mortgage industry and consumer groups; agency estimated measure would save homebuyers $700 each on their loans, or $8 billion per year, more than sixth of $50 billion that HUD says Americans spend each year on closing costs (M)

headline: Washington's Arabic TV Effort Gets Mixed Reviews
abstract: Al Hurra, American-sponsored satellite television station broadcasting in Arabic, draws mixed reviews in Middle East after less than a week of operation; viewers find some appeal in mix of news and pop culture, but many remain wary of underlying political message; station is pilloried in Arab press as propaganda arm of US government, trying to gloss over America's anti-Arab bias, particularly with regard to Israel; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Serbia: Trial In Ex-Leader's Murder Begins
abstract: Belgrade (Serbia) trial begins for nine members of elite police unit accused of 2000 assassination of former Yugoslav President Ivan Stambolic; prosecution holds execution was ordered by then President Slobodan Milosevic (S)

headline: Profits Rise 47% at British-Australian Mining Giant
abstract: Profits Rise 47% at Briti

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Railway's Profit Rises
abstract: Canadian National Railway announces three-for-two stock split and 17 percent increase in its quarterly dividend; says fourth-quarter profit rose to 224 million Canadian dollars ($169 million) from 22 million Canadian dollars year earlier (S)

headline: New Searches and a Suicide In Parmalat Investigation
abstract: Italian authorities continue to investigate financial history of now-bankrupt dairy producer Parmalat, which collapsed amid accounting scandals in December, as well as companies which did business with Parmalat; police search offices of banks which had relationships with Parmalat, including Deutsche Bank and Bank of America, as well as credit-rating firm Standard & Poor's, which had rated Parmalat as 'investment-grade' immediately prior to dairy company's collapse; Alessandro Bassi, mid-level executive with Parmalat who may have been involved in accounting scandal, commits suicide by jumping from bridge; photo (M)

headline: Frequent Flier; On Travel and Matchmaking From a Woman in a Ball Cap
abstract: Frequent Flier column on air travel experiences of Trish McDermott, vice president for romance in San Francisco office of Match.com; photo (M)

headline: Your Taxes; Four Ways That Conventional Wisdom Can Go Astray
abstract: Advice on some common misconceptions about federal income taxes; cites situations in which so-called marriage penalty does not exist and spouses save on taxes by being married; notes many workers can take advantage of recently enacted health care savings accounts; discusses when home office is deductible; notes information people get at Internal Revenue Service walk-in advice centers is often unreliable; diagram for determining deductibility of home office (M)

headline: John W. Seybold, 88, Innovator in Printing
abstract: John W Seybold, pioneer in field of computerized typesetting, which transformed publishing industry, dies at age 88; photo (M)

headline: XO COMMUNICATIONS TO BUY MOST OF ALLEGIANCE TELECOM
abstract: XO Communications, telephone and Internet access company controlled by financier Carl C Icahn, wins bankruptcy court approval to purchase most of Allegiance Telecom's assets for $631 million (S)

headline: Ex-adviser says Bush undermined war on terror
abstract: WASHINGTON:—  In the gripping conclusion to an extraordinary two-day hearing on the 2001 terror attacks, a former counterterrorism adviser in the past two U.S. administrations said President George W. Bush had undermined the war on terror by starting a war with Iraq and giving the fight against terror a lower priority than assigned it by President Bill Clinton.

headline: The F.D.A. may ask drug advertisers to make information on side effects more prominent.
abstract: FDA asks makers of prescription drugs to have their advertising provide clearer information about side effects and significant risks that drugs may pose (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Governor Injured In Shooting
abstract: Jose Murat, governor of Oxaca (Mexico), survives ambush of his motorcade in which shower of gunfire wounds politician and two bodyguards (S)

headline: Pakistani Finger-Pointing and Denials Spread in the Furor Over Nuclear Transfers Abroad
abstract: Debate over who bears responsibility for transfer of Pakistan's nuclear technology to Iran, North Korea and Libya intensifies, with surrogates for Dr Abdul Qadeer Khan and Pres Pervez Musharraf denying charges of impropriety; Khan backers deny he acted without government permission; government and intelligence officials, speaking anonymously, have been portraying Khan as corrupt rogue; Khan and his allies, including secular and Islamist political parties, charge army approved transfers and that Musharraf knew of nuclear transfers to North Korea (M)

headline: U.S. Flies Home Large Group Of Illegal Brazilian Detainees
abstract: US flies home 277 deportees, about quarter of illegal Brazilian immigrants held in detention, under agreement between Homeland Security Department and Brazilian Congress; Brazilians rank fifth among those caught trying to enter US, behind illegal aliens from Mexico and three Central American countries (S)

headline: Loan Index Rose for Week
abstract: Mortgage Bankers Association's index of mortgage applications rose 4.9 percent, to 837.1 from 797.8 week before (S)

headline: J.P. MORGAN CHASE AND BANK ONE EXCHANGE OPTIONS
abstract: J P Morgan Chase & Co and Bank One Corp grant each other options to buy up to 19.9 percent of their outstanding common stock in connection with their pending merger (S)

headline: COMPETING BID FOR MOORE MEDICAL PUSHES STOCK UP 25%
abstract: Shares of Moore Medical rise 25 percent after SJ Strategic Investments tops McKesson Corp's bid to buy company; SJ Strategic offers $15 per share compared with McKesson's bid of $12 (S)

headline: An Inquiry That's Awash In Disputes at the Outset
abstract: Intelligence officials have reluctantly begun to admit that major overhaul could be in order in wake of their failure to anticipate Sept 11 terrorist attacks and misjudgment of Iraq's arms stockpiles; hope independent panel Pres Bush will appoint can offer them more help and less finger pointing; have often derided recommendations of such panels as naive or unworkable; are least upset by Rep Porter J Goss's stand that any new inquiry should look forward, rather than dwell on past mistakes; Sen John D Rockefeller IV and others want inquiry to take Bush administration to task for building what they call flawed case that United States needed to act quickly against Iraq (M)

headline: Russia Levels New Charge of Theft Against Yukos Oil Stockholder
abstract: Russian prosecutors expand charges against major Yukos shareholder Platon Lebedev day after Leonid Nevzlin and other major shareholders offer to give up their stake in oil company in exchange for release of Lebedev, billionaire Mikhail Khodorkovsky and Aleksei Pichugin; three are awaiting trial on charges including fraud and embezzlement; authorities also seek Interpol warrant for Nevzlin, who lives in Israel (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Inquiry Into Pneumonia In Army
abstract: Russian President Vladimir V Putin calls for inquiry into death of one soldier and hospitalization of dozens of others, who developed respiratory illness and pneumonia after they were forced to stand outside as transport plane refueled in Siberia (S)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: NORWAY: 2 Dead, 16 Missing As Freighter Capsizes; BRITAIN: Cases Of Infant Death To Be Reopened; IRELAND: Arrest In Plane Hoax; NORTHERN IRELAND: Power-Sharing Review; SWEDEN: Suspect In MinisterS Death Must Undergo Tests; FINLAND: Rigor Mortis On The Job;.

headline: Shares Hit New Lows for Year on Reports From Spain
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 137.19 points, to 10,102.89; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 16.08 points, to 1,104.49; Nasdaq composite index falls 45.53 points, to 1,939.20; US Treasury bonds rise; 10-year note gains 6/32, to 101 30/32; yield falls to 3.76 percent from 3.78 percent; graphs; charts (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Doner is named ad agency of record for Hotels.com and Lexmark International (S)

headline: Traders Who Bet on Deals Are Cautiously Celebrating
abstract: Traders in financial community who make their living by betting on mergers, buyouts and hostile bids are cautiously celebrating; what is unexpected is just how many of these traders, known as arbitragers, are on sidelines; perhaps

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Saudi Arabia: A Human Rights First
abstract: National Society for Human Rights, first nongovernmental rights group in Saudi Arabia, is approved by King Fahd; chairman Dr Abdullah bin Salih Al-Obaid will preside over 42 member group, which includes 10 women (S)

headline: Testimony on Tyco Bonuses
abstract: Donna Sharpless, Tyco International's former director of executive compensation, tells jurors that most of bonuses paid to former chief executive L Dennis Kozlowski had been deferred so they would not have to be disclosed to investors; says goal of deferring much of annual bonuses paid to Kozlowski and former chief financial officer Mark H Swartz was to make company's proxy more shareholder-friendly (S)

headline: 2 Lawyers Barred From U.S. Tax Court
abstract: William A Sims and Kenneth W McWade, former Internal Revenue Service lawyers who won case related to tax shelters by entering secret agreement with three of defendants, are suspending by chief tax court judge Thomas B Wells from practicing before US Tax Court for two years and Sims has his license to practice law in Arkansas suspended for year (M)

headline: Thrifty Camera Choice Works for Small Prints
abstract: Q. Two-megapixel digital cameras have become more affordable, but how large can their photos be printed and still look good?    A. A two-megapixel camera -- one that can create images made up of two million pixels -- costs far less than it did a few years ago. Canon, Kodak, Konica, Fuji and other companies offer two-megapixel models for less than $150.

headline: Strong Exports Bolster South Korean Economy
abstract: South Korean economy expanded by 2.7 percent in fourth quarter, its fastest pace in almost two years, as exports remained strong; economy grew 3.1 percent in 2003, slowest pace since 1997-98 Asian financial crisis; consumer spending slipped 0.5 percent in fourth quarter; exports rose almost 11 percent from previous three months; capital spending grew 4.3 percent; February unemployment rate remained at 3.3 percent; government is pushing for laws that would allow companies tax break of around $1,000 for every person they hire over next three years; graph; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Deere & Co., Moline, Ill., the maker of agricultural and construction equipment, said it would contribute $1 billion to its pension plans, using cash on hand.    Hain Celestial Group Inc., Melville, N.Y., which distributes Celestial Seasonings teas and Health Valley soups, said it had purchased Natumi AG, a German beverage and dessert company. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Economic Scene; With free trade, what goes abroad usually finds its way back, to everyone's benefit.
abstract: Hal R Varian Economic Scene column on how outsourcing of jobs in free-trade environment helps US economy; says money paid to foreign producers, whether businesses or workers, typically comes back home to buy domestic goods and services, thereby generating domestic employment; graph (M)

headline: Shell Sells Stake in China's Largest Refiner
abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group sells its 2.1 percent stake in China Petroleum and Chemical, China's largest refiner, raising $742 million (S)

headline: Ex-Leader of Japan Cult Sentenced to Death in Gas Attack
abstract: Shoko Asahara was found guilty today of directing the release of deadly sarin gas into the Tokyo subway in 1995.

headline: Ex-Chief Financial Officer of Enron and Wife Plead Guilty
abstract: Enron's former chief financial officer Andrew S Fastow pleads guilty to two felonies, becoming highest ranking officer at company to admit to participating in crimes that contributed to Enron's collapse into bankruptcy protection more than two years ago; also settles related civil charges with Securities and Exchange Commission; agrees to surrender more than $23 million in civil and criminal penalties; deal requires Fastow to cooperate with prosecutors in their probe; prosecutors will recommend Fastow serve 10-year sentence, maximum under two counts to which he pleaded guilty; Fastow's wife Lea, who was former assistant treasurer at Enron, enters separate guilty plea to single tax felony stemming from efforts she made to hide income that came from one of her husband's secret dealings with Enron colleague; plea agreement calls for five-month prison term and then five months of home detention; judge could still toss aside deal; Fastows are scheduled to be sentenced in April (M)

headline: American Commanders Say That Keeping a Lower Profile in Baghdad Is Their Primary Goal
abstract: American commanders in Iraq outline their new plans for patrolling streets of Baghad, saying main goal is to be less conspicuous; Brig Gen Mark Hertling says Army is closing down most of its bases in central Baghdad, withdrawing to outskirts of city; First Armored Division is preparing to hand authority for Baghdad to First Cavalry Division, whose members have been tutored in Arab culture; many Baghdad residents feel torn about new plans for lower-profile American presence (M)

headline: G.E. Signals a Growing Interest in Solar
abstract: General Electric to acquire major assets of AstroPower, largest American-owned maker of solar equipment, for $15 million in cash and estimated $3.5 million in debt; move is seeen in solar power industry as major vote of confidence in business; photos (M)

headline: H.I.V. Surge Catches Tradition-Bound Estonia Off Guard
abstract: Estonia is ill-equipped to deal with surge in HIV infections; nearly 4,000 of 1.4 million people are known to carry virus as of 2003; epidemic that began among intravenous drug-users is moving from depressed northern areas to capital Tallinn; $11 million grant from Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria will help national health institute establish AIDS-prevention programs; photo (M)

headline: Dispute Prompts Scrutiny Of Bush's Daily Reading
abstract: Highly classified digest that provides Pres Bush with his daily intelligence updates is being scrutinized within government and Congress after criticism that information Bush has been given on Iraq and other matters has not reflected broad range of views; Central Intelligence Agency and Senate Intelligence Committee will examine shaping and presentation of daily briefing; Bush reduced number of intelligence agencies receiving data, prompting complaints from senior officials in those agencies (M)

headline: Fastest Growth In 2 Decades In '03 Last Half
abstract: Commerce Department reports economy grew at 4.1 percent annual pace in fourth quarter of 2003 compared with 8.2 percent increase in third quarter; corporate profit was up 31 percent compared with fourth quarter of 2002; consumer spending grew at 3.2 percent annual pace, faster than 2.7 percent previously reported; Labor Department reports number of people continuing to collect state jobless benefits dropped to 3 million in week ended March 13 from 3.05 million week earlier; National Association of Realtors data show resales of single-family houses climbed 2 percent in February, bringing annual pace of such sales to 6.12 million houses in February from 6 million in January; graph (M)

headline: Liberty to Split Off Foreign Cable Business
abstract: Liberty Media, the diversified American media company that is controlled by John C. Malone and owns stakes in cable television systems and programming companies, said yesterday that it would spin off its overseas cable operations into a separate, publicly traded company.       Mr. Malone, the chairman and controlling shareholder of Liberty Media, said he would serve as chief executive of the new company, which will be called Liberty Media International and will be based in Englewood, Colo., near Denver.

headline: At Least One Iraqi Child Is Killed in an Explosion in a Schoolyard
abstract: Explosion in corner of crowded school playground in northern Baghdad kills at least one child and wounds at least three others; US military says cause was homemade bomb, but police bomb squad says old grenade buried in trash exploded while being incinerated and that second bomb found was far from school; photos (M)

headline: Be Prepared; One Possible Cost Of Mobile Technology: A Tired, Aching Back
abstract: Article discusses devices carried by Deborah Apton, producer for ABC News, when traveling to cover political campaigns; many reporters find devices that merge many technologies are better; photo (M)

headline: Business; In Search of Fine Art Amid the Paper Towels
abstract: in search

headline: New Sport in Hollywood: Watching Eisner's Fall
abstract: Watching Michael D Eisner stagger at Walt Disney Co has become spectator sport in Hollywood, where he has never been popular figure; people are watching carefully to see whether shareholder revolt that cost him chairman's title will go on to deprive him of chief executive's post; many trace beginning of Eisner's fall to his contentious relationship with Jeffrey Katzenberg and Michael Ovitz, both of whom were Disney executives before falling out with Eisner in luridly public fashion; Eisner has his defenders as well as critics (M)

headline: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC AND GUIDANT SETTLE STENT SUITS
abstract: Boston Scientific Corp and Guidant Corp agree to settle all pending lawsuits over medical stents they make (S)

headline: Setting out to break down barriers and to foster harmony
abstract: NOVA GORICA, Slovenia—  From a nearby hilltop, the collection of small houses, low-rise apartment buildings and scattered industrial sites look like they belong to a single city.

headline: U.S. Tries to Give Moderates an Edge in Iraqi Elections
abstract: U.S. officials are struggling to cobble together an electoral process that will favor Iraqi moderates for the handover of sovereignty just five and a half months away.

headline: FleetBoston Fires 3 Fund Executives
abstract: FleetBoston Financial Corp firest executives James Tambone, Louis Tasiopoulos and Joseph Palombo at its mutual fund sales unit, which is accused of helping to arrange improper trading; two unidentified employees at Fleet Boston's Columbia Management Group are also let go (S)

headline: A Palestinian Asks, Who Made My Son a Suicide Bomber?
abstract: Bilal al-Masri condemns Palestinian militants who turned his 16-year-son, Iyad, into suicide bomber; Iyad was seeking revenge for death of his brother, Amjad, who was killed by Israeli Army gunfire; Bilal al-Masri says those who sent him out on suicide mission should not have let him do such a thing, even if he asked; parents of Palestinian suicide bombers almost always praise their sons and daughters as martyrs and heroes; Masri's opposition is sentiment rarely voiced (M)

headline: Rebel Says He Is in Charge; Political Chaos Deepens
abstract: Haiti veered toward anarchy when a rebel leader proclaimed himself chief of a revived army and threatened to jail the prime minister.

headline: Business; As Newcomers Swarm, Sony Girds for a Fight
abstract: Interview with Sony Corp president Kunitake Ando on challenges Sony faces as technology companies seek share of home-entertainment hardware market once dominated by Sony and other Japanese companies; Sony, which built reputation on being first, must now play catch-up; Ando says Sony will leap-frog competition and develop new generation of products that few consumers can now imagine; photo (M)

headline: Job Data Provides Ammunition for Two Sides in Presidential Race
abstract: Latest jobs data escalate political war over economy, with Democrats charging slow job growth underscores Pres Bush's economic policy failures and Republicans holding Democratic president would make problem worse; leading Democrats, including Sens Tom Daschle and John Kerry, ridicule Bush administration for falling far short of pledge to restore healthy job market; photo (M)

headline: California Lottery Selects 5 Finalists
abstract: California Lottery Commission names five finalists in latest review for its ad account, with four-year contract and total billings estimated at $100 million (S)

headline: Pakistan Questions 8 Connected to Its Nuclear Program
abstract: Authorities in Pakistan question eight officials from its nuclear weapons program regarding allegations that nuclear weapons technology was shared with Iran; Information Min Sheik Rashid Ahmed says those questioned include personal assistant to Dr Abdul Qadeer Khan, father of Pakistan's nuclear bomb and hero in his own country, and two retired brigadiers; disclosure comes day after Pres Pervez Musharraf says country must convince world that Pakistan is not proliferator of nuclear weapons; senior Western diplomat says Khan himself should be focus of any inquiry, but Pakistani analysts say it would be political suicide for Musharraf to detain or prosecute him; photo (M)

headline: The Man Behind Grasso's Payday
abstract: Kenneth G Langone, who as chairman of New York Stock Exchange compensation committee approved Richard A Grasso's richest deals, defends $139.5 million pay package that forced Grasso to resign, interview; denies he allowed his friendship with Grasso to color his judgment; scores board members who endorsed contract and later turned on Grasso as furor built; holds interim chairman John S Reed has heightened tensions at exchange; photos; recipe (M)

headline: For the Newly Stylish Man, Magazines Off the Rack
abstract: Conde Nast Publications and Fairchild Publications plan shopping magazines for men, following on success of Conde Nast's Lucky, shopping magazine for women; Conde Nast's Cargo and Fairchild's Vitals will serve as guides to growing array of clothing and grooming products aimed at men, on premise that male vanity is now business, not isolated trend; some retailers are also responding, seeking to attract new generation of young men around nation who care great deal about how they look; are increasing advertising geared to men and rejiggering shops and merchandise; photos (M)

headline: To Save a Life or a Limb, Gently Shake a Minefield
abstract: What's Next column on new technology to find land mines; devices use gentle seismic waves generated with loudspeakers or mechanical shakers that thump ground; waves are strong enough to vibrate mines, but not enough to set them off; drawing (M)

headline: Your Taxes; That Out-of-State Shopping Trip May Buy a Higher Tax Bill
abstract: New York and other states that require residents to pay 'compensating use tax' for out-of-state purchases that would have been subject to sales tax if bought in state have added separate line to income tax form to alert taxpayers; cumbersome rules are part of growing effort by states to devise ways to increase revenues; many states have increased some taxes for businesses or individuals or added assortment of fees and surcharges; growing number are distancing their tax rules from tax breaks in federal tax system; sampling of state tax changes and their effects on taxpayers; graph of percentage of income taken by state and local taxes; photo (M)

headline: Rating Cut on Debt Backed by Musician
abstract: Rating Cut on Debt Backed by Musician**Ratings on $55 million of debt by Jones/Tintoretto Enterprises, backed by royalties of recording artist David Bowie, is cut three levels by Moody's Investors Service because of drop in music industry sales (S)

headline: Deal to Let MBNA Issue American Express Cards
abstract: American Express reaches deal to have its credit cards issued by MBNA, country's second-largest credit card issuer, making its first foray into Visa and MasterCard networks in US; agreement hinges on two-year-old court decision that Visa and MasterCard are appealing; card networks' bylaws prevent their members from issuing cards by rivals, including American Express and Discover Financial Services, unit of Morgan Stanley; American Express says Visa and MasterCard are stalling and that its ability to reach agreement with MBNA signals change is coming; American Express chairman-chief executive Kenneth I Chenault and MBNA chairman-chief executive Bruce L Hammonds comment; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Worried as Caribbean Nations Defer on Haiti Leaders
abstract: Bush administration voices concern over refusal by Caribbean leaders to recognize that country's American-backed interim government; skepticism of members of 15-nation Caribbean Community toward United States actions in Haiti is latest obstacle for American policy makers seeking to quell political violence there and return it to sense of normality; crucial part of effort has been deployment of American and other foreign forces; they have made significant progress in pacifying Port-au-Prince and Cap Haitien; Bush administration wants more foreign contributions to reinforce interim multinational force and then to provide peacekeepers and police trainers over longer term; so far, only Brazil has committed itself to providing security forces for second phase; photo (M)

headline: Which High-End Television?
abstract: Last week in this space, I wrote about the chic factor of plasma TV's.

headline: Mutual Funds Report; FOURTH QUARTER: OCT.1 -- DEC.31, 2003
abstract: All categories of sector funds rise in fourth quarter; largest gains are for precious metals; leaders and laggards noted; charts (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Audi of America, Auburn Hills, Mich., kept Enlighten, Ann Arbor, Mich., as its North American interactive agency of record, an assignment the agency has handled since 2002. The decision came after a three-month review by Audi, a division of Volkswagen.

headline: Business People; Welcoming Baby To the Workplace
abstract: Carolyn Gable, chief executive of New Age Transportation, which arranges shipment of products, lets mothers bring their babies to work and keep them in bassinets next to their desks; company has playroom for older children, if accompanied by nanny; photo (M)

headline: AVENTIS CLOSER TO U.S. APPROVAL FOR AIDS-RELATED DRUG
abstract: Aventis moves closer to US approval of its Sculptura wrinkle-filing injections for AIDS patients with related condition called wasting; government advisory panel votes unanimously to recommend Food and Drug Administration approval of Sculptura (S)

headline: Colombian TV Star Rewrites Street Children's Lives
abstract: Profile of popular Colombian actor Manuel Busquets notes that he is helping some of Colombia's poorest youths, former child soldiers of Marxist rebel groups, by teaching them about acting, directing and writing scripts; Busquets photo (M)

headline: Dead Falcon in Hong Kong Found to Be Infected With Bird Flu
abstract: Agricultural officials in Hong Kong report that dead peregrine falcon found near two chicken farms there was infected with avian influenza virus, in first sign that disease may be present in China; it is spreading in chicken flocks in Vietnam, South Korea and Japan; World Health Orgn officials describe scale of spread as 'unprecedented' and warn that disease could evolve to spread from person to person, and not just from birds to people; Thailand and Laos have also reported large scale deaths of chickens in last several days and Thai officials say they are testing three people for possible bird flu; WHO has confirmed five cases in people in Vietnam, all of whom have died (M)

headline: Ex-WorldCom Chief Pleads Not Guilty to Fraud
abstract: Bernard J. Ebbers, the former chief executive of WorldCom, pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges of conspiracy and fraud growing out of the accounting scandal that drove the company into bankruptcy protection in 2002.     Mr. Ebbers, 62, was brought to Federal District Court in Manhattan in handcuffs after turning himself in to the F.B.I. yesterday morning, a day after the charges against him were announced at a news conference led by Attorney General John Ashcroft.    Mr. Ebbers is accused of conspiring with Scott D. Sullivan, WorldCom's former chief financial officer, to conceal the company's weakening performance starting in 2000 and participating in fraudulent reports to Wall Street and regulators about its finances.

headline: Rowan Atkinson : Correction
abstract: An item on Jan. 2 referred to a report on an English Web site that the comedian Rowan Atkinson was being treated for depression in Arizona and was upset at the critical failure of his last film, "Johnny English." We fully accept assurances by his solicitors that Atkinson has never suffered from depression and has not been treated for depression in an Arizona clinic. We are happy to put the record straight and express regret for any upset caused to Atkinson.

headline: On the Witness Stand, Friendships Can Also Face a Trial
abstract: Does Douglas Faneuil have better friends than Martha Stewart has?

headline: Iraq Companies Seek Contracts At Trade Fair Held in Jordan
abstract: Representatives of more than 300 international companies and nearly 300 Iraqi businessmen attend three-day conference in Amman, Jordan, in effort to pick up pace of reconstruction in Iraq; Iraqi companies are desperate for business and chance to revive their battered country, but many are thin on capital, equipment and technology and feel they are getting only scraps from American reconstruction project; Americans and other foreign companies have resources, yet many remain hesitant about setting up shop in Iraq, which is still plagued by almost daily violence; photo (M)

headline: China Warns Taiwan It Won't Tolerate Post-Vote Turmoil
abstract: China warns Taiwan that it will not tolerate turmoil in Taipei, where hundreds of stone-throwing protesters are fighting with riot police in unsuccessful attempt to prevent official certification of Pres Chen Shui-bian as winner of disputed election; photo (M)

headline: Israeli Officials Report Secret Meeting With Libyans
abstract: Israeli and Libyan officials held a secret meeting in December and discussed the possibility of ties between the longstanding enemies, Israeli officials said today.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Economic Assessment Raised
abstract: Japan's government raises its assessment of country's economy and says economy is recovering steadily; warns that yen's rise against dollar poses risk to recovery (S)

headline: VALERO TO BUY ARUBA REFINERY FROM EL PASO
abstract: Valero Energy Corporation, a leading oil refiner, agrees to buy El Paso Corp's refinery in Aruba for $365 million (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: Journalist Killed
abstract: Bangladesh journalist Manik Shaha, reporting for daily newspaper New Age and BBC, is killed while reporting on Maoist insurgents and criminal groups in southwest part of Bangladesh (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Parmalat Rescue Endorsed
abstract: European competition commissioner Mario Monti says Italy's proposed new insolvency law for large companies facing bankruptcy, like dairy group Parmalat, does not pose any problems under unionwide government aid laws; new law allows for quicker procedures for adopting restructuring plan of any Italian company with more than 1,000 employees and debt of more than 1 billion euros (S)

headline: Job Growth Picks Up But Misses Forecast
abstract: Bureau of Labor Statistics reports that job creation revived in January after abrupt year-end slowdown, with employers adding 112,000 jobs for the month; this is job market's best performance since economy started pulling out of recession in 2001, but growth in employment is well under 175,000 jobs expected by forecasters, and short of 150,000 new jobs that economists consider necessary to absorb new entrants into labor force; unemployment rate declines slightly in January, to 5.6 percent from 5.7 percent in December; charts (M)

headline: Update E-Mail Software That Fills In the Blanks
abstract: Q. After I type the first few letters of an e-mail address in Microsoft Outlook, the program obligingly suggests a name. Occasionally the suggestion is one that contains an outdated e-mail address. Is there a way to update it?    A. Outlook, the e-mail, contacts and calendar program in the Microsoft Office suite, offers many features designed to save you time, including the automatic completion of e-mail addresses. (Outlook is distinct from Outlook Express, a free e-mail program included with Windows and available as a free download from Microsoft's Web site, www.microsoft.com, for Mac OS 9 systems.)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: SERBIA: Parliament Picks A Speaker; SPAIN: Outcry As Bishops Tie Battering To Sex; ROMANIA: Adoption Dispute With Europeans;.

headline: Jervis Langdon Jr., 99, Dies; Rail Executive Led Penn Central
abstract: Jervis Langdon Jr, top railroad executive during era in which industry was reshaped, dies at age 99; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Publisher Posts A Profit
abstract: Pearson says 2003 pretax profit rose 2.7 percent, to 410 million pounds ($766 million); sales declined 6 percent, to 4 billion pounds; net income was 55 million pounds compared with loss of 111 million pounds year ago (S)

headline: Let's All Gather Round the Screen
abstract: Rise in popularity of home theater systems discussed; big-screen televisions, video cassette recorders and digital versatile disks have changed how Americans watch movies and television, turning living room into gathering place where neighbors congregate to watch big games or special events; home theater has encouraged some to reconsider moviegoing habits, which is having small but adverse impact on movie industry; photos (M)

headline: Executive Life; The New Cost of Keeping Workers Happy
abstract: Prospect that economic upturn could tempt more people to leave their jobs for better opportunities is leading many senior executives to plan new enticements and perks to retain workers; some say process has begun; note job applicants are becoming more selective and mentioning competing offers in interviews; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Economic Recovery Begins to Trickle Into Mexico
abstract: Mexico's gross domestic product rose 1.3 percent in 2003 and 2 percent in fourth quarter compared with year earlier; government is forecasting growth of 3.1 percent; many business leaders say China's low wages, lax regulation and government incentives are siphoning off Mexico's much-needed manufacturing jobs; Mexico's role as chief low-wage producer for American market appears to be jeopardy; series of investment announcements in recent weeks suggest that some version of that role is still secure (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Corning To Increase L.C.D. Production
abstract: Corning will invest $600 million to increase production of liquid crystal displays for computers and televisions to meet rising demand (S)

headline: Boston to New York: Four Ways to Make the Trip
abstract: Article on various modes of travel between New York City and Boston with creation of luxury bus service LimoLiner; descriptions of two round trips, starting in Boston on LimoLiner, returning on Amtrak's Acela Express, going back to Manhattan on Greyhound bus and making final leg home to Boston on US Airways Shuttle; photo (M)

headline: Market Place; A new act leads European companies to seek easier ways to avoid compliance with U.S. securities laws.
abstract: Europoean companies, worried about costs and restrictions of complying with Sarbanes-Oxley Act, are mounting drive to make it easier for them to stop complying with US securities laws; 11 organizations representing 100,000 European companies, in letter to Securities and Exchange Commission chairman William H Donaldson, ask for changes that would make it easier for them to stop being registered with SEC (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Novell Makes Offer To Linux Customers
abstract: Novell will offer to pay legal fees of any Linux customer that is sued; Novell's move is latest by computer companies supporting Linux operating sytem to shield customers from threat of litigation from SCO Group; consortium, led by IBM and Intel, is setting up $10 million fund for any companies that are sued by SCO; graph (S)

headline: Fight Against Illegal File Sharing Is Moving Overseas
abstract: Recording industry associations in Denmark, Germany, Italy and Canada announce legal action against 247 people accuse of illegal file sharing outside US, taking its war against Internet piracy abroad for first time; photo (M)

headline: Economic Calendar Expected
abstract: Today.

headline: Low-Wage Costa Ricans Make Baseballs for Millionaires
abstract: Rawlings Sporting Goods runs factory in free-trade zone in Torrialba, Costa Rica, where all baseballs are made for major leagues; factory makes about 2.2 million balls per year and sells about 1.8 million to majors; workers are paid about 30 cents apiece for hand-stitched balls, which retail for $14.99 in United States; average worker earns about $2,750 per year, while baseball player in United States makes average $2,377,000; Rawlings, which was acquired by K2 Inc in 2003, moved to Costa Rica from Haiti 16 years ago; photos, map (M)

headline: In the Latest Numbers, Economists See the Cold, Hard Truth About Jobs
abstract: Economists both inside and outside government say jobs report that shows economy added just 21,000 jobs in Feb after months of rapid economic growth undermines Republican claims that unemployment situation is better than numbers suggest; Federal Reserve officials believe jobs are being created more slowly than in any previous recovery, and well below rate needed to bring down unemployment; are expected to delay interest-rate increase for at least several more months; debate over reliability of jobs data noted (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Bid For Canary Wharf
abstract: Group led by Morgan Stanley raises its bid for Canary Wharf Group by 6 percent, to 1.7 billion pounds ($1.3 billion), to surpass Branscan Corp; British Land Co agrees to join Morgan Stanley bid; graph (S)

headline: BOEING RECEIVES EXTENSION ON SPACE STATION CONTRACT
abstract: Boeing Co receives contract extension from NASA for work on International Space Station that could be worth $1.62 billion (S)

headline: Memory Evolution: Survival of the Smallest
abstract: Flash memory cards used to store digital photographs are becoming storage media of choice for range of other consumer products, including TV's, cellphones, music players, personal digital assistants and camcorders; some formats are losing market share as flash memory business grows, and analysts say a few will disappear altogether within next few years; flash memory's dominance will also be challenged by yet another storage format: mini hard drives, which are tiny, fast-spinning disks that can store multiple gigabytes of information (M)

headline: Iraq Debate Shifts to Expanding the U.S.-Appointed Council
abstract: The political conversation has shifted from whether to keep the Iraqi Governing Council to how to expand it.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Carmaker Strikes Continue
abstract: DaimlerChrysler and Adam Opel unit of General Motors are among German auto companies affected in seventh day of labor stoppages aimed at pressing demands for more pay (S)

headline: Slower Growth in Cable
abstract: InStat/MDR reports global growth of cable television is slowing, with number of subscribers worldwide rising by only 3 percent in 2003, to 332 million households, compared with 8 percent gains in each of previous two years; graphs; photo (S)

headline: E-Mail Worm Snarls Computers Around Globe
abstract: The new malicious computer program is spreading rapidly throughout the Internet and may become the largest ever outbreak of viral e-mail.

headline: Treasury Chief Defends Outsourcing of U.S. Work
abstract: Bush administration, still sparring with Sen John Kerry over issue of trade, says practice of exporting work overseas has little to do with loss of jobs in US; Treas Sec John W Snow says practice of moving American jobs to low-cost countries 'is part of trade' and that 'there can't be any about the fact that trade makes the economy stronger'; Kerry's spokesman Stephanie Cutter immediately pounces on Snow for tacitly encouraging companies that shift work overseas; Bush says Kerry would build walls around America by re-examining North American Free Trade Agreement and other trade treaties (M)

headline: 3 Banks Had Early Concern On WorldCom
abstract: Documents filed in connection with class-action lawsuit arising from collapse of WorldCom reveal that J P Morgan, Deutsche Bank and Bank of America expressed misgivings about WorldCom's financial soundness in early 2001 just months before they helped company sell $12 billion in debt -- misgivings that were not disclosed to investors who bought debt; WorldCom bonds recently traded at about $350, down from offering price of $1,000; it is up to courts to decide whether signs of company's deteriorating financial condition should have been disclosed to investors; banks all ended up losing money they lent to WorldCom after it sought bankruptcy protection (M)

headline: Schröder Quitting Party Post, Citing Need to Pursue Reforms
abstract: Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, facing disaffection within his own party and hampered by low public approval ratings, announces that he will step down as chairman of Social Democratic Party while remaining chancellor; says move will enable him to concentrate on economic reforms in Germany; will propose that Franz Muntefering, party's parliamentary floor leader, succeed him as party chairman; Schroder photo (M)

headline: Bashful vs. Brash in the New Field of Nanotech
abstract: Divergent business models in field of nanotechnology are exemplified by Nanosys in Palo Alto, Calif, and Nanofilm, in Vally View, Ohio; Nanosys impressed Wall Street with its team of experienced entrepreneurs, academic researchers and venture capitalists, its portfolio of patents covering processes like ways to make superthin wires and its research projects that could affect consumer electronics, energy and communications, but it does not expect to sell products commercially until 2006; Nanofilm does not have such business experience or such an array of patents, but it has been profitable since 2001, concentrating on new, unusually rapid way to make ultrathin, superrepellent coatings for glass, platic and metal surfaces; photos (M)

headline: Big Profits for Big Board's Public Traders
abstract: New York Stock Exchange says profit at its 234 member brokerage firms that do business with public more than tripled to $3.1 billion in last quarter of 2003; seven market-making firms lost record $135 million (S)

headline: In Philadelphia, Southwest Is Trying The Front Door
abstract: Southwest Airlines' advertising blitz promoting its upcoming Phildelphia service marks departure from carrier's usual tactic of establishing itself at lesser-used airports and attracting customers with heavily discounted fares; competitor US Airways, which emerged from Chapter 11 protection just 10 months ago, has responded by putting its own Philadelphia operations up for sale; Southwest's Philadelphia service, scheduled to begin in May, is also seen as threat to airlines servicing New York, including Continental and JetBlue, and has sparked concerns among carriers such as American and United, who fear company may have designs on another big city; map; photo (M)

headline: Money Flowing To Stock Funds At a Fast Pace
abstract: AMG Data Services says Americans put near record $40.8 billion into stock mutual funds in January, suggesting that last year's rebound from three-year rout has restored investors' confidence in stocks; some analysts consider inflow sign that investors may be too bullish, too willing to expect last year's enormous gains to be repeated; mutual fund data show many investors are jumping into 2003's best bets, like foreign and smaller company stocks, which have already had big runs; graph (M)

headline: Lebanon Resumes Capital Punishment
abstract: Lebanon resumed capital punishment in January after informal five-year moratorium; Pres Emile Lahoud, under pressure to execute Shiite Muslim convicted of murdering eight people, chose also to execute one convict from each of nation's other major creeds, a Sunni Muslim and a Christian, both of whom had also killed more than one person; human rights advocates and clergy members led protest campaign to eliminate capital punishment, and executions took place amid unusual amount of public soul-searching; photos (M)

headline: Killings of Vendors in Iraqi City Drive Alcohol Sales Off Streets
abstract: Recent attack by gunmen that killed at least five people on Basra, Iraq, street, is latest and deadliest in string of assaults on alcohol vendors in city where conservative Shiite movements and political parties are vying for dominance, possibly with aid of police; earlier attacks drove liquor store owners, both Muslim and Christian, to shut shops and take business underground; latest attack drives vendors off streets; mystery around attack continues to grow; police officers say attackers wore police uniforms and used two police trucks, raising question of whether police are working with religious groups to impose Islamic law on city; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Music Deal For Roxio And Target
abstract: Technology Briefing: Music Deal For Roxio a

headline: U.S. Drafting Proposal to Help End Haitis Violence
abstract: The Bush administration is drafting a peace proposal with specific steps the government and its opponents should take.

headline: Kabul Journal; With Future Charted, U.N. Envoy Departs
abstract: United Nations special representative Lakhdar Brahimi, one of main architects of Afghanistan's new Constitution, prepares to bow out after two years in job; Brahimi, an Algerian diplomat, has been loyal ally to Afghans since brokering Bonn accords in Dec 2001 for new Afghan order after defeat of Taliban; is personal friend of Pres Hamid Karzai, and has served in Afghanistan twice; was UN special envoy from 1997 to 1999, during Taliban years; photo (M)

headline: This Winning Streak Is Moving Up the Charts
abstract: Comment on stock market's broad rally; graph showing that S&P 500 index has now risen for 305 days without decline of at least 5 percent from any near peak, 11th-longest such period in market history (M)

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: CONGO: Boat Massacres Reported; MOROCCO: Writer Spurns Prize Over Illiteracy;.

headline: Economic Scene; In their hiring of teachers, do the nation's public schools get what they pay for?
abstract: Virginia Postrel Economic Scene column discusses two studies on teacher quality and pay; one examines how quality of women entering teaching has been affected by new job opportunities in other field and by rise in number of women going on to college degrees; other examines effects of changes in ratio of male and female pay across all professions and changes in level of unionization among teachers; photo (M)

headline: A Legal Approach to Music
abstract: Lisa Blackburn, second-year University of Michigan law student, wins Grammy Foundation's sixth annual legal essay contest with article on how federal trademark law can collide with First Amendment free speech expression when it comes to song titles; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Advertising account changes are announced at Enterprise Rent-a-Car, TJX Companies, New Jersey Office of the Attorney General and Gold Toe Brands (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)ú

headline: Investigation of Swiss Airline Crash May Widen
abstract: Andre Dose, who resigned this week as chief executive of Swiss International Airlines, may revisit earlier part of his career if Swiss prosecutors broaden their probe into Crossair passenger jet from Berlin that crashed near Zurich on Nov 24, 2001, killing 24 of 33 people on board; Dose was chief executive of Crossair at time of accident; Swiss investigators pinpointed pilot error and safety lapses that contributed to accident; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Car Bomb Kills One
abstract: Car bomb explodes in southern city of Vladikavkaz (Russia) as car carrying Russian military cadets passes by; one person is killed and 10 others are wounded; bomb has not been linked to Chechyan conflict (S)

headline: Bush Scaling Back Dollars for Third World
abstract: Pres Bush will scale back funds to fight AIDS and poverty in third world, putting off fulfillment of promises to spent more than $20 billion; hardest-hit would be UN-supported Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, which would get $200 million from US in fiscal 2005, down from $550 million (M)

headline: A Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 2 Iraqis at a Police Station Northeast of Baghdad
abstract: Car bomb explodes outside police headquarters in Baquba, Iraq, killing driver and at least two bystanders and wounding 26 others, mostly policemen; Gen Mark Kimmitt announces capture of Khamis Sirhan al-Muhammad, 54 on US list of 55 most-wanted former officials; two Pakistanis and one Turk traveling with supply convoy are killed near Tikrit; 62 Bulgarian soldiers reportedly have left 480-member peacekeeping unit bound for Iraq; Francis J Ricciardone is named State Department director of policy on Iraq (M)

headline: Retail Sales in February
abstract: Chart on Goldman, Sachs retail composite index for February

headline: The Cost Basis In the Haystack
abstract: James Schembari column on task of uncovering cost basis for tax purposes of long held stock, adjusted for splits; notes Internet sites are now available to do calculations at no charge if seller knows purchase date; drawing (M)

headline: American Group Says North Koreans Are Eager to Deal With West
abstract: John W Lewis, leader of unofficial American delegation that visited North Korea recently, says North Korea seems anxious to resolve differences with US over its nuclear program(S)

headline: Ousted Aristide Arrives in Africa, but Final Stop Is in Doubt
abstract: Newly arrived in the Central African Republic, Haitis ex-president today assailed the rebels who ousted him from power.

headline: Making Space for Ponytails And Many Shopping Bags
abstract: making space for

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: AFGHANISTAN: Kidnapped Engineers Freed; SRI LANKA: Rebels Warn Renegade Commander;.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Lucent Shareholders Approve 1-Year Board Terms
abstract: Shareholders for Lucent Technologies approve proposals to have directors stand for election annually and to allow board to enact reverse stock split at ratio of 1-for-5 to as much as 1-for-30; graph (S)

headline: Downstage From the Oscars, Awards for the Awards
abstract: Awards and Recognition Association is set to honor year's best achievements in field of trophies, loving cups and other tokens of esteem; R S Owens & Co, which makes Oscar statuettes, is nominated in four categories, including one for best new product engravable material, where it is represented by high-gloss plaque board; photo (M)

headline: MTV in Royalty Dispute With Producers in Europe
abstract: British and European independent record producers threaten to boycott MTV channels to protest 55 percent cut in royalties paid for music videos; MTV says it will reopen talks to look for way to defuse problem that erupted after it said it would stop broadcasting videos from companies that refused to accept reduced royalty payments; European independents regard royalties for video clips as significant source of money to promote often innovative music and little-known musicians; MTV does not pay for video clips from independent producers in US; photo (M)

headline: Music Industry Returns to Court, Altering Tactics On File Sharing
abstract: Recording Industry Association of America sues 532 people it accuses of large-scale copyright infringement; suits, involving largest group of defendants to date, represent third round against suspected file sharers since industry began its litigation campaign last summer; are first suits after federal appeals court ruled against industry's use of special copyright subpoenas to force Internet service providers to disclose names of music traders; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Hog futures rise by exchange limit after government report signals lower pig production in coming months; hogs for June delivery rises 2 cents, or 2.8 percent, to 73.775 cents per pound in Chicago trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: Chief Executives Planning to Hire Outnumber Those Who Foresee Cuts
abstract: Chief executives of the nation's largest companies say they are finally ready to begin hiring again.    For the first time in at least a year and a half, more executives plan to increase employment in the United States over the next six months than plan to cut jobs, according to a survey released yesterday by the Business Roundtable, a lobbying group. Thirty-three percent of the executives said they would add jobs, up from just 12 percent in October, while 22 percent said they would reduce the number of employees.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Cruise To Nowhere
abstract: Spanish judge impounds Festival cruise ship and strands 750 Italian and French passengers in Barcelona port; holds that Festival cruise line owes $5 million to European Stars for lease of ship (S)

headline: Do Dividends Help? Look at Interest Rates, Not Tax Rates
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer column holds reduced tax rate on stock dividends has not played much of role in stock performance; dividend-paying stocks in Standard & Poor's 500-stock index are expected to outperform rest of index in February for only second month since tax cut was approved last May; table of performance, by sector, of stocks that do and do not pay dividends (M)

headline: Bush and Schröeder Pledge Unity on Middle East Approach
abstract: President Bush and Chancellor Gerhard Schröeder said today that their damaged personal relationship had improved.

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: INDONESIA: Dengue Outbreak Worsens; MALAYSIA: Early Election Called; CHINA: DissidentS Sentence Cut; NEPAL: Rebels Kill 29 Soldiers;.

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: HAITI: 18 Months To Elections, U.N. Envoy Says; BOLIVIA: Miner Blows Self Up In Congress Building; CANADA: Missing Girl Found Dead; DOMINICA: Taiwan Severs Ties; MEXICO: Tycoon Who Set Off Mexican Scandal Held;.

headline: Hip colors are ruling hair styles as Japanese shun natural hues
abstract: TOKYO—  Caramel mocha, mocha tea, jasmine tea, pink ash, sugar pink — it could be a beverage list off the table of one of Tokyo's groovy Shibuya district cafés. Except that if you were to drink any one of these concoctions, you would probably meet an untimely end. For these are hair colorings and they are some of the hottest hues among Japanese women right now.

headline: Tyco Judge Is Known For Skills With People
abstract: Outside lawyers and other who know Judge Michael J Obus, presiding justice in Tyco International fraud case, says Obus's temperament is perfect for case; Obus has calmly encouraged jury to deliberate with goal of reaching verdict instead of issuing last-gasp instruction that judges use to urge jurors to continue to deliberate with goal of reaching verdict; photo (M)

headline: Quarter's Growth Rose in Japan To 7%, Buoyed by China Trade
abstract: Japanese economy grew at 7 percent annual pace in fourth quarter of 2003, bringing growth for all of 2003 to 2.7 percent; exports were engine behind growth, pulling Japan out of recession; crucial demand for Japanese goods came from China; 80 percent of growth in exports in last 12 months is due to Chinese demand; Japan's current account surplus increased 11.6 percent last year, to record $150 billion, aided by 33 percent rise in exports to China and 20 percent fall in Japanese travel overseas; unemployment fell to 4.9 percent in December, lowest level in two and half years; corporate bankruptcies continued yearlong decline in December, running 16 percent below period year earlier; bankruptcy debt was down 63 percent (M)

headline: Business People; Not Quite Nanki-Poo
abstract: Albert L Cohn, senior partner with law firm of Cohn Lifland Pearlman Herrmann & Knopf, will perform non-singing bit part in New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players' production of The Mikado at New Jersey Performing Arts Center; has served on board of troupe for years (S)

headline: Powell Asserts Saudi Bond Despite Rift
abstract: Sec of State Colin L Powell, in meeting with Saudi Foreign Min Prince Saud al-Faisal and Crown Prince Abdullah in Riyadh, repeats US concerns over arrest of critics of Saudi Arabian government; says countries' relations remain strong and free of tension; praises Saudi Arabia for its campaign against terrorism (S)

headline: Schröder and Bush find mutual interest : U.S.-German reasons to reconcile
abstract: BERLIN:—  Apart from the ruffles-and-flourishes overstatement of a too grandly named joint declaration — A German-American Alliance for the 21st Century — the White House meeting between President George W. Bush and Chancellor Gerhard Schröder last week opened a pathway to what, at the least, are more temperate and cooperative trans-Atlantic relations.

headline: Gaming With an Opponent Who's 'Over There'
abstract: Microsoft and USO have developed projects that are changing modes of communication between military personnel and their families and friends; Operation: Live Connections allows online gaming; America Online, Hewlett-Packard and VIDISolutions have developed VIDITalk, which sends video messages; photos (M)

headline: Cashmere Moves On, And Scotland Feels a Chill
abstract: At first glance, this modest town of aging textile mills set by a river in a bowl of hills seems an unlikely link in a chain of commerce that stretches from the pastures of Inner Mongolia to the designer boutiques of New York, Paris and London.    Yet, for many decades, Hawick and other places in the Scottish Borders region have traced the fortunes of one of the great alchemies of the luxury goods market: the transformation of the soft underfleece of a breed of Asian goat into cashmere scarves and sweaters, twin sets and V-necks bearing labels like Ralph Lauren or Chanel.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: SBC Posts 62% Plunge In Earnings
abstract: SBC Communications says fourth-quarter earnings dropped 62 percent on shrinking sales of telephone access lines and one-time charges; net income totaled $905 million compared with $2.36 billion; revenue fell to $10.07 billion from $11.22 billion (S)

headline: Thailand Brings in Troops to Fight Bird Flu
abstract: Provincial governments in west-central Thailand dispatched hundreds of soldiers and prisoners today to slaughter chickens in flocks infected with avian influenza.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    Today  None    Tomorrow  None

headline: 3rd Suspected SARS Case Emerges in China Province
abstract: Health officials expressed growing worry over the weekend about the possibility of another outbreak Chinas Guangdong Province.

headline: Profits Rose At 3 Big Banks In 4th Quarter
abstract: J P Morgan Chase & Co, Bank of New York Co and PNC Financial Services Group report higher fourth-quarter earnings; J P Morgan Chase reports profit of $1.86 billion compared to net loss of $387 million year earlier; revenue rose 21 percent, to $7.93 billion; Bank of New York Co's net income rose to $307 million from $100 million; revenue rose 15 percent, to $1.69 billion; PNC Financial's net income climbed to $274 million from $262 million year ago; revenue rose 4.3 percent, to $1.35 billion (M)

headline: Indonesia Cuts Sentence of Cleric Tied to Terror Group
abstract: Abu Bakar Bashir, who was convicted last September on relatively minor immigration charges and sentenced to three years, is likely to be free within a few weeks.

headline: NCR to Buy a Competitor
abstract: NCR plans to buy Optimal Robotics Corp's self-checkout business for $30 million, adding competitor's machines in growing retail-sales area (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Judge Says She Is Satisfied With Microsoft's Actions  A federal judge said that she was generally satisfied with Microsoft's efforts to comply with the settlement terms in the government's antitrust case, after the software maker announced steps to make it easier for companies to license its technology.      The judge's comments come a week after the Justice Department, along with 16 states and the District of Columbia, said the November 2002 decree had ''fallen short'' in nurturing competition in the industry. [Page C14.]

headline: Kosovars Survey the Damage of Ethnic Violence
abstract: United Nations says 31 people died in rioting by ethnic Albanians in Kosovo province, including 15 Albanians and seven Serbs; violence initially seemed like spontaneous response to drowning of three Albanian children, but now seems to have been well-planned and organized to drive Serbs from province; 2,000 new troops will supplement 17,000 United Nations police and peace-keepers already there; police and troops at riots felt outnumbered and overwhelmed, helpless to do anything but watch; Finnish troops helped rescue 300 Serbs besieged in homes; photo (M)

headline: KOS BUYS RIGHTS TO AVENTIS ASTHMA TREATMENT
abstract: Kos Pharmaceuticals Inc acquires rights to asthma treatment Azmacort from Aventis for about $200 million (S)

headline: World Business
abstract: The French catering company Sodexho asked the French financial market regulator to investigate a 3.5 percent decline in its share price on Monday after a report issued by Citigroups Smith Barney questioned a filing it made with the S.E.C. in the U.S.

headline: Commission to Decide Itself On Depth of Its Investigation
abstract: White House officials say commission Pres Bush will create to probe intelligence shortcomings will decide for itself whether to examine whether Bush and other senior administration officials exaggerated evidence that Iraq had large stockpiles of illicit arms; Congressional Democratic leaders, including Sen Tom Daschle, have sent Bush letter urging scope of inquiry include collection, analysis, dissemination and use by policymakers of intelligence on Iraq and that panel members be appointed by Congressional leadership, not Bush; Bush has lunch at White House with David A Kay, whose acknowledgments that American intelligence agencies overestimated Iraq's capabilities forced Bush to order probe; State Sec Colin L Powell says he is not sure whether he would have recommended invading Iraq based on what is now known about illicit arms, newspaper interview (M)

headline: Report Criticizes Effects Of Ads on Children
abstract: American Psychological Association is joining debate on potentially harmful effects of advertising on children by recommending that government restrict marketing to those younger than 7 or 8 because they are unable 'to recognize advertising's persuasive intent'; report's conclusion is that such advertising is 'inherently unfair' because children younger than 7 or 8 'comprehend the information contained in television commercials uncritically, accepting most advertising claims and appeals as truthful, accurate and unbiased'; American Association of Advertising Agencies executive vice president Robert O'Brien denounces report (M)

headline: Pakistani Scientist Admits That He Passed On Nuclear Secrets
abstract: The revered founder of Pakistans nuclear arms program confessed he had shared nuclear technology with other countries.

headline: In the Hall as a Lobbyist After Time in the House
abstract: Steve Largent, former Seattle Seakhawks wide receiver and Republican congressman from Oklahoma from 1994 to 2001, begins new career as chief executive of Cellular Telecommunications and Internet Association, telecommunications industry's main lobbying group; opposes increased government regulation of cellphone industry, whether federal or state; argues that wireless service is not sufficiently developed to provide 911 service and that industry can eventually serve low-income population less expensively without government intervention; photo (M)

headline: GEORGIA-PACIFIC AGREES TO SELL PULP BUSINESSES TO KOCH
abstract: Georgia-Pacifiï

headline: RedEnvelope, a Web Retailer, Is Too Popular for Its Own Good
abstract: Shares of RedEnvelope, which sells personalized gift items, often over the Internet, lose nearly third of their value after company says it will have to revise downward significantly its revenue and income figures for quarter ending in December because of its inability to fill December orders; company gravely underestimated demand and ran into inventory shortages, management problems at its Ohio shipping center and overload on its system for personalizing gifts; damage was magnified by fact that RedEnvelope, unlike other online retailers, designs many of its own products; this gives it higher margins than retailers who rely on large suppliers for mass-produced products, but deprives it of flexibility to meet surprise increase in demand; photos; graph (M)

headline: Israelis Approve $22 Million For Settlements on West Bank
abstract: Israeli lawmakers approve more than $20 million in new spending on Jewish settlements, mostly on West Bank; Palestinians see evidence that Prime Min Ariel Sharon remains committed to settlements, despite talk of unilateral withdrawal, particulary from Gaza (S)

headline: Israeli Invites Leader of Syria To Jerusalem, but Is Rebuffed
abstract: Pres Moshe Katsav of Israel issues invitation to Syrian Pres Bashar al-Assad to come to Jerusalem, but Assad rebuffs offer as stunt; this is latest strange sign that while they are still not talking openly to each other, Israeli and Syrian leaders seem suddenly preoccupied with talking about each other to everyone else; Assad has used Turkish, Egyptian and other channels to let it be known that he would like to resume talks that collapsed in 2000; Israeli government has used many of same conduits to let it be known that it suspects Assad is merely trying to evade American pressure; on another matter, Israeli government discloses arrest of Israeli Jew accused of using his taxi to drive suicide bomber to site of attack on Dec 25 that left four people dead; man, Ofer Schwartzbaum, settler living in West Bank, says he knew he was driving two Palestinians who lacked legal permits, but did not know he was driving suicide bombers (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Parmalat Testimony
abstract: Italian economics minister, Giulio Tremonti, calls for creation of new government agency to protect individual investors in wake of bankruptcy of Parmalat (S)

headline: French Rival Said to Be Considering Aventis for Takeover
abstract: Sanofi-Synthelabo, French pharmaceutical company, is considering making takeover offer worth more than $60 billion for rival Aventis; bid, if successful, would create world's third-largest drug company, behind Pfizer Inc and GlaxoSmithKline, and new corporate standard-bearer for France (M)

headline: UNION PLANTERS AND REGIONS FINANCIAL TO MERGE
abstract: Regions Financial Corp to combine with Union Planters Corp in merger of equals valued at $5.9 billion (S)

headline: Pedigree luxe for pampered pups
abstract: PARIS—  Opening his recent, and last, men's show for Yves Saint Laurent Rive Gauche in January, Tom Ford sent out his models accompanied by large poodles. It was a play on a quintessential idea of Paris, but it also threw an eye toward a trend that just won't leave fashion — dogs.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Court Blocks Proxy Tactic In Offer For MONY
abstract: Judge Loretta Preska bars Highfields Capital Management from sending out copies of MONY Group's proxy ballot card with letters recommending that shareholders vote against company's proposed acquisition by AXA Financial for $31 a share, a price Highfields says is too low; institutional investors like Highfields would like to use this tactic against management in proxy battles rather than go through complete proxy solicitation process, since it would make it easier for shareholders to change their vote or to vote for first time if they have not already done so; 1993 SEC rule has been informally interpreted as allowing tactic, and it has been used in other takeover battles without being challenged in court; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Broker Acquired
abstract: Japanese online securities company Monex will buy rival Nikko Beans in 47 billion yen ($440 million) deal that will create Japan's largest online brokerage firm; Sony Corp will hold 20 percent and Monex founder Oki Matsumoto will hold 12.8 percent; Matsumoto will be president of new firm (S)

headline: The Japanese woman's perpetual quest for perfect skin
abstract: TOKYO—  'Let's face it, we're not the most beautiful of women but at least we've got good skin!" So said makeup artist Taeko Mikami of her own Japanese culture as she celebrates 15 years of "applying makeup to the silkiest, softest, most unblemished skin in the world."

headline: Afghan Says He Didn't Resign but Was Fired From Cabinet
abstract: Afghan former minister Hajji Mohammad Mohaqiq, who is running against Pres Hamid Karzai in elections this June, says he was dismissed and did not resign as government announced; signs of ethnic rifts discussed (M)

headline: U.S. Sees No Rebel Role In New Haiti Government
abstract: Bush administration says armed rebels will play no role in Haiti's political reconstruction; urges them to lay down their arms and go home; says it will seek to reach understanding with political opposition and leaders loyal to ex-Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide; some Haitian observers say administration draws false distinction between political leaders, whose fortunes were enhanced by rebel assault, and rebels themselves; Rep Charles B Rangel charges Bush aided in 'coup d'etat' (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Premier Anxious To Testify
abstract: Canadian Prime Minister Paul Martin, in response to eroding public opinion for governing Liberal Party, says he is looking forward to testifying before judicial inquiry into Quebec public relations financing scandal (S)

headline: Seoul to await probe after report on North : Skepticism over gas tests
abstract: SEOUL:—  Voicing skepticism about a documentary program by the British Broadcasting Corp. that said North Korea was using humans to test biological and chemical weapons, the South Korean government said Monday that it would have to investigate before drawing any conclusions.

headline: 2 NEW JERSEY LAW FIRMS ARE EXPECTED TO MERGE
abstract: Partners at two New Jersey law firms -- McElroy, Deutsch & Mulvaney and Carpenter, Bennett & Morrissey -- have agreed to merge, the firms are expected to announce today. McElroy has about 130 lawyers in offices in Morristown and Ridgewood and in Denver and New York City. Carpenter has about 60 lawyers in its offices in Newark. Terms of the merger were not disclosed. The combined firm will be known as McElroy, Deutsch, Mulvaney & Carpenter and its headquarters will be in Morristown.   Jonathan D. Glater (NYT)

headline: FEDERATED'S STORE CLOSINGS TO ELIMINATE 369 JOBS
abstract: Federated Department Stores to close five stores in order to reduce costs; will shut Rich's-Macy's and Lazarus-Macy's in four states (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Rebels Kill 29 Soldiers
abstract: At least 29 soldiers are killed when Maoist rebels attack and demolish telecommunications station in eastern Nepal (S)

headline: Business People; For Toilet Paper King, A Constant Question And a Simple Answer
abstract: Pete Correll, Georgia-Pacific chief executive, says he is constantly asked how it feels to sell toilet paper; his reply is that it is a wonderful product; photo (S)

headline: HAUTE COUTURE FASHION : Chanel:Couture to the core
abstract: 'I want it to be very French in attitude," said Karl Lagerfeld before sending out his new Chanel collection in the tented grounds of the historic Bourbon Condé mansion, which the designer said he had chosen to express the mood of his show.

headline: Finally, Xerox Is Back on the Buy Lists
abstract: Xerox Corp has been put on buy lists of brokerage firms after four consecutive quarters of rising sales and profits and dropping costs and debt; Xerox chief executive Anne M Mulcahy comments (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: FRANCE: 3 Held In Rail Bomb Threats; RUSSIA: Yukos Co-Owner Faces Trial;.

headline: A restaurant known for its humorous ads hands that task to the New York office of a British agency.
abstract: Advertising: A restaurant known for it

headline: A Candidate From Russia Is in London With New Tale
abstract: Ivan P Rybkin, Russian presidential candidate who disappeared for five days before resurfacing in Ukraine, appears in London and offers another explanation for his bizarre absence; says he was drugged and kidnapped; his new version contradicts earlier statement that he was lured to Kiev on pretense of meeting Chechen separatist Aslan Maskhadov (M)

headline: INGERSOLL-RAND RAISES QUARTERLY PROFIT ESTIMATE
abstract: Ingersoll-Rand Co raises its first-quarter profit forecast becasuse demand is increasing, though it does not say in which markets (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Telecom Profit Rises
abstract: Telefonos de Mexico, Mexico's largest telecommunications company, reports that profit grew 10.3 percnt in 2003, to $2 billion; revenue is flat for year, at $10.6 billion (S)

headline: Announcement of Aristide Plan to Visit Jamaica Draws Complaints
abstract: Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Haiti's exiled president, will leave his temporary refuge in Bangui, Central African Republic, and fly to Jamaica, which has agreed to allow him to visit for up to 10 weeks--decision that has drawn protests from Haitian leaders (M)

headline: 10 Years Later in Rwanda, The Dead Are Ever Present
