abstract: Church in Ntarama, Rwanda, is filled with grisly remains of victims of 1994 massacre; caretaker Emmanuel Murangira himself survived blood bath that killed tens of thousands of people seeking refuge at school; photos (M)

headline: Putnam Paid $24 Million In Restitution
abstract: Marsh & McLennan Cos says it had $24 million in restitution and other costs in fourth quarter for Putnam Investments, its mutual fund unit; Putnam customers withdrew $53.7 billion more than they put in, about 20 times $2.7 billion of previous three months; managed assets declined $32 billion, to $240 billion, in quarter; assets are up about $1 billion so far in January as redemptions have slowed; Marsh & McLennan's fourth-quarter profit rose 21 percent; net income climbed to $378 million from $312 million year earlier; revenue rose 15 percent, to $3 billion (M)

headline: For Wall Street Chiefs, Big Paydays Continue
abstract: Wall Street executives continued to receive big paychecks in 2003 despite investor outrage; Citigroup's chief executive Sanford I Weill and Merrill Lynch's chief E Stanley O'Neal collected their biggest paychecks ever in 2003--$44 million and $28 million; Bear Stearns' head James E Cayne received three times as much in stock options as he did year before, receiving $27 million last year compared with $19.6 million in 2002; companies that reduced pay of their chief executives despite healthy performances included MetLife, American Express and MBNA Corp; American Express paid chief executive Kenneth I Chenault 18 percent less in 2003 than in 2002, despite 36 percent rise in its share price; J P Morgan Chase's chief William B Harrison and Goldman Sachs Group's head Henry M Paulson Jr each received $20 million in 2003; graph; photos (M)

headline: S.E.C. Said to Open New Inquiry Into Unit of Bank of America
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether one or more employees of investment banking division of Bank of America traded stocks in advance of ratings changes by research analysts; SEC is considering taking action against bank unit for improperly storing documents sought by regulators in connection with investigation (M)

headline: That Stock Purchase From Long Ago
abstract: that stock pu

headline: Three Marketers Make Changes in Accounts
abstract: Ad account changes are announced for Smokey Bones Barbecue and Grill, Rizt-Carlton Hotel Co and Baskin-Robbins (S)

headline: Shell's Top Executive Is Forced to Step Down
abstract: The top executive of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, the world's third-largest oil company, was forced to resign on Wednesday after an internal investigation into the company's surprise disclosure in January that it had overstated its oil and natural gas reserves by 20 percent.     The chairman of the company, Sir Philip Watts, stepped down less than a month after insisting that he would stay on despite a firestorm of criticism from investors over how the company handled the restatement.

headline: New Officers Chosen For Terms at Four A's
abstract: American Association of Advertising Agencies nominates Ron Berger as chairman, succeeding Ken Kaess; nominates Victor Ornelas to second one-year term as secretary-treasurer (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Move For Life Terms For Terrorists
abstract: Russian Parliament's lower house unanimously approves increase in punishment for terrorism to life in prison; change comes in wake of recent Moscow subway bombing that killed 41 people (S)

headline: Executive Life; For the Boss, Days of Sweat and Fumbles
abstract: New reality television program Now Who's Boss? shows corporate leaders working for five days in rank-and-file jobs in their companies; experts comment on how such exercises can make improve executive performance; several executives who have appeared on show say they have already made changes in companies as result of their experiences; photos (M)

headline: Loan Applications Rise
abstract: Mortgage applications rose for a third consecutive week as low borrowing costs helped spur refinancing, an industry group said.     The Mortgage Bankers Association said its index increased 2.8 percent, to 878.7 last week, the highest since the middle of January, from 854.5 the week before. The gauge of refinancing rose 5.1 percent, to 3,532.2, the highest since the week ended Aug. 1, from 3,361.9.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Lucent Credit Rating Raised
abstract: Lucent Technologies, which has had seven debt downgrades since 2000, has its credit rating raised by Standard & Poor's (S)

headline: Beijing Journal; Offended by the V-Word, China Mutes 'Monologues'
abstract: Eve Ensler's play The Vagina Monologues is prevented from holding its China premiere in Shanghai when Chinese propaganda officials order indefinite postponement of play; official censure was set off not by content of play but by word vagina, which appears in most standard Chinese dictionaries but is almost never printed in mainstream media; photos (M)

headline: The Tipping PointFor Safety
abstract: Danny Hakim article on driving car and sport utility vehicle on test track to compare handling in light of new federal rollover testing standards; describes driving vehicles with and without stability technology standard in both; notes SUV's are more prone than cars to rollovers and that rollover accidents, while rare, account for disproportionate percentage of occupant deaths; fatality rate graphs; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: FRANCE: Railway Bomb Threats Suspended; SPAIN: 5 More Arrested In Train Bombings; SPAIN: Protest Against Bullfighting; SWITZERLAND: Bishops Reject Call To End Celibacy;.

headline: European Union Says U.S. Faces $4 Billion in Trade Sanctions
abstract: The U.S. faces $4 billion in sanctions starting Monday because Congress failed to eliminate overseas tax shelters for exporters.

headline: Israel Says It Will Dismantle 2 More Settlements
abstract: The government also backed away from a previously announced plan to expand settlements in the Golan Heights.

headline: Call to Indict Sharon Ignites Political Storm
abstract: Israel's Justice Ministry confirms news report that state prosecutor Edna Arbel has recommended that Atty Gen Menachem Mazuz indict Prime Min Ariel Sharon on charges of taking bribes from developer; Israeli politicians say that politically, if not legally, an indictment would almost surely compel Sharon to step down; news leak outrages Sharon's office and ignites political storm around him just as he is seeking American agreement to his announced plan to withdraw soldiers and settlers unilaterally from most of Gaza Strip and part of West Bank (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Sect Sues Minister
abstract: Four members of Falun Gong, spiritual group, file complaint in Paris against visiting Chinese Culture Minister Sun Jiazheng for his alleged responsibility for group's mistreatment by Chinese police; Chinese President Hu Jintao is also in France (S)

headline: Life Is Hard and Short in Haiti's Bleak Villages
abstract: Bleak portrait of Haiti, which is slipping further into poverty and despair, where public health, education and economy have been collapsing for decades, where leaders fail to keep promises, and where even soil is disappearing from steep hills because trees are turned into charcoal; small isolated villages like Plaine Danger are insulated from armed politics of Port-au-Prince, but that isolation provides no protection from 200 years of bad government; illness is prevalent, as is malnourishment, and subsistence on one meager meal a day is common; international aid has all but ceased and even World Bank will not deliver further aid, concluding that it has little or no impact; photo; map; table of data (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: InterActiveCorp To Acquire TripAdvisor
abstract: Technology B

headline: Executive Life; Vacations Are Back, But in Smaller Sizes
abstract: Many executives have been reluctant in recent years to take long or expensive vacations, largely because of lagging economy; more are stepping out of offices for real breaks as economy improves; some feel they have gone too long without slowing down; photos (M)

headline: Equity Offerings for Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:      American Home Mortgage Investment, 10 million shares. Lehman Brothers and Friedman, Billings, Ramsey.

headline: Rifts Increase Iraqis' Fear For the Future
abstract: Foreign diplomats and allied military officers see threat of communal strife in angry clamoring of Iraq's Shiite and Sunni Muslims, and of Arabs, Turkmens and Kurds; say potential for civil clashes is there, as politicans and allied forces try to forge one country out of ethnic and religious groups with conflicting grievances; one flash point is demand from Shiite majority for swift elections; Sunnis, who provided power base for Saddam Hussein, worry that discrimination they practiced against Shiites could be turned against them; deadly riots between Arabs, Turkmens and Kurds have already shaken Kirkuk, as groups battle for property and primacy; widespread fear that neighboring countries want to destabilize Iraq was underscored when American officials disclosed document they seized in Baghdad asking Al Qaeda's leaders for help in waging 'sectarian war' in Iraq; photos (M)

headline: Iraqis Say Deal On U.S. Troops Must Be Put Off
abstract: Members of Iraq's American-appointed interim Governing Council say they cannot negotiate formal accord with United States on maintaining troops in Iraq, holding task must await next sovereign Iraqi government; delay means US may have to negotiate with leaders it did not appoint on such sensitive issues as when use of force is allowed and legal immunity for American troops; photo (M)

headline: Market Place; Good Times Roll On for Developing World, for Now
abstract: Developing countries seem more solid financially than they have in years; prices for their raw material exports are strong and economic growth is picking up broadly; global interest rates are low, but most current accounts of these nations are in surplus, so they do not need to borrow much money from rest of world; Federal Reserve System's Jan 28 statement replacing its promise of low rates 'for considerable period' with promise to be 'patient' before raising them sent developing country debt into financial swoon; frisson provided abrupt reminder of effect that tighter credit in US would have on economies of developing world; price of insurance against default on Brazil's foreign bonds rose 25 percent, to little under 5 cents on dollar, two days after Federal Reserve's statement; Turkey spiked by more than 20 percent, to just under 4 cents; graphs (Market Place column) (M)

headline: White Hats Take to the Web to Dispel Anti-Tax Schemes
abstract: Some tax lawyers and accountants are launching Web sites to counter newsgroups and other sites that are giving bad tax advice; Web sites noted; photo (M)

headline: Solectron Plan Rejected
abstract: By Bloomberg News.

headline: To Avoid Fuel Limits, Subaru Is Turning a Sedan Into a Truck
abstract: Subaru is tweaking some parts of its Outback sedan and wagon to meet specifications of light truck, mostly to avoid tougher fuel economy and air pollution standards for cars; move will let Subaru sell more vehicles with turbochargers, which pep up performance but hurt mileage and increase pollution; Subaru's strategy highlights what environmentalists, consumer groups and some politicians say is loophole in fuel economy regulations that has undermined government's ability to actually cut gas consumption; average fuel economy for new vehicles is lower now than it was two decades ago, despite advances in fuel-saving technology; federal regulations originally set less-stringent fuel economy and emissions requirements for light trucks to avoid penalizing builders, farmers and other working people who rely on pickups; that exemption opened way for automakers to replace sedans and station wagons with vehicles that fit definition of light truck, notably sport utility vehicles and minivans; photos (M)

headline: Tax Evader Pleads Guilty In Fraud Case
abstract: Jerome Schneider, leading promoter of use of offshore bank accounts to escape taxes, pleads guilty to one felony tax charge and can reduce his prison sentence by cooperating in prosecution of his clients; faces up to 24 months in prison under plea agreement and potentially far less if he helps in prosecution of his clients; court records show Schneider is suspected of helping wealthy Americans hide more than $100 million from Internal Revenue Service (M)

headline: Desktop, or Hand-Held? A Device Changes Costumes
abstract: Modular Computing Core by Antelope Technologies is stand-alone personal computer in 3-by-5 inch box; photo (S)

headline: At a West Bank Checkpoint, a Soldier's Duty Is to His Father, Too
abstract: Adel Hussein, illegal Palestinian worker, is expelled from Israel into West Bank, but his son, Israeli Army Sgt Muhammad Hussein, takes him back into Israel; Adel Hussein, with help of his son and ex-wife Stella Peretz, has tried for years to get permission to live in Israel; it is not known what effect his return might have on his legal case, or his son; map; photo (M)

headline: The Cable Guy Reimagined as Wireless Guru
abstract: Article discusses installation and maintenance services for home networks attached to broadband Internet access; services offered by cable companies and electronics retailers reviewed; photo (M)

headline: U.N. Official Expects Return of Millions of African Refugees
abstract: The United Nations said today that the end of wars in a number of African nations should lead to a mass migration home of people who have long been languishing in refugee and displacement camps across the continent.

headline: CERIDIAN SAYS IT IS UNDER INVESTIGATION BY S.E.C.
abstract: Ceridian says Securities and Exchange Commission is conducting formal investigation of company; says commission has requested documents related to its accounting and financial reporting practices (S)

headline: Shell Structure Has to Change, Investor Says
abstract: Knight Vinke Asset Management calls for changes in board and management structure of Royal Dutch/Shell Group; says members of supervisory and management boards control nominations to boards, excluding shareholders from process; says group is managed by committee at operating level, acting as deterrent to strong leadership (M)

headline: Now Playing on Your iPod, Words You'll Never Forget
abstract: News Watch column reviews iPod accessory iTalk from Griffin Technology; device turns iPod into voice recorder and downloads recordings when connected to computer; photo (S)

headline: Loan Office in New York Looks to Tap Mexican Market
abstract: Seeking to tap into the billions of dollars that Mexicans working in the United States send home each year, a Mexican mortgage finance company is opening a New York branch on Thursday to offer loans to Mexicans who want to buy a house in their country.     Last year, Mexicans sent home $13.27 billion, more than the country earned from foreign tourism. The money lifts many families out of poverty and in some regions is the only source of income.

headline: Israel Will Not Join In Hearing in Hague
abstract: Israel says it will not take part in hearing at International Court of Justice on legality of contentious separation barrier under construction in West Bank; says court has no authority to discuss barrier, since it concerns Israel's basic right of self-defense against terrorism (S)

headline: S.& P. 500 Index Reaches Its Highest Level Since 2002
abstract: Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 1.45 points, or 0.1 percent, to 1,123.67; Nasdaq composite index adds 10.01 points, or 0.5 percent, to 2,057.37; Dow Jones industrial average declines 5.41 points, or 0.1 percent, to 10,538.66; US Treasury prices rise; price of benchmark 10-year note climbs 28/32, to 99 27/32; yield declines to 4.27 percent from 4.38 percent; graphs; charts (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Profit At Refiner
abstract: Indian petrochemical maker Reliance Industries reports 27 percent increase in quarterly profit; net profit rose to 13.74 rupees ($304 million) in quarter ended Dec 31, from 10.83 rupees ($240 million) year earlier (S)

headline: Justice Dept. Opens Inquiry Into Shell Oil
abstract: Justice Department opens inquiry into whether executives at Royal Dutch/Shell Group violated any laws by failing to disclose in timely fashion significantly shortfall in proven reserves of oil and natural gas; company and its executives are already focus of probes by European regulators and officials from Securities and Exchange Commission; Justice Department, unlike commission, has authority to bring criminal charges as well as civil ones; British and Dutch regulators are also examining company; company lowered its estimates of proven oil and gas reserves two months ago by about 20 percent, or 3.9 billion barrels; company documents from two years ago show current and former top executives were aware of significant shortfall in reserves and came up with 'external storyline' and 'investor relations script' that minimized its significance; chairman Sir Philip Watts and Walter van de Vijver, head of exploration and production, were dismissed two weeks ago (M)

headline: CONSECO SAYS IT HAS SETTLED S.E.C. ACCOUNTING INQUIRY
abstract: Conseco, which emerged from bankruptcy protection in September, says it has settled Securities and Exchange Commission probe into accounting practices at its former Conseco Finance unit (S)

headline: President of Delta Air Lines to Join Virgin
abstract: Delta Air Lines president Frederick W Reid is joining Virgin Group and will be overseeing low-fare carrier that Sir Richard Branson hopes to start in US in 2005; Reid's departure from Delta will be effective April 1; no successor is named; photo (M)0

headline: Ex-Accountant Testifies On Dealings With Rigas
abstract: Christopher Thurner, former accountant of Adelphia Communications' founder John J Rigas, testifies that Rigas pressured him into charging personal expenses to company and pushed him into taking out fraudulent $20,000 loan for benefit of Rigas; testimony clashes sharply with previous portrayals of Rigas as even-tempered executive who had little to do with problems at Adelphia; Thurner describes Rigas as man who played by his own rules, taking millions out of Adelphia in loans to finance family businesses and even defrauding cable company to get money (M)

headline: Cross-cultural training : How much difference does it really make?
abstract: VIENNA—  Before moving abroad, Alecia Myers and her husband Ken drove to Chicago to attend a daylong cross-cultural training seminar designed to teach them how to understand and relate to people from foreign cultures. There they learned about high context and low context cultures, sub-cultures, and co-cultures, the seven dimensions of culture, and increasing intercultural business competency. One year later, happily settled in Austria, Alecia looks back favorably on her cross-cultural training and tries to remember what she learned.

headline: Lessons in Ethics, On and Off Campus
abstract: Zino Vogiatzis letter on March 7 article deplores need to teach ethical behavior and values in business school

headline: Revamping Costs and Rising Yen Hurt Sony Profit
abstract: Sony Corp's profit fell 26 percent in October to December quarter, hurt by restructuring costs, stronger yen and declining revenue in movie and video game divisions; profit of 92.6 billion yen ($874 million) in quarter is larger than expected; sales over all rose 0.7 percent, to quarterly record of 2.32 trillion yen ($21.9 billion); raises its profit goal for financial year ending in March by 10 percent, to 55 billion yen ($519 million), because of yen's decline against euro; does not alter its revenue goal of 7.4 trillion yen or its operating profit forecast of 100 billion yen; chief financial officer Takao Yuhara comments; photo (M)

headline: Songwriters Say Piracy Eats Into Their Pay
abstract: Songwriters say they are also being hurt financially by illicit Internet music downloading; their incomes are more directly tied to record sales than those of recording artists, who can potentially earn substantial sums through live concerts and merchandise sales; songwriter Charles Strouse holds illegal downloading has had disastrous impact on profession, interview; hardest hit is Nashville, nation's songwriting capital; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: EUROPE.

headline: PFIZER SUES TO PREVENT SALES OF GENERIC PAINKILLER
abstract: Pfizer sues Teva Pharmaceutical Industries to block generic version of painkiller Celebrex, top-selling arthritis drug; cites unexpired patents (S)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: MEXICO: Lawmakers Want Registry For Tourists; CUBA: Police Search For Refugee Boat-Cars;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Satellite Concern's Profit Falls
abstract: Thailand's Shin Satellite reports its second year of lower profit and says it plans to sell $90 million worth of new shares in public offering to finance expansion and pay debts; says net profit fell 23 percent, to 1.08 billion baht ($27.5 million) (S)

headline: Your Taxes; Talking Simplicity, Building A Maze
abstract: Tradition of using tax code to engineer social goals and hand out favors, trend that accelerated during Clinton administration, has become supercharged under Pres George W Bush, who has introduced vast changes in such rapid-fire order that not all consequences are understood even by experts; three major tax bills enacted in three years have vastly complicated tax code, despite Republican pledges to simplify tax system; complexities include five different tax breaks that define qualifying child differently; photo (M)

headline: Annan Hopes U.N. Team Will Help Break the Impasse in Iraq
abstract: Kofi Annan also suggested that he saw the June 30 date set by the U.S. for a handover of power to Iraqis as only a target.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Lukoil In Iraq Deal
abstract: Russian oil companú

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Ivory Coast: U.N. Creates Peacekeeping Force
abstract: United Nations Security Council unanimously approves 12-month peacekeeping mission to Ivory Coast that will involve at least 6,240 troops, 200 military observers and 350 police; cease-fire agreement between government and rebels has become increasingly unstable (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Airline Posts A Profit
abstract: World Business Briefing: The Netherlands: Airline Posts A Prof

headline: Judge Says DaimlerChrysler Trial Will Resume
abstract: Federal Judge Joseph J Farnan Jr, who is presiding over billionaire Kirk Kerkorian's fraud lawsuit against DaimlerChrysler, tells lawyers that trial he suspended in December will resume either Feb 9 or March 11; gives two sides until Jan 2 to agree on date (M)

headline: Hamas Leader Says God Has Declared War on U.S.
abstract: The new Hamas leader in the Gaza Strip, Dr. Abdel Aziz Rantisi, called President Bush the enemy of Muslims.

headline: Israel Diplomat Defends Attack On Bomber Art In Stockholm
abstract: Israeli Amb Zvi Mazel physically attacks art exhibit at museum in Stockholm; says he became enraged over exhibit by Israeli emigree Dror Feiler and his Swedish wife Gunilla Skold Feiler that glorified suicide-bomber Hanadi Jaradat, who killed 22 people at restaurant in Haifa on Oct 4; Swedish Foreign Ministry summons Mazel 'to explain himself', while Israel in turn summons Swedish ambassador to lodge its own protest; photo (M)

headline: Cutting and Pasting
abstract: Prof

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Strong Sales Help Amazon Report a 4th-Quarter Profit  Better-than-expected sales, buoyed by a falling dollar that helped lift overseas results, led Amazon.com to earn $73 million in the fourth quarter.      Shares of Amazon, the once struggling online retailer that has secured a position as one of the best-known brand names on the Internet, fell as investors worried that the company's price-cutting strategy would erode its long-term profit potential. [Page C3.]

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Publisher's Profit Rises
abstract: World Business Briefing: The

headline: Sprint Seen as Jockeying For Place in Merger Game
abstract: Sprint's decision to combine its wireless tracking stock with stock of its traditional phone operations is leading to speculation that it is preparing to join in consolidation of telecommunications industry by becoming either acquirer or takeover target; chief executive Gary D Forsee has gone out of his way to say Sprint is well positioned to compete as stand-alone company; some Wall Street analysts say move also puts relatively weak Sprint in much better position to participate in deal (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Ministers Dismissed
abstract: Sri Lankan President Chandrika Kumaratunga dismisses 39 junior ministers just days after she dissolved Parliament and set new elections for April 2; ministers are allied with presidential rival Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe; photo (S)

headline: An Oops Button, or a Tool for Retrieving That E-Mail Note You Sent
abstract: New e-mail service called BigString allows subscribers to retrieve, edit or delete sent e-mail; recipient sees only final version (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: FRANCE: Senate Passes Ban On Religious Symbols; FINLAND: Ex-Premier Goes On Trial; GERMANY: Court Orders Controls On Bugging; SWITZERLAND: Pardon For A Woman Who Saved Jews; BRITAIN: Gay American Bishop Pulls Out Of Debate; BRITAIN: Life On Mars? You Can Wonder But No Wagering;.

headline: India and Kashmir Separatists Begin Talks on Ending Strife
abstract: Senior Indian officials and separatist political leaders from Kashmir hold talks for first time in 14 years on how to end insurgency that has killed as many as 80,000 people since 1989 and brought India and Pakistan to brink of war; talks are held in New Delhi, and both sides say talks are good beginning (S)

headline: Steven H. Bazerman, 63; Extended Intellectual Property Law
abstract: Steven H Bazerman, lawyer specializing in intellectual property, dies at age 63; (M)

headline: In Hussein's Shadow, New Iraqi Army Strives to Be Both New and Iraqi
abstract: New Iraqi army recruits march past rows of saluting American officers, to tune of Colonel Bogey March; photo; map; scene at huge Taji base, onetime symbol of Saddam Hussein's yearning for conquest, strains credulity of onlookers (M)

headline: Family-Dominated Comcast Good at Pleasing Investors
abstract: Family-dominated Comcast Corp, which has made bid for Walt Disney Co, is welcomed by investors, but family's voting structure, and ties linking some outside diretors to company, has earned Comcast 'F' by governance research group Corporate Library; big investors seem quite comfortable with Roberts family's clout; Comcast's chief exective is Brian L Roberts and founder is Ralph Roberts; photo (M)

headline: India's Leader Plans Election As a Mandate For His Party
abstract: India's governing party says it would seek to hold early elections with aim of securing renewed mandate for Prime Min Atal Bihari Vajpayee by Apr; party hopes to capitalize on both booming economy and new peace prospects with Pakistan (M)

headline: Radio Advertising Increased in February
abstract: Radio Advertising Bureau says combined national and local radio advertising revenue rose 1 percent in February from year ago (S)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: List of American service members newly killed in Iraq

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.S. Threatens Action Against Online Gambling  Federal prosecutors have begun a wide-ranging effort to curb the growing popularity of online gambling by quietly threatening legal action against American companies that do business with Internet casinos and sports betting operations situated outside the country, lawyers and industry executives say.     The investigation into the activities of media, public relations and technology companies relies on a controversial legal concept that the American businesses, by providing advertising and other services that support Internet gambling, are aiding and abetting online casinos. That gives prosecutors an indirect way to attack the overseas enterprises, whose operations are illegal here but fall outside their jurisdiction. [Section A.]

headline: Schröder to Step Down as Party Chairman in Germany
abstract: The German chancellor announced that he would step down as party chairman, while retaining the chancellorship.

headline: After Decades, Saigon Figure Visits Vietnam With U.S. Nod
abstract: Nguyen Cao Ky, former South Vietnamese prime minister, returns to his home city of Hanoi after 50 years; his visit has approval of Hanoi government, which wants to improve relations with United States; trip has aroused opposition among faction of South Vietnamese exile community in United States, particularly in California, where anti-Communist sentiment runs strong and where Ky has spent most of his time as businessman since fleeing Vietnam after fall of Saigon in 1975; Ky says he believes it is time for reconciliation; claims young men now in charge in Hanoi know they have to get along with America; notes Vietnam wants to balance its complicated relationship with China with better dealings with US; photo (M)

headline: XO Buys Most of Allegiance for $628 Million
abstract: XO BUYS MOST OF ALLEGIANCE FOR $628 MILLION.

headline: Fujitsu Uses Pay Cuts as a Motivational Tool
abstract: Fujitsu Ltd will cut salaries of about 14,000 managers to motivate them--and their subordinates--to work harder; company hopes to return to profit soon for first time in three years; is betting that pay cuts will push managers to rally rank-and-file workers in remaining months of fiscal year, which ends March 31 (M)

headline: CHIEF EXECUTIVE OF BLOOD REPLACEMENT COMPANY RESIGNS
abstract: Biopure Corp's chief executive Thomas A Moore resigns less than two months after Food and Drug Administration delays approval of its artificial blood product; will be succeeded temporarily by senior vice president Francis H Murphy (S)

headline: Plane Crash Kills Macedonias President
abstract: The president of Macedonia was missing and presumed dead today after the plane he was in crashed in Bosnia.

headline: In Brazil, Chafing at Economic Restraints
abstract: Brazil's business community calls on Pres Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva to loosen his fiscal and monetary discipline, which they fear is suffocating Brazil's economy; one observer notes that with country showing negative growth and inflation at completely acceptable level, insisting on high interest rates and strong currency will not do anything to get economy rolling again and create jobs; photo (L)

headline: VERIZON WIRELESS AND NEXTEL AGREE TO END LAWSUITS
abstract: Verizon Wireless and Nextel Communications end two lawsuits over walkie-talkie telephones and advertising; Verizon agrees to drop claims that Nextl misused prototypes of its new telephones and Nextel agrees to drop suit that said Verizon Wireless's advertising was misleading; still pending is Verizon Wireless's lawsuit challenging Nextel's right to trademark phrase 'Push to Talk' (S)

headline: Ex-Inspector Says C.I.A. Missed Disarray in Iraqi Arms Program
abstract: David A Kay, recently resigned chief weapons inspector for CIA, says American intelligence agencies failed to recognize that Iraq had all but abandoned its efforts to produce large quantities of chemical or biological weapons after first Persian Gulf war in 1991; says they did not detect that Iraq's unconventional weapons programs were in state of disarray in recent years under increasingly erratic leadership of Saddam Hussein, and they did not know that Hussein insisted on self-directing projects that were not vetted by anyone else, allowing wily scientists to fake weapons programs and pocket money themselves; says Iraq did attempt to revive its efforts to develop nuclear weapons in 2000 and 2001, but never got as far toward making bomb as Iran and Libya did; says Baghdad was working to produce biological weapon using poison ricon until American invasion last Mar; says Tariq Aziz, former deputy prime minister, said after his capture that Hussein had become increasingly divorced from reality during last two years of his rule; Kay says CIA missed significance of chaos in Iraqi leadership; photo (L)

headline: The Fine Art of Taunting the Gamer
abstract: Charles Herold Game Theory column reviews Sonic Heroes and Star Wars Rebel Strike: Rogue Squadron III photos (M)

headline: Increasing Turmoil on Jury Threatens Tyco Trial
abstract: Escalating turmoil in jury room appears to bring six-month trial of former Tyco International executives L Dennis Kozlowski and Mark H Swartz to verge of collapse after several unusual events, including hand gesture from one juror in open court that seemed to signal her support for defense; jury sends note to State Supreme Court Justice Michael J Obus describing its deliberations as 'irreparably compromised'; Obus denies defense motion for mistrial; case appears to be at impasse because of one juror who is holding out for acquittal on all 32 criminal charges against Kozlowski and Swartz, who are accused of stealing $170 million from Tyco by hiding details of their pay package from board and pilfering $430 million by selling Tyco shares after artificially pumping up their price; Justice Obus photo (M)

headline: ACTIVCARD CHIEF RESIGNS IN DISPUTE WITH BOARD
abstract: ActivCard Corp says chief executive George Garrick resigned in dispute with board over strategy after four months with company (S)

headline: Foreign Workers Assessing What a New Bill Will Mean
abstract: Pres Bush's proposal to allow employers to sponsor immigrants, including those already in country illegally, for three years or more to fill jobs they say they cannot otherwise fill could be boon to small businesses, but they have doubts about how it will play out; small businesses do not have resources large employers have to obtain visas for workers, and Bush proposal might be costly for small businesses; photos (Special section: Small Business)

headline: Interbrew Said to Be Near Deal for Brazil Brewer
abstract: Interbrew, Belgian brewer of Rolling Rock and Labatt Blue, is near agreement to purchase controlling interest in AmBev, Brazil's largest beer company, in complex stock swap valued at $12 billion; two companies hope to announce 'merger of equals' by March 3, when Interbrew reports 2003 earnings; graph; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: One Diana Rumor Down
abstract: British coroner Dr John Burton, who was present at Diana, Princess of Wales, post-mortem, tells Evening Standard that princess was not pregnant when she died in 1997 car accident (S)

headline: Employment Giant Discloses Accounting Problems
abstract: Shares in Switzerland-based Adecco, world's largest employment-services company, plunge after company says problems with accounting and financial controls will force indefinite delay in its 2003 profit figures; chief financial officer Felix Weber says company has found material weaknesses in internal controls in company's North American operations of Adecco staffing; adds Adecco is also looking into possible accounting, control and compliance issues in company's operations in certain countries; graph; photo (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    Today  None

headline: Compressed Data; Google Protests Give Web Site an Audience
abstract: Google, Internet search engine, claims trademark infringement by Booble, search engine for sex sites that mimics Google site; Booble says it is entitled to protection under copyright and trademark law because it is parody; cartoon (M)

headline: Investing; A Lender Hopes to Profit From the New Taxi Math
abstract: Medallion Financial Corp president Andrew M Murstein sees New York City Mayor Michael R Bloomberg's proposal to sell 300 new taxi medallions a year for three years as boon for company, which lends money to buyers of taxi licenses; sees it spurring interest in owning cabs, despite concern that it could undercut value of existing taxi licenses; medallion price graph; photo (M)

headline: Drug Company With No Products Raises $250 Million
abstract: Jazz Pharmaceuticals, year-old company with no products on market, raises $250 million from private investors, apparently record amount for second round of venture capital financing in biotechnology; financing is led by affiliate of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co; Jazz chief executive Samuel R Saks comments (M)

headline: China Aims to Cut Pollution From Scrap Metal Industry
abstract: China is laying plans for stricter regulation of scrap metal industry; businesses shipping scrap to China will be required to register with Chinese government by July 1 and get government approval; Chinese regulators have not yet said what standard they will set in deciding which companies may register; Meng Jianbin, director of international cooperation at Metallurgical Council of China for Promotion of International Trade, says scrap industry poses continuing environmental problem; graph; photo (M)

headline: BUSH BACKS AWAY FROM HIS CLAIMS ABOUT IRAQ ARMS
abstract: Pres Bush declines to repeat his claim that evidence that Iraq had illicit arms will eventually be found, but insists war was justified because Saddam Hussein posed 'grave and gathering threat' to America and world; lauds work of former chief weapons inspector David A Kay, who holds Hussein got rid of illicit arms well before war; defends Central Intelligence Agency, whose reporting on Iraq's arms programs Kay sharply criticized; many White House and congressional officials say it is obvious that intelligence reports on Iraq were deeply flawed; believe Bush will have to face issue; Democrats, including Senate minority leader Tom Daschle, demand independent panel probe flawed intelligence; Daschle and other Congressional leaders from both parties meet with Bush; photo (M)

headline: U.S. in Huge Troop Movement With New Unit to Find Bombs
abstract: Senior Army officer says American military forces flowing to Iraq would be more mobile and aided by first unit to be assigned to detect homemade bombs; in major movement, about 123,000 personnel will be sent home from Iraq and Kuwait, to be replaced by 110,000, mostly from Army; officers acknowledge that Iraq rotation, to be completed by May, presents risk for troops traveling across unfamiliar territory before reaching more secure bases (M)

headline: Men's Wearhouse Net Cut
abstract: Men's Wearhouse, the men's clothing retailer, has reduced fiscal 2003 earnings by 6 cents a share because of legal costs associated with allegations that it failed to pay overtime.     Men's Wearhouse said profit for the year ended Jan. 31 was $1.27 a share, less than the $1.33 reported earlier, after estimating costs expected from wage-and-hour litigation in California.

headline: Stocks Rise, but Interest Rates May Dampen Enthusiasm
abstract: Stocks rallied but interest rates moved higher, which may not be a positive sign for the equity market.

headline: Martha Stewart Is Denied New Trial by U.S. Judge
abstract: A federal judge in Manhattan refused to grant a new trial for Martha Stewart and her former stockbroker.

headline: Call In The Feds. Uh, Maybe Not.
abstract: Critics of federal law intended to streamline securities regulation that shifted oversight in 2000 from state to federal regulators cite failure to protect Washington State bond investors hurt by Metropolitan Mortgage and Securities default in urging state regulators, who had previously kept firm on short leash, to stay in oversight mix; debacle goes to heart of escalating battle between local and national officials over who should police financial institutions; Securities and Exchange Commission officials admit investors were burned by Metropolitan, but deny case represents regulatory lapse; rivalry between federal and state regulators has increased since New York Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer began probing conflicts of interest on Wall Street and abusive mutual fund practices; graphs of securities Metropolitan and its unit sold to investors under state and federal regulation; drawing; photos (M)

headline: The Collections / Florence : Florence 2004:A 1980's body odyssey
abstract: FLORENCE—  'Look how much space women took up!" said Stefano Tonchi, referring to the bold, gold outfit with shark's tooth edging and padded shoulder jackets pushing for room in the display area, as they once did in the workplace.

headline: WorldCom And AT&T Settle Dispute
abstract: AT&T drop its claims that WorldCom defrauded it of tens of millions of dollars in telephones; two sides agreed to drop multimillion-dollar claims against each other in separate matter, WorldCom's Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings; proposed settlement is subject to approval of federal bankruptcy court overseeing reorganization of WorldCom, which plans to change its name to MCI; AT&T sued WorldCom in September, accusing it of fraud and racketeering; bankruptcy court stayed lawsuit in October pending resolution of WorldCom's Chapter 11 status; SBC Communications and Verizon Communications say WorldCom owes them money, but neither has filed lawsuit (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Petrochemical Unit Sale
abstract: ABB Ltd sells most of its oil, gas and petrochemicals business to group that includes J P Morgan Chase, Candover Investments and 3i Group for $925 million (S)

headline: Market Timer's Quick Rise and Sharp Fall
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission has sued Daniel G Calugar for improper mutual fund trading, and New York State Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer may bring charges against him; Calugar selected managers with policies that he thought were loose enough to let him make short-term trades without incurring special fees or running afoul of securities laws; Calugar made $175 million on short-term fund trades, mostly in portfolios managed by Alliance Capital and Massachusetts Financial Services; also traded rapidly in Franklin Resources and FleetBoston funds; Securities and Exchange Commission regional director Randall R Lee says agency is still trying to determine scope of Calugar's trading (M)

headline: Aristide, Now in Central African Republic, Has Harsh Words for the Haitian Rebels
abstract: Jean-Bertrand Aristide, now in Central African Republic, says rebels who ousted him in Haiti chopped down 'tree of peace'; South African Pres Thabo Mbeki, one of Aristide's few international supporters, is denounced by domestic critics for considering offering asylum; issue in upcoming election may be charge that Mbeki has soft spot for shunned dictators (M)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: BRAZIL: Slave Workers Found On SenatorS Ranch; BRAZIL: Boy Returns After Custody Fight In Taiwan; MEXICO: Audit Of PresidentS Office Ordered;.

headline: Haiti's New Cabinet and Rebels Hit the Road
abstract: New Haitian Prime Min Gerard Latortue appears outside capital for first time, visiting port of Gonaives with rebel leaders; appearance is meant to encourage stability after months of revolt and years of corruption; Latortue vows to lead non-partisan government until elections can be held; officials have not specified how they will treat rebels who have been arrested, but promise series of public works to rebuild Gonaives; rebels refuse to give up weapons until national police department is strong enough to protect citizens (M)

headline: Anxiously, Shiites Await U.N. Word On Elections
abstract: Najaf, at heart of Shiite Iraq, anxiously awaits UN statement on feasibility of holding elections before June 30 transfer of power (M)

headline: A Funny Looking Keyboard Thats Very, Very Comfortable
abstract: Anyone who comes into New York Times Labs (as I facetiously call the cluttered, cable-strewn home office in my attic) always has the same reaction to the contraption on my desk. "What is THAT thing?" they inevitably exclaim.

headline: Putin Eager to Show Russian Gains In Meeting With World Bank Head
abstract: Pres Vladimir Putin tells visiting World Bank head James D Wolfensohn that Russia wants to use its higher profile as Bank member to illustrate gains in economic and fiscal situation (S)

headline: Aristide's Foes Given 24 Hours To Study Plan
abstract: Haitian rebels consolidate grip in Cap Haitien, sending truckloads of armed men to patrol streets and go house to house arresting pro-government militants; political opposition in capital asks day to consider peace plan offered by Bush administration and other countries; opposition leaders tell Sec Colin Powell their radical followers are adamantly opposed to allowing Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide to remain in office even in titular role; residents of Cap Haitien pillage and burn symbols of Aristide party, exacting chaotic revenge on government they say has terrorized them; US marines arrive in Port-au-Prince to secure Embassy; photos (M)

headline: Job Growth Stalls in February, Surprising Forecasters
abstract: In what may be more troubling economic news for President Bush, a government report showed today that the U.S. economy created just 21,000 jobs last month.

headline: Suspect kept in detention in slaying of controller
abstract: ZURICH:—  A Swiss judge decided on Friday to keep in detention a man suspected of killing an air traffic controller in revenge for the death of his wife, daughter and son in a midair collision in southern Germany in 2002, the police said.

headline: Savings Are Found In Details
abstract: Advice on ways to save on federal income taxes because of tax law changes; pitfalls noted; drawings (M)l

headline: Mexico Media Mogul Follows the Money
abstract: Emilio Azcarraga Jean, chairman of Mexican media giant Grupo Televisa, will wed Sharon Fastlicht in Mexico City, and couple will move to Miami after honeymoon; Azcarraga has long said he wants to find way to expand Televisa's reach into Hispanic market in US; Televisa owns 11 percent of Univision Communications; because Federal Communications Commission restrictions limit foreign ownership of US broadcasters to 25 percent, Azcarraga would need American passport if he were to seek control of company; photo (M)

headline: 2 Equipment Makers Settle Dispute With Amtrak
abstract: Bombardier of Montreal and Alstom of Paris agree to settle legal dispute with Amtrak in which sides blamed each other for failed attempt to apply European high-speed train technology to US rail system; agreement, which comes as Bombardier announces plans to eliminate 6,600 jobs worldwide in huge realignment of its troubled rail division in Europe, will enable manufacturers to concentrate on return to financial health; will also allow Amtrak to eliminate distraction just as it appears to be making progress in improving deteriorated infrastructure; all legal claims will be dropped and Bombardier-Alstom consortium will collect $42.5 million of approximately $70 million that Amtrak withheld in payments for $1.2 billion Acela high-speed rail project; Amtrak will assume responsibility for maintaining 20 Acela trains, beginning in October 2006, about seven years earlier than planned; photo (M)

headline: Dominicans And the U.S. Complete A Trade Deal
abstract: Bush administration completes negotiations on free trade deal with Dominican Republic, accord that would remove nearly all trade barriers over next decade and allow Dominican Republic to become sixth nation to join new Central American Free Trade Agreement (M)

headline: ADOLOR'S NEWS ABOUT DRUG STUDY SENDS STOCK DOWN 37%
abstract: Adolor its experimental drug Entereg did not restore bowel function after surgery as fast as intended (S)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Dept confirms death of service member in Iraq (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Bank Investigation
abstract: National Australia Bank says Securities and Exchange Commission in US is investigating possible auditing breach and that it might have to pay 543 million Australian dollars ($418 million) in extra tax (S)

headline: Toward a Clean Sweep, Without the Human Touch
abstract: How It Works column on robotic vacuum cleaners such as Roomba that use combination of systems to get around room; photos; illustrations show how system works (M)

headline: U.S. Weighs Not Paying For All Uses Of Some Drugs
abstract: Federal Medicare officials are close to deciding whether to refuse for first time to pay for unapproved uses of expensive cancer drugs, decision they say could represent first step in broad overhaul of program's drug reimbursement policies; only four drugs, for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma or colorectal cancer, are part of initial Medicare review, but officials say decision on those drugs could set precedent for payment decisions on other costly medications as government prepares to add far-reaching prescription drug benefit to Medicare program; Federal law allows doctors to prescribe drugs for any purpose once they have been cleared for sale by Food and Drug Administration, and doctors routinely use many cancer drugs for conditions beyond those approved by FDA or recognized by medical texts; Medicare officials believe that reimbursement limits would discourage such use (M)

headline: JETBLUE PLANS DAILY FLIGHTS TO DOMINICAN REPUBLIC
abstract: JetBlue Airways Corp plans to begin daily flights between Dominican Republic's cities of Santiago and Santo Domingo and New York on June 17 (S)

headline: Bordello Business Unsettled After Spanish Court Ruling
abstract: A court in the city of Seville has ruled that the owner of a so-called alternative club must make social security payments for 12 women who worked there as prostitutes.

headline: U.N. Panel Backs Plan To Aid Haiti With Troops
abstract: United Nations Security Council, in emergency session, approves immediate dispatch of multinational force to Haiti and creation of UN peacekeeping force to replace it within three months; council president Wang Guangya says he called meeting after getting letters from new Haitian Pres Boniface Alexandre, United States Amb John D Negroponte and French Amb Jean-Marc de la Sabliere; France says it will send from its overseas departments about 300 troops overnight, followed by 100 police officers (M)

headline: Mortgage Index Rises
abstract: Mortgage Bankers Association says its index of mortgage applications rose 25.6 percent for the week; gauge of refinancing surged 39.7 percent (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Prime Minister To Appeal For Investment
abstract: Japanese government will sponsor television commercials in US and Europe, one featuring Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi, to encourage foreign companies to investment in Japan; photos (M)

headline: Frankfurt-to-Atlanta Jet Lands At Shannon After a Bomb Scare
abstract: Bomb scare on Delta Airlines flight from Frankfurt to Atlanta forces plane to make emergency landing at Shannon Airport in Ireland; plane is evacuated and Irish police search plane and passengers' baggage but find nothing suspicious; crew members had found note saying bomb was on board in bathroom (S)

headline: AOL Is Changing Its Marketing Team
abstract: Len Short is stepping down after 13 months as executive vice president for brand marketing at America Online as part of change in management direction; Short shifts to handling strategic projects of AOL; will be succeeded by Richard Taylor, who will become senior vice president for brand advertising and promotion; AOL decides to continue with Initiative Media as media agency of record on its account; billings estimated at more than $200 million (M)

headline: Agency Alert About Iraqi Not Heeded, Officials Say
abstract: Senior US government officials say Iraqi military defector identified as unreliable by Defense Intelligence Agency provided some of information that went into intelligence estimates that Iraq had stockpiles of biological weapons at time of US invasion; say classified 'fabrication notification' about defector, former Iraqi major, was issued by DIA to other US intelligence agencies in May 2002, but it was repeatedly overlooked (M)

headline: Marshes a Vengeful Hussein Drained Stir Again
abstract: Marshes in southern Iraq were once among largest wetland ecosystems in world but they have nearly disappeared since Saddam Hussein ordered them drained in early 1990's; Hussein wanted to force out Shiites he suspected of resisting his rule; engineers in 2003 began breaking dams and levees upriver to reflood area; scientists and engineers, in largest and most complex wetlands restoration project being undertaken by US, are grappling with problems ranging from dismal water quality to uncertainty over whether residents can sustain themselves; dam-breaking brought some early success; swamp is teeming with renewed life; US Agency for International Development has budgeted $4 million for restoration effort; central concern is how to reintegrate people into wetlands environment; researchers say there were about 73,000 people in marshes in July 2003, down significantly from estimates of 250,000 in 1991, but more than recent tallies of 40,000; maps; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: UKRAINE: Parliament Votes To Let People Choose Leader; RUSSIA: Car Bomb Kills One; THE HAGUE: Top Bosnian Serb Goes On Trial; NORTHERN IRELAND: Peace Accord Review Starts; GERMANY: Students Arrested In Abuse Video;.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Jobs Paid $74.8 Million In Stock
abstract: Apple Computer paid chief exeutive Steven P Jobs $74.8 million in restricted stock in last fiscal year after company replaced his unprofitable stock options (S)

headline: FOOTSTAR PLANS TO CLOSE 165 ATHLETIC-SHOE STORES
abstract: footstar plans to close 165 athleti

headline: Economic Scene; Paper currency can have value without government backing, but such backing adds substantially to its value.
abstract: Hal R Varian Economic Scene column on how paper currency can have value without government backing focuses on how Iraq's Saddam Hussein printed his own currency after gulf war of 1991, which became worthless because so much was printed, while Kurds in northern Iraq continued to use dinar notes, which became more valuable in fall 2002 as US invasion neared; photo (M)

headline: Carry a Concert Home in Your Pocket
abstract: Dimensional Associates is testing digital kiosks that allow concertgoers to download recording of show to small USB drive almost immediately after concert; Clear Channel Communications offers similar service using CD burners to produce recording minutes after concert ends; photo (M)

headline: Business People; A Love Story With a Few Co-co-co-authors
abstract: Pen maker Montblanc will invite customers at its stores around nation to add lines to book begun by Candace Bushnell; photo (M)
