headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ESTÉE LAUDER COS., the cosmetics maker, said it had sold its Jane brand of makeup for younger women to Jane & Co., a newly created company, New York. Terms were not disclosed.    BORGWARNER INC., Chicago, the world's largest maker of automatic-transmission parts for vehicles, said it had formed a joint venture with Korea Flange Co., Pyongtaek, South Korea, to produce turbochargers in South Korea. Financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: Jobs Expected to Continue to Lag Economy
abstract: Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia economists say job growth is likely to remain tepid even as economy moves ahead; increase their forecast for economic growth this year to 4.6 percent from previous projection of 4.3 percent; trim forecast of job creation to 1.1 million jobs, from 1.25 million jobs (M)

headline: G.M. Says Costs For Retiree Care Top $60 Billion
abstract: General Motors Corp says its future health care obligation for retirees rose last year to $63.4 billion, from $57 billion in 2002; obligation would have been $67.5 billion if not for effects of new Medicare legislation signed in December by Pres Bush; Ford Motor Co and Chrysler Group reinstate contributions to their employees' 401(k) plans; Ford also says it will begin paying bonuses of first time in three years to its top 6,200 managers worldwide (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Girl Dies As Mafia Target Uses Her As Shield
abstract: Gunmen in Naples (Italy) aiming to kill Camorra, Neapolitan Mafia, boss Salvatore Giuliano kill 14-year-old Annalisa Durante when Giuliano uses her as human shield during attack (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Vivendi Investigation
abstract: French police raid offices

headline: Rocket Fired At U.S. Post In Baghdad
abstract: Guerrillas fire rocket across Tigris River into parking lot of Baghdad headquarters of US occupation forces; roadside bomb kills one Iraqi civilian in city; attacks, more than twenty daily, are thorny problem as US works to hand over sovereignty; Sec Gen Kofi Annan considers sending in UN team to help plan voting; photo of former high-ranking officers gathered in Mosul to sign statement promising to work on rebuilding country (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ATTENTUS HEALTHCARE, Nashville, a hospital acquisition company, said it offered to buy SunLink Health Systems, Atlanta, for $4 a share in cash, a 44 percent premium to SunLink's Thursday closing price of $2.77.    NATIONAL EQUIPMENT SERVICES INC., Chicago, a United States construction-equipment rental company by revenue, said it completed its bankruptcy reorganization after reducing debt by $275 million.

headline: LYDALL TO CLOSE OHIO PLANT AND LAY OFF 139 WORKERS
abstract: Lydall Inc, which makes industrial air filters, to close its plant in Columbus, Ohio, by end of year and cut 139 jobs; plans to move automotive manufacturing operations at plant to other plants; about 100 to 120 new jobs will be created at other plants as result of shift (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.25       Federal Funds   1.00   1.00   1.31       3-month Libor   1.11   1.11   1.25       3-month T-bills   0.94   0.95   1.11       6-month T-bills   0.98   0.99   1.11       10-yr. T-infl.   1.39   1.43   1.76       10-yr. T-note   3.69   3.73   3.75       30-yr. T-bond   4.65   4.67   4.75       Telephone bd.   5.84   5.82   5.85       Municipal bds.   4.31   4.31   4.93          (Sources by Bloomberg News; Telerate; The Bond Buyer; British Bankers' Assoc.)

headline: Called Mercenaries, Men on Seized Plane Face Death Threat
abstract: Zimbabwean authorities said that 64 men on a plane seized Sunday at the airport in Harare, the Zimbabwean capital, were mercenaries on their way to sow conflict in Equatorial Guinea, and threatened on Wednesday to execute them.

headline: BP to Increase Cash Payouts to Investors
abstract: BP pledges to return extra cash to its shareholders in form of dividends and stock buybacks over next three years as long crude oil prices remain firm, saying that it is stepping back from its strategy of growth by acquisition; also says it expects production to increase 5 percent each year through 2008, up from previous estimates of 3 percent; chief executive Lord Browne and chief financial officer Byron Grote comment; photo (M)

headline: Ousted McCann-Erickson Executive to Lead Havas Unit
abstract: James R Heekin is promoted to chairman and chief executive at Euro RSCG Worldwide's Havas unit, succeeding Bob Schmetterer, who is retiring; Heekin was fired as top executive at McCann-Erickson 11 months ago; Havas labels speculation about accounting irregularities as 'unfounded rumors' (M)

headline: McDONALD'S IS TAKING ITS PORTIONS DOWN A SIZE
abstract: The McDonald's Corporation said it is phasing out its supersize French fries and drinks in an effort to trim its menu in the United States. The plan, part of a larger move to streamline the menu and make customer service more efficient, is already under way at the company's 13,000 American restaurants. Among other changes, the company said it would cut the number of French fry sizes to three from five and reduce its largest order to 6 ounces from 7 ounces. McDonald's, based in Oak Brook, Ill., said it would not phase out supersize products offered by its restaurants in other countries.   Jo Napolitano (NYT)

headline: The Super Spots Lighten Up, At $2.3 Million For 30 Seconds
abstract: Companies including Anheuser-Busch, FedEx, General Motors, IBM, Monster Worldwide and Procter & Gamble are paying average of $2.3 million for 30-second commercial, up from $2.1 million last year, for privilege of appearing during Super Bowl; CBS will have no trouble selling out commercial time for game, even though growing cost of spot has drastically outpaced inflation rate of years; graph; photos (M)

headline: 2 Are Charged In Billing Investigation
abstract: Federal prosecutors charge former Ogilvy & Mather executive Shona Seifert and current executive Thomas Early with conspiring to defraud government by overbilling White House Office of National Drug Control Policy for work on its advertising account; Seifert, who left Ogilvy in January 2002 to become president at New York office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, says she is innocent and plans to contest charges; Early cannot be reached for comment (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Tomorrow.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Phone Stake Sale
abstract: Orange, wireleÿ

headline: Sharon's Gaza Strategy: Good for Hamas, or Israel?
abstract: Analysis: as Prime Min Ariel Sharon tries to build support for unilateral withdrawal from Gaza, militant group Hamas works to secure role in governing once Israelis leave; Israel's killing of Sheik Ahmed Yassin has given Hamas increase in support among Gaza's Palestinians; Hamas has always refused role within governing Palestinian Authority, regarding it as creature of Oslo peace framework; how much of role Hamas now wants to play in running Gaza is unclear; Palestinian Authority in Gaza is struggling, its popularity faded as Palestinians come to view it as incompetent and corrupt; by contrast, Hamas has built network of schools and low-cost health clinics; its leaders live modestly and have reputations as incorruptible (M)

headline: VERIZON WIRELESS LOOKS OUTSIDE INTERPUBLIC GROUP
abstract: Verizon Wireless expands search for marketing ideas beyond Lowe & Partners Worldwide and McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, both members of Interpublic Group of Companies; Verizon, which spends $700 million per year on marketing, says it is not 'completely satisfied' with Interpublic advertising, and will consider other advertising agencies (S)

headline: MOODY'S LOWERS AMERADA HESS'S UNSECURED DEBT RATING
abstract: Amerada Hess Cor's senior unsecured debt rating is cut below investment grade by Moody's Investors Service (S)

headline: Now Where Was I? New Ways to Revisit Web Sites
abstract: Lisa Guernsey What's Next column discusses prototype software, developed by the University of Washington, to organize bookmarks in Internet Explorer; software allows adding descriptive text, e-mailing the link and saving it in document folder; drawing (M)

headline: Prints Worthy Of a Scrapbook, Made at Home
abstract: Basics column on printers, paper, adjusting settings and compatability among brands to create photographic prints from digital images; photo (M)

headline: Bye-Bye, Big Box. A Thin Screen Is Bringing Fresh Air.
abstract: Daniel Akst column on thin, flat computer screens that are replacing traditional cathode ray tube monitors; notes they are easier on eyes, consume less power and take up much less space; sees them transforming offices, letting workers interact again, or at least reclaim their primacy in work space; sales graph (M)

headline: China's Leader Urges Shift in Development to Rural Areas
abstract: Prime Min Wen Jiabao, delivering China's equivalent of State of the Union address, vows to cool surging economy and focus resources on hundreds of millions of Chinese left behind in boom; in implicit criticism of predecessors, says rapid growth has led to rampant waste and done little to raise incomes of 800 million rural peasants who have little to show for urban-centered growth (M)

headline: Less Urgency in Effort to Sell Crucial Assets
abstract: Auction of Hollinger International's most v

headline: 2 Big Banks In Merger Settle Case on Fund Trading
abstract: Bank of America and FleetBoston Financial, which are merging, reach $675 million settlement with New York State Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer's office and Securities and Exchange Commission over improper trading in their mutual funds, requiring Bank of America to replace most of its fund directors within year; settlement is largest to date in wide-ranging fund probes and first to focus on role of boards in permitting improper trades; settlement brings to $1.65 billion total in fines and other payments by fund companies that have reached agreements with regulators at federal and state levels; Bank of America and Fleet will cut their fees by $160 million over next five years, chart (M)

headline: For Soothing TV Viewing, Choose a Background Aura
abstract: A new line of flat-panel televisions coming this spring from Philips produces images that are not only superior to those of conventional sets but also more restful. These seven plasma and liquid-crystal sets, priced at $4,500 to $10,000, incorporate a feature called Ambilight, a series of cold-cathode fluorescent lights that project various colors onto the wall just behind the television.

headline: Been Robbed on a Stock? I.R.S. May Not Think So
abstract: US Treasury and Internal Revenue Service rule that investors will not be allowed theft deduction for loss of value of stock bought on open market, even if stock declined because of crimes committed by corporate officials; Treasury says it understands that some taxpayers have been advised that they could take such deductions (M)

headline: Ride During Moscow Rush Ends Under Pile of Bodies
abstract: Bomb explodes on Moscow subway train during morning rush hour, killing at least 39 people and wounding more than 130; investigators suspect Chechen separatists are behind attack (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Poet's Nobel Medal Stolen
abstract: Bengali author Rabindranath Tagore's nobel prize medal is stolen from West Bengal (India) museum; won prize in 1913 for Gitanjali, book of selected poetry; photo (S)

headline: A Namesake Company Plugs Ahead On Its Own
abstract: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia presses on without Martha Stewart, and its creative team insists that Stewart, who is now being tried on federal charges stemming from stock sale in late 2001, left them more than prepared to keep company in vanguard of style and entertaining; say Stewart remains very much involved in operations, e-mailing in ideas for magazine and approving merchandise for her Signature line by looking at digital pictures; some analysts, advertisers and business consultants are skeptical that company, which is expected to post its first yearly loss within a week or so, will ever truly rebound; photos; graph of share price (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Rhodia Shares And Bonds Plunge
abstract: Shares of Rhodia SA, French chemical maker that haslost almost two-thirds of its value in last year, drops as much as 13 percent after Moody's Investors Service cuts company's credit rating on concern that it might have to repay $290 million in bonds early; graph (S)/

headline: Privacy Fears Erode Support For a Network To Fight Crime
abstract: New York and Wisconsin withdraw from Matrix, controversial multistate program designed to find criminals or terrorists by sifting through databases of public and private information, reducing number of states in program to 5 from high of 16; supporters of Matrix, including Florida officials, who commissioned Seisint to develop it, insist it merely gives law enforcement agencies quicker access to data that they already have legal authority to see, not information that they would need subpoena or other judicial order to obtain; opponents say ability of computer networks to combine and sift mountains of data greatly amplifies police surveillance power, putting innocent people at greater risk of being entangled in data dragnets and that problem is compounded in world where many aspects of daily life leave online tracts; critics include ACLU, which has filed Freedom of Information Act requests to uncover inner workings of system, Electronic Privacy Information Center and Electronic Frontier Foundation; photo (M)

headline: The Uncensored Executive at the Mike
abstract: Wall Street firms are not supposed to tailor their investment recommendations to get investment banking business. But some companies evidently think they should.

headline: Bush Proposes Strict Limits on Black Market Sale of Equipment to Make Nuclear Fuel
abstract: Pres Bush proposes seven-point plan to make it far more difficult to sell nuclear equipment on black market; says ease with which North Korea, Iran and Libya received help from Pakistani scientist Abdul Qadeer Khan shows that United States must prevent governments from developing nuclear weapons under falsh pretenses; Bush, speaking at National Defense University, breaks years of official silence about Khan, man who American intelligence agencies determined years ago was one of world's most successful traffickers in nuclear technology (M)

headline: Takashi Ishihara, 91, Dies; Led Nissan's Rise
abstract: Former Nissan Motor Company president Takashi Ishihara dies at age 91; photo (M)

headline: Ministers in Brussels Reject Idea of a C.I.A. for Europe
abstract: European Union ministers agreed that a growing threat to the region makes greater intelligence coordination essential.

headline: Stock Offerings Planned
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:      Endurance Specialty Holdings Ltd., 8 million ordinary shares. Goldman, Sachs and Merrill Lynch.

headline: Press Baron's Adversaries Opt For a Committee Over a Clash
abstract: Hollinger International board stops short of taking action against former chairman-chief executive Conrad M Black, instead setting up review committee consisting of all company's directors except for Lord Black, his wife Barbara Amiel Black and vice chairman Daniel Colson, who is seen as ally of Blacks (M)

headline: Videophones Revisited, By Way of the Modem
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on VisiFone from Viseon; device uses broadband connectivity and Internet protocol addressing to complete call with full-motion video; photo; drawing (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: L.C.D. Joint Venture
abstract: Sanyo Electric and Seiko Epson merge their liquid crystal display businesses; graph (S)

headline: Leaders of India and Pakistan Try to Maintain Momentum Toward Improved Relations
abstract: Prime Min Atal Bihari Vajpayee of India and Pres Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan, in Islamabad for summit meeting of regional leaders, meet, in sign of further thaw in their nations' cold war; two nuclear-armed neighbors have fought three wars, and nearly fought fourth in 2002; each of leaders is staking considerable political capital on making peace and appearing to be making progress in doing so; comments by officials on both sides suggest groundwork is being laid for dialogue betweeen countries that would include their core dispute, divided border region of Kashmir; photo (M)

headline: Uranium Traveled to Iran Via Russia, Inspectors Find
abstract: European diplomats and US experts say inspectors have found evidence that some of highly enriched uranium found on nuclear machinery in Iran came from Russia; say nuclear fuel appears to have come through global black market, and not with blessings of Moscow; Bush administration has long accused Iran of harboring secret bomb project, which Tehran denies (M)

headline: Proposal to Limit Oil and Coal Projects Draws Fire
abstract: African mining companies, governments of developing countries and international banks express concern over proposal that World Bank restrict oil and coal projects to protect environment; African governments that are heavily dependent on oil and mineral extraction fear new proposals could harm future investment; proposal came in form of report drafted by Emil Salim, former environmental minister from Indonesia who was appointed to prepare it in 2001 by World Bank president James D Wolfensohn; photo (M)

headline: IRAQ REBELS SEEN USING MORE SKILL TO DOWN COPTERS
abstract: Classified Army study of downings of military helicopters in Iraq finds that guerrillas have used increasingly sophisticated tactics and weapons to attack American aircraft; insurgents are proving adept at using both rocket-propelled grenades and heat-seeking surface-to-air missiles; study recommends specific changes to help pilots evade gruond fire, but Army officials decline to elaborate; goal of study was to detect more about insurgents' techniques and weaponry and pinpoint weaknesses in Americans' defensive countermeasures and tactics; chart illustrates specific incidents under investigation by date and type of helicopter; photo (M)

headline: Powell Calms The Russians On U.S. Intent Over Georgia
abstract: Secretary of State Colin Powell, in Tbilisi for inauguration of Georgian president Mikhail Saakashvili, assures Russia that American friendship for Georgia is not threat to Russian interests; dismisses Russian concerns about presence of 80 to 200 American military trainers in Georgia since mid-2002; insists those troops are helping Georgians combat terrorists who threaten Russia; says upcoming talks in Moscow will show Russia and US 'can cooperate in areas where people might think we should be in competition' (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Textile Concern Fights Takeover
abstract: World Business Briefing: Ja

headline: Colombia's Landed Gentry: Coca Lords and Other Bullies
abstract: Rightwing paramilitaries are taking over Colombia's most fertile land, forcing farmers off or intimidating them into selling at low prices, even as government tries to wrest control of historically lawless country; photo; paramilitary leaders are negotiating with government while quietly laundering drug money by taking huge tracts from poor farmers and even big landowners (M)

headline: 'X' Marks His (Disputed) Spot in Canada's Art Scene
abstract: Profile of Istvan Kantor, Canada's leading shock artist, notes that on March 10 he received Governor General's Award in visual and media arts, one of nation's highest artistic awards; Kantor is recognized as founder of Neoism, international anarchist art movement; photo (M)

headline: Vote in Doubt, AXA and MONY Alter Their Deal
abstract: AXA's planned takeover of MONY Group sweeten terms of team with shareholder approval in doubt; both delay shareholder vote and change who gets to vote; sweetener, extra 10 cents per share, will come out of money that otherwise would have gone to MONY executives; AXA had vowed it would not raise its $31 per share offer, but this move will give MONY ability to raise effective offer by 10 cents per share; MONY asks Judge Stephen P Lamb to allow it to reschedule meeting shareholder meeting for May 18, with voting limited to those who own shares as new record date, April 8; rescheduling would enable investors to buy shares over next several weeks and vote on merger, which could significantly change profile of shareholders who would be allowed to vote (Market Place column) (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Cabinet Backs Rule Against Scarves
abstract: French cabinet approves draft law prohibiting wearing of religious symbols, including Islamic head scarves, in public schools; bill, supported by President Jacques Chirac, must be approved by National Assembly to become law (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Sanofi's Bid Delayed
abstract: French market regulators will postpone closing date for Sanofi-Synthelabo's bid for its rival drug company, Aventis, which has accused regulators in court of failing to evaluate proposal properly (S)

headline: Executive Life; A Question of Ethics: How to Teach Them?
abstract: Not all business schools are rushing to introduce or enhance ethics courses in response to scandals that have rippled through corporate world; roughly half of 1,700 graduate business students interviewed by Aspen Institute say they think they will have to make a decision in future that will test their values, but only 22 percent say their schools are doing 'a lot' to prepare them to manage value conflicts; 20 percent say they are not being prepared at all; photo (M)

headline: General Urges NATO to Send Afghanistan More Troops
abstract: Gen James L Jones, NATO's top commander in Europe, voices frustration that NATO members are not providing enough troops for reconstruction effort in Afghanistan, Senate committee; blames administrative details; sees 'defining moment' for NATO as it adopts broader agenda in world; senators from both parties express concern that Bush administration might fail to solidify gains in Afghanistan; William B Taylor Jr of State Department tells committee that voter registration is lagging; map (M)

headline: Private Sector; Quickening the Pace for Bonds
abstract: PrivateSector interview with Jim Toffey, who founded TradeWeb in 1998 to make bond trading more efficient; 2003 trading volume reached $18.3 trillion, up 70 percent from 2002; headquarters, formerly in World Trade Center, is now in Jersey City; photo (M)

headline: Making of the Digital Press Corps, 2004
abstract: Article discusses how technology has changed ways reporters collect and relay information on political campaigns; cellular phones, minicams, digital recorders, laptops, wireless networks and e-mail help reporters do their job faster, if not better; some reporters feel it has eroded the relationship they used to build with candidates; photo (L)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Software Service Profit
abstract: India's Wipro says quarterly profit rose 18.6 percent, to 2.74 billion rupees ($61 million); photo (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sharp To Double Spending On Chip Plants
abstract: Sharp Corp will double spending on chip-making plants next year; will spend 27 billion yen ($242 million) on semiconductor development and equipment in year ending March 2005 (S)

headline: COURT REJECTS INVESTOR CLAIMS AGAINST JOHN HANCOCK
abstract: John Hancock Financial Services says federal court has dismissed shareholder accusations that company overpaid its executives; suit says chief executive David D'Alessandro and other executives were wrongfully awarded compensation, and sought repayment; company spokesman Steve Burgay says court did not dismiss one minor claim against Hancock directors, but company also expects that allegation to be rejected (S)

headline: Ethnic Morass Bogs Down Afghan Talks On Charter
abstract: Afghanistan's constitutional convention is deadlocked for third day as some delegates refuse to vote on amendments and faction leaders argue over some remaining issues; members of assembly show rising frustration and anger at proceedings and warn that ethnic divisions are being aggravated to dangerous level (M)

headline: New Delays in Boeing Deal With Air Force
abstract: Boeing's $27.6 billion deal to lease and sell Air Force up to 100 refueling tankers will face at least three more months of scrutiny before Air Force can proceed with contract (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Telmex Invests In Brazil
abstract: Telefonos de Mexico is buying control of Brazil's largest long-distance carrier Embratel from WorldCom for $360 million; will acquire almost 20 percent economic interest in Embratel and almost 52 percent of voting shares (S)

headline: O'Neill Says Bush Was Set On Cutting Taxes, Too
abstract: Edmund L Andrews column on The Price of Loyalty, Ron Suskind book about Paul O'Neill's tumultuous tenure as Treasury secretary, especially O'Neill's contention that Pres Bush made big decisions on tax cuts and budget deficits with almost no discussion and even less debate; photo (L)

headline: IRAQ ILLICIT ARMS GONE BEFORE WAR, INSPECTOR STATES
abstract: David Kay, who led US effort to find banned weapons in Iraq, says after stepping down from his post that he has concluded that Iraq had no stockpiles of chemical and biological weapons at start of war; says he thinks Iraq had illicit weapons at end of 1991 Persian Gulf war, but that United Nations inspections and Iraq's own decisions 'got rid of them'; CIA Dir George J Tenet names Charles A Duelfer to replace Kay; Duelfer photo (M)

headline: LEADER OF HAMAS KILLED BY MISSILE IN ISRAELI STRIKE
abstract: Israeli missile strike kills Sheik Ahmed Yassin, spiritual leader and founder of militant Palestinian group Hamas, in Gaza City; two bodyguards are also killed; Yassin is most significant Palestinian miiltant killed by Israel in more than three years of conflict; Israeli military blames Yassin for 'numerous murderous terror attacks' that have killed many civilians, charge Yassin had denied; in Palestinian refugee camps, thousands of people take to streets to protest Yassin's death; Palestinian Prime Minister Ahmed Qurei condemns attack, claiming Yassin was voice of moderation within Hamas; Israeli Army closes off Gaza Strip and shuts checkpoints that effectively divide it into three sections; Israel has stepped up pressure on militants in Gaza since Palestinian suicide bombing in Israeli port of Ashdod that killed 10 Israelis; photos (M)

headline: Five Ways to Get Into the Minds of Marketers
abstract: Paul B Brown reviews five new books on marketing: Building Reputational Capital by Kevin T Jackson, The 18 Immutable Laws of Corporate Reputation by Ronald J Alsop, Wordcraft by Alex Frankel, Brand Portfolio Strategy by David A Aaker and The 5 Paths to Persuasion by Robert B Miller and Gary A Williams; photo (M)

headline: Daimler Will Add to Stake in Mitsubishi Truck Unit
abstract: DaimlerChrysler will buy additional 22 percent of Mitsubishi Fuso Truck and Bus from Mitsubishi Motors, Daimler's struggling Japanese affiliate; will spend about 52 billion yen ($489 million) for stake; photos (M)

headline: Big Swiss Bank Reports Profit Of $1.5 Billion In 4th Quarter
abstract: Big Swiss Bank Reports Profit of $1.5 Billion in 4tï

headline: American Companies Rebuilding Iraq Find They Are Having to Start From the Ground Up
abstract: American companies involved in reconstruction projects in Iraq often find infrastructure missing or badly impaired, and meet unexpected problems in every sphere of activity because of years of neglect and abuse; scale of project dwarfs anything done previously, including reconstruction of Japan after World War II; United States has budgeted $20 billion since last winter to rebuild infrastructure, revamp economic, judicial and law enforcement institutions and rebuild Iraqi army (M)

headline: Canada Can Bid on Next Round of Iraq Contracts, Bush Says
abstract: President Bush used his second fence-mending session in two days to relay the decision to the Canadian prime minister.

headline: Time Warner Posts Profitable Quarter and Year
abstract: Time Warner posts net income of $638 million in fourth quarter compared with loss of $44.9 billion loss year earlier; revenue rose 6.3 percent, to $10.9 billion from $10.25 billion; operating income rose to $8.5 billion on revenue of $39.6 billion (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Europe May Ask Microsoft For 2 Versions of Windows  European antitrust regulators are considering a requirement that Microsoft sell two versions of Windows in Europe -- one with the music- and video-playing software stripped out -- should they find the company to be an abusive monopoly, people close to the case said.     The European Commission, which is nearing a ruling in the five-year-old case, may also ask Microsoft to propose ''within a few months of a ruling'' what computer code for Windows it should disclose to make the operating system fully compatible with programs and servers manufactured by rivals. [Page C5.]

headline: Fed Chief Outlines Risk in Yuan Policy
abstract: Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan tells Sen Richard Shelby, chairman of Senate Committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs, that China should shore up its 'quite weak' banking system to prevent instability as it moves toward floating yuan's value against dollar; says China needs to improve banks' internal controls by giving local managers more training and authority (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: For Audio Players, A Chance to Cut the Cord
abstract: New headsets from Reason Products and FoneGear use near-field magnetic communication to connect headset to base station plugged into cellular phone, eliminating need for cord; real promise of technology is seen in its application with streaming music; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Deal To Tighten Border
abstract: United States and Mexico sign agreement to tighten border controls and provide transportation home for illegal Mexican migrants rather than dropping them at border; Asa Hutchinson, border and transportation security under secretary, holds new controls are essential for success of President Bush's proposed legislation granting temporary legal status to some immigrants (S)

headline: PHARMION DRUG TO GET PRIORITY REVIEW FROM REGULATORS
abstract: Pharmion Corp says Food and Drug Administration has granted priority review to Vidaza, company's drug for treating cancerlike bone marrow disorder; FDA will decide by June 29 whether to approve treatment (S)

headline: Verizon Wireless Selects LevyTenny
abstract: Verizon Wireless names LevyTenny to create ad campaign promoting instant messaging on its cellphones (S)

headline: As a Tracking Stock, It Led Many Astray
abstract: Short, unhappy life of AT&T Wireless as stock by public is coming to end; will be remembered as emblem of way Wall Street fads can come and go, enriching investment bankers while damaging investors who follow those fads; AT&T Wireless was born not as real stock but as tracking stock, way for AT&T to demonstrate value of its really hot property, wireless telephone service; more than 66,000 people participated in initial public offering on April 26, 2000 at price of $29.50 per share; investors are set to receive $15 per share for Cingular Wireless; graph (Market Place column) (M)

headline: From Cereal to Juice, a Year of Innovation
abstract: Many consumers may look back at 2003 as the year in which the economy and stock market finally started to bounce back. But it was also a year of product innovation.    Consumers could buy portable cereal that never becomes soggy, plastic wrap that clings only to the things they want it to cling to, and orange juice that could lower cholesterol.

headline: People
abstract: Steve Soldano is named to new post of worldwide strategic planning director on American Express ad account at MindShare (S)

headline: Violence in Ivory Coast Threatens Disarmament Process
abstract: Clashes erupted in Abidjan today, leading to the pullout of former rebels from a power-sharing government.

headline: Book Chain Taps Underserved Neighborhoods
abstract: Borders Books and Music is tapping into one of retail industry's few remaining new frontiers--underserved urban neighborhoods--with stores in Detroit and Chicago; company opened 8,000-square-foot store in heart of downtown Detroit at Compuware Corp's new world headquarters building; company is also main retail anchor for ambitious new mixed-use retail and residential complex on North Side of Chicago; Alex Lelli, vice president for development at Borders, comments; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Accused Drug Lord Sent To U.S.
abstract: Arcangel de Jesus Henao, suspected leader of Norte del Valle cocaine cartel in Panama, is extradited to United States; was captured last week during joint Panamanian-American raid in remote region of Panama (S)

headline: Target Indicates It May Sell Department Store Chains
abstract: Target Corp says it might sell department store divisions Mervyn's, with 266 stores, and Marshall Field's; hires investment bank Goldman, Sachs to provide 'alternatives'; photo (M)

headline: Report Backs Overturning Of Election at Writers Guild
abstract: William B Gould IV, independent investigator and labor law expert, says Writers Guild of America president Victoria Riskin was ineligible to run for re-election in September because she did not fulfill requirement for maintaining active membership: being paid for writing assignment; recommends that election be overturned; screenwriter Michael Alan Eddy sues Writers Guild along with writer-producers and director of Warner Brothers film The Last Samurai, contending he was denied credit for originating story; suit accuses defendants of fraud, breach of contract and breach of duty of fair representatiion; Eddy says he and writers Garner Simmons and Robert Schenkkan were not given opportunity to go through guild's arbitration process on assigning credit; photo (M)

headline: NEW IRAQ AGENCY TO HUNT REBELS
abstract: Iraqi authorities, with help of US intelligence agencies, are creating intelligence service that will focus on rooting out guerrilla fighters, especially those from outside country; service will employ some former agents of Saddam Hussein's security apparatus and will probably receive financing from US; it will employ 500 to 2,000 people, and is expected to be formed before Bush administration transfers sovereignty to Iraqi government on June 30; CIA is taking lead in helping put together new service; photo shows partly destroyed headquarters of Saddam Hussein's secret police (M)

headline: G.I. Toll Is Rising as Insurgents Try Wilier Bombs and Tactics
abstract: Six more American soldiers in Iraq are killed by homemade bombs that military officers say are becoming increasingly sophisticated and effective; one soldier is killed by roadside bomb west of Baghdad, and three more while on patrol in southeast Baghdad; attack in Tikrit day before kills two soldiers; officers say new explosives are smaller, can be planted more quickly and are being detonated from greater distances; bombs remain leading cause of American casualties since end of major combat operations on May 1; countermeasures range from surveillance planes to ground patrols who fire at suspected explosives to detonate them; photo (M)

headline: Havas Says It Is Not Selling Its Media Services Agency
abstract: Havas Says Media Unit.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: Aristide Promises Elections
abstract: Haitian President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, attending Summit of Americas (Monterrey, Mexico), announces he will hold legislative elections within next six months; terms ran out this week for many of those serving in Legislature; protests against Aristide's government have been escalating over past few months; photo (S)

headline: 4 Afghan Mine-Removal Workers Shot Dead
abstract: Four Afghan mine-removal workers are killed by suspected Taliban or al-Qaeda attackers in southern Farar province; attack is latest in series in which at least 20 foreign and Afghan aid workers have been killed since March 2003 in apparent campaign to scare away foreign aid and undermine government (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Poor Telecom Result
abstract: LG Telecom, smallest of South Korea's three mobile phone operators, says fourth-quarter profit more than doubled, but is less than what analysts forecast; net income rises to 9.5 billion won ($8 million) from 3.7 billion won year ago; graph shows stock price (S)

headline: After Rumsfeld Visit, Afghan Leader Asserts Taliban Is Beaten
abstract: Afghan Pres Hamid Karzai says Taliban has been defeated and that exiled former members are appealing to be allowed to return; comments come at news conference after meeting with Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld in Kabul; also shortly follow attack east of Kabul in which suspected terrorists fatally shoot five members of Afghan nonprofit organization, one of worst attacks in months (M)

headline: A Long Fuse Links Tangier To Bombings In Madrid
abstract: At least five of suspects arrested in connection with Madrid train bombings came from Tangier, and are linked to broader group of militants who returned to Morocco from Afghanistan in late 1990's; Islamic revival is strong in region, focused on Salafia Jihadia movement of Muhammad al-Fizazi, who is serving 30-year prison sentence for inciting violence in Morocco; unemployment is estimated at 30 percent among young men, and Spain is only eight miles away; many are secular when they journey to Europe in search of work, but come back radicalized; photos (M)

headline: Stock Offerings This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:      Capital Lease Funding, an initial public offering of 20 million shares. Friedman, Billings, Ramsey and Wachovia.

headline: Jury Is in Turmoil Over Tyco Case
abstract: Jurors in trial of Tyco International's former chief executive L Dennis Kozlowski and chief financial officer Mark H Swartz tell Judge Michael Obus that they may have reached impasse, saying 'the atmosphere in the jury room has turned poisonous'; wording of two notes sent to Obus indicates that one juor may be holding out for acquittal while 11 others favor conviction on at least some of 32 charges; disclosure creates possibility that Obus could be forced to declare mistrial if jurors are unable to reach consensus; copy of notes sent to Obus (M)

headline: G.M. Returns 10 Years After End Of Apartheid
abstract: General Motors is returing to South Africa 10 years after end of apartheid, one of largest companies to divest itself of its South African holdings; GM, which sold its operations to local management in 1987, will buy back remaining 51 percent of Delta Motor Corp under deal approved by South African regulators; Delta, which has been 49 percent owned by GM sicne 1997, will become General Motors South Africa; terms of deal undisclosed; GM group vice president Maureen Kempston Darkes meets with South Africa's Pres Thabo Mbeki and says Delta buyback is vote of confidence in new South Africa; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: More Jobs Lost
abstract: Canada unexpectedly lost 21,200 jobs in February; unemployment rate was 7.4 percent for third month; companies added 11,400 full-time workers while laying off 32,500 part-time employees on top of 31,900 they let go in January (S)

headline: Above All, Money Matters Are What Matter to Poles
abstract: Prime Min Leszek Miller's government is collapsing one month before Poland joins European Union; Poles are waiting with anticipation to see just what changes are in store; recent rebound in long-stifled economy, combined with fears that European Union membership will make life harder in short term, have left people focused on their pocketbooks--with little left over for issues like Miller's fall (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: First Community Bancorp, Rancho Santa Fe, Calif, holding company for Pacific Western National Bank and First National Bank, says it agreed to buy closely held First Community Financial Corp, Phoenix, for $40 million in cash (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Governments Urged To Fight Spam
abstract: Governments around world are urged to cooperate more in their fight against proliferation of spam, or unsolicited e-mail, at conference organized by Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (S)

headline: When Necessity Meets Ingenuity: Art of Restoring What's Missing
abstract: National Museum of American History has exhibit on prosthetic devices, including artificial limbs, cochlear implants and implantable artificial lung; some prosthetics on view replace or enhance physical abilities without being attached to body at all, such as device for hearing-impaired people that is embedded in telephones or headsets rather than worn as hearing aid; photos of prosthetic limb whose design was inspired by cheetah's leg and device that allows disabled people to play golf (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bank's Profit Rises
abstract: Bank of Montreal says first-quarter income rose 34 percent and it raises its quarterly dividend to 40 Canadian cents per share from 35; net income in latest quarter was 532 million Canadian dollars ($398 million) (S)

headline: Patents; Youngsters are seeking patents for their ideas, from toys to software that harnesses brain waves.
abstract: Patents column notes growing number of young people are filing for patent rights; their inventions run gamut from toys to software; By Kids For Kids, new company, plans to commercialize children's patented inventions; company head Daniel Gwartz says young inventors usually have some sort of mentor, like parent, grandparent or teacher; photo (M)

headline: Fast Forward; For TiVo, More Hours and Lower Prices
abstract: TiVo Series 2 digital video recorder records 140 hours of television and incorporates several of new features; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sprint PCS Adds Customers
abstract: Sprint Corp's PCS Group added 390,000 subscribers in fourth quarter, defying some analysts' expectations that new federal rule would hurt it; monthly rate of customer defections was 2.7 perent, same as in third quarter, when PCS added 184,000 customers (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: 3Com Posts Slightly Wider Loss
abstract: 3M Corp reports slightly wider loss for third quarter as sales dropped 21 percent, to approximately $172 million; net loss was $86 million compared with loss of $79 million year earlier (S)

headline: Study Finds a Waning Appetite for News
abstract: Project for Excellence in Journalism, which is associated with Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, reports that immediate prospects for newspapers and broadcast television news are bleak; says circulation of English-language newspapers in US has declined by 11 percent since 1990; says combined audience of three major cable news channels -- Fox News, CNN and MSNBC -- has been flat since late 2001; questions whether so-called new media can succeed on scale large enough to plug losses being incurred by old; says Spanish-language newspapers, alternative weeklies and news Web sites are bucking negative trend; photo (M)

headline: Taiwans President Appears to Win Election
abstract: But the opposition partys candidate refused today to accept results showing he narrowly lost and demanded that the ballots be recounted.

headline: In Face of Report, Iran Acknowledges Buying Nuclear Components
abstract: Iran, faced w

headline: Powell Reassures India on Technology Jobs but Presses for Opening of Markets
abstract: Sec of State Colin L Powell visits India, assuring government leaders and college students that Bush administration will not try to halt outsourcing of high-technology jobs to their country and asserting that appropriate American response to outsourcing is to press India to drop trade barriers against American investments, goods and services (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Bank Raises Loss Estimate
abstract: National Australia Bank says its total loss from unauthorized currency trading since October was 360 million Australian dollars ($280 million), double its original estimate (S)

headline: Correction: Kodak Employees
abstract: Correction of chart accompanying Jan 23 article detailing Eastman Kodak's work force (S)

headline: Mutual Funds Report; Value Investor of Omaha (and Not the One You Think)
abstract: Omaha, Neb, home Warren E Buffet and his company, Berkshire Hathaway, is also headquarters of another canny, although less well-known, value investor: Wally Weitz, manager of $4.12 billion Weitz Value Fund; Buffet made impromptu appearance at shareholder meeting in May honoring Weitz for his 20 years at helm of his investment firm and paid homage to him by wearing plaid shirt, Weitz's trademark; photo (M)

headline: That Parent-Child Conversation Is Becoming Instant, and Online
abstract: Instant messaging, long a part of teenagers lives, is working its way into broader fabric of American family; almost three-quarters of all teenagers with online access use instant messaging and about half of all adults have tried services; adults use instant messaging to stay in touch with co-workers, friends and far-flung family members; instant messaging is taking root within home itself as families own more than one computer; psychologists say that sometimes it is easier for teenager to talk to their parents online about difficult subject; graph; photos (M)

headline: Scientologists' Tax Break Cited in Suit Against I.R.S.
abstract: Trial is to beginin Los Angeles to determine whether Jewish couple Michael and Marla Sklar can deduct cost of religious education for their five children, tax benefit they say federal government has granted to members of just one religion, Church of Scientology; potential ramifications are huge, for ruling in favor of couple could affect millions of Americans who send their children to religious schools of all types; at stake is whether people of all religions can deduct cost of religious education as charitable gift, as Scientologists are allowed to do under officiallysecret 1993 agreement with Internal Revenue Service; photo (M)

headline: O.A.S. Seeks Peaceful Solution to Tense Venezuelan Impasse
abstract: The Organization of American States met Wednesday with electoral officials and opposition leaders in a last-ditch effort to find a peaceful solution to Venezuela's political turmoil, while opponents of President Hugo Chávez called for a major protest march on Thursday.    The situation here has remained tense since the National Electoral Council announced on Tuesday the disqualification of hundreds of thousands of signatures needed to allow a recall referendum on Mr. Chávez.

headline: Energy Scarce As Argentina Faces Winter
abstract: Energy Scarce As

headline: Kirshenbaum Bond Loses Its Independence
abstract: Kirshenbaum Bond Creative Network sells 60 percent stake to MDC Partners; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: The Ink Expert for the Defense Defends His Densitometer
abstract: Article on technically forensic experts in ink analysis who have provided some of fireworks at Martha Stewart securities fraud trial; prosecution's expert is Larry F Stewart (no relation) and defense's expert is Albert H Lyter III (M)

headline: MEN'S FASHION : Knits and leather:Bringing into focus Italy's twin icons
abstract: Sweater boys in showy knits and cool dudes in sleek leather are icons of Italian style. In the movies or the streets and especially on the fashion runways, knits and leather are fixtures. But two houses showed on Tuesday how to take the look forward for the 2004 autumn/winter menswear season.

headline: Pension Funds of 5 States Seek to Meet Disney Directors
abstract: Representatives of pension funds California, Connecticut, New York, North Carolina and Ohio call for meeting with directors of Walt Disney Co to voice their concern about company's future; representatives of funds, in letter to chairman George J Mitchell, say they want to discuss company's governance and long-term performance; all pension funds declined to support chief executive Michael D Eisner in Disney's annual board election March 3 (M)

headline: Invisible Yet Accessible, Your Noisy Family Printer
abstract: News Watch column reviews Keyspan USB Server; connects up to four USB devices over wired or wireless network; photo (S)

headline: South Africans Are Reeling Over Lion's Den Homicide Case
abstract: South African police officers and ordinary citizens alike reel in wake of report that disgruntled worker was thrown by his angry employer into lion pen, where lions attacked and ate him; body parts believed to be those of victim Nelson Shisane are found with scraps of clothing in enclosure of Mokwalo White Lion Project in Limpopo Province; Shisane's former boss Mark Scott-Crossley and three of Scott-Crossley's employees have been jailed but not charged; map (M)

headline: Speculation Breaks Out As Verdict Comes In
abstract: Word that jury reached verdict in case involving Martha Stewart's sale of Imclone Systems shares spurred speculative trading in Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia; traders who guessed wrongly that jury acquitted her face big losses; New York Stock Exchange was unable for nearly five minutes to find sellers to offset wave of buy orders; other markets continued trading during period; trading is halted on verdict and shares plummet when trading resumes; trading graph (M)

headline: Lenders Seek Debt Deferral For Korean Credit Card Issuer
abstract: Woorie Bank and 15 other largest creditors of LG Card Co, South Korean credit card company, seek written guarantee from other lenders that they will not attempt to force company to repay 21 trillion won ($18 billion) in debt for at least a year; LG Card is seeking another 2 trillion won from creditors to keep operating, and South Korea's financial watchdog agency recommends that creditors accept extension, saying that new bailout might not be approved without it; photo (M)

headline: Comcast Says Offer Is Final; Some Doubt It
abstract: Comcast Corp has repeatedly indicated in talks with investors that it has no plans to sweeten its offer for Walt Disney Co, and many of them seem certain that company is playing waiting game; Comcast's bid is worth $23.90 per share, or about $50 billion; shares of Disney continue to run far ahead of offer price, closing at $26.90, but Comcast is betting that Disney's stock will fall below bid price as time passes and no new bidder emerges; Disney's shares fall 2 cents while Comcast shares rise 85 cent, to $30.75 (M)

headline: Market Place; In a vexingly competitive media environment, a big stakeholder mutes his enthusiasm for Viacom.
abstract: Capital Research and Management has been quietly sell off much of its stake in Viacom Inc; Capital Research has cut its stake in half--to 47.8 million shares on Sept 30, 2003, from 97.8 million at end of March 2002; sell-off is significant because Capital's media investments are overseen by Gordon Crawford, senior vice president whose moves are watched on Wall Street; several analysts say Crawford has no management issues with Viacom, but he thinks stock has become expensive and company's growth is slowing; graph; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Prosecutor For Unexplained Killings
abstract: Mexican Attorney General names special prosecutor to investigate unsolved murders of at least 300 women in Ciudad Juarez over past ten years (S)

headline: Fearing That a Gap Will Become a Chasm
abstract: Analysis of looming shortfalls in Social Security and Medicare programs; Bush administration has estimated gap between promises under current law and revenues expected will total $18 trillion over next 75 years; Treasury Department study in 2002 concluded that gap is actually $44 trillion and will climb each year that nothing is done; analysts in Congress and administration warn that flood of retiring baby boomers will cause federal spending on old-age benefits to eventually consume as much of nation's economy as entire federal budget does now; government is borrowing more than $200 billion per year from Social Security and Medicare trust funds to finance its operating deficits (M)

headline: Popularity Contest
abstract: Gains and losses in circulation are reported for selected men's and women's magazines; graph; photo (S)

headline: WIRE MAKER FOR CARS AND COMPUTERS SEEKS BANKRUPTCY
abstract: International Wire Group files for bankruptcy protection to permit it to reorganize (S)

headline: Russia Rebukes Qatar for Arresting 2 Agents Held in Killing
abstract: Qatar arrests two Russian secret agents and charges them in car-bombing death of exiled Chechen leader Zelimkhan Yandarbiyev; Russia denies any involvement in death and accuses Qatar of violating international law (S)

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Queens; Renovations And Renewal For a Mall
abstract: First phase of large expansion of Queens Center, which has 21 million visitors a year and is one of region's busiest schopping centers, is to be opened at end of March; construction will almost double retail space by end of year; when completed, shopping center will have 175 retailers, up from original 67; map; photo (M)

headline: Spain Decides Against an Intelligence Inquiry
abstract: Spanish government, one of staunchest supporters of war in Iraq, says it will not investigate possible intelligence flaws on existence of unconventional weapons there; says Spain relied on United Nations arms inspectors, not on military intelligence from Britain or United States; photo (S)

headline: The newest Yankee may become the athlete companies pick for pitches.
abstract: Coming of Alex Rodriguez to New York Yankees could set up off-field rivalry between Rodriguez and teammate Derek Jeter for endorsement dollars; sports marketing experts say trade that brought Rodriguez to New York is likely to transform athlete who has been of only mild interest to advertisers into endorsement superstar; photo (M)

headline: Business People; Where's the Beef? Not on Beef.com
abstract: People for Ethical Treatment of Animals takes control of Web domain beef.com and puts up Web pages urging consumers to become vegetarians (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Parmalat Unit Hires Specialist
abstract: Brazilian unit of Parmalat hires corporate turnaround specialist Claudio Galeazzi to help overhaul its money-losing operations; unit operated under two sets of rules, one for its listed operational unit, which owes local banks $160 million, and other more byzantine set of practices used by its two holding companies under direct control of Tanzi family in Parma (S)

headline: The Unused Gift Card
abstract: To the Editor:    ''A Second Life for Unused Gift Certificates'' (Online Shopper, Jan. 29) hit it just right. Gift certificates are a stupidly clumsy way for people to delude themselves into thinking they have given someone a gift that's a step above money. Money is crass, but a gift certificate shows care and thought? Wrong!

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett To Sell Linux PC's In Asia
abstract: Technology Briefing: Hewlett To Sell Linux PC's in Asü

headline: Journalists Say Paper Failed To Stop Deceit Of a Reporter
abstract: Interviews with USA Today journalists indicate former star correspondent Jack Kelley was able to insert fabrications and uncredited passages from other publications in his articles because of paper's ambitions, perceived favoritism of editors and Kelley's charm; six journalists say they or their colleagues approached editors with suspicions about accuracy of four Kelley articles in recent years, but that concerns were often dismissed or Kelley was able to convince editors of soundness of his work; John Seigenthaler, who heads panel of outside editors brought in to probe Kelley's work, says they have interviewed over 70 USA Today staff members and indentified more suspect articles (M)

headline: WALGREEN SAYS PROFIT ROSE 10% IN FIRST QUARTER
abstract: Walgreen's first-quarter profit rose 10 percent; net income rose to $254.9 million from $231.6 million year earlier; sales rose 17 percent, to $8.7 billion (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Norway: Overspending Minister Resigns
abstract: Norwegian Labor Minister Victor D Norman resigns amid criticism that he misused his expense account; holds resignation is not related to financial controversy (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Appeals Court Revives Gemstar Suit
abstract: Federal appeals court revives Gemstar-TV Guide International's patent lawsuit against EchoStar Communications and makers of television set-top boxes; rules federal judge in North Carolina incorrectly interpreted patents related to on-screen TV program guides; judge had ruled that EchoStar, Hughes Electronics' DirecTV unit and Thomson's consumer electronics division did not infringe on patents; Gemstar settles consolidated shareholder lawsuits for $67.5 million (S)

headline: Vaulting To No. 1, A Truism At a Time
abstract: Profile of David Bach, author of The Automatic Millionaire, top-selling business book, and other books on personal finances; Bach, armed with clear message, has mastered mechanics of popularity, training and overseeing huge network of seminar-givers, who spread his ideas and sell his books; photos (M)

headline: Tyco Jury to View Divorce Deal
abstract: New York State Supreme Court Justice Michael Obus says jurors at fraud trial of former Tyco International executive L Dennis Kozlowski will learn how much money and property he gave his wife Angie as part of their July 2000 divorce settlement (M)

headline: F.C.C. Opens Phone Lines To Plug-Ins Over the Net
abstract: Federal Communications Commission is preparing rules that will allow homes to start being connected to Internet through electrical outlets and make it easier for consumers and business to make cheaper telephone calls online; new rules could profoundly affect architecture of Internet and services it provides and have enormous implications for consumers, telephone and energy industries, and equipment manufacturers; FCC chairman Michael K Powell and his two Republican colleagues on commission say telecommunications industry and Internet will ultimately by transformed by two moves and separate 4-to-1 vote to allow Pulver.com, which provides computer-to-computer phone connections, to operate under different rules from ordinary phone companies (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Catalan Leader Had E.T.A. Talks
abstract: Spanish Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar calls for resignation of Catalonian Minister Josep Lluis Carod-Rovira for holding talks with ETA, banned Basque separatist group; regional leader holds meeting was attempt to stop ETA from further violent acts (S)

headline: U.S. Tightens Security Measures at Iraq's Borders
abstract: American civil administrator in Iraq, L Paul Bremer III, announces new security measures at border crossings to cut down on terrorist infiltration and smuggling; crossings between Iran and Iraq are cut from 19 to three; restrictions will be placed on border crossings with Syria in next phase of program; U-2 spy planes and E-8C surveillance aircraft will increase patrols; $300 million program will double Iraqi border security forces, increase training and buy equipment (M)

headline: Correction: Mutual Fund Leaders and Laggards
abstract: correction: mutual fund

headline: Lincoln Taught Me That
abstract: Playboy Enterprises chairman and chief executive Christie Hefner The Boss article on her life and career; photo (M)n

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Brewer Forecasts Gain
abstract: Kirin Brewery Co expects cost cuts to help increase profit by almost third this year; forecasts 33 percent increase in income, to 43 billion yen ($403 million); profit for year ended Dec 31 fell to 32.4 billion yen, from 32.5 billion yen year before; sales last year rose 0.9 percent, to 1.6 trillion yen, and Kirin forecasts further gain to 1.7 trillin for 2004; graph (S)

headline: Verizon Plans Fast Internet For Cellphones
abstract: Verizon Wireless will deploy advanced data network that will allow people to use Internet at high speed on mobile phones and other devices, including laptop computers; will spend $1 billion on network over next two years; chief executive Ivan G Seidenberg says moves reflect shift at company toward focusing on data services (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.25       Federal Funds   1.00   0.99   1.26       3-month Libor   1.12   1.14   1.37       3-month T-bills   0.87   0.85   1.18       6-month T-bills   0.95   0.96   1.23       10-yr. T-infl.   1.84   1.85   2.34       10-yr. T-note   4.09   4.08   4.12       30-yr.
