headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Raytheon Co., Waltham, Mass., the world's largest maker of air traffic control systems, won a contract to provide such systems to as many as seven commercial airports in Iraq for up to $49.4 million.    Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide, White Plains, the owner of the Sheraton and Westin chains, said it had acquired the Bliss chain of spas from LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, Paris, a maker of luxury goods, for $25 million in cash.

headline: Taiwan's Leader and Deputy Are Shot on Election Eve
abstract: Pres Chen Shui-bian and Vice Pres Annette Lu are shot on eve of bitterly contested national elections in Taiwan while riding in open-roofed Jeep through streets crowded with supporters in Tainan; neither suffers life-threatening injuries; polls open as scheduled (M)

headline: Leader of '85 Achille Lauro Attack Dies at Prison in Iraq
abstract: Abu Abbas, Palestinian mastermind of 1985 Achille Lauro hijacking in which Leon Klinghoffer, American passenger in wheelchair, was shot and thrown into sea, dies at prison in Iraq at age 55; photos; Abbas went into hiding when Saddam Hussein regime collapsed last year but was captured by US forces last April (M)

headline: McDonald's Promotes Menu As a Good Fit for Many Diets
abstract: Some McDonald's restaurants in New York metropolitan area, in effort to attract dieters, begin displaying posters and brochures that show how company's products can fit into low-carbohydrate, low-fat and low-calorie meal plans; Burger King Corp is scheduled to announce low-fat, low-carbohydrate, low-calorie menu platform next week (M)

headline: 15 Palestinians Killed as Israelis Launch 2 Raids
abstract: Fourteen Palestinians were killed and dozens were wounded today during army raids into Gaza City and southern Gaza.

headline: European Union Mends Rift With Jewish Groups
abstract: European Commission agrees to revive planning for conference on anti-Semitism that it suspended two days ago after accusations from European and American Jewish figures that some of its recent decisions have been anti-Semitic themselves; this prompted angry reaction by EC president Romano Prodi, high-profile European generally seen as friendly to Jewish interests, and opened up rifts among Jews, some of whom found accusation of anti-Semitism to be reckless and inaccurate; in background is another issue, debate among Jews and non-Jews alike about whether some expressions of rage against Israel are really disguises for old-fashioned anti-Semitism; photo of Prodi with World Jewish Congress chairman Israel Singer (M)

headline: 9 Fabergé Eggs Sold in U.S. Will Soon Be Back in Russia
abstract: The nine imperial Fabergé eggs will be going on tour in Russia beginning at the Kremlin in May.

headline: Federal Reserve Statement Gives Investors a Rude Shock
abstract: The Fed jolted markets on Wednesday by retreating from its open-ended pledge to keep rates low for "a considerable period."

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Profit In Semiconductors
abstract: ASML Holding, Europe's largest maker of machinery for semiconductor industry, posts its first profit in six quarters after eliminating jobs; net income reaches 16 million euros ($20.3 million) (S)

headline: El Paso to Sell Most Of Its Canada Unit
abstract: BG Group PLC agrees to buy most of El Paso Corp's busie

headline: After 6 Months, Tyco Prosecutors Close Case Against Ex-Officials
abstract: Prosecutors conclude their case against Tyco International's former chief financial officer Mark H Swartz and chief executive L Dennis Kozlowski with daylong argument that focuses on inconsistencies in Swartz's testimony; photo (M)

headline: FEDEX SHAREHOLDERS TO VOTE ON BOARD TERMS
abstract: FedEx Corp to hold shareholder vote on electing all of its 13 directors annually, after investor pressure to increase accountability (S)

headline: Audit Results Move Google A Step Closer To Offering
abstract: Google has cleared of last remaining hurdles in its closely watched effort to sell shares to public, receiving clean bill of health in company-paid audit certifying its compliance with requirements of Sarbanes-Oxley law approved by Congress in 2002 in response to wave of corrupt scandals; report is crucial step in Google's carefully staged path toward initial public offering that is expected to take place this spring (M)

headline: Federal Grand Jury Indicts Protester for Tax Evasion
abstract: Federal grand jury indicts Irwin Schiff, who government says has helped thousands of Americans evade income taxes in last nine years, on tax evasion, conspiracy and other charges; Schiff's former girlfriend, Cindy Neun, is charged with conspiracy, failure to file tax returns, Social Security disability fraud and theft of government property; Lawrence Cohen, employees of Schiff's bookstore, Freedom Books, is charged with conspiracy, preparing fraudulent tax returns and tax evasion (M)

headline: Your Taxes; A Spin on Route 1040: Testing the Software Programs
abstract: Charles Delafuente compares pros and cons of popular tax-preparation software programs; photo (M)

headline: When College Graduates Struggle to Find Jobs
abstract: Felicia Ackerman letter comments on March 14 article on diminishing job prospects for college graduates

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Brazil: Report On Fatal Launching-Pad Accident
abstract: Brazilian government-appointed commission finds 15 years of hidden deficiencies at root of August rocket explosion that killed 21 scientists and technicians; cites need for more resources for space program (S)

headline: Game Wars 2: Battle for the Living Room; Giants Look to Create the Next Digital Hub
abstract: Two competing visions of digital age of home entertainment are emerging: one centered on personal computer and the other on video game console; Intel Corp and Microsoft Corp hope to reshape PC into entertainment-oriented multimedia computer that will fit comfortably into family room; Microsoft is also hedging its bets by turning to IBM to develop chip for its next-generation Xbox game player; Sony Corp and Microsoft are weighing how many interactive media and digital video recording features they can add to their next-generation game players without making them too complex or expensive; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Army Officer Charged
abstract: Israeli military court charges army lieutenant colonel with manslaughter in deaths of four Palestinians, who were killed in 2002 when tank was fired to enforce curfew (S)

headline: Libya Ships Materials on Nuclear Weapons to Tennessee
abstract: Libya has shipped material related to its nuclear weapons on a flight to a secure facility, the White House announced today.

headline: Investors Said to Be Looking at 3 Publications
abstract: Group led by Mortimer B Zuckerman is considering investing up to $11 million in Radar, magazine focused on celebrities that published two issues last year before running out of money; is also interested in investing in--or even acquiring--New York Observer and Time Out New York; other members of group are Nelson Peltz, Jeffrey Epstein, Donny Deutsch and Harvey Weinstein (M)

headline: As Prices Rise, Washington Debates Saving Oil or Selling It
abstract: Members of Congress and Bush administration are scrutinizing use of Strategic Petroleum Reserve as oil prices continue to climb, but they are reaching opposition conclusions; Senate has voted to sell millions of barrels of reserved oil and use money for homeland security; Sen Barbara Boxer and Rep Mike Thompson wrote Energy Sec Spencer Abraham asking government to stop filling reserve; Abraham spokeswoman says administration will retain goal set by Pres Bush after terrorist attacks on Sept 11, 2001, to fill reserve to its capacity, 700 million barrels, 'in a deliberate and cost-effective manner'; Energy Department experts say flow into reserve is less than 0.2 percent of world demand and will not affect prices much; graph (M)

headline: PENTHOUSE SEEKS TO PROVIDE CAPITAL FOR TROUBLED UNIT
abstract: General Media, which owns Penthouse magazine, scraps reorganization plan intended to help it shed debt and will instead ask judge to approve injection of capital fromits parent company Penthouse International (S)

headline: Venezuela Panel Rules Against Chávez's Foes
abstract: Venezuela's National Electoral Council rules Pres Hugo Chavez's foes failed to obtain enough signatures to allow referendum on recalling him from office; holds only 1.8 million of 3.4 million signatures are valid; says 876,017 signatures could be reconfirmed by signers and referendum could still be set if enough are validated; opposition leaders defend signatures' validity and reject 'repair period' for reconfirming them; call on Organization of American States and Carter Center to prod electoral officials to reconsider; antigovernment protesters react with rage; National Guard troops are deployed in large numbers; OAS official Fernando Jaramillo says repair period remains best option to resolve turmoil; photo (M)

headline: Ex-President in Mexico Casts New Light on Rigged 1988 Election
abstract: Former Mexican Pres Miguel de la Madrid's autobiography casts more light on open secret that his successor Carlos Salinas de Gortari was elected in 1988 in rigged vote; says government lied and said computer system tabulating votes had crashed when initial results showed Salinas was losing badly to opposition leader Cuauhtemoc Cardenas; seeks to link fraud to his advisers and need for national stability (M)

headline: President Khatami Warns Clerics Ruling Iran Against Extremism
abstract: Pres Mohammad Khatami warns Iran's ruling clerics against taking anti-democratic 'path of extremism' that he says risks alienating people from Islam and Islamic Republic; says country faces three possible paths to future: to imitate West while denying religion, culture and identity of Iranians; to take path of extremism while denying demands or votes of the people; or, choice he favors, to embrace reform; his speech comes 10 days before scheduled parliamentary elections; reformers' plans to boycott elections evaporates after Khatami bows to order by supreme religious leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and announces that elections would go ahead (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: New Version Of Virus Appears
abstract: New version of MyDoom virus has appeared; Network Associates virus researcher Craig Schmugar and other virus experts will program infected computers to start online attack on Feb 1 against SCO Group, which sells Unix operating system; new version will begin similar attack against Microsoft, and blocks access to antivirus online sites that could help users protect against malicious software, as well as some online advertising sites (S)

headline: Take to the Streets? It Worked for Them
abstract: WeWantWork, marketing campaign by and for group of 43 jobless New Yorkers, was started in Sept 2002 by group of white-collar workers who had been unemployed for months; so far, three creators of group and 27 other members have found jobs; group has inspired similar self-help efforts in other cities; group members' success in finding jobs may be partly attributable to improving economy, though in New York City that improvement has been slow; that might explain why many of group's members have moved to other cities to take new jobs; photo (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Corrections: March 7 article on investing in Chinese Internet portals misstated title of official and role of company that introduced portal managers to Boston investors

headline: Moss/Dragoti to Join DDB New York Office
abstract: Omnicom Group combines Moss/Dragoti in New York with New York office of DDB Worldwide (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Aids Treatment Closer
abstract: South African officials begin plan to supply antiretroviral drugs to HIV positive individuals; estimated 5.3 million South Africans are HIV positive (S)

headline: U.N. Team Arrives in Iraq To Study Plans For Elections
abstract: UN team arrives in Iraq to assess feasibility of holding direct elections before June 30 deadline for handing back sovereignty to Iraqis; United States favors caucuses to choose assembly, while Shiite leader Ayatollah Sistani wants direct elections, though he will abide by UN decision; Kurds and Sunni Arabs oppose direct elections, which are expected to favor Shiites; Iraqi Governing Council does not hold itself bound by UN decision (M)

headline: The Handling Of Expert Testimony
abstract: Dr Jerry Frankel letter comments on Dec 21 article on changes in rules regarding expert witness testimony in malpractice cases

headline: Business People; All Those Jars Add Up
abstract: A E Hotchner, who runs Newman's Own food company with actor Paul Newman, preaches virtues of philanthropy; all of company's profits, more than $150 million since its founding in 1982, have been given to charity (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Region Imposes Emergency
abstract: Abkhazia (Georgia) region declares state of emergency after election of Mikhail Saakashvili; leadership of self-declared autonomous region opposed ouster of President Eduard A Shevardnadze in November 2003 (S)

headline: 2 U.S. Civilians Slain by Men Said to Be Dressed as Iraqi Police
abstract: Two American civilians working for the Coalition Provisional Authority and an Iraqi interpreter were killed by what Iraqi police officials said today they believe were four men dressed as Iraqi police officers.

headline: Oracle Raises Its Bid for PeopleSoft Again
abstract: Oracle Corp raises its bid to acquire PeopleSoft to $9.4 billion, or $26 a share, which is 33 percent more than offer it made last June and $3.30 higher than shares of PeopleSoft closed on Feb 4; surprise increase in offer price signals new stage in hostile takeover fight for PeopleSoft that had appeared stalled in recent months; graph shows rise in closing stock price of PeopleSoft, June 2003-Jan 2004; photo of Lawrence J Ellison, chief executive of Oracle (M)

headline: Verizon Wireless Picks Finalists in Review
abstract: Verizon Wireless narrows to three finalists review for general creative part of its advertising account, with billings estimated at $300 million (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: Ex-President Loses Immunity And Leaves
abstract: Former Guatemalan President Alfonso Portillo, who left office just last month, enters Mexico under tourist visa while under investigation for corruption in Guatemala; photo (S)

headline: Annan Is Said to Have Doubt on Iraq Voting
abstract: The U.N. secretary general will endorse the view that the interim Iraqi government cannot be chosen by direct elections.

headline: Dr. Fred Brown, 79, Pioneer In Fighting Foot-and-Mouth
abstract: Dr Fred Brown, virologist who led in development of vaccines and tests for foot-and-mouth disease in cattle, dies at age 79 (M)

headline: EBay Seller Of Fake Artwork Again Upsets The Auction Site
abstract: EBay forces Kenneth Walton to sell HammerTap, company that sells software that scans eBay's past sales to predict future selling prices; Walton, who ran company anonymously, is awaiting sentencing for trying to sell fake Richard Diebenkorn painting on eBay for $135,000; prosecutors do not regard Walton's connection with HammerTap software as violation of his plea agreement to abstain from personal involvement in online auctions; photo (M)

headline: Mutual Funds Report; In a Good Year, These Funds Managed to Do Even Better
abstract: Managers of three of top-performing mutual funds that are open to new investors comment on what led to their strong results in 2003 and on their outlook for 2004; they are Derek N Rollingson, manager of Icon Materials fund, Jean-Pierre Conreur, manager of Tocqueville Small Cap Value fund, and Robert E Killen and Lee S Grout, managers of Berwyn Fund; graphs show funds' performance; photos (M)

headline: Iran Official Disputes U.N. Nuclear Report
abstract: Iran's top national security official Hassan Rowhani says Iran is not required to proclaim its nuclear research programs, including advanced centrifuges, to UN agency (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Mayor Says Subway Toll Will Climb
abstract: Moscow Mayor Yuri M Luzhkov reports that death toll in February 6 subway bombing could rise as high as 50 people once forensic experts finish identifying remains; Russian President Vladimir V Putin blames Chechan guerrillas for attack (S)

headline: Filings for Jobless Claims Drop
abstract: Labor Department reports initial jobless claims fell 1,000 last week, to 342,000; claims at end of 2003 reached 339,000; number of people continuing to collect state jobless benefits in week ended Jan 17 rose 11,000, to 3.131 million; department reports employment cost index rose 0.7 percent in fourth quarter, smallest increase in year; photo (M)

headline: State Dept. Denies Leader Was Forced Out of Office
abstract: Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide claims he was driven from power in Haiti by US in 'coup'; relays charges to media and members of Congress by phone from Central African Reupblic; Sec Colin Powell says charge is 'absurd,' that Aristide was not kidnapped or forced onto plane; US officials acknowledge they made clear that Aristide could not be protected if he clung to power and offered safe passage if he left by dawn Feb 29, and that ultimate goal is to put in place transitional government until elections are held (M)

headline: Pakistani A-Bomb Guru Says He, Alone, Let Secrets Out
abstract: Abdul Qadeer Khan, founder of Pakistan's nuclear weapons program, goes on national television to admit that he shared Pakistani nuclear technology with other countries and to ask his nation for forgiveness; calls his actions 'errors in judgment'; says he acted entirely on his own; his three-minute speech is widely perceived in Pakistan to be carefully staged attempt to defuse potentially grave political crisis for Pres Pervez Musharraf, and to prevent Khan from naming senior military officials who knew of his activities; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: EURO COUNTERFEITS ON THE RISE; FRANCE: Muslims Remarks Investigated; ITALY: Vatican Envoy To Visit Moscow; BRITAIN: Naked Hiker Completes Trek;.

headline: SAKS FIFTH AVENUE GETS A NEW PRESIDENT
abstract: Saks Inc names Canadian retail executive Andrew Jennings to newly created position of president and chief merchandising officer of Saks Fifth Avenue as company assembles new management team at its luxury chain; Fred Wilson, who took over chain in January, is named chairman (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Plant Sale Offered
abstract: Foreign stakeholders in Enron Corp's stalled $2.9 billion power project Dabhol Power offer to sell their 85 percent for less than hanlf their original investment; Enron, which owns 65 percent stake, and General Electric Co and Bechtel Group, which own 10 percent each, offer to sell their combined stake for $380 million; project came to halt two years ago when sole buyer of power it generated, utility of western state of Maharashtra, defaulted on payments (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Insignia In Venture With I.B.M.
abstract: Technology Briefing: Insignia In Venture With I.B.M.ÿ

headline: The Stewart Trial's Other Star
abstract: Profile of Peter Bacanovic, Martha Stewart's co-defendant and former broker at Merrill Lynch, who now plays key role as her chief alibi; he has consistently held that they had pre-existing accord to sell her ImClone Systems shares if stock fell below $60; their fates hinge on whether jury in their trial on obstruction of justice and perjury charges believes claim; he has remained mystery, disappearing from New York social scene, while she has started campaign to restore her public image; photos (M)

headline: Seeking Top Qaeda Figure, Pakistanis Battle Militants
abstract: Thousands of Pakistani soldiers make limited progress advancing into 10-square-mile pocket of farming villages where 300 to 600 suspected militants have been surrounded near border with Afghanistan; senior Pakistani officials believe that Al Qaeda's No 2 leader Ayman al-Zawahiri may be trapped with group in South Waziristan; map; photo (M)

headline: Urban Golfwear Faces a Tough Course
abstract: Small Business column on Urban Golf Gear founder Craig Tanner's efforts to market his golfwear aimed at minority golfers; Tanner comments; photo (M)

headline: 'Business as Usual' at Plant That Tenet Says Was Shut
abstract: CIA Dir George Tenet, in recent speech at Georgetown University, praised actions taken against black market nuclear proliferation network run by Pakistani scientist A Q Khan, and mistakenly said that plant used by network in Malaysia had been shut down; Malaysian authorities and plant officials say Scomi Precision Engineering installation in Shah Alam is still operating (M)

headline: For Africa's Deaf and Blind, AIDS Is an Unknown Language
abstract: Deaf and blind Africans often have very limited information about AIDS as result of discrimination or inability to communicate; rape of disabled women is significant problem in parts of Africa, aggravated by belief that sex with virgins cures disease; advocacy groups in Uganda and Ghana seek to draw attention to problem; Peace Corps has program in Kenya to educate deaf children about AIDS through signing; Kenyan government AIDS council last year gave money to hold AIDS seminars for disabled people, and has made sign language commercial to reach disabled; photo (M)

headline: JUDGE CLEARS WAY FOR VIVENDI AND DILLER TO GO TO TRIAL
abstract: Judge sets date of May 6 or 7 for start of trial of Vivendi Universal's lawsuit to force Barry Diller to get out of way of planned deal with General Electric Co's NBC unit (S)

headline: Executive Life; Your Next Boss Could Be a Temp
abstract: Small but growing number of executives are building careers as itinerant managers, moving from one senior-level assignment to next; such short-term jobs often pay better than permanent positions; offer relief for some from unemployment while offering others flexibility, variety and chance to use skills; companies find these executives can fill gaps quickly and often bring fresh solutions to longstanding problems; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro rises after European Central Bank council member says currency's advance is 'not excessive'; euro settles at $1.2633, up from $1.2568 in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: Help Grandparents of Rich Kids Now. Deal With Real Problems Later.
abstract: Floyd Norris comments on Bush administration's tax priorities; sees administration not very interested in biggest tax fight now going on with Europe--tax break for exporters that has been ruled illegal by World Trade Orgn; sees administration also not eager to deal with prospect of alternative minimum tax, which was intended for high-income earners, harming many middle-class taxpayers; sees Bush deeming it important to assure that wealthy Americans who die in 2011 and after will not face taxes on their estates; notes that in one of lesser tax proposals in budget released this week, Bush offers tax break for what must be very small group of taxpayers: those who support their grandchildren even though children are independenthly wealthy or earning substantial income on their own; chart shows revenue lost from Bush tax proposals each fiscal year, 2005 to 2014 (M)

headline: Leading Chinese Dissident Released From Prison
abstract: Chinese government, under international pressure, releases prominent pro-democracy dissident Wang Youcai, second political prisoner released in week; Wang arrives in San Francisco; he was sentenced to 11 years in prison in 1998 after co-founding China Democracy Party; China also frees Phuntsog Nyidron, Tibetan Buddhist nun imprisoned after peacefully protesting for Tibetan independence, and reduced sentence of Rebiya Kadeer, ethnic Uighur (M)

headline: Bank of India Ordered to Pay $82 Million
abstract: Bank of India is ordered to pay $82 million

headline: Palestinians Swear Vengeance For Killing of Cleric by Israelis
abstract: Sheik Ahmed Yassin, spiritual leader of militant group Hamas, is heralded as new unifying martyr by tens of thousands of Palestinians who flock to Gaza for his funeral; killing of Yassin by Israeli missile attack will almost certainly deepen divide between current Israeli and Palestinian leaderships, possibly ruling out further negotiations between them over Bush administration's sidelined peace plan; it is measure of Yassin's status as icon to Palestinians and as perceived threat to Israelis that his death seems to hold consequences for every player in conflict, from Israelis and Palestinians to Egyptians and Americans; Prime Min Ariel Sharon of Israel calls Yassin 'archmurderer' committed to killing Jews and destroying state of Israel, while Palestinian Prime Min Ahmed Qurei calls Yassin 'great leader'; Yasir Arafat, for whom Yassin was leading rival as national symbol, calls him 'martyr'; Israeli officials repeatedly compare Yassin to Osama bin Laden; Arab and European nations condemn killing of Yassin; Bush administration says it is 'troubled' by killing, but national security adviser Condoleezza Rice notes that Hamas is terrorist organization and Yassin is believed to have personally been involved in terrorist planning; photos (L)

headline: CHIQUITA IN TALKS TO SELL COLOMBIAN BANANA OPERATIONS
abstract: Chiquita Brands International Inc is in talks with C I Banacol, unit of Invesmar, to sell its Colombian banana operations (S)

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: Push On Cyprus
abstract: United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan has invited Greek and Turkish Cypriots to New York for eleventh-hour negotiations to try reuniting island that has been divided for 30 years; will work to develop Cyprus referendum that can be voted on in April; hopes to reunify island before entrance into European Union scheduled for May (S)

headline: Iraq's Path Hinges on Words of Enigmatic Cleric
abstract: Profile of Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, reclusive cleric revered by many Iraqi Shiites; his Najaf home has become center of power in Iraq; visitors clearly vie for his backing in current political free-for-all; his advisers range from formerly exiled politicians to local imams to envoys of coalition authority head L Paul Bremer III; photo (M)

headline: Retrieving a Rare Glimpse Of Those Fabled 1,000 Days
abstract: Jacques Lowe's book marking 40th anniversary of John F Kennedy assassination is posthumously completed after pictures destroyed in World Trade Center attacks are digitally recreated; scanning technology used in process described; photos (M)

headline: Dr. Norman Heatley, 92, Dies; Pioneer in Penicillin Supply
abstract: Penicillin developer Dr Norman Heatley dies at age 92 (M)

headline: Russia Issues International Wanted List in Oil Case
abstract: Russia places 10 Yukos Oil shareholders or employees on international wanted lists, including some senior executives who have sought asylum in Israel; move suggests prosecution of Yukos is extending far beyond former chief executive Mikhail B Kodorkovsky and his partner, Platon Lebedev, who are both in jail; Russia names three of those sought, Leonid B Nevzlin, Mikhail B Brudno and Vladimir M Dubov, all of whom are in Israel; Moscow court rejects Khodorkovsky's challenge of his Oct arrest (M)

headline: UNION PACIFIC NAMES CHIEF FOR RAILROAD UNIT
abstract: Union Pacific Corp appoints chief financial officer James Young to head its railroad unit and names Robert Knight to succeed him in finance post; Young to succeed Ivor Evans, who becomes vice chairman; Young and Evans are also named to new office of chairman along with chief executive Richard Davidson (S)

headline: Swiss Hold 8 Suspects in Saudi Attacks
abstract: Swiss police arrest eight foreign nationals suspected of involvement in suicide bomb attacks in May 2003 in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, that killed 35 people (S)

headline: Officer Is Promoted To Times Controller
abstract: Phyllis Calvano, executive director of finance and business development for circulation department of New York Times, is named vice president and controller; will oversee newspaper's payroll, budget and credit operations (S)

headline: Algeria Shows Willingness to Abandon Its Violent Past
abstract: Algeria's tough-minded military-backed government, which has fought Islamic insurgents for decade, at cost of 120,000 lives, faces next big test in presidential elections set for April 8; photo; some parties are not taking part to protest continuing state of emergency, but country is starting to return to fold of diplomacy and international commerce, as seen in recent OPEC meeting and stopovers by Sec Colin Powell and French Pres Jacques Chirac (M)

headline: Army Delays Discharge for Some G.I.'s in Afghanistan and Mideast
abstract: United States Army is preparing order that would require about 7,000 troops now in Iraq, Kuwait and Afghanistan to remain on duty through end of their deployments this spring, even if they could otherwise leave service before then; another order, previously announced, already prevents active-duty and reserve troops rotating into Iraq and Kuwait this year from leaving Army before serving 12 months on ground, plus 90-day period after they return (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Chipmaker Reverses
abstract: Infineon Technologies earned 34 million euros ($42 million) in its first quarter ended Dec 31, reversing loss of 40 million euros, despite 8 percent decline in revenue; sales totaled $1.62 billion euros; chief executive Ulrich Schumacher comments (S)

headline: Libya's Crude Bomb Design Eases Western Experts' Fear
abstract: Investigators determine that nuclear weapon blueprints found in Libya from Pakistani scientist Abdul Qadeer Khan were of his own relatively crude type of bomb--not more advanced models that Pakistan developed and successfully tested; analysis of blueprints has heartened investigators in Europe and United States because his design is seen as less threatening in terms of spread of nuclear weapons (M)

headline: Security Poor in Electronic Voting Machines, Study Warns
abstract: A report finds that widely used electronic voting machines have such poor computer and physical security that an election could be disrupted or even stolen.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Ivory Coast: Calls For Inquiry
abstract: France calls for United Nations inquiry into recent opposition march in Abidjan (Ivory Coast) that turned violent; estimated 37 to 600 individuals were killed during demonstration (S)

headline: It's Not Only the Giants With Franchises Abroad
abstract: Article on growing number of small US franchises that have businesses overseas; focuses on Le Gourmet Gift Basket Inc, which has 510 franchises, including 25 outside US, expanding into Hong Kong in 2002; chief executive Cynthia McKay comments; photo (M)

headline: Questions Seen On Seed Prices Set in the 90's
abstract: Senior executives at two biggest seed companies in world reportedly met repeatedly in mid- to late 1990's and agreed to charge higher prices for genetically modified seeds; Monsanto Co and Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc acknowledge meetings, but Monsanto says they were legitimate negotiations about changes to existing licensing agreement, not illegal price fixing; former and current executives of major seed companies, along with company documents, show Monsanto tried to control market for genetically altered corn and soybean seeds; Monsanto spent billions in 1980's to invent specialized seeds and sold rights to make them to big seed companies like Pioneer; together, Pioneer and Monsanto control 60 percent of nation's $5 billion market for corn and soybean seeds; dozen legal experts say if goal of their talks was to limit competition on prices, or even just to coordinate prices, it would be violation of federal antitrust law; companies found to have violated that law could be subject to criminal fines and civil class-action litigation; photos; drawings (L)

headline: S.E.C. Asks Tyson to Explain Benefits Received by Officers
abstract: Tyson Foods says Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating benefits provided to company officers, including chief executive John H Tyson; commission is also seeking information about bonuses provided to former senior chairman Don Tyson; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Cites 'Excellent Progress' With Libya
abstract: US says it is making 'excellent progress' with Libya in carrying out that country's decision to end its illicit weapon and missile programs and that curbs on travel by Americans and other sanctions could soon be lifted; announcement is made in London after meeting between Libyan officials and Asst Sec of State William J Burns (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia And Estonia Expel Diplomats
abstract: Russia retaliates against Estonia's recent expulsion of Russian diplomats accused of spying by requesting that two Estonian diplomats leave Russia (S)

headline: Ford Said to Be Planning Assembly Plant in China
abstract: Ford Motor Co is strongly leaning toward selection of Nanjing to be site for large assembly plant in China, as cornerstone of plan to invest more than $1 billion in world's fastest-growing auto market; plant will most likely produce versions of Ford Focus; map (M)

headline: Inquest on Dianas Death Begins, Reviving Theories of a Plot
abstract: Britains royal coroner said today that he would consider whether to include the conspiracy theories that are generally dismissed as absurd.

headline: Manufactured Drama Assists 'Survivor'-CBS Deal
abstract: CBS enters deal with Mark Burnett to produce two more editions of hit reality series Survivor; photo (M)

headline: Learning Entrepreneurship The U.S. Way at M.I.T.
abstract: British government has spent $118 million on partnership with Cambridge University and Massachusetts Institute of Technology to create Cambridge-MIT Institute, which offers three one-year graduate programs with aim to cultivate Britain's future technology entrepreneurs, create jobs and spur growth in British technology sector; inspiration for progams, which began in 2002, was phenomenal impact MIT has had on US economy through creation of technology-related companies by its alumni; Marie-Louis Huber, who started Cambridge Laboratories after finishing progam, comments; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Suspected Plotters In Prison Court
abstract: Seventy men accused of plotting to overthrow Equatorial Guinea's government are arraigned in Zimbabwe prison where they have been held since they and their plane were seized at airport; many are associated with mercenary organizations (S)

headline: Israeli Warplanes Attack 2 Hezbollah Bases in Lebanon
abstract: Israeli warplanes bomb two Hezbollah bases in southern Lebanon in retaliation for missile attack that killed Israeli soldier along border; Sec Colin Powell blames Hezbollah for border strife; Israeli forces knock down homes and mosque in Rafah, in Gaza Strip, in search of smuggling tunnel; also demolish synagogue set up at West Bank outpost, scuffling with radical settlers; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Airgas Inc., Radnor, Pa., a distributor of industrial and medical gases, said it had agreed to buy part of a cylinder-packaged gases business from the BOC Group, Windlesham, England, for as much as $200 million in cash.    MBNA Corp., Wilmington, Del., the credit card issuer, said it had bought Premium Credit Ltd. of Britain, an insurance premium finance company. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Americans in general 'just don't care' : Washington shrugs off trans-Atlantic discord
abstract: WASHINGTON:—  First of two articles.

headline: Treasury Bills Set For This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three-and six-month bills and a four-week bill on Tuesday. According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was at 0.90 percent and the rate on the six-month issue at 0.99 percent and the four-week issue at 0.84 percent.    The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week:

headline: Trial Against I.B.M. Over Worker Safety Practices Is Nearing a Finish
abstract: Closing arguments are set to begin in five-month-long trial of lawsuit brought against IBM by two former employees who accuse it of knowingly exposing them to dangerous chemicals; defense lawyer has tried to show that no link exists between IBM factory where plaintiffs worked and cancers they later developed; suit was brought by Alida Hernandez and James Moore, both of whom worked at IBM factory in South San Jose, Calif; photo (M)

headline: British Police Arrest 8 Suspected of Plotting Terrorist Attack
abstract: Hundreds of police sweep through London and commuter towns south of city, arresting eight men suspected of preparing terrorist attack and seizing 1,000 pounds of ammonium nitrate fertilizer from storage locker near central London; map; all reportedly are Pakistani Britons; antiterrorism chief Peter Clarke warns public to remain watchful, but also tries to reassure Muslim community that they are not all under suspicion (M)

headline: Japanese Capital and Jobs Flowing to China
abstract: Japan's top-end electronics manufacturers are building immense new plants and research centers in China to take advantage of abundant Chinese labor, doing nearly every kind of job their Japanese work force does; cost pressures are driving them to forget old fears of having their best technology stolen or of harsh publicity at home from moving high-paying jobs out of country; operations of Pioneer Corp, Sharp, NEC and Toshiba in China discussed; graph; photo (M)

headline: Business People; This Is One C.E.O. Who's Fond of Bond
abstract: this is one c.e.o. who's fond of bon

headline: In the Center of Baghdad, an Escape to America
abstract: The U.S. Army has converted a former Iraqi Republican Guard officers club into an American oasis for war-weary soldiers.

headline: Beijing Leaders' Populist Touch Is Not Felt by Most Rural Poor
abstract: China's Prime Min Wen Jiabao and Pres Hu Jintao have cast themselves as populists, but issues like income distribution, labor rights, taxation and land policy tend to divide Communist Party against itself--creating pockets of opposition that top leaders often seem unable or unwilling to overcome; political analysts say Wen and Hu fear that party may collapse unless it does more to share China's increasing prosperity with more of its 1.3 billion people; that requires that local officials, government-backed companies and well-connected businessmen give up power and profits; map of Yunyang, where many peasants are owed pay for work on construction projects; photo of Xiong Deming, who received personal help from Wen after her husband was not paid for work he had done (M)

headline: U.N. Security Council Considers Multinational Force
abstract: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 29 — The United Nations Security Council met in emergency session tonight to take up a resolution calling for the immediate deployment of a multinational force to Haiti.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Former Chief Executive Of WorldCom Is Indicted  Federal prosecutors charged Bernard J. Ebbers, the former chief executive of the telecommunications giant WorldCom, with conspiring to commit the biggest accounting fraud in the history of American business.     The company's former chief accounting officer, Scott D. Sullivan, who was also named in the indictment, pleaded guilty and said he would cooperate with prosecutors. Legal experts say Mr. Sullivan's decision to reach a plea agreement paved the way for the indictment of Mr. Ebbers and will be crucial to the chances of convicting him. [Page A1.]

headline: Liberal Talk Radio Network To Start Up in Three Cities
abstract: Liberal network known as Air America Radio says its progamming will make its debut on March 31 on low-rated stations in New York, Los Angeles and Chicago; says its hosts will include Al Franken, comedian and political satirist, actress Janeane Garofalo, hip-hop artist Chuck D and media analyst Martin Kaplan; network's chief executive is Mark Walsh; photo (M)

headline: Slides and Video Set to Music, In a Paperback-Size Package
abstract: RCA Lyra Audio/Video Jukebox 2780 from Thompson plays and records digital video, photos and music and is portable hard drive; photo (S)

headline: Turkey, Seeking U.S. Pledge on the Kurds' Role in the New Iraq, Finds Mixed Message
abstract: Sec of State Colin L Powell, meeting with Turkish Prime Min Recep Tayyip Erdogan in Washington, offers assurances that Kurds in a newly soverign Iraq will have to relinquish their control of oil resources in north; Turkish officials say they remain concerned that United States may still yield to Kurdish demands for autonomous state; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil prices rise above $37 a barrel; contract for Apr delivery jumps 62 cents, or 1.7 percent, to $37.26 a barrel; graphs; table (S)

headline: MFS Is Facing Another S.E.C. Inquiry
abstract: Massachusetts Financial Services Co, mutual fund unit of Sun Life Financial Inc of Canada, is facing second inquiry by Securities and Exchange Commission over its links with Morgan Stanley and other brokers; MFS is one of 14 companies reported to have paid Morgan Stanley in return for preferred marketing of its funds (S)

headline: Tax preparers fight hard for business in the brief season before April 15.
abstract: Nation's biggest tax preparation services, Jackson Hewitt and H & R Block, are fighting hard for business in brief tax season before April 15; Jackson Hewitt has prepared its most aggressive advertising to date, with $15 million to $20 million campaign that uses humor intended to convey speed and expertise; its campaign is bumping up against new commercials by industry leader H & R Block; photo (M)

headline: Beijing Journal; Chinese Take Recklessly to Cars (Just Count the Wrecks)
abstract: China's booming economy has established country as world's fastest-growing car market, and one of most dangerous places to drive; flood of new cars and novice drivers has led to fivefold increase in road deaths in two decades; photos (Beijing Journal) (M)

headline: 2 Killed as Troops Fight Protesters in Venezuela
abstract: Venezuelan troops and antigovernment demonstrators clash in Caracas, leaving at least two people dead and several wounded as Pres Hugo Chavez convenes summit meeting of developing countries; confrontation comes two days before government electoral board is to rule on validity of signatures opponents collected to force referendum on recalling Chavez from office; photo (M)

headline: Dutch House Votes to Expel Many Denied Political Shelter
abstract: Dutch lower house votes to expel up to 26,000 failed asylum-seekers, those who arrived before April 2001, who are mostly from former Yugoslavia, Iraq and Afghanistan; proponents say many can safely go home now and that many are 'benefit shoppers'; close to 700 on list are under investigation for war crimes; plan underscores anti-immigrant feelings in historically open society, in which huge influx is projected to create Muslim majorities in biggest cities by 2010 (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Gates Demonstrates Security Measures
abstract: Microsoft's chairman Bill Gates demonstrates security features planned for Windows XP operating system; says company decided to turn on, by default, firewall protection for Windows-based computers connected to Internet, to make it harder to exploit vulnerabilities in operating system; features also include additions to Internet Explorer and centralized Windows Security Center panel (S)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Blackfriars Communications issues first edition of Blackfriars Marketing Index, quarterly report intended to measure corporate marketing demand and spending; sets index at 119 for first quarter, meaning that executives responding to Blackfriars survey say they intend to spend 19 percent more on marketing in quarter than they spent on average in each quarter of 2003 (S)

headline: How Much Is That Drug in the Window?
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column on purchasing veterinary drugs online; Web sites noted; drawing (M)

headline: Revival in New York? Well, That Depends
abstract: Despite statistics indicating decreasing rate of unemployment in Greater New York area, some key industries actually suffered job losses in period from Jan-Nov, 2003, and most recent New York State figures show that unemployment in city proper actually increased to 7.9 percent in Dec 2003 from 7.7 percent in Nov; employers, employees and union officials say inconsistencies and contradictions in hiring abound; graphs; chart showing employment by industry (M)

headline: Rebel Leader in Haiti Says Hell Disarm
abstract: Haiti continued to grapple with the violence and lawlessness that has overrun the country in the last month.

headline: U.N. Aide Backs Cleric on Elections; Offers No Timetable
abstract: The U.N. envoy did not address whether it was feasible to hold the elections by June 30, the date for the scheduled transfer of sovereignty.

headline: Is Biotechnology Losing Its Nerve?
abstract: Many biotechnology companies seem to be taking fewer chances lately, raising concerns that industry may be losing its nerve and will produce fewer innovative drugs; such companies were once known for tackling challenges avoided by big pharmaceutical companies, developing genetically engineered medicines and plunging into experimental research that might never pay off; more and more start-ups now seem focused on scrounging around for existing drugs to license, avoiding toil and risk of trying to find new cause of disease or new compound; some do not even have laboratories; licensing graph; photos (M)

headline: GENERAL MOTORS TO BUY OUT SOUTH AFRICAN AUTOMAKER
abstract: General Motors Corp acquires 51 percent of South African automaker Delta Motor Corp that it does not already own (S)

headline: PeopleSoft Says Justice Dept. Is Urged to Block Oracle Bid
abstract: Staff lawyers at Justice Department are recommending that agency seek to block Oracle Corp's $9.4 billion hostile takeover of PeopleSoft Inc on grounds that deal would be anticompetitive (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Europe Renews Sanctions
abstract: European Union, citing worsening human rights conditions in Zimbabwe, votes to renew two-year-old economic sanctions levied against nation and top officials, including President Robert Mugabe (S)

headline: Business; Companies Hope Profits Run From Clean Water
abstract: Profile of growing industry that seeks to provide clean water for industrial and municipal use and clean dirty water when use is done; industry is complex business with 100,000 players providing all kinds of services and products; potential profits have attracted industrial giants like General Electric; photos (M)

headline: Moving to Singapore : The twists and turns of apartment hunting
abstract: SINGAPORE—  Southeast Asia's cities conjure up some nightmarish images: horrendous traffic, ghastly pollution, crime, slums and prostitution — not the kind of places you want to live, in other words.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Yukos Executive Arrested
abstract: World Business Brie

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Missile Test
abstract: Indian defense officials announce successful test of Prithvi, medium-range ballistic missile capable of housing nuclear warhead; hold test does not reflect any changes in diplomatic policies toward South Asian neighbors (S)

headline: A Software Aimed at Taming File-Sharing
abstract: Recording Industry Assn of America sees promise in technology developed by Audible Magic that it says can spot copyrighted materials while they are being passed from computer to computer and block transfer; says file-sharing companies, who have argued that they cannot control copyright infringement on their peer-to-peer networks, can show that they are serious about becoming legitimate by adding this technology to their wares (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: A Bid Too Low
abstract: Aventis chief executive Igor Landau says $60 billion takeover bid made by rival Sanofi-Synthelabo is too low (S)

headline: Pfizer Ad Stirs Talk of Entry Into Rivals' Fight
abstract: Ad placed by Pfizer Inc in Fren

headline: MediaTalk; For Disney's Embattled Chief, a Double Rebuke From Fidelity
abstract: Walt Disney Co confirms that Fidelity Investments, one of its largest shareholders, voted at annual meeting to withhold votes for Michael D Eisner, chief executive and then chairman as well; Fidelity also manages Disney's 401(k) retirement plan, so its decision means that Disney employees investing in Fidelity mutual funds that hold Disney stock were withholding support from Eisner; T Rowe Price Group, mutual fund company that is Disney's 14th-largest shareholder, also withholds votes for Eisner and some other directors (S)

headline: India's Soybean Farmers Join the Global Village
abstract: India's soybean farmers now rely on computers to check futures prices on commodities exchanges, check local prices before going to market and communicate with other farmers worldwide; network, called e-choupal, from Hindi word for village square or gathering place, was started by ITC Ltd; network has done as much as anything to bridge nation's vast digital divide, and may offer model for all developing countries; through array of satellites that allow it to sidestep shaky power supply and lack of phone lines, ITC has instantly broadened villagers' horizons; idea of e-choupals was to allow company to capture more of soybean market, but it is blooming into vast network providing data that will increase farmers' production and income as well; other ventures, agricultural and beyond, planned by ITC discussed; map; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Sumatran Tiger Reportedly Near Extinction
abstract: Sue Lieberman, World Wildlife Fund and Traffic director, reports that Sumatran tiger is near extinction with only 500 to 600 living in wild; stresses that Indonesia must enforce laws against poaching and endangered animal trading if animal is to survive; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Saudi Arabia: First All-News TV Channel
abstract: Saudi Arabia's first all-news satellite television channel begins broadcasting; news is anchored by Bothaina al-Nasr, woman who appears in western clothing, but wears head scarf; Deputy Information Minister Prince Turki bin Sultan bin Abdel Aziz holds that state-owned broadcast shows real Saudi Arabia (S)

headline: SIX FLAGS TO SELL TWO OF ITS DIVISIONS FOR $345 MILLION
abstract: Six Flags sells its two worst-performing businesses for $345 million; sells its European division to undisclosed company in London for $200 million and Six Flags Worlds of Adventure, near Cleveland, to Cedar Fair for $145 million (S)

headline: Pakistan Parliament Jeers Musharraf for Speech Against Extremism
abstract: Islamist legislators walk out and secular deputies jeer as Pakistani leader Pervez Musharraf condemns religious extremism in first speech to Parliament since seizing power in 1999; Musharraf, who narrowly escaped two assassination attempts by suspected militants in December, shows no sign of backing off from renewed promise to crack down on religious extremism; Musharraf contends extremism and foreign elements harm Pakistan internally and injure reputation abroad; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Inquiry In Deportation Case
abstract: Canadian government will open public inquiry into Syrian-born Canadian citizen Maher Arar's detention in New York and deportation to Syria under suspicion of involvement in terrorist activities; Arar claims he was tortured during his detention in Syria (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Tourist Concern Sells Assets
abstract: Germany-based TUI, Europe's largest travel company, will sell additional industrial units this year to concentrate on its tourism business and to cut its debt to less than 2 billion euros in third quarter; graph (S)

headline: Israel Seals Off Gaza Strip Following Suicide Bombing
abstract: Israel sealed off the Gaza Strip, preventing thousands of Palestinians with Israeli permits from entering Israel a day after a Palestinian suicide bomber killed four Israelis near the Erez crossing point.

headline: U.S. JOINS IRAQIS TO SEEK U.N. ROLE IN INTERIM RULE
abstract: Bush administration, hoping to rescue its troubled plan to restore sovereignty to Iraq, is joining Iraqi leaders to press United Nations to play role in choosing interim government in Baghdad; American administrator L Paul Bremer III and Iraqi delegation led by Adnan Pachachi, chairman of Iraqi Governing Council, will make urgent appeal for greater UN involvement; tens of thousands of demonstrators in Basra put pressure on US to support calls by leading Shiite cleric Grand Ayatollah Ali Al-Sistani for direct elections; new move at UN involves yet another change in strategy for administration under pressure from shifting events in Iraq; administration has had ambivalent attitude toward UN from very start of planning war to oust Saddam Hussein; it is also considering reversing itself and allowing businesses in countries that opposed war, including France, Germany and Russia, to bid on contracts to rebuild Iraq; photos (M)

headline: Barriers disappear in high-tech world : A blurring of the lines
abstract: HANNOVER, Germany:—  What does Philips, a Dutch consumer electronics company that makes everything from light bulbs to television sets, have in common with Universal the movie studio, Vodafone the telecom company, and Nokia the cellphone maker?

headline: Co-Defendant Bacanovic Is Convicted of 4 of 5 Counts
abstract: Martha Stewart was convicted of conspiracy, obstruction of justice and two counts of making false statements.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Brewery Stake Is Acquired
abstract: Dutch brewer Heineken is investing 28.5 million euros ($35.6 million) through Asian-affiliated company Heineken Asia Pacific Breweries China to acquire stake in Guangdong Brewery Holdings in southern China; affiliate is acquiring 21 percent of Guangdong Brewery, whose subsidiaries make Kingway beer; Asia Pacific, co-owner of affiliate, is also investing 28.5 million euros; graph (S)

headline: Coke's Chief Set to Retire at End of 2004
abstract: Coca-Cola Co's chairman-chief executive Douglas N Daft will retire at end of year; company board plans to hire search firm and will immediately begin looking both inside and outside company for successor; Coke's president-chief operating officer Steven J Heyer is strong internal candidate; Donald R Keough is elected to company's board; chart; photo (M)

headline: Britain Drops Charges in Leak of U.S. Memo
abstract: British government, in sudden reversal, will not prosecute Katharine Gun, government intelligence translator who admitted leaking top-secret request by US National Security Agency for help in bugging UN diplomats during Iraq war debate last year; her photo; her lawyers say they would have turned trial into debate on legality of Britain's entry into war; Gun claims she acted to expose US attempt to undermine UN debate (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Orange juice futures fall because of concern that record orange crop in Florida will overwhelm demand; orange juice for March delivery falls 4.55 cents, or 6.9 percent, to 61.45 cents a pound in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: NRG ENERGY PLANS TO RELOCATE ITS HEADQUARTERS
abstract: NRG Eü

headline: Toll-Free Apology Soothes Savage Beast
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column on Web site Planetfeedback.com that forwards complaints, questions and suggestions directly to online purveyors of goods and services; users can elect to have comments posted on Web site; drawing (M)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: AFGHANISTAN: U.S. Soldier Killed; GOVERNMENTS WARNED ON BIRD FLU;.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: $2.4 Trillion Budget Plan Raises Security Spending  President Bush proposed a $2.4 trillion budget that would substantially increase funding next year for national security but would cut or strictly limit spending on most domestic programs and, on paper at least, put the government on a path of declining deficits.      The plan called for an increase in military spending of 7 percent, to $401.7 billion, and a rise in spending on domestic security programs of 9.7 percent, to $30.5 billion. It makes good on Mr. Bush's pledge to cut the deficit in half within five years. [Page A1.]

headline: McDONALD'S SAYS MAD COW WORRIES AREN'T HURTING SALES
abstract: McDonald's Corp chief executive James R Cantalupo says mad cow disease in US and bird flu in Asia and US will not affect first-quarter sales (S)

headline: Turkey wants right-of-return scaled back : Ankara to offer land in Cyprus deadlock
abstract: ANKARA:—  Turkey will offer a land-for-peace deal in an attempt to break a deadlock over the reunification of Cyprus, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, prime minister of Turkey, said Wednesday.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Canary Wharf Bid Raised
abstract: Canada's Brascan raises its bid for Canary Wharf office development in London to 1.6 billion pounds ($3.03 billion), matching earlier offer made by consortium led by Morgan Stanley (S)

headline: Among Cancer Doctors, a Medicare Revolt; New Payment System Spurs Talk of Return to Hospital Care and Old Drugs
abstract: Medicare program is changing way it pays cancer doctors, and some oncologists are so angry that, hoping to turn patients into lobbyists, they are warning patients that they face return to hospitalization and nausea instead of current practice of treating patients in their offices; doctors in practice called Oncology Associates in Hartford wrote letter recently to their patients saying that because of new reimbursement system, patients might have to 'switch to older medications'; contended that they would be financially unable to give chemotherapy medications which cost more than Medicare reimbursement; similar letters are being delivered to patients around country, according to oncologists, advocates for cancer patients and American Society of Clinical Oncology, nation's largest professional society of cancer doctors; Dr Peter D Eisenberg of Greenbrae, Calif, says his practice has cut staff and can no longer provide all services patients have grown accustomed to; photos (M)

headline: Oil Companies Find Ecuador Frustrating
abstract: Oil analysts and Petroleo Brasileiro official say Brazilian company is trying to unload much of its stake of two big oil blocks in Ecuador that produce 17,000 barrel of oil per day; acknowledge Ecuador has plenty of oil but country has dismal record of managing oil contracts; oil consultants and managers of 3 of about 20 companies that operate in Ecuador say Ecuador has reneged on agreements, raised tax and royalty rates beyond what is palatable to investors and otherwise changed legal framework governing how companies operate, alienating host of international oil companies; oil companies like ExxonMobil and BP that could be spending billions of dollars to drive development of Ecuador's oil industry are long gone; some policies of Pres Lucio Gutierrez are drawing complaints from oil companies; photo (M)

headline: Brazilian Slums Are Seen as Pawns in Political Games
abstract: Estrutural shantytown outside Brasilia is example of problem of squatters' settlements in developing world; 20,000 people live with no services or infrastructure and no political representation in sprawling slum named for highway that runs alongside; Estrutural fits pattern of squatters settlements in which UN estimates one third of world's urban population, or almost 1 billion people, live; UN finds squatting has become large and profitable business, often carried out with active, if clandestine, participation of politicians, police and privateers of all kinds; photos, map (M)

headline: Wal-Mart Sales Optimism
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores says US sales are rising close to 6 percent in March as shoppers buy more Easter decorations and spring clothing (S)

headline: NBC Asks Leno to Work Late Through End of the Decade
abstract: NBC is expected to announce five-year contract extension that will continue Jay Leno's run as host of The Tonight Show With Jay Leno until Dec 31, 2009; move leaves open questions about NBC's intentions for late-night show Late Night With Conan O'Brien; O'Brien, whose contract with network will expire in Dec 2005, has followed Leno for 11 years and will have to wait until start of new decade before he could hope to succeed him as host of Tonight show; Leno's contract extension could inspire other networks to pursue O'Brien; photo (M)

headline: Hotels Learn to Deal With Disability
abstract: Hotels Learn to

headline: COURT EXAMINER FINDS FOR UAL ON RETIREE BENEFITS
abstract: Court-appointed examiner finds UAL Corp, parent of United Airlines, did not mislead employees about possible changes in medical benefits to persuade workers to retire early; unions representing flight attendants, baggage handlers and mechanics say that thousands of employees agreed to retire before July 1, 2003, believing that if they did so, their benefits would remain intact (S)

headline: A TV show spurs moves and countermoves from CBS and NBC.
abstract: Battle between CBS and NBC over The Apprentice, new rat-race reality series on NBC featuring Donald J Trump, is developing into feud; CBS is taking several unusual steps in effort to blunt viewership of The Apprentice before reality series begins on Wednesday nights; among its maneuvers, CBS counter-scheduling popular hourlong dramas like CSI: Crime Scene Investigation and Cold Case; moves come after NBC decides to broadcast special preview edition of The Apprentive on Thursday, Jan 8; combatants are NBC president Jeff Zucker and CBS chairman-chief executive Leslie Moonves; photo (M)

headline: WAL-MART SALES MEET FORECAST; TARGET FALLS SHORT
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores Inc says sales so far in January have met its forecast for gain of as much as 5 percent at stores open at least year, while Target Corp says sales are slightly below its forecast (S)

headline: 2 COMPANIES TO FORM INTERNATIONAL TEXTILE GROUP
abstract: Wilbur Ross, who bought Cone Mills Corp out of bankruptcy, will combine company with his Burlington Industries to create International Textile Group; two companies will have combined annual revenue of about $900 million (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Prosecutor In Crime-Torn State Quits
abstract: Jesus Jose Solis, leading prosecutor in crime-ridden Chihuahua State (Mexico), resigns amid accusations of providing protection for Juarez drug cartel (S)

headline: Modified Seeds Found Amid Unmodified Crops
abstract: Union of Concerned Scientists says seeds that are supposed to be free of genetic engineering routinely contain biotehnology traits anyway; says if seeds to not contain traits, it would be virtually impossible for farmers to grow crops that are completely free of genetic modification; could mean disruption of crop exports to countries that do not allow genetically engineered foods; also makes it harder for organic farmers to supply customers who will not accept even tiny degrees of genetic engineering (M)

headline: World Briefing | Ecology: Gorillas Making A Comeback
abstract: Wildlife Conservation Society reports that current census of mountain gorilla population in Uganda, Rwanda and Congo shows 17 percent increase since 1989 (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Airline Plans Growth
abstract: Korean Air Co will spend 10.6 trillion won ($9 billion) in next 10 years on its fleet and services as it aims to become one of world's top airlines (S)

headline: Pfizer Gives Up Testing Viagra On Women
abstract: Pfizer Inc is abandoning its effort to prove that impotence drug Viagra improves sexual function in women; company's researchers say problem is that men and women have fundamentally different relationship between arousal and desire; arousal almost always leads to desire for men; Viagra measurably affects man's sexual function by improving his ability to have erections; arousal and desire are often disconnected in women to their consternation; researchers find although Viagra can create outward signs of arousal in many women, that seems to have little effect on woman's willingness, or desire, to have sex (M)

headline: The Electronic Verification Is in the Mail
abstract: Article discusses software developed by the United States Postal Service, Microsoft and Authentidate; Electronic Postmark, compatible with Word XP and Word 2003, locks documents preventing further changes; drawing (M)

headline: Europeans Rule Against Microsoft; Appeal Is Promised
abstract: The penalty, consultations and negotiations, went well beyond what the U.S. Justice Department agreed to in its antitrust case brought in the late 1990s.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Aladdin Shares Surge 27%
abstract: Shares of Aladdin Knowledge Systems, maker of software used for secure Internet transactions, rise 27 percent after company increases its forecast for first-quarter revenue (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Johnson & Johnson, New Brunswick, N.J., the world's biggest maker of medical devices, said its Centocor unit that makes the rheumatoid arthritis drug Remicade agreed to buy a manufacturing plant in St. Louis from Wyeth, Madison, N.J., the health care products company. Terms were not disclosed.    Lucent Technologies Inc., Murray Hill, N.J., the largest maker of telephone equipment in the United States, had its credit outlook changed to positive from negative by Moody's Investors Service, which cited the company's cost cuts and stabilized sales.

headline: U.N. to Send Envoy Back to Iraq to Help in Transfer of Power
abstract: The chief U.N. envoy for Iraq, Lakhdar Brahimi, will return to Iraq in coming weeks to help shape the transfer of power.

headline: For Those in the Fast Lane, MSN Tries to Smooth the Way
abstract: THE assumption of many providers of high-speed Internet service today is that you are a power user; that is, you don't need any help. You manage your e-mail with a free service like Hotmail or Yahoo, or know how to set up a POP3 account in Outlook.     You already have software to protect you from hackers, viruses and spyware. You have a working knowledge of Photoshop (or at least Photoshop Elements) and you share pictures with family members at Ofoto. Google is your research hub, you download movie trailers at QuickTime.com, and you may even subscribe to a streaming music service like Rhapsody. You're a Net veteran, and all you require of your service provider is an always-on connection to a fat Internet pipeline.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Retailer's Sales Fall
abstract: British retailer Marks & Spencer reports 3.3 percent decline in Christmas season clothing sales; says David Norgrove, executive in charge of clothing division, will resign; photo (S)

headline: Truck Bombs Kill 11 Iraqis At Army Base Run by Poles
abstract: Suicide bombers in two trucks loaded with explosives attack Polish military base, Hillah, Iraq, killing 11 Iraqis and wounding over 100 others, including 58 soldiers; attack, third such bombing in eight days, seems aimed at alienating Iraqis who may support American-led occupation and at nations supporting occupation with troops; photos (M)

headline: Bogotá's Social Capitalism, Led by a Marxist of Old
abstract: Antonio Sanguino is one of number of former Marxist rebel fighters in Colombia who now lead Nuevo Arco Iris, or New Rainbow, socially minded business model that channels money from business enterprises into social programs; he says he believes market can generate wealth, which benefits people in long run; survival of Arco Iris, along with similar but smaller programs run by former rebels, is crucial in country that is trying, through two-pronged strategy of military offensives and disarmament negotiations, to sideline three armed insurgencies; Nuevo Arcos owns hotels, agricultural brokerage firm, has built 600 homes and other ventures; photos (L)

headline: Cheney Calls for More Unity in Fight Against Terrorism
abstract: Speaking on Saturday at an international conference in Davos, Switzerland, Vice President Dick Cheney sought to patch up strains with European allies.

headline: Cypriots Facing Deadline Today In Unity Talks
abstract: Greek and Turkish Cypriot negotiators, sequestered at Swiss hotel, enter tense final stages of effort to reunite island before May 1 deadline for entering European Union; both sides offer responses to UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan's proposals; island would be federaton under loose central government (S)

headline: With a Sweep of a Baton, Scan Pages on the Go
abstract: Hand-held scanner from Planon looks like pen and scans page in single sweep; does not have to be connected to computer when scans are made; photo (S)

headline: Easing of Internet Regulations Challenges Surveillance Efforts
abstract: Federal law enforcement agencies say their ability to monitor terrorists and other criminal suspects electronically is being threatened by easing of Internet rules; officials from Justice Dept, FBI and Drug Enforcement Adm have held series of unpublicized meetings, complaining about Federal Communications Comm's 2002 decision to classify high-speed Internet cable services under looser regulatory regime than phone system; Justice Dept fears deregulation order impedes its ability to enforce wiretapping orders, and it has tried to block FCC from appealing recent federal appeals court decision that strikes down major parts of its deregulatory order; FCC has appealed, and as result some telecommunications carriers have taken position in court proceedings that they do not need to make their networks available to federal agents for court-approved wiretapping; law enforcement officials are also concerned about recent statements by FCC Chmn Michael K Powell that he intends to propose rules placing nascent Internet-based telephone services under looser regulatory regime than traditional phone system (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Contract For Iron Ore
abstract: BHP Billiton agrees to sell $9 billion of iron ore to four Chinese steel makers under 25-year contract; graph (S)
