headline: Blasts at Shiite Ceremonies in Iraq Kill More Than 140
abstract: Bombs and explosions ripped through Baghdad and Karbala as pilgrims flocked to shrines on one of the Shiites holiest days.

headline: MEMO PAD
abstract: SpeedNews estimates total of 1,622 big jets were in storage as of January, chiefly at sites in Mojave desert near Los Angeles and Sonoran desert near Tucson; another 173 smaller regional jets and 848 turboprop aircraft were also in mothballs; National Business Travel Association survey finds most corporate travel managers think that business travel will rebound significantly this year and next; Singapore Airlines will claim record for longest scheduled nonstop flight Feb 3 when it starts service between Singapore and Los Angeles; flight time is 18 1/2 hours; Delta Air Lines will invest $300 million over six years to improve its terminal at Kennedy International Airport, also home base for JetBlue Airways; Delta also says it will add eight new destinations and increase its daily departures from Kennedy International; graph; drawing (Memo Pad column) (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Disney Chairman Has Task Of Quelling the Unrest  George J. Mitchell has just assumed one of the most challenging jobs in corporate America, chairman of the Walt Disney Company.     But rather than running the company, Mr. Mitchell, a former United States senator who helped broker a peace agreement in Northern Ireland, sees his main job as negotiating among factions of disgruntled investors, other board members and Michael D. Eisner. Mr. Eisner, the chief executive, lost the chairman's title in the wake of a no-confidence vote at the shareholder meeting. [Page A1.]

headline: After Attacks, Iraqi Security Looks Unready
abstract: Iraqi security forces are not expected to be able to guarantee safety after planned transfer of sovereignty to Iraqi government at end of June; series of bold attacks on military and police forces culminated in overrunning of police station in Falluja; photos; at least 25 people died (M)

headline: Market Place; S.E.C. HAS FOUND PAYOFFS IN SALES OF MUTUAL FUNDS
abstract: SEC investigators find widespread instances of brokers receiving undisclosed payments of cash and other compensation for steering investors toward specific mutual funds; say investors were not informed, as required by law, when funds engaged in one particularly prevalent form of compensation, steering trading of stocks in their portfolios to brokerage houses that would promote funds to their brokerage clients; harm caused to individual investor by most of mutual fund abuses revealed in last four months has been abstract and indirect, but new disclosures suggest that many ordinary investors were misled (M)

headline: Wells Fargo and Bank One Report Increases in Profit
abstract: Wells Fargo and Bank One report double-digit growth in fourth-quarter earnings; Wells Fargo's net income increased 10 percent, to $1.62 billion from $1.47 billion year ago; revenue from mortgage banking increased 23 percent, to $636 million; revenue from fes rose 18 percent, to $3.4 billion; revenue from taking in deposits and making loans grew 7 percent, to $3.58 billion; Bank One's net income rose 16 percent, to $978 million compared with $842 million year ago (M)

headline: Martha Stewart's Lawyers Score Legal Victory On Testimony
abstract: Martha Stewart's lawyers score victory when Federal Judge Miriam Goldman Cedarbaum, presiding judge in Stewart's criminal trial involving her sale of ImClone Systems stock, says shw will not allow jury to hear testimony from Wall Street analysts and other experts about whether public statements she made influenced investors in her company; ruling is helpful to Stewart's defense on charge of securities fraud she faces; Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia sustains public-relations blow with revelation that Kmart, its longtime partner in selling Martha Stewart products, is suing it in federal bankruptcy court; Kmart is seeking to pay Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia less than it was owed under contract signed in 2001; at issue are royalty payments that Stewart's company says is owed but that Kmart contends are part of contract; Stewart's company is guaranteed minimum payment even if sales in Kmart stores fall short, and her company has said that it expects only minimum for last year (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Freeze On Ex-President's Assets
abstract: Federal judge freezes personal assets of former Argentinian President Carlos Saul Menem after Swiss banks place his name on list of foreign leaders suspected of corruption and money laundering and at least $500,000 of undeclared money in Swiss account is discovered; photo (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen rises after reports show overseas investors bought record amount of Japanese shares and country's trade surplus widened; dollar settles at 106.04 yen, down from 106.10 yen in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: Historic Haitian City Squeezed by Uprising
abstract: Dozens of houses and businesses in historic Haitian city of Cap Haitien are burned down, reportedly by roving band of militiamen loyal to Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide; leaders of growing opposition movement claim fires are part of all-out effort by police and militias aligned with Aristide government to remain in control of city by terrorizing government opponents into submission; police deny charge and claim armed Aristide opponents are trying to overrun their precincts and destabilize city; photo; map (M)

headline: Bond Manager Hires Ex-Treasury Aide
abstract: BlackRock Inc, large bond manager for institu

headline: CONGOLEUM FILES BANKRUPTCY PLAN WITH ASBESTOS LIABILITY
abstract: Congoleum Corp files for bankruptcy protection with plan in place to resolve asbestos-related litigation, pay creditors and reorganize (S)

headline: Business People; A Supersized Tailgate Party
abstract: Bo Jackson, former football star turned food entrepreneur, will spend Super Bowl Sunday in Iraq, visiting troops and holding Super Bowl party featuring some of his food products; photo (S)

headline: Pakistan Adopting A Tough Old Tactic To Flush Out Qaeda
abstract: Pakistan recently massed several thousand troops in and around Wana, near border with Afghanistan; officials, using century-old British tactic, told tribal elders that if 72 men wanted for sheltering Al Qaeda were not produced, Pakistani Army would punish tribe as group; tribes handed over 42 of wanted men, and tribal members bulldozed homes of eight men who refused to surrender; most wanted fugitives, including foreign Al Qaeda members, remain at large; Pakistani officials have promised not to hand over any fugitive Pakistanis to US; photo; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: A Joint Lottery
abstract: Euro Millions, weekly lottery game sponsored by national lotteries of France, Spain and Britain, is scheduled to hold first drawing on Feb 13 with starting jackpot of $18.88 million or 15 million euros (S)

headline: For Her, U.S. Borders Are Profit Centers
abstract: Small Business column on New Technology Management, which installs border surveillance systems for Department of Homeland Security; company was founded in 1990 by chief executive-president Lurita Doan; photo (M)

headline: Saudis Push Plan for Cut In Production By OPEC
abstract: Saudi Arabia, pivotal member of OPEC, is pushing ahead with plan to lower cartel's target for crude oil production by million barrels per day, move that would keep oil prices high; Saudi Oil Min Ali al-Naimi says throwing more oil on market would be destructive for everybody; says recent run-up in prices has been caused by spate of speculative activity in commodity markets, not by inadequate supply; crude oil reaches near-record high of $36.25 in New York trading; average retail price for gasoline rises to record $1.753 per gallon; twenty-five Democratic senators urge Pres Bush to press OPEC to increase production; Sen John Kerry says Bush administration has not done enough to hold down energy costs; says US should be putting pressure on OPEC to increase supplies and not allow those countries to undermine economies of world; White House spokesman Scott McClellan dismisses criticism; chart; photo (M)

headline: Intergraph And Intel Settle Chip Dispute
abstract: Intel agrees to pay $225 million to Intergraph Corp to settle remaining claims that its Itanium chip infringed on Intergraph's patents; settlement brings total amount Intel has paid or will pay to Intergraph to $675 million; Intergraph agrees to drop 2002 lawsuit against Dell, which uses Intel's chips in its personal computers, and to give Dell license to all of Intergraph's patents (M)

headline: Haiti's Embattled Leader Vows to Finish Term
abstract: Haitian Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide, defiant in face of increasingly violent opposition movement, denounces it as effort to overthrow elected government, declares that only he can save country from civil war and vows to finish term that expires in Feb 2006; interview; photo (M)

headline: Oracle Names 5 for Board Of PeopleSoft
abstract: Oracle Corp names five people it plans to nominate to PeopleSoft Inc board, advancing its threat to stage proxy fight to acquire company; also asks that appointment of Mike Maples to board as result of company's acquisition of J D Edwards be presented to shareholders for election (M)

headline: Howard Stern's Radio Show Is Suspended by Clear Channel
abstract: Clear Channel Communications suspends Howard Stern from its radio stations after announcing policy to prevent broadcasting of indecent content; earlier fired Todd Clem as host of show broadcast from Florida for airing sexually explicit material (M)

headline: Judging the Boss's Pay
abstract: Mark Z Sappir letter on

headline: XO BUYS MOST OF ALLEGIANCE FOR $628 MILLION
abstract: XO Communications, controlled by fina

headline: Piercing the Fog With a Tiny Chip
abstract: What's Next column column discusses radar system built on fully integrated silicon chip by electrical engineers at California Institute of Technology; possible applications noted; photos (M)

headline: Over There; Catching the Big Game by Satellite Feed in Iraq
abstract: Article discusses American Forces Network's use of device called VBrick to retransmit Super Bowl, to military bases, over military-closed Internet (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Turk Killed In Highway Ambush
abstract: Taliban gunmen, attempting to disrupt construction efforts on American-built Kabul to Kandahar highway, are thought to have kidnapped Turkish engineer and his driver and killed second Turkish engineer and his Afghan guard (S)

headline: Judge Clears Blair of Wrongdoing in Scientists Suicide
abstract: The chairman of the BBC, which used the scientist as a source for reports on Iraqs arms that caused a political crisis, resigned after the government was cleared.

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: SOUTH AFRICA: Sister Beating Remark Draws Fire; ZIMBABWE: Suspected Plotters In Prison Court;.

headline: Ready for Takeoff, With Emphasis on 'Off'
abstract: Federal Aviation Administration committee is exploring use of wireless devices on airplanes to determine impact of interference with aircraft systems; will need to make broad recommendations because new products are entering market so quickly; drawing (M)

headline: E-Mailing a Cellphone by the Numbers
abstract: Teleflip is e-mail service that allows anyone to send e-mail message to any text-equipped cellphone in North America without knowing that phone's e-mail address; sender uses telephone number followed by code atteleflip.com and message reaches phone in minutes; photo (M)

headline: A Road Less Traveled Through Immigration Lines
abstract: INS Passenger Accelerated Service System, or Inspass, enables participants to use self-service machines at inspection points at airports instead of waiting to show agent their passports; Inspass programs is in limbo as government overhauls airport and border security, so machines are installed at only half dozen airports, and even those are not always working; photo (M)

headline: Saudi Economy Defies Terrorism Fears
abstract: Saudi Arabia's economy is expected to deliver second year of growth in 2004, helped by highest sustained oil prices in more than two decades, though its performance is expected to fall short of surprising 6 percent increase in output last year; there is considerable concern whether economy will grow fast enough to alleviate social concerns like unemployment, which stands at 10 percent in government figures but is probably above 13 percent (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Interest Rate Move
abstract: Bank of England raises its benchmark interest rate by quarter point, second increase in four months, on concerns that stronger economic growth in Britain and global recovery may lead to higher inflation (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Consumer Spending Rises
abstract: South Korea's retail and wholesale spending rose 0.6 percent in December from year earlier, possibly indicating consumer spending will lift country's sluggish economy (S)

headline: Where to Go When the Easy Gains Are Gone
abstract: Robert D Arnot, manager of $1 billion Pimco All Asset fund, answers questions on outlook for stock and bond markets in 2004; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Deutsche Telekom Posts 4th-Quarter Loss
abstract: Deutsche Telekom posts fourth-quarter loss because it had to write off 442 million euros ($544 million) on Germany's road toll system; net loss was 364 million euros ($448 million), up from 77 million euros year earlier; pretax earnings rose 3.4 percent to 4.5 billion euros while sales remained at 14.55 billion euros (S)

headline: Big TVs Without a Fortune
abstract: Television pictures as big as those offered by plasma behemoths are now available at much lower prices.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: Jail For Colonel In 1990 Murder
abstract: Guatemalan Supreme Court sentences former army Colonel Juan Valencia Osorio to 30 years in prison for ordering 1990 murder of anthropologist Myrna Mack; Mack was researching rights abuses committed by military personnel against Mayan Indians (S)

headline: AGCO SAYS S.E.C. IS INVESTIGATING ITS ACCOUNTING
abstract: Agco, maker of farm equipment, says SEC had begun informal inquiry of accounting practices used in last two years (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Federal-Mogul Corp., Southfield, Mich., an auto parts maker operating under bankruptcy protection since October 2001, said that Robert S. Miller Jr. had returned as chairman, replacing Frank E. Macher.    Formica Corp., Warren, N.J., a maker of laminates and other surfacing products, won approval of a revamping plan from a judge in New York, clearing its last legal hurdle to emerging from bankruptcy.

headline: Creative Officer Leaves J. Walter Thompson
abstract: Michael J Campbell is leaving his post as executive vice president and chief creative officer at flagship New York office of J Walter Thompson; agency promotes Eric Steinhauser and Nat Whitten to assume Campbell's duties (S)

headline: Iraqi Shiites, in Setback to U.S., Fail to Sign Temporary Charter
abstract: Shiite leaders refuse to sign Iraq's temporary constitution unless changes are made that will strengthen Shiite power, throwing political process into disarray and posing major embarrassment for US officials; five Shiite leaders say they decided to back out of agreement after meeting with Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani; say they want to strike from temporary constitution provision that would allow relatively small minority of country's voters to block passage of permanent constitution; disputed provision was inserted to help gain support of Kurds, who are trying to maintain large measure of autonomy they gained over last 13 years; photos (M)

headline: Jorge Guinle, 88, a Playboy Who Outlived His Millions
abstract: Jorge Guinle, one of last of millionaire playboys whose free-spending ways and romantic exploits made them global celebrities from 1930's onward, dies at age 88; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: TURKEY: Woman Survives Week In Rubble; BRITAIN: 7 Arrested In Drownings; GREECE: Socialists Elect New Leader; FRANCE: Compensation Ordered For War Loot;.

headline: Immigrant's Life in the Shadows Ends in a Jerusalem Blast
abstract: Menbere Waldi Tzadik, illegal worker from Ethiopia, was among 11 people killed by Palestinian suicide bomber on Jerusalem bus; body was so badly shattered and family's status in Israel so tenuous that it took almost two days to confirm she was victim; her husband comments, interview (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Nuclear Inquiry To Be Quick
abstract: Pakistani Information Ministry inquiry into alleged sharing of nuclear technology with Iran will be concluded within one week; nine people, including assistant to Pakistan's leading nuclear scientist Abdul Qadeer Khan, will be questioned (S)

headline: Radio Sees Nirvana of the 90's in Its Future
abstract: Small but growing number of radio stations are embracing 'classic alternative' format, playing songs from alternative rock explosion of early 1990's; format appeals to aging Generation X'ers; changes are part of broader reaction to growing competition; photos (M)

headline: Disney Rejects Comcast Offer
abstract: Disney company board's rejection of Comcast merger bid noted

headline: Tempers Flare Around the iPod
abstract: The feedback from last week’s "State of the Art" column,” which reviewed alternatives to the Apple iPod music player, contained some of the rudest personal attacks I’ve ever received. I already knew that a huge population of Windows bashers, and a huge population of Mac bashers populate the Internet - but now I’ve met the iPod bashers.

headline: A Discount Airline Creates Some Wealthy Admirers
abstract: Article on JetBlue Airways focuses on how discount carrier's desire to please has gone long way in turning many JetBlue regulars into enthusiastic loyalists, especially upscale business fliers; says chief executive David G Neeleman makes point of contract with passengers and line employees when he flies; photo (M)

headline: Hearing on West Bank Wall Draws Demonstrators
abstract: International Court in The Hague opens hearing on Israeli barrier around West Bank; Palestinian Authority charges violation of international law; Israel sees necessary bulwark against suicide bombers; burned wreckage of Jerusalem bus is flown in as backdrop and demonstrators carry photos of nearly 1,000 victims of Palestinian terrorism; photo; pro-Palestinian demonstrations are also held (S)

headline: Bite Your Tongue
abstract: Shayna Kravetz letter comments on software that allows e-mailers to pull back message or prevent its being printed by recipient (March 11 article)

headline: FAO Receives Approval to Auction Assets
abstract: FAO Inc receives approval from US Bankruptcy Judge Joel Rosenthal to auction its FAO Schwarz assets, including leases for stores on Fifth Avenue in New York and in Las Vegas; VGACS Acquisition Inc, unit of D E Shaw & Co, has offered $20 million for leases as well as FAO's catalog and Internet businesses; offer will become minimum bid at Jan 22 auction (S)

headline: STEWART FOUND GUILTY OF LYING IN SALE OF STOCK
abstract: Martha Stewart is found guilty by Manhattan jury of lying about reasons she sold 3,928 shares of ImClone Systems over two years ago; Peter E Bacanovic, her former Merrill Lynch stockbroker, is also convicted; Judge Miriam Goldman Cedarbaum sets sentencing hearing for June 17; Stewart says she plans to appeal; outcome raises questions about strategy of defense team; Stewart's lawyer Robert G Morvillo called only one witness and questioned him for just 20 minutes; photos (M)

headline: Filled With Bodies, a Fairground Turns Suddenly Solemn
abstract: The sprawling Zona Zero convention center in Madrid has been transformed into a giant temporary morgue.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Gasoline Prices on Course To Reach Record Levels  Anyone who has not been shocked by the rapid climb in retail gasoline prices may want to brace for what is to come. The fear of disruptions in oil supplies and stricter environmental regulations are expected to push prices even higher this spring and summer.    A federal agency said that gasoline supplies declined by 800,000 barrels last month, to 5 percent below the five-year running average. Earlier in the month, the agency warned that gasoline prices might rise to a nationwide average of $1.83 a gallon in April and $1.82 in May. Moreover, crude oil prices rose nearly 2 percent, to a 13-year high. [Page A1.]

headline: U.S. Landlords Face Post-9/11 Standards
abstract: Interagency Security Committee subcommittee has begun trying to establish nationwide security standards for 150 million square feet that fderal government leases from private landlords; process has proved challenging because safety measures are costly, whether they involve giving up space so that building can be set far back from curb or hiring guards and installing electronic turnstiles to limit access; real estate industry representatives have met several times with federal officials during past year to seek assurance that landlords will not have to foot additional costs, which they say could make it impractical for them to lease space to government agencies; complicating matters is fact that Federal Protection Service, security agency for federal tenants, has moved from General Services Administration to new Homeland Security Department, adding layer of bureaucracy; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Autodesk Profit Rises Ninefold
abstract: Autodesk says profit rose ninefold as sales jumped 51 percent in fourth quarter ended Jan 31; net nicome was $57.6 million compared with $6.41 million year ago; sales rose to $295.3 milion from $195.5 million (S)

headline: FACTORY 2-U, A DISCOUNT RETAILER, FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
abstract: Factr

headline: Saudis Aiding U.S. in Cutting Off Terrorism Funds, Panel Is Told
abstract: J Cofer Black (State Department), Thomas J Harrington (FBI) and Juan Carlos Zarate (Treasury Department) tell House subcommittee that May terrorist bombings that rocked Riyadh has spurred Saudi government to work more closely with United States in stemming flow of money to terrorist groups like Al Qaeda and Hamas; point to closed nature of Saudi society and banks in saying more is needed to stop money from reaching groups warring on United States, Israel and their allies; Rep Shelley Berkley questions Saudi Arabia's professed eagerness to fight terrorism; other witnesses cite obstacles to Saudi efforts to dismantle terrorist groups (M)

headline: Librarians as Web Guides
abstract: Letter from librarian David Ettinger suggests checking with librarian before wasting time on futile Web searches (Feb 5 article)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: List of American service members newly confirmed dead in Iraq

headline: Grief Pervades Beach Resort In Egypt
abstract: Divers scour waters of Sharm El Sheik, Egypt, working to recover bodies of 148 people killed there when Boeing 737 crashed into sea; remains of 60 people have been found so far; feeling in Sharm El Sheik resort is of deep grief for 133 French tourists killed in crash after spending carefree week at resort; photos; map (M)

headline: An Open-and-Shut Case? Well, Not So Fast
abstract: Jurors appear tired and distracted at seemingly endless trial of L Dennis Kozlowski, former chief executive of Tyco International, and doubts are being raised about supposedly open-and-shut case against him; legal experts say prosecutors have not yet built a compelling case; photos of Kozlowski and Mark H Swartz, former chief financial officer of Tyco (L)

headline: S.&P. 500 and Dow Decline a Fifth Consecutive Day
abstract: Standard & Poor's 500-stock index loses 1.90 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,139.09; Dow Jones industrial average falls 43.25 points, or 0.4 percent, to 10,556.37; Nasdaq composite index drops 2.08 points, or 0.1 percent, to 2,005.44; US Treasury securities rise; price of benchmark 10-year note rises 4/32, to 99 26/32; yield drops to 4.03 percent, from 4.04 percent; graph; chart (M)

headline: A.G. Edwards Says Profit More Than Doubled
abstract: AG Edwards Inc says profit more than doubled in fourth quarter ended Feb 29; net income rose to $54.4 million from $21.2 million year earlier; revenue rose 34 percent, to $689.3 million (S)

headline: Welch Makes Another Major Book Deal
abstract: General Electric's former chairman Jack F Welch Jr sells world rights for how-to business manual to HarperCollins, unit of News Corp, for estimated $4 million; book, which will be called Winning, does not fetch advance of book Jack: Straight From the Gut, which he sold in 2000 without any written proposal for advance of $7.1 million; Suzy Wetlaufer, Welch's fiancee and former editor of Harvard Business Review, will help him write book; Welch comments; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Paris Journal; A Love That Transcends Death Is Blessed by the State
abstract: Christelle Demichel marries her late fiance, Nice, France, under 1959 French law that enables president to approve marriage to dead person if couple had planned to wed before death and parents of deceased approve; marriage is retroactive to eve of groom's demise; some 20 such marriages are approved each year; photo (M)

headline: People
abstract: Ned Russell is named executive vice president at New York office of Arnold Worldwide (S)

headline: New Pocket Camcorder Demands Notice
abstract: Afew weeks ago, I reviewed, in Circuits, a couple of tapeless camcorders.

headline: CHEVRONTEXACO PLACES $535 MILLION IN PENSION PLANS
abstract: ChevronTexaco Corp says it contributed $535 million to shore up its domestic pension plans early this year and that it expects to add about $50 million more by end of 2004 (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Sales Fall At Havas
abstract: Advertising company Havas says fourth-quarter sales fell 15 percent; revenue was 436 million euros ($559 million), compared with 515 million euros year earlier (S)

headline: U.N. Help on Iraq
abstract: The Bush administration, seeing little hope for an early accord on Iraq's government, is likely to ask for more help from a special United Nations envoy to solidify a consensus on how Iraq will be run after June 30.    Article, Page A6.

headline: Before Facing Judge, Stewart Is Out and About
abstract: Martha Stewart is looking more like a carefree socialite than a woman on the edge of incarceration.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Yahoo To Use Inktomi Software
abstract: Yahoo will start using modified version of software made buy Inktomi, which it purchased year ago, for its Web searches; Yahoo's Web searches have been provided by rival Google; Yahoo's move is first shot in what it hopes will be assault on Google in several search-related areas (S)

headline: Online Teenage Gender Gap
abstract: Jupiter Research, which surveyed more than 1,800 teenage Internet users about their music-buying habits, finds teenage girls spend more money on music than boys, and are also more active digital music users; finds boys are more apt to download music without paying for it and to make their own CD's; photo; graph (S)

headline: ATLAS AIR NAMES CHIEF TO LEAD IT OUT OF BANKRUPTCY
abstract: Atlas Air Worldwide Holdings Inc names Jeffrey H Erickson chief executive, replacing John Blue, who served as chief executive from last March until company's Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing Jan 30 (S)

headline: Kirshenbaum Bond Reorganizes Agency
abstract: Kirshenbaum Bond Creative Network is reorganizing its largest agency Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners two day after unexpected firing of longtime senior executive Nigel Carr; West Coast operation of Kirshenbaum Bond called KB&P West is being dissolved and combined with Kirshenbaum Bond; Noel Cottrell, who had been managing partner and executive creative director at KB&P West, keeps those titles at Kirshenbaum Bond San Francisco; Porter Gale and Matt Hofherr are joining San Francisco operation as managing partners (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Hotel Company's Profit Falls
abstract: The hotel and leisure company Accor reported a 37 percent decline in net income for 2003 as the global economic slowdown, the war in Iraq, the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome and foreign exchange fluctuations hurt results. The company said it earned 270 million euros ($329 million) last year, down from 430 million euros in 2002 and below the 281 million euros expected by analysts. The company said, however, that it had seen signs of recovery in the second half of the year, particularly in the United States, Britain and Germany. The company, which is based in Paris, said it cut its debt by 370 million euros and maintained its dividend; and its share price rose 3 percent.

headline: E-Mail Worm Snarls Computers Around Globe
abstract: The new malicious computer program is spreading rapidly throughout the Internet today and may become the largest ever outbreak of viral e-mail, some analysts predict.

headline: At 2 Airlines, Management And Unions Focus on Cuts
abstract: Unions and management at United Airlines and US Airways are facing off over cuts that executives say are critical to help their companies' survival; battle at United Airlines is over reductions in health care benefits for 35,000 retired workers; executives say savings are necessary for airline to secure federal loan guarantees and emerge from bankruptcy protection as planned later this year; US Airways wants third round of concessions from its unions, on top of two granted while it was in bankruptcy; sees wage and benefit cuts as major component in its drive to reduce its costs to level of low-fare carriers; anger is hottest at United, where flight attendants are leading charge to stop airline from carrying out its plans to have retirees pay more for medical coverage; photo (M)

headline: House Is Raided In Madrid Inquiry
abstract: Spanish police raid house outside Madrid in connection with March 11 terrorist bombings; Spanish news media reports demolition materials, including explosive Goma 2, were found in house, but government will not confirm report (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; S.E.C. Is Looking at U.S. Underwriters of Parmalat Bonds
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission is looking into whether American underwriters who sold Parmalat bonds committed fraud; some securities law experts say commission could file civil case even if no evidence emerges that banks knew of fraud; Manhattan District Atty Robert M Morgenthau confirms his office searched New York office and home of Gian Paolo Zini, lawyer for Parmalat who is under arrest in Italy; says he acted at request of Italian authorities, as relayed to him by SEC (Market Place) (M)

headline: European Commission to Sue Over Deficits of 2 Countries
abstract: European Commission to sue 15 members of European Union for voting to suspend rules that would have forced France and Germany to make deep cuts to bring their budget deficits within lawful limits; France and Germany flouted those rules, which cap deficits to 3 percent of gross domestic product, saying they risk choking off fragile economic recovery; commission is seeking to overturn vote (M)

headline: General, a 'Bridge' From Islam to the West, Worries About His Foundations
abstract: Pres Pervez Musharraf sits inside heavily fortified military compound in Rawalpindi, recalling social outings he enjoyed before two assassination attempts in Dec; has become bridge, or pivot, between Islam and West in past two years; leads country that has produced more than its share of Islamic militants, yet is crucial ally in American campaign against those militants; speaks about his own efforts to combat fundamentalism in Pakistan, conceding that it has proceeded slowly in some areas, like reform of hard-line Islamic religious schools (M)

headline: 1,100 JOBS TO BE LOST IN CLOSINGS OF OFFICEMAX STORES
abstract: Boise Cascade Corp expects to close 45 of its recently acquired OfficeMax stores in second quarter and eliminate 1,100 jobs; 500 of 1,100 employees whose jobs are to be eliminated will be offered transfers to other stores (S)

headline: Sharons Son Told to Hand Over Papers in Corruption Cases
abstract: Israels Supreme Court ordered Prime Minister Ariel Sharons son to hand over documents in two corruption investigations.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Finland: Financial Services Acquisition
abstract: World Business BriÔ

headline: Campaign Aims To Prevent File Sharing
abstract: National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences plans extensive public education drive to explain value of paying for music to younger consumers most likely to share computer files (M)

headline: An Irate Shopper Soothed
abstract: Chris Hart letter suggests using different Web browser if user is having difficulty shopping online (Feb 12 article)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of March 14 article on Financo Global Consulting, team of former retail executives

headline: Radio en Espanol
abstract: The porportion of radio stations programmed primarily in Spanish is growing. Also: the most popular music, software, TV shows and movies.

headline: Wife of Ex-Parmalat Officer Arrested
abstract: Donatella Alinovi, wife of Parmalat's former chief financial officer Fausto Tonna, is arrested for suspected money laundering; is supected of withdrawing about 1 million euros last week from account linked to Parmalat unit after her husband was arrested; photo (M)

headline: Array of Drug Cards May Prove Confusing
abstract: Consumer advocates are warning that millions of elderly Americans will face a bewildering array of new government-approved drug discount cards this spring, and Bush administration officials are acknowledging that a serious effort will be needed to clear up the confusion.    Administration officials said that 106 health industry companies -- an unexpectedly large number -- met a deadline last week for applying to sponsor the new cards. They will be available to 10 million Medicare beneficiaries who do not have drug coverage, as a precursor to the prescription drug benefit scheduled to begin in 2006.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Putin Watches As Missile Test Fails
abstract: Itar-Tass, Russian news agency, reports that two ballistic missiles that were part of one of Russia's largest military exercises misfired because of satellite communications problems; Admiral Vladimir I Kuroyedov denies misfire took place; President Vladimir V Putin observed exercises; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Railway Bomb Threats Suspended
abstract: AZF, French group that has been threatening to bomb railroads throughout France if $5 million is not paid, sends letter to President Jacques Chirac and Interior Minister Nicolas Sarkozy that says it has suspended threats against railroads (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Indian Concern Reports Profit
abstract: India's Satyam Computer Services earned 1.46 billion rupees ($32 million) in its fiscal third quarter ended Dec 31, up from 1.17 billion rupees ($26 million) year ago; sales increased 33 percent (S)

headline: Indonesian Court Overturns Politician's Corruption Conviction
abstract: Indonesian Supreme Court overturns corruption conviction against Akbar Tandjung, powerful politician, who was found guilty of embezzling nearly $4.8 million of state funds intended for poor; Akbar, parliamentary speaker and leader of political party, is now free to run for presidency; court's decision will dampen presidential prospects of Gen Wiranto, who belongs to same party as Akbar (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: BASF To Buy Back Shares
abstract: BASF to buy back up to 500 million euros ($635 million) of its shares in 2004 to reduce its equity ratio and increase earnings per share (S)

headline: Iraqis Shell Living Quarters At U.S. Base, Wounding 35
abstract: Iraqi insurgents fire six mortar rounds at US military camp northwest of Baghdad, wounding 35 soldiers; administrator Paul Bremer announces plan to free about 500 of 9,000 Iraqis held in American camps, starting with about 100; plans to restore Iraqi sovereignty are jarred by Shiite leader Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, who objects to waiting until next year to elect delegates to constitutional convention; US death toll is nearing 500, with several thousand others wounded, many severely; US commanders are nevertheless sounding more upbeat about conflict (M)

headline: Gruner & Jahr Fires Chief of U.S. Unit, Confirming Reports
abstract: Gruner & Jahr USA Publishing president-chief executive Daniel B Brewster Jr is fired; Axel Ganz, president of publisher's international division, to succeed Brewster temporarily (M)

headline: Delicate Dance For Musharraf In Nuclear Case
abstract: Some former and current American officials say there was considerable evidence that Gen Pervez Musharraf turned blind eye to Dr Abdul Qadeer Khan's selling of nuclear secrets to Iran, North Korea and Libya, even as Musharraf says he lacked proof; with recent confession by Khan and pardon, Musharraf continues balancing act, privately calling Khan 'bad news,' but praising him publicly and giving him title 'special adviser'; US has been engaged in its own balancing act, weighing Pakistan's lack of action against Khan with its need to support Musharraf government in campaign against terrorism; details leading to confrontation between Musharraf and Khan and Khan's apology to nation described; Western experts say Khan, who is seen in Pakistan as founder of nuclear program, is egomaniac who is expert at making centrifuges but is not due all credit he is receiving; deal struck by Khan leaves many questions unanswered, including whether government officials or other scientists kenw about or played role in nuclear network; since Musharraf's pardon, US has refrained from criticism or any further action against Pakistan, but Simon Henderson, Washington Institute for Near East Policy, says there is much more potentially embarrassing information that could come to light (M)

headline: European Regulators Back Proposed Microsoft Ruling
abstract: European Commission says European antitrust regulators are united behind antitrust official Mario Monti on his proposed finding that Microsoft abused its dominant position in software market; commission will rule as soon as March 24 that Microsoft is abusive monopolist and will order company to change way it sells its software in its 15 member nations (M)

headline: Arrest Warrant Issued in Income Tax Case
abstract: Arrest warrant is issued for Al Thompson, who stopped withholding taxes from employees four years ago, after he fails to appear at hearing on matter; Thompson, who runs Cencal Aviation Products in Shasta, Calif, asserts that any arrest warrant will be invalid if his name is printed in capital letters, as names normally are on federal court documents (S)

headline: New Attacks Kill 2 Children and 2 U.S. Soldiers
abstract: Iraqi forces will be unable to guarantee safety after the planned transfer of sovereignty on June 30, a range of specialists concluded.

headline: With Smiles And Kisses, Stewart Trial Commences
abstract: Trial begins for Martha Stewart, who is charged with conspiracy, obstruction of justice and securities fraud, stemming from her sale of ImClone Systems stock in Deccember 2001; she and co-defendant Peter E Bacanovic both plead not guilty; jury selection begins; photo (M)

headline: Weaving the Threads of Law, War and Shakespeare
abstract: Marlise Simons profile of Judge Theodor Meron, president of United Nations war crimes tribunal that deals with atrocities of former Yugoslavia; notes that Meron, scholar of international law, spent four years in Nazi camp in Poland; his photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Mass-Mailing Virus Infects PC's
abstract: Antivirus concerns warn new mass-mailing computer virus dubbed MyDoom that has gained foothold in large number of personal computers by masquerading as e-mail error; Network Associates received 19,500 e-mail messages with virus from 3,400 Internet addresses; mail systems that remove executable files from e-mail can stop program from spreading (S)

headline: A report the possibility that ads contribute to obesity in children; the industry begs to differ.
abstract: Report by Henry J Kaiser Family Foundation suggests that advertising contributes to childhood obesity; summarizes existing studies on obesity and media like television, video games and movies that capture children's attention; some marketers charge report fails to support its conclusions adequately; call for parents to accept responsibility for their children's health; photo (M)

headline: Agency Asks Zimbabwe to Release Stored Food
abstract: United Nations officials ask Zimbabwe to release some of government's stockpile of 236,000 tons of corn, after month in which three million malnourished people are forced to subsist on half rations from program; Human Rights Watch has accused Pres Robert G Mugabe of denying subsidized government food to people who are not listed as supporters of his party; since Dec, European Union has donated $35 million for food and United States has provided $12 million worth of food (M)

headline: $58 BILLION DEAL TO UNITE 2 GIANTS OF U.S. BANKING
abstract: J P Morgan Chase agrees to acquire Bank One for $58 billion in stock in deal that would realign competitive landscape for banks and create true rival to Citigroup; transaction would unite investment and commercial banking strength of J P Morgan Chase with Bank One's much larger consumer banking operations; combined company would have 2,300 branches in 17 states; J P Morgan, nation's second-largest bank, would also become even bigger issuer of credit cards; combined company would have $1.1 trillion in assets, compared with nearly $1.2 trillion for Citigroup; Bank One chief executive James L Dimon will become J P Morgan's president and chief operating officer; will take over as chief executive in two years from J P Morgan's leader William B Harrison, settling persistent question of succession; merger is expected to result in elimination of about 10,000 jobs as part of J P Morgan's effort to save $2.2 billion over three years; cuts will be concentrated in retail banking, with greatest number in New York area; banks' branches do not overlap, and they plan to maintain both brand names pending review; photo; chart (M)

headline: The N.A.A.C.P. and Congress weigh in on the tracking of black and Hispanic TV viewers.
abstract: NAACP and leading members of Congress from both parties, including Sen Hillary Rodham Clinton, add their voices to growing number complaining that proposed changes in how Nielsen gathers local television ratings will drastically undercount number of black and Hispanic viewers; Nielsen Media Research, whose ratings have been used for decades to help set TV advertising rates, says number of households sampled with African-American and Hispanic viewers will increase under proposed changes (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: EUROPE.

headline: Challenges For Comcast, Before or After a Deal
abstract: Interview with Sanford C Bernstein & Co media analyst Tom Wolzien on Comcast Corp's bid for Walt Disney Co; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: EUROPE.

headline: Better at Languages, U.S. Spy Agencies Still Lag
abstract: Since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, American intelligence agencies have doubled or even tripled the number of Arabic and Persian linguists on their payrolls, but ''much remains to be done'' to address a remaining shortfall, a senior intelligence official has told Congress.    Among the sharpest increases was at the National Security Agency, which hired seven times as many foreign-language speakers last year as in 1999, a senior official from that agency said in separate testimony.

headline: Making a Pitch to a Client On a Digital Whiteboard
abstract: Smart Technologies Sympodium ID250 is self-contained computer geared to elegant presentations; photo (S)

headline: Economic Talks Draw Elite to Davos, but Have No Salient Issue
abstract: World Economic Forum is once again luring elite of business and government and handful of advocacy groups to luxurious enclave of Davos in Swiss Alps; forum chairman Klaus Schwab comments (M)

headline: Richards Group Wins Red Lobster Account
abstract: Red Lobster, part of Darden Restaurants, names Richards Group as ad agency of record (S)

headline: Putin Fires Premier and Cabinet Ahead of March 14 Election
abstract: The president of Russia said that he would appoint a new government only days before an election that he is sure to win.

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Feb 8 article on pornography industry's approach to copyright issues

headline: Ogilvy Executive Resigns After Arrest
abstract: Thomas Early, finance director at New York office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, resigns one day after being charged with conspiring to inflate billings for work on ad account of White House Office of National Drug Control Policy; Ogilvy says Early left 'to devote his full energies to obtaining a full vindication of this matter'; Early and former Ogilvy colleague Shona Seifert are charged with falsifying time sheets and other documents to overbill drug office from May 1999 through April 2000; Early and Seifert plead not guilty (S)

headline: WARNACO AND S.E.C. DISCUSS SETTLEMENT OF COMPLAINT
abstract: Warnaco Group says Securities and Exchange Commission has proposed settlement of its investigation into company's financial statements (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Croatians Surrender; Serb Sentenced
abstract: Retired Croatian Generals Ivan Cermak and Mladen Markac surrender to Hague international war crimes tribunal and plead not guilty to war crimes they are accused of committing during 1991-1995 Balkan war; Bosnian Serb Ranko Cesic is sentenced by tribunal to 18 years in prison for murder and sexual assault of Muslim men held at detention facility (S)

headline: Miramax in Deal With Mother Agency
abstract: Miramax Films, part of Walt Disney Co, and Mother, creatively focused London agency that recently opened New York office, say they will collaborate on advertising, marketing, entertainment and branding projects (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Telecom Executive Resigns
abstract: Tapr

headline: Of Ethics and Revenue
abstract: Christopher J Lahoda letter on Mar 21 article holds companies stress revenue over ethics because revenue is measurable as well as essential and visible

headline: Careers Settle Within a Thriving Home
abstract: Life's Work column looks at how Jim and Kim Derk of Evansville, Ind, are able to care for their large family through generous family leave policy and flexible hours program at General Electric, where they both work; drawing (M)

headline: CANADIAN COMPANY BUYS MAKER OF SCHWINN BIKES
abstract: Dorel Ind

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: EUROPE.

headline: Fund Planned To Defend Users of Linux
abstract: Group of companies, led by IBM and Intel, is setting up $10 million legal defense fund to help pay litigation costs of corporate users of popular GNU Linux operating system if they are sued by SCO Group; SCO holds Linux, variant of Unix, violates its Unix license and copyright; fund is effort to reduce risk to corporations, which increasingly use Linux to run data-serving computers that power big networks and Web sites; Open Source Development Laboratories will run fund (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Rash of Canceled Flights May Curb Business Travel  The rash of holiday flight cancellations, security actions and terrorism warnings are going to compel many American companies to reassess whether to send employees abroad in coming weeks, not only out of fear of attack but because of the inconvenience of canceled and delayed flights, business travel experts said.    Kevin P. Mitchell, chairman of the Business Travel Coalition, which represents business travelers and corporate travel departments, said bookings could drop 10 percent to 15 percent. [Page A10.]

headline: Afghan Blast That Killed 7 G.I.s Is Seen as Accidental
abstract: The explosion that killed at least seven soldiers on Thursday was probably an accident, a U.S. military spokesman said today.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Warning On Microsoft Antitrust Case
abstract: European Union Comr Mario Monti says time is running out for settlement between European Commission and Microsoft in long-running antitrust case; draft ruling that brands Microsoft abusive monopolist is being circulated internally within commission, before it is shown to national competition regulators for comments next month; final decision is expected in March or April; photo (S)

headline: Mission to Iraq Eases Japan Toward a True Military
abstract: Advance team of Japan's Self-Defense Forces prepares to leave for Iraq, while first Japanese troops to be deployed since World War II to country embroiled in combat continue their training at base in northern Japan; they are focusing on mastering their rules of engagement, way in which they would respond to hostile situation in southern Iraq; because Self-Defense Forces are not considered military, their rules of engagement are weaker than those under which American and other soldiers operate; Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi has said he wants Self-Defense Forces to become full-fledged military; government of Japan is drawing, in stark terms it has not done since World War II, a direct link between its forces' overseas activities and its national interests; photo (M)

headline: Report Focuses on False ID's Made at Motor Vehicle Offices
abstract: Center for Democracy and Technology reports that bribery and poor security at motor vehicle offices across country allowed thousands of fraudulent driver's licenses to change hands in 2002, for as little as $350 each; report should add to doubts about wisdom of allowing state-issued licenses to serve as identification cards nationwide (M)

headline: Bank's Ex-Chief Arrested in Parmalat Case
abstract: Italian police officials arrest Banca del Monte di Parma's former president Franco Gorreri as investigation into collapse of Parmalat continues; Gorreri was finance chief of Parmalat until 1992 and conintued to work as part-time employee of Parmalat; another former finance chief Fausto Tonna is escorted by investigators to his former office; Tonna is accompanied by former Parmalat accountant Gianfranco Bocchi; two men are detained in Parma prison (S)

headline: Tyco Auditor Discusses Bonuses
abstract: Richard P Scalzo, former lead auditor of Tyco International, testifies that he informed board committee about bonuses paid to former chief executive L Dennis Kozlowski, which prosecutors say were stolen from company (S)

headline: As Prices Soar, Some in OPEC Balk at Cuts
abstract: Some OPEC members are signaling their reluctance to proceed with announced cuts in production as crude oil prices have climbed to their highest level since first gulf war; oil prices for May delivery ease after members' statements, falling 57 cents, or more than 1.5 percent, in New York, to $37.05 per barrel; OPEC is scheduled to discuss quotas at meeting March 31 in Vienna; chart; graph (M)

headline: Enron Pleas Expected
abstract: Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron, and his wife, Lea, have agreed to plead guilty to crimes today in Houston, people involved in the case said.    Business Day, Page C1.

headline: U.S. STARTS ANTITRUST INVESTIGATION OF YARN MAKER
abstract: Unifi Inc says Justice Department is investigating possible violations of antitrust rules by its Parkdale America affiliate, which participated in activities with competitors in markets for cotton fibers used in hosiery and other garments (S)

headline: Swiss Back Tougher Laws on Violent Crime
abstract: Swiss voters approve measure that would require country to put into effect some of Europe's harshest laws on violent criminals, even though legal experts say country would be in violation of European Human Rights Convention if proposals are strictly interpreted; Swiss government opposed proposal (S)

headline: Talking With the Googlers
abstract: Set the TiVo! This Sunday morning, "CBS News Sunday Morning" will begin with my report on Google, the Web search page-slash-cultural deity that's expected to go public this Spring--the biggest in high-tech history, with a valuation as high as $25 billion.

headline: The Ivy-Covered Console
abstract: Princeton University holds first conference on video-game studies, new field of academic study; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Oil Profit Short Of Forecast
abstract: China Petroleum and Chemical Corp says earnings in 2003 rose 32 percent, to 12.6 bilion yuan ($1.5 billion) but its profit falls short of analysts' forecasts; revenue increased to 443.14 billion yuan from 345.15 billion yuan in 2003; crude oil production rose 0.43 percent, to 271 million barrels and natural gas production rose 5 percent, to 187.7 billion cubic feet (S)

headline: MediaTalk; New Yorker Writer Accumulates Points In Corporate Circles
abstract: Simmons Market Research Bureau develops Tipping Point index and forms what it calls 'researech advisory alliance' with Malcolm Gladwell, New Yorker writer and author of The Tipping Point, who argues that what people buy and think is influenced by just 12.5 percent of population, so-called 'connectors'; Simmons offers to help companies reach these people; photo (M)

headline: DataBank; Greenspan Can Still Move Markets
abstract: Stock and bond market performance in week of Feb 9-13 noted; market graphs and tables (S)3

headline: Suicide Bombers Kill 10 in Israel, And Derail Prime Ministers' Talks
abstract: Two Palestinian suicide bombers blow themselves up just minutes apart at Israeli industrial port of Ashdod, killing 10 people and wounding at least 18 others; are believed to have come from Gaza, in which case it would be first time in more than three years of conflict that suicide bombers have overcome electronic fence enclosing Gaza to strike inside Israel; militant groups had vowed retaliation after Israeli forces killed 14 people in Gaza raid on March 7; bombing prompts Prime Min Ariel Sharon to cancel meeting with Palestinian Prime Min Ahmed Qurei; Palestinian Authority condemns bombings, for which Hamas and Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades claim responsibility; thousands of Palestinians march in Gaza to celebrate attack; map; photo (M)

headline: AOL to Add Spyware Detection to Service
abstract: America Online will give its customers built-in software to detect and remove 'spyware,' hidden tools that can monitor Web surfers' online habits for marketing purposes; spyware-removal program that AOL will use is made by Aluria Software; will be bundled with next version of AOL's software, which will be released soon; AOL customers using older software will be able to download program separately (M)

headline: Unemployment Claims Reach Lowest Level in Three Years
abstract: Labor Dept reports that number of Americans filing first-time applications for state unemployment benefits declined to 339,000 for week, lowest level in almost three years; graph; Conference Board reports that consumers are more optimistic about outlook for employment than they are about current job market (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: New Chip For Hynix
abstract: South Korea's Hynix Semiconductor says it will start production in February of so-called NAND flash-memory chips; goal is to become world's third-largest producer of NAND flash memory by 2005 (S)

headline: REBELS NEARING HAITIAN CAPITAL, DEEPENING PANIC
abstract: Armed rebels come within 25 miles of Port-au-Prince, Haiti; Bush administration says it is pursuing diplomatic resolution, but Pentagon is drawing up plans for possible intervention by Marines; State Dept says administration is in 'very close touch' with French government, which has called for Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide to resign and has offered to take part in multinational effort to stabilize Haiti; looters pillage warehouses at port, and at least four people are killed in violence sweeping city; map; photos (M)

headline: S.C. Johnson Starts Broad Account Review
abstract: S C Johnsn

headline: Database Business Helps Oracle to a Solid Third Quarter
abstract: Oracle Corp reports solid gains in third-quarter profit and revenue, driven by strong sales of company's database products; net income rose 11 percent, to $635 million compared with $571 million year earlier; revenue increased 9 percent, to $2.5 billion from $2.3 billion (M)

headline: Executive Pay, Hiding Behind Small Print
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column on on need for regulatory reform to force companies to better disclose executive pay; calls for increased disclosure of deferred compensation, supplemental retirement plans and payouts when company undergoes change in control (M)0

headline: Aventis Said to Be Talking of Asset Sales
abstract: Aventis, French pharmaceutial company that is target of $60 billion hostile takeover bid by Sanofi-Synthelabo, has been in talks to sell assets; such asset sales might be seen as effort to make Aventis seem more viable as independent company, helping to fend off takeover bid; photo (M)

headline: Kohlberg Kravis Sets $5.9 Billion Payout
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co is returning about $5.9 billion to investors after more than tripling their money from holdings in companies including insurance broker Willis Group Holdings of London (S)

headline: Mexico Lifts Ban on Many U.S. Beef Products
abstract: Mexico lifts part of its ban on imports of beef from US, easing restrictions imposed after case of mad cow disease was discovered in Washington State in December; ends ban on beef products like boneless cuts from animals under 30 months old and veal from animals under nine months old; holds firm on its ban on live calves and cattle from US (M)

headline: WB Ratings Slide: Reality vs. Reality Shows
abstract: WB television network executives acknowledge network has had loser of season so far; blame several new programs that misfired, most notably Tarzan, as well as what they call faulty methodology used by Nielsen Media Research in measuring ratings of younger viewers; another possible explanation for WB slide among core audience, viewers aged 12 to 34, could be its disdain for reality television genre; photo (M)

headline: Nottingham Journal; When Robin Hood Supped, Was It on Yorkshire Pudding?
abstract: Yorkshire lays claim to 800-year-old legend of Robin Hood with parliamentary motion for neighboring Nottinghamshire to take down signs proclaiming itself 'Robin Hood Country'; claimants say master archer who was committed to spreading the wealth may have been Robert Hode of Wakefield, who lived in 1300's, when Sherwood Forest extended well into Yorkshire; photos; map (M)

headline: Paying the Price Of Retirees' Health Care
abstract: Adam J Reese letter says that when it comes to poorly funded pension and retirement plans, main culprit is Congress, not companies that are providing benefits (Dec 14 column)

headline: The art of conjuring up a fragrance
abstract: SAN FRANCISCO—  The creation of a perfume is a kind of alchemy, and like alchemy, it can become an obsession.

headline: In the Center Of Baghdad, An Escape To America
abstract: United States Army has converted former Iraqi Republican Guard officers' club in Baghdad into little American oasis for war-weary soldiers; it now serves as First Armored Div's version of five-star hotel for as many as 100 soldiers at a time who are lucky enough to get three-day, two-night pass; more than 1,800 troops have cycled through since hotel opened in mid-Oct; amenities described; photo (M)

headline: Foreign Cellphone Bidders Still in Running in Iran
abstract: Iranian government, faced with growing demand for mobile phone service and unreliable, overburdened state-run network, is moving ahead with its plan to hand control of second network to one of foreign-led consortiums; consortium must pay Iran's telecommunications ministry concession of 300 million euros (about $380 million) immediately and agree to give up 25 percent of revenues to state; only 4.3 percent of Iran's 67 million people subscribe to Telecommunications Company of Iran, which runs sole, state-owned mobile service available; company has annual mobile revenues of about $425 million; five finalists are consortiums led by Orascom Group of Egypt, Istanbul-based Turkcell, MTN Group of South Africa, Austria's Mobilkom and joint venture of Mobile Telecommunications Co of Kuwait, Kuwaiti rival Wataniya Telecom and Deutsche Telekom's mobil unit T-Mobile International; photo (M)

headline: MediaTalk; A Movie Hoax Finds Life as a Courtroom Reality
abstract: California appeals court panel rules that several moviegoers who were disappointed by The Animal, 2001 Sony Pictures film, may bring suit against studio for fabricating film critic called David Manning to trumpet The Animal and other Sony films in advertisements; signals that fake attributions and other falsehoods in adveritising can give rise to big damages under California's expansive consumer protection law; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Telephone And Data Systems Posts Sales Increase
abstract: Telephone and Data Systems Inc reports fourth-quarter net income of $25.8 million as sales rise 8 percent; keeps customer defections to record low (S)

headline: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES TO BUY GERMAN REFRIGERATION UNIT
abstract: United Technologies Corp acquires refrigeration unit of Linde of Germany for 325 million euros ($398 million) to gain customers and expand product range (S)

headline: BBDO West Wins Lottery Account
abstract: California Lottery Commission tentatively awards BBDO West four-year contract to handle its general account, with total billings estimated at $100 million (S)

headline: Much of Europe Is Derisive About Report on Iraqi Arms
abstract: Much of Europe is ridiculing US following weapons inspector David Kay's testimony that there probably were no illicit weapons in Iraq before US-led war; there is greater bemusement in Europe over Britain's seemingly contradictory report that chastised British Broadcasting Corp for suggesting that Prime Min Tony Blair's administration had hyped intelligence reports of weapons in Iraq (M)

headline: Zimbabwe Holds 64 Men Said to Be Part of African Coup Plot
abstract: Zimbabwean authorities say 64 men on plane seized at airport were mercenaries en route to sow coflict in Equatorial Guinea (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Heating oil falls as price for natural gas dropped, bolstering expectations that consumers will not seek alternatives; heating oil for March delivery drops 0.8 cents, or 0.9 percent, to 91.56 cents per gallon; graph; chart (S)

headline: Greenspan Plays Down 2 Threats to U.S. Economy
abstract: Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan says that neither huge US trade deficit nor large currency interventions by Japan and China pose serious threat to US, speech to Economic Club of New York; says central bank will eventually have to raise short-term interest rates from their current low levels; says Asian governments, led by Japan and China, have been buying Treasury securities at 'extraordinary' pace for two years to keep their own currencies from rising too far against dollar (M)

headline: E*TRADE SAYS OUSTED CHIEF PAID BACK $4.6 MILLION
abstract: E*Trade Financial's former chief executive Christos M Cotsakos, ousted after receiving $77 million as company lost money, gives back $4.6 million of unapproved gifts and travel during his seven-year tenure (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Compensation Ordered For War Loot
abstract: Commission for Indemnity of Looting Victims, French government panel, recommends paying remaining $154 million in compensation to Jewish families whose property was looted during Nazi occupation of World War II; has suggested compensation for 9,717 Jews out of 15,696 making requests since 1999 (S)

headline: Hamas Leader Calls Bush Foe Of Muslims
abstract: New Hamas leader Dr Abdel Aziz Rantisi says Pres Bush is enemy of Muslims and that God has declared war on United States; although Hamas has long said its battle is with Israel, it has issued bitter denunciations of US since Israel killed Sheik Ahmed Yassin last week; it has stopped short of saying it will strike at American targets; Hamas contends US must have given its blessing to attack on Yassin; US denies this; photo (M)

headline: S.E.C. INVESTIGATES EL PASO'S RESERVE ESTIMATES
abstract: The El Paso Corporation said the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating a recent reduction of 41 percent in the company's estimate of oil and gas reserves. El Paso was notified of the formal investigation in a letter from the commission, which was accompanied by a subpoena requesting documents related to the estimate cut last month, El Paso said. The company is cooperating with the investigation, Doug Foshee, the chief executive, said in a statement. The company cut its estimate of year-end natural gas and oil reserves by the equivalent of 1.82 trillion cubic feet of gas, to 2.64 trillion cubic feet. The company has since said it will have to restate financial statements for prior years.

headline: Accounts
abstract: The United States division of Castle Brands, New York, to Fathom Communications, New York, to handle the introduction of Boru Vodka to the United States. Billings were estimated at $2.5 million.

headline: F.D.A. PUTS APPROVAL FOR KIDNEY DRUG ON FAST TRACK
abstract: Neurochem Inc says Food and Drug Administration agrees to put its Fibrillex drug on fast-track status in approval process; Fibrillex is intended to treat condition called secondary amyloid A amyloidosis, which can cause kidneys to fail (S)

headline: Moody's to Review Tobacco Bonds
abstract: Moody's Investors Services says it would review municipal bonds worth $19 billion that are backed by 1998 tobacco settlement for possible downgrade because of recent federal appeals court decision; that decision reinstates suit challenging provision of New York law that allows for collection of payments from companies outside settlement (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Purchase Of Cable Concern
abstract: Investment group l

headline: Afghan Leader Removes Chief Of Intelligence
abstract: Pres Hamid Karzai removes Muhammad Arif Sarwari as head of Afghanistan's National Security Directorate, its intelligence service, in move seen as sign of Karzai's growing confidence; foreign diplomats and military, United Nations and human rights officials have long called for Sarwari's removal; his dismissal comes amid flurry of new appointments, including four new provincial governors and many new regional police chiefs (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Court Is Urged to Rewrite Media-Ownership Rules  Broadcasters and public interest groups urged a federal appeals court to order the Federal Communications Commission to rewrite the agency's new media ownership rules that govern the size and reach of conglomerates.    The case has enormous implications for the newspaper, television and radio industries. The rules make it much easier for the biggest companies to acquire other companies in their existing markets and new ones. [Page C14.]

headline: Mindful of Old Wounds, Eircom to Offer Stock Again
abstract: Ireland's phone company Eircom, owned by consortium led by Providence Equity Partners and billionaires George Soros and Sir Anthony O'Reilly, will sell Eircom to public March 19 at 1.55 euros a share in offering that will value company at $1.15 billion; required initial investment of 40,000 euros ($49,000) will prevent small investors from losing their money as they did when initial public offering in 1999 turned out to be financial disaster; photo (M)

headline: Pakistan TV: A New Look At the News
abstract: Geo TV, Pakistani cable station transmitting from Dubai, is example of private television stations that are gaining favor over state-run media across South Asia; Pakistani Pres Pervez Musharraf reversed ban on private television stations in 2002, in part because many Pakistanis turned to Indian cable stations for news rather than state-run Pakistan Television; ban on Indian programming remains in place; private media ownership allows greater freedom in material transmitted; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: New U.S. Sanctions
abstract: United States blacklists several companies in Zimbabwe and tightens economic sanctions against nation citing continued oppression by government and mounting political concerns about President Robert Mugabe's leadership (S)

headline: A Samurai Fighter, Clad in Jeans, Takes On Putin
abstract: Profile of Irina M Khakamada, 48-year-old half Japanese woman who is one of six candidates opposing Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin in March election; she is economist and liberal democrat who opened Russia's first securities exchange board, ran presidential commission on small and medium businesses and served two terms in Parliament; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: American Express Reports 12% Rise in 2003 Earnings  American Express said that its earnings rose 12 percent in the fourth quarter and the full year, driven by greater spending and borrowing on its credit and charge cards as well as by more investment activity.     In 2003, American Express earned $2.99 billion, or $2.30 a diluted share. The fourth quarter contributed $763 million to those earnings, translating into 60 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had predicted 59 cents a share for the quarter. [Page C11.]

headline: Haitian Cabinet Installed as Interim Leader Apologizes to People
abstract: Gerard Latortue, interim prime minister of Haiti, installs his cabinet, promising to head what he calls nonpartisan administration; ceremony is held under heavy American and Haitian guard; Latortue promises to introduce government of accountability and to battle corruption (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: U.S. Aids Plan Is Under Way
abstract: Randall L Tobias, United States global AIDS initiative coordinator, reports first release of aid, $350 million to finance antiretroviral treatments in sub-Saharan Africa; addresses Congress about initiative's five-year, $15 billion plan that would eventually provide treatment for two million HIV positive individuals, primarily in Africa (S)

headline: DELTA ADDS $10 TO SOME FLIGHTS TO COVER AIRPORT FEES
abstract: Delta Air Lines raises fares as much as $10 on roundtrip flights that require connection to cover passenger fees charged by some airports (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: CRUDE OIL CLIMBS***Crude oil soars on concern that inventories will not be adequate to meet increased industrial demand; crude oil for March delivery rises $1.93, or 5.8 percent, to $34.98 per barrel in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: Halliburton Stops Billing U.S. For Meals Served to Troops
abstract: Halliburton Co moves to defuse growing election-year issue by suspending billing of Pentagon for cost of feeding US troops in Iraq and Kuwait, pending resolution of dispute over number of meals served; Kellogg Brown & Root subsidiary president Randy Harl sees no admission of wrongdoing (S)

headline: Russia Detains 2 Athletes From Qatar as Rift Continues
abstract: The move escalated a diplomatic confrontation that began with the arrest of two Russian secret agents for the murder of an exiled Chechen leader.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Suspect In Minister's Death Must Undergo Tests
abstract: World Briefing: Sweden: Suspet In Minister's Death Must Undergo Tests**Trial of Mijailo Mijailovic, who confessed to stabbing to death Swedish Foreign Minister Anna Lindh, is suspended while he undergoes court-ordered psychiatric examination (S)

headline: Judge Moves to Allow Plea By Wife of Ex-Enron Officer
abstract: Federal Judge David Hittner will allow Lea Fastow, wife of Enron Corp's former chief financial officer Andrew Fastow, to plead guilty to single tax violation, but signals he will not yet decide whether he will feel bound by agreement she reached with prosecutors on five-month sentence; photo (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Dept confirms death of two soldiers in Iraq (S)

headline: Other Attacks Averted in Iraq, A General Says
abstract: A senior American military commander said Wednesday that his men had foiled several terrorist attacks intended to accompany those that killed as many as 185 people in two cities here on Tuesday.     But a rising chorus of anti-American anger poured out among officials and Iraqi citizens, with leaders of Iraqi political parties demanding that their private militias play a greater role in policing the country.

headline: 10 Bombs Shatter Trains in Madrid, Killing 192
abstract: Ten bombs rip through four commuter trains in Madrid during morning rush hour, killing at least 192 people and wounding more than 1,400 in deadliest terrorist attack on European target since World War II; Spanish authorities initially blame Basque separatist group ETA but later add possibility of Islamic terrorism after finding stolen van with detonators and Koran tape; US intelligence is skeptical about Al Qaeda link claimed in letter to Arab paper in London; Spain has 1,300 troops in Iraq and was explicitly threatened in Osama bin Laden audiotape; attack, three days before election, cuts train in two at main Atocha station in heart of city; bloodied victims crawl through wreckage and bodies are found burned in seats; rescue workers there and at two nearby stations struggle to separate wounded from dead; Spanish official says bomb was titadine, compressed dynamite found in van headed for Madrid last month; two ETA suspects were arrested; police in December also foiled plot to bomb train in Madrid (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Red Cross Condemns West Bank Barrier
abstract: International Red Cross criticizes Israel's West Bank barrier, contending that barrier, which, according to Israeli authorities, was constructed as security measure, denies Palestinians basic needs and causes destruction and damage (S)

headline: A Guided Tour of the I.R.S.
abstract: Paul B Brown reviews book Confessions of a Tax Collector: One Man's Tour of Duty Inside the IRS by Richard Yancey (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Diagnostic Imaging Moves Into Many Doctor's Offices  Doctors are installing imaging equipment, particularly M.R.I. machines, in their offices instead of sending patients to a radiologist or local hospitals.     This has made diagnostic imaging nearly a $100 billion-a-year business, up about 40 percent since 2000, and one of the fastest-growing components of physician services in the Medicare program. [Page A1.]

headline: Magazine Finds a Rival a Bit Too Familiar
abstract: Redesign of Men's Fitness bears such close resemblance to Men's Health, leading men's fitness magazine, that Rodale Inc, publisher of Men's Health, intends to sue; suit is expected to revolve around trade dress, distinctive features that convey to consumers who is providing the goods at hand; American Media, owner of Men's Fitness, says there was no intent to copy Men's Health; photo (M)

headline: U.N. Inspectors Report Evidence That Iran Itself Made Fuel That Could Be Used for A-Bombs
abstract: International Atomic Energy Agency experts, despite Iranian disavowals, report finding evidence that Iran made highly enriched uranium that could be used to make nuclear arms; say they found fuel on parts made in Iran and 'only negligible traces' on imported parts; stop well short of declaring that Iran has arms program under way; Bush administration official says Iran's disclosure failures makes it easier to build international consensus about what Iran is doing (M)

headline: Jury Starts Deliberations In Stewart Case
abstract: The jury in the Martha Stewart trial completed its first day of deliberations yesterday after making several requests for transcript excerpts, charts and phone logs, most of them focused on Dec. 27, 2001, the day she sold nearly 4,000 shares of ImClone Systems.    The jury of eight women and four men, which was dispatched to deliberate shortly before noon, sent a note early in the afternoon seeking parts of the trial transcript in which Douglas Faneuil, the former stockbroker's assistant, testified about his Dec. 27 phone calls to Ms. Stewart and her co-defendant and former Merrill Lynch stockbroker, Peter E. Bacanovic.

headline: British Official Sees No Early Exit From Iraq
abstract: Britains foreign secretary, Jack Straw, said today that British troops would stay in Iraq for years, perhaps as late as 2007.

headline: Beijing's Criticism of Democracy Advocates Divides Hong Kong
abstract: Beijing's heavy criticism of Hong Kong democracy advocates in past two weeks is increasingly dividing Hong Kong public; many worry democratic movement has gone too far, while others want to press on; division is visible when unruly throng of supporters and detractors, in unusual confrontation, greet Democratic Party founder Martin Lee at airport on his return from Washington to testify on democratic reforms before Senate panel; senior Communist officials seem to have put movement on defensive by repeatedly questioning patriotism of democracy advocates; effort has begun upsetting social stability Chinese leaders also prize (M)

headline: The File Metaphor
abstract: David Jensen letter rejects premise that terminology used to describe computer storage is outdated (Feb 19 article)
